PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(1) The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

(2) We therefore request that the House of Representatives ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew (from 7 citizens), Mr Hawker (from 2,617 citizens), Mr Jull (from 10 citizens) and Mr Lloyd (from 27 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the increase in excise of 7 cents per litre on leaded petrol and 5 cents per litre on unleaded petrol resulting from the Budget. This rise in petrol tax:
(1)discriminates against low income families and those living in rural areas
(2)increases business costs and will cause further unemployment
(3)adds further to the price of an already heavily taxed product
(4)breaks Mr Keating's election promise not to put up tax.
And your petitioners therefore pray that the House oppose these increases in petrol excise.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew (from 222 citizens), Mr Evans (from 299 citizens) and Dr Kemp (from 969 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Breast Cancer Screening
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the state of Western Australia draws to the attention of the House:
1. Overwhelming evidence is now available in Australia to indicate breast cancer can be treated and many deaths can be avoided if screening takes place early enough.
2. Many Australian women are finding it increasingly difficult, if not impossible, to be able to undertake mammography screening.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House requests the Federal Government to undertake an urgent review of the present policies with a view to introducing expanded mammography screening services and including them in the schedules to attract medical benefits.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cameron (from 96 citizens) and Mr Lieberman (from 902 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Off-road Diesel Fuel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposal to charge users of off-road diesel fuel a tax equal to one per cent of the amount rebated to them through the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme under the Diesel Fuel (Excise Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 and the Diesel Fuel (Customs Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: 1. Users of off-road diesel fuel currently receive a full or partial rebate of fuel excise paid in recognition that they should not have to contribute to road funding and maintenance in the same manner as on-road users of diesel fuel;
2. We object to being forced to pay fuel excise on diesel fuel and then being charged a tax, which the Government is calling an `administration fee', to have that money returned to us as a rebate;
3. This tax sets a dangerous precedent and could lead to governments charging similar taxes on rebates, such as those for personal income tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawker (from 92 citizens) and Mr Lloyd (from 30 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Wartime Mariners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House—
that less than five per cent of wartime mariners are entitled to any disability pensions under the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowance Act of 1940.
Your petitioners therefore pray

that the house repeal the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowance Act 1940. Those mariners then be covered under the Veterans' Entitlement Act with the same benefits as those who served in the Armed Forces.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Allan Morris (from 26 citizens) and Mr Peter Morris (from 13,447 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Wine: Wholesale Sales Tax
PETITION.PARA: To Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens respectfully ask the House to ensure that the Government's proposals to increase the level of wholesale sales tax on wine from 20% to 31% be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:-
(1) At least $500 million in investment in the wine industry is threatened by this proposal.
(2) The implementation of this proposal could force more than 500 grape growers from the industry and threaten the jobs of hundreds of employees in wineries and other associated industries.
(3) The proposed tax increase will accentuate the current decline in domestic wine sales.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
This humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia calls upon the House to:

PARA.TAB: 1. Ensure its members cease promoting Australia to become a Republic and to firmly uphold and maintain the existing Australian Constitution 1901 in its entirety and
2. Oppose any move to remove the Queen of Australia as the Head of State.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Benefits for Optometric Examinations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled—
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:

PARA.TAB: 1. Optometry has been covered by Medicare since its inception in 1975, and currently provides eye care to over 2.4 million people each year.
2. Removal of optometric benefits from Medicare will increase Government expenditure on eye care, as people will instead obtain their care from a more expensive source.

3. The cost to the public of eye care will increase, both through the removal of benefits for optometric consultations and the shift to ophthalmologists who generally charge well over the schedule fee.

4. The visual welfare of the community will suffer as people are discouraged from seeking eye care. Many eye diseases, such as glaucoma, do not produce symptoms until they are in an advanced stage. Any discouragement from seeking regular eye care will increase suffering from these diseases.
5. The removal of benefits for optometric examinations will disadvantage children, as undetected visual disorders will adversely affect their development and school performance.
6. Access to eye care will be reduced, particularly in rural areas, as part-time and visiting optometric practices will no longer be economically viable, and alternate care is not available.

PETITION.PARA: We therefore request that the Parliament take steps to ensure that Medicare continues to be a universal health insurance system and that all eye examinations by optometrists are covered.

PETITION.TITLE: Senior Citizens: Radio Programming
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens (aged 50 years and over) residing throughout the Melbourne metropolitan area draws to the attention of the House that radio programmers of existing national, commercial and public radio stations, which have coverage of the Melbourne metropolitan area, devote less than 2% of the approximate 3500 hours per week airtime available to them, to either quality of life issues of ever increasing importance to persons in their old age or to the nostalgic and popular music so well remembered from their youth.

Your petitioners, therefore, request the House to give unqualified support to the application already made to the Australian Broadcasting Authority by Golden Days Radio for Senior Citizens Incorporated for the establishment of a "special interest" public radio station to provide:-
(a)specific programmes of information, education and entertainment which will reflect the aspirations, needs, interests and recreational pursuits of senior citizens; and

(b)programmes of comedy, drama and music popular from at least the early 1900's to the early `50's together with a pleasant mix of light classical, traditional jazz, instrumental, brass and military band and choral music as well as the more melodic and "listenable" music of later decades.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Home: Wongaburra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain electors of the Division of Rankin draws to the attention of the House the plight of the elderly in the shire of Beaudesert who face the prospect of having to leave Beaudesert to obtain nursing home care, which because of the lack of transport would isolate them from family and friends.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to persuade the Minister for Health (The Honourable Brian Howe) to consider favourably the submission of Wongaburra for extra nursing home beds.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows
That the majority of Australians clearly stand united in satisfaction with the existing Australian National Flag which reflects their values, history, and heritage.
And that they condemn unwarranted attacks on their historic Australia Flag, whenever or wherever made by any Australian citizens.

So therefore we call upon the House of Representatives to ensure that the Australian National Flag, as publicly acclaimed in 1901 and confirmed under the Flags Act (1953), is not changed, replaced, or diminished at any time, or in any manner whatsoever, without such a proposal being first voted upon and approved by a majority of Australian citizens in a national referendum.

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on TV
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned, are concerned about the escalation of sexually explicit and gratuitously violent material on television.

We do NOT believe that the Australian Broadcasting Authority is, to use its own terminology, "in tune with current community attitudes." Over 100,000 Australians have expressed their concern relating to violence and pornography on television to the ABA, with no apparent effect. Dozens of major national companies have refused to associate their products with pornographic programs. "Blasphemous, indecent or obscene" material, which is PROHIBITED by ABT standards, continues to be broadcast on television regularly.

In addition, we are concerned that the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Station's Codes of Practice seem designed NOT to protect impressionable children, immature adolescents and adults from offensive television BUT to protect networks from prosecution.
We urge the Parliament to investigate the escalation of gratuitous violence and sexually explicit material on television and to institute appropriate measures to lift television standards.
And we will, as in duty bound, ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Free the Bears
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the state of Western Australia draws to the attention of the House that approximately 8,000 bears are being kept in cages in China for the purpose of extracting bile for medical purposes and that the cages are so small the bears cannot move, which results in some of them going mad. It is further brought to the attention of the House that the Chinese plan to increase the number of bears for these purposes to 40,000.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to object most strongly to this horrendous and tragic practice and ask that steps be taken to stop it immediately.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Army Band
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain residents of the State of Western Australia draws to the attention of the House our strongest opposition to the decision of the Federal Government to disband the Australian Army Band, Perth.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to oppose any attempt to dissolve the Australian Army Band, Perth.

PETITION.TITLE: VIP Aircraft
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House our strongest opposition to the Prime Minister's intentions of purchasing a new VIP aircraft, particularly given that the Prime Minister is responsible for the record unemployment and the worst recession in sixty years, and calls on the Prime Minister to abandon his plans to purchase any new aircraft until Australia's economy improves and unemployment falls dramatically. Further, that the House recognises the Prime Minister's previous misuse of such aircraft, in particular, his using one to fly from Canberra to Melbourne and back to watch a football game.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to oppose any plan by the Prime Minister to purchase any new VIP aircraft.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned parents and friends of Possum's Place Kindergarten draws attention to the House that the Federal Government is seeking to link accreditation to eligibility for Childcare Assistance and in the opinion of your petitioners this link will only lead to higher fees for parents and no guarantee for improvement in quality of care for children. We know that quality care cannot be legislated for—it comes from the heart. PLEASE HELP US TO HELP OUR CHILDREN.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to reject accreditation being linked to Childcare Assistance.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS Television: Turkish Community
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows:

PARA.TAB: We protest the showing of the film "Duvar" on SBS TV on 4 August 1993, which has no place in the tradition of the Turkish nation and reflects poorly on the Turkish people.

We request that SBS TV changes its broadcasting policy, which is insulting to Turkish people, and note that Radio Stations 2EA Sydney and 3EA Melbourne have been transformed into "PKK Radio". Rather, these stations should provide programming which adequately services the needs of the Turkish community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Austrade Office: Rangoon
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of Victoria draws to the attention of the House the disregard for human rights by the SLORC government in Burma.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to close our Austrade Office in Rangoon.

PETITION.TITLE: Increase in Wholesale Sales Tax and Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: that pensioners, the unemployed and low and middle income Australians will be worse off if the Government's 1993-94 Budget is passed unchanged by the Parliament;
the increase in the rate of wholesale sales tax will add to the tax burden on basic household goods;

the increase in petrol excise—in particular the excise on leaded petrol which is overwhelmingly used by low income people and farmers—will significantly add to the costs of operating a vehicle in Australia;
the increase in the tax on wine from 20 to 31 per cent immediately and 32 per cent next year will do serious damage to one of this nation's most successful industries;
the increase in the tax on lump sums received from unused leave is retrospective and unfair.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will reject these measures on behalf of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:
The 1993 Federal Budget announcement by the Keating Labor Government to increase the excise on leaded fuel by 7 cents per litre,
is a selective, discriminatory tax on owners of older cars;
discriminates against lower income earners and country people who own most of these older cars;
will make it more difficult for people to save to purchase newer, more fuel efficient, less-polluting vehicles;
is therefore counter-productive to reducing lead pollution in the air.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject this increase in fuel excise and that the House of Representatives will urge the Government to take initiatives to reduce the cost of manufacturing cars in Australia, thereby making new cars cheaper to buy. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled
The petition of the undersigned shows:

PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:-

PARA.TAB: 1. The majority of Australians regard the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses as unfair and inequitable;
2. The implementation of this measure will have a deleterious effect on national savings and investments of pensioners and veterans;
3. We regard the Government's estimates of cost saving as spurious.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes: Validation Guidelines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; we, the undersigned aged care nurses in Australia, petition you in regard to our serious concern about:

PARA.TAB: (i) The excessive amount of nursing documentation and the validation guidelines used by nursing officers of the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services for a resident classification instrument.

(ii) The monitoring of outcome standards in nursing homes by the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services officers who are not working in a nursing home, and the absence of a tested methodology with measurable criteria for this monitoring process.
Your petitioners respectfully request that the House should, in consultation with aged care nursing practitioners:
(a) change the resident classification instrument documentation requirements and validation to a professionally acceptable model
(b) introduce a methodology with measurable criteria for the outcome standards.

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia: United Nations Protective Force
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House:

PARA.TAB: That the UNITED NATIONS PROTECTIVE FORCE (UNPROFOR) in the Republic of Croatia has failed to enforce the terms of their mandate as set in the Vance Peace Plan;
That armed Serbian bandits continue to terrorise the non-Serbian population;
That the policy of `ethnic cleansing' is continuing in the UNPA Zones;
That refugees are not being permitted to return to their homes as set out in the Vance Peace Plan;
That control of the territories terrorised by Serbian bandits has not been returned to the Republic of Croatia;
Your Petitioners request the House to:
Recognise that the UNPROFOR has failed to carry out its duties in the Republic of Croatia as required by its mandate;
Recognise that the United Nations has not got the strength to ensure the implementation of the Vance Peace Plan;
Support the withdrawal of UNPROFOR from the Republic of Croatia if the United Nations is not prepared to significantly change its attitude towards Croatian sovereignty over the UNPA Zones.

PETITION.TITLE: Starcke Pastoral Holding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned Concerned Citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully Showeth:

That the area of crown land currently leased as the Starcke Pastoral Holding, and the area of freehold land south of the Jeannie River within that pastoral holding, and herein referred to as Starcke, is an area recognised through the National Wilderness Inventory as being of high wilderness quality.
That little scientific research has been done on the natural heritage of Starcke.
That the coastline of Starcke has the largest seagrass beds on the east coast of Australia, and that these beds are an important dugong habitat, and breeding ground for the prawning industry.
That the proposed overseas sale of Starcke poses a grave threat to the cultural and natural values of the area.

Your Petitioners humbly pray that Parliament will act to stop the proposed overseas sale of Starcke, in the interests of Australian control of Australian soil, the protection of the nation's natural and cultural heritage, and as an act of reconciliation with indigenous Australians.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

PARA.TAB: 1. We believe that our current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of our Nation's history.

2. We submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note that our Constitution based on the Monarchy, has:
ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society
Your petitioners therefore request that:
a. There be no change in the design or colour of the Australian National Flag
b. Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia, as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House, the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains on listed securities as Income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986. The petitioners also point out to the House that:
(1) The majority of Australians regard the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses as unfair and inequitable;
(2) The implementation of this measure will have a damaging effect on national savings and investments of pensioners and veterans;
(3) We regard the Government's estimates of cost savings as spurious;
(4) The Federal Government's proposal will seriously disadvantage thousands of Australians who have helped provide for their own retirement through savings in shares.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to support measures by the Federal Liberal and National Parties to overturn the Government's proposal and call for measures to encourage savings and provide greater financial rewards for Australians who have provided fully, or partly, for their own financial needs in retirement.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
(1) We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the Australian National Flag.
(2) We believe that the current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of the Nation's history.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives and parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully ask the House to ensure that the Government abandons proposals to increase the duty on leaded petrol by 10 cents per litre and unleaded petrol by five cents per litre:
unleaded petrol by 3 cents per litre effective now, followed by a further one per cent per litre in February 1994 and August 1994.
leaded petrol by 3 cents per litre effective now, followed by a further 2 cents per litre in February 1994 and August 1994 and a further 3 cents per litre in February 1995.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the committee's report entitled Australia's relations with Indonesia.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report I have just tabled completes the committee's survey of the countries in Australia's immediate region. This survey entailed the 1989 South Pacific countries report and the 1991 report on Papua New Guinea.

PARA.TAB: This report into relations with Indonesia results from a reference to the committee on 20 June 1991. In its activity, the committee received over 200 submissions and held 18 public hearings in various capital cities and one in Broome. The report makes 36 recommendations about the relationship with Indonesia. The committee also received a reference to examine the 1990-91 and 1991-92 annual reports of the Australia-Indonesia Institute.

Before outlining some of the more significant recommendations in our report, I would like to make some more general comments on the relationship this country has with Indonesia. While the current relationship is open and positive, it has not always been this way. There are still issues of the greatest sensitivity which must be dealt with on a regular basis. Rather than concentrating on the difficulties of the past, the committee has sought to emphasise ways to broaden and deepen what currently exists.

While our two nations do have contrasts, these differences should not be overemphasised. One of the differences which are significant is the major role played by the armed forces in Indonesia compared with the role of the Defence Force in Australia. Because of the role the Indonesian armed forces played in the struggle against the Dutch after 1945, they have a special place in Indonesian society. A significant number of positions are reserved for military representatives in the parliament. Many officers work outside what we might consider formal military structures. The military has an important nation building role in addition to the one we would recognise.

It seems that at times it was easier to concentrate on the differences rather than the similarities. Reactions on both sides to the actions of the other have sometimes smacked of xenophobia. It has also been easy to ignore or play down the similarities and the things which bring Indonesia and Australia together. In a regional context the two nations have outlooks which are surprisingly similar. For example, we both value the concepts of self-reliance and national resilience. Moreover, Australia and Indonesia share fundamental security interests in a strong, politically stable and economically dynamic region, free from the involvement of external powers with interests inimical to our region.

Indonesia is a central player in ASEAN, consistent with having the largest population and GDP. The ASEAN secretariat is located in Jakarta. Australia is one of ASEAN's seven dialogue partners and meets annually at ministerial and official level to discuss economic and a range of other issues. In recent years, Australia has aspired to an acceptance of a closer relationship on these fronts.

Although still cautious about the way APEC might develop, Indonesia has shown a lively interest in a range of matters involving that body. It is an active contributor to several of the APEC work projects and has provided valuable support to Australian initiatives.

Indonesia and Australia have cooperated in other international matters such as initiatives for the settlement to the Cambodia tragedy, and on the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations. Indonesia's international role has been augmented by its leadership of the non-aligned movement and its election to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights.

Fortunately, it is now not difficult to provide a range of examples of cooperation and ties between Indonesia and Australia in both regional and multilateral matters. One of the more surprising features of this inquiry was discovering just how many ties exist and how deep they are. The relationship has grown and developed substantially over the past five years or so. The intensity and diversity of state-provincial connections also impressed the committee.

The welcome received throughout Indonesia on the study tour by 10 members of the committee in October 1992 was clear evidence of Indonesia's interest in Australia. Members were generally impressed by the willingness of Indonesian authorities to enter into dialogue on matters of committee interest.

As this report makes clear, there are many opportunities for Australia in a relationship with Indonesia: in trade, education and technology, particularly. The defence links are very concrete, and significant personal relationships have arisen through exchanges and visits of the service personnel of each country.

The flow of tourists between the two countries is, perhaps fortunately, now more two-way than it used to be and not simply to and from Bali. Thanks in part to the work of the Australia-Indonesia Institute, people to people contact has increased. Some high level cultural programs and exchanges are also taking place. All of these positive developments bode well for the relationship, and it is pleasing to document them briefly in the House.

Inevitably, during any discussion of relations with Indonesia, the issue of human rights is raised. The subject engendered the greatest amount of interest in the inquiry. Many witnesses with deep interests in these matters made valuable contributions. The committee has made a number of recommendations on this subject.

Two major concerns guided our considerations. The first was the recognition of the limits of national sovereignty, together with the principle of non-intervention in the internal affairs of other nations. The second was an earnest desire not to sermonise or be offensive while, at the same time, being fully aware that many Australians are deeply and justifiably distressed about general and specific abuses of human rights in Indonesia. To ignore the strong input of the evidence on human rights in Indonesia would also deny a significant strand in Australian foreign policy.

In this report there are a number of references to an earlier report by this committee: A review of Australia's efforts to promote and protect human rights. It provided a useful reference point on these issues and a valid framework for our ideas on human rights in Indonesia. That also was a unanimous report. It is reasonable to point out that, in that report, the committee was critical of some aspects of human rights in Australia. It was tabled in December 1992.

Our major recommendation in the matter is that the Australian government should continue to make representations about the principles and practice of human rights in Indonesia. East Timor, Irian Jaya and Aceh are areas of special concern. We have also recommended the reopening of the Australian consulate in Dili. The committee believes this would be a recognisable and diplomatic statement of Australia's concerns about East Timor and provide the Australian people with worthwhile information of any advances in this matter. It was unfortunate that the study tour could not enter East Timor.

The other subject which generated a great amount of evidence was fishing by Indonesian nationals off the north and north-west coasts of Australia. Many of those who fish illegally have been forced to do so because of economic necessity. Some species have been so overfished in Indonesian waters that it is understandable that attempts are made to seek stock in southern waters.

The 1974 memorandum of understanding with Indonesia was negotiated to solve a number of problems. Among other things it governs the right of traditional Indonesian fishermen to visit and fish in waters on the outer edge of the continental shelf. Since then other situations have arisen and the MOU does not deal with all categories of fishermen who should be considered as traditional.

Moreover, arrangements for fishermen of both nations in the Arafura Sea are not satisfactory. We have recommended a thorough examination of all aspects of Indonesian fishing in Australian waters, with a view to renegotiating the MOU with Indonesia, defining `traditional' fishermen more appropriately and arriving at a more satisfactory arrangement for fishermen in the Arafura Sea.

While we made a number of suggestions about human rights and fishery matters, we also made recommendations to encourage Australian business in Indonesia. In this area, we recommended that the Australia-Indonesia Business Council and the chambers of commerce and industry be involved in the distribution of a publication titled Austrade's Business Guide to Indonesia.

The committee has also recommended that an Australian consulate be opened in Surabaya in East Java, which is an area of growing importance to Australian business in Indonesia. However, it was in the scientific and educational fields that the committee made the greatest number of recommendations. The principal recommendation was a proposal for consultation with Indonesian authorities about providing additional resources to schools in the eastern provinces of Indonesia. During the inquiry, we heard evidence about the importance of the existence of the Australian Studies Centre at the University of Indonesia in providing Indonesians with the knowledge to explain Australia and its ways to other Indonesians.

The eastern provinces are significant recipients of Australian development assistance. In addition, because of the proximity of Darwin to such places as Ambon, there are already other connections between these provinces and Australia. We have therefore recommended that there be a study of the costs and feasibility of establishing an Australian studies centre in the eastern provinces. If the outcome of this study is favourable, we believe that an approach should be made to an appropriate university in these provinces to assist in the establishment of such a centre.

The Australia-Indonesia Institute was set up in 1989, amongst other things, to increase people to people contact. Members of the committee were concerned to discover that not only has it had to cope with the same allocation of funds, but it now also has to pay for the printing of its annual report and for administrative expenses incurred in supporting its board.

Of greater concern is a proposal to reduce the institute's dedicated staff from four to two. The director's position, which would be downgraded as part of this proposal, has been vacant since February 1993. The committee does not regard this as a satisfactory state of affairs for an institute central to our continuing relationship with a neighbour which the government itself acknowledges to be of crucial importance.

Finally, I thank the committee staff for the contribution they have made throughout the inquiry. A number of situations, including the election and the early advertising of the inquiry, have meant that it has perhaps gone on for longer than expected. Particularly in the last few months, there has been a great call on the staff's resources, and I thank them and the members of the committee for their efforts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleague opposite the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) in speaking to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, Australia's relations with Indonesia. I am glad that the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) is in the House because he was a member of the committee when the decision was made to take on this particular inquiry. In fact, his concern about aspects of the relationship, particularly those relating to the fisheries situation, was one of the determining factors in having the inquiry established.

PARA.TAB: It was a very important inquiry and Australia's relations with Indonesia is a very important report. One of the things that we discovered during the inquiry was the great degree of ignorance in Australia about the total situation in relation to Australia's connections with Indonesia. As honourable members will be aware, within the Australian community—and this is even mentioned in the report—a significant number of people view the development of Indonesia with some concern.

This report adds greatly to the store of knowledge on Indonesia which is available to the community. I hope that it will be widely read and made available throughout Australia because it sets out the background to the situation quite well, and it addresses many of the concerns that people have in relation to Australia's contacts with Indonesia.

Australia's contacts and relationships with Indonesia are extraordinarily important. It is a nation of 180 million-plus people, and that number is growing—it will be well over 200 million early next century. It is a nation of incredible natural wealth and incredible energy. The growth rates, as recorded in this report, are impressive.

Naturally enough, as the chairman of the committee has said, this leads to some concerns amongst Australians when we see ourselves with a vast landmass with a very small population faced by a rapidly growing population to our north with increasing resources available to it. Obviously this is something which needs to be addressed.

In the report, apart from the matters that have already been referred to, I would like to stress that, whilst a great number of the submissions to the inquiry concerned human rights abuses in Indonesia, particularly in relation to East Timor, we were at great pains not to allow that issue to dominate the inquiry that we undertook. I think it is most important that that be stressed. Whilst it is, of course, extremely important and we do not hesitate to make recommendations in relation to that most significant and serious matter of human rights abuse, there are very positive aspects of the relationship which need to be understood and need to be stressed.

The ones I want to draw some attention to in the brief time available to me this morning relate particularly to education within Australia about Indonesia and education within Indonesia about Australia. I was most impressed, as were other members of the committee, by the very real appreciation of the opportunities for close cooperation between Australia and Indonesia which were exhibited particularly in the Northern Territory. There is a very great significance being placed on the study of the Indonesian language; there are relationships between provinces and between schools in the Northern Territory and in Indonesia; and, of course, there is a growing trade relationship based around Darwin and in eastern Indonesia.

This is terribly important, but it is only one part of the potential which is offered by a greater understanding of the opportunities for Australia by increasing the significance of its relations, particularly its business relations, with Indonesia. That will come about when more and more people understand more about our close neighbour, and that again will come about when we have a greater emphasis on study, for instance, of the Indonesian language within Australian schools. I was very disappointed at the low level of the study of the Indonesian language within Australian educational institutions, and I would like to see a very much greater emphasis put on Australian studies at the University of Indonesia, and put on Indonesian studies at various educational institutions within Australia.

I think it is tremendously important that our young people not only learn to speak the language but also have a greater appreciation of the culture, background and actuality of life in Indonesia itself. I would commend particularly the Northern Territory and Western Australia for their continuing efforts to improve this understanding through the educational medium.

One of the things that disappointed me was the lack of Australian business interest in and understanding of the opportunities presented by the burgeoning economy of Indonesia as an export market. Obviously there are some who do understand and who are working hard in this area, but I do not believe there is a sufficient across-the-board appreciation of the opportunities that are there within the Indonesian market. It does require, of course, close cooperation with institutions, businesses and professions within Indonesia itself. Joint ventures seem to be the way to go, and the picking of local Indonesian partners for these joint ventures is of critical importance. Nevertheless, the growth of the economy in Indonesia in recent times and the purchasing power which is available to a greater and greater proportion of the Indonesian population really offer Australian exporters an enormous opportunity, and there should be much greater incentive given within the business community to accepting and exploiting those opportunities.

The other area which is of great significance to us relates to the defence relationships. There is, within the Australian community, quite a degree of concern about the size of the Indonesian military forces, but that concern is, I believe, misplaced. There is a general misunderstanding about the structure of the Indonesian forces and their capacity to operate in defence situations as we would understand them. The defence forces of Indonesia have a much greater role within that country than Australian defence forces have in Australia and that needs to be appreciated by a far greater percentage of the Australian population.

There are, I think, encouraging signs that defence cooperation between the two countries is becoming more successful. During the inquiry, we had some joint training exercises between the Australian navy and the Indonesian navy and I believe at the moment there are some joint exercises involving the air forces of the two countries. In my view, it is essential that that defence relationship be expanded so that there is again a greater understanding between defence personnel and senior defence personnel in Indonesia and their counterparts in Australia and this development of understanding and appreciation of each other's point of view can only lead to a more successful and more soundly based relationship in the future.

It was encouraging to meet a number of Indonesians within Indonesia who have been educated in Australia or partly trained in Australia and I believe that more emphasis should be given to that area of the relationship as well. There are continuing areas of difficulty and the report makes a number of recommendations in relation to them. For instance, as the chairman has already reported, the problem of Indonesian fishermen in Australian territorial waters is still a factor which needs to be worked on and I believe there are some positive recommendations in that area which could, if implemented, not only develop the resources within the Indonesian territorial waters themselves but also lead to a greater understanding of Australia's position amongst Indonesian fishermen and authorities, in particular.

This is the third of the trilogy, as the chairman has already mentioned, and, taken together, I believe these reports do a great deal to develop an understanding of our relationships with countries immediately surrounding us and to provide a very useful historical and academic background to those relationships.

Finally, I would like to thank very much indeed all those members of staff who have worked so long and hard over many months now, burning the midnight oil. They have been absolutely outstanding and we value very much their contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I welcome the opportunity to join my colleagues the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) and the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) in responding to the report Australia's relations with Indonesia. Apart from being a report about Papua New Guinea, our nearest neighbour, it is also a report about our most important neighbour. Countries cannot escape the constraints of their geography. We and Indonesia are locked by geography in perpetuity together. No other relationship will be more significant for the fate of future generations of Australians than that with Indonesia. No other relationship demands so much attention, requires so much effort and justifies so much hard work. It is certainly not an easy task nor an easy relationship because rarely in the world do we find neighbouring countries so different in culture, religion and historical experience as are Indonesia and Australia, and our very proximity throws up complex bilateral issues. But, if that makes the challenge tougher, it makes even more imperative the need for each country to understand each other and to work together to resolve the inevitable tensions that derive from proximity combined with very different cultural perspectives.

PARA.TAB: As other colleagues have observed, central to the tensions that have existed between Indonesia and Australia are fundamental differences in national approaches to human rights, exemplified for many Australians by the contemporary tragedy in East Timor and by abuses of human rights in Aceh.

The report does not shy from that tension. Indeed, it devotes its longest chapter, chapter 7, to human rights in Indonesia and the issue, of course, is touched upon throughout the report. Yet the report does caution against allowing that issue, important as it is, to completely overshadow the relationship between the two countries.

I do not accept the view promulgated by some that concern for human rights is somehow simply a Western concern, a neo-colonialist notion. Respect for the sanctity of human life and respect for human liberty and the rights of the human conscience are embodied at the core of nearly every religion and system of ethics known to man.

And even if at times, men—Christians, I am afraid, not least amongst them—have failed to respect those fundamental rights, we do have a duty, not as Westerners but as human beings, to protect such basic rights and protest their violation. As an earlier report from this committee pointed out, `the diminution of the rights of any group detracts from the whole'.

But while not yielding on this fundamental point, we have to recognise the very different historical and cultural experiences of Indonesia and seek to understand its cultural attitudes and perspectives. Unless we do this we will simply talk at Indonesians, not with them. And only by a dialogue with them can we ultimately hope to change attitudes and policies. Neighbours do not have the luxury of striking moral postures. They can either talk and work together to resolve their differences or drift into isolation and perhaps hostility.

We have suggested a series of practical steps whereby we can contribute in practical ways to increase sensitivity to human rights within the Indonesian elites. But perhaps even more important to achieving this understanding is increasing the people to people contact between our two countries. Despite significant advances in recent years, for neighbours we still have a disappointing level of person to person contacts except perhaps for Bali. Thus there is a strong emphasis in the report on furthering the cultural contacts between the two nations, particularly the enhancement of the role of the Australia-Indonesia Institute, giving substance to our scientific agreements, improving our education exchanges, increasing the language skills between the two countries and providing greater support for Australian studies in Indonesia.

Trade too breaches the barriers of misunderstanding. Total trade has quadrupled in the past 10 years and Indonesia is now our 10th largest export market. Yet our trade lags behind its potential, given the pace of growth in Indonesia. Therefore the committee welcomes the recently established Australian-Indonesian Ministerial Forum and its working group structure to develop bilateral trade. We also welcome the initiatives that state governments have taken in trade with Indonesia.

The report looks at practical ways in which trade and investment can be furthered and it tackles sensitive trade related issues such as Indonesian fishing in Australian waters—which my colleagues have referred to—and the role Australia might play in assisting Indonesia with its energy needs.

I would therefore recommend the report to all interested Australians not as a definitive survey of our most important neighbour but as a snapshot of a point in time of the Australia-Indonesia relationship, the challenges it faces today and the ways we may go about resolving those challenges. I thank the chairman and all members of the committee and the staff for their excellent supportive work.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes available to me I do not intend to canvass the ground covered by my colleagues. I share their concerns and identify the points that they have raised as matters of common concern. I also would like to express my thanks not just to the staff, whose work has been exemplary, and particularly to Patrick Regan, but also to His Excellency Mr Sabam Siagian, the Indonesian Ambassador to Australia. Through him and in conjunction with President Suharto and his government, significant cooperation was given to the presentation and production of the report, when at times they may perhaps have been sceptical about what emphasis we might put on it.

PARA.TAB: I do not wish to spend a great deal of time covering general matters. There are three matters, however, that I want to briefly advert to. The first is that most Australians know Indonesia largely through visits to Bali. Bali is not Indonesia. Indeed, while there is a broadening of our relationship—and we were delighted to see the benefit of associations made by Western Australia and the Northern Territory—there is far more to our relationship than just that visit to the exotica of Bali, delightful resort though it might be.

Importantly, what I found delightful was the extent to which relations with the eastern provinces of Indonesia have flourished. Within our recommendations, there are a number that really give new emphasis to this. I trust that the government will pick those out and proceed with them because, if we are able to proceed with improving our contacts and our relationships with those eastern provinces, I see an opportunity to overcome some of the prejudices and the concerns that we have.

As the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) just remarked, chapter 7 within the report spends a great deal of time on the human rights issues which concerned every member of the committee. An aspect of that, of course, is the degree to which there is free and open contact with those eastern provinces, particularly with East Timor and Irian Jaya. I commend those recommendations within the report that suggest an opening and extension of our relationship with those provinces, for it is one way for Indonesia to see Australia as not intruding in its affairs and, by opening up those provinces, to allow them to grow at a perhaps greater rate than is presently possible.

The second part of my concern, in looking at the genesis of the report, was the degree to which transmigration within Indonesia and the extent of Javanisation were going to intrude on the preservation of what is really a remarkably diverse archipelagic country. It is incredible to think of the extent of the islands that represent Indonesia. There is much in this report that identifies them, and I do not intend to comment further on that.

Having looked at the extent to which transmigration is now being processed, I believe there has been a recognition by the Indonesian administration of some of the problems. I was pleased to see that, particularly in the eastern provinces again, it has withdrawn from some of the arbitrary character of those movements. I think it is necessary for Indonesia to do that, if it wishes to preserve the harmony that Pancasila essentially represents.

The third area, and the one that I really wanted to spend a little more time on, was the relations between Indonesia and Papua New Guinea. Whilst the committee's last report was on Papua New Guinea, it remains my major concern that there is a difficulty in trying to ensure Papua New Guinea's understanding that Australia today sees Papua New Guinea as an entirely independent country and Australia as being a friendly neighbour. I am delighted that that same approach appeared to us to develop between Indonesia and Papua New Guinea. There is, of course, reference within the report to Indonesia's relations with Papua New Guinea. Without going into that in detail—it is in chapter 5—I think that any dispassionate reader will see that we found that defence, political and commercial relationships have matured significantly, and I commend the Indonesian administration in that respect.

I do believe that, for the progress of Irian Jaya, a great deal more needs to be done. It is still, as is Papua New Guinea, a country which has been transformed from the Stone Age into the modern world in a remarkably short period of time—in only two generations, indeed. There are enormous challenges, but it would be a pity if the changes in character of Irian Jaya—any more than of PNG—were not to allow the development of the individual people there, for they do have unique characteristics, and I think it is important that they be preserved. I commend this report for reading and consideration. I think it will make a very valuable contribution to the improved understanding of our relations with this very important and close neighbour of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to participate in this debate, because I believe that the report that has been tabled today, entitled Australia's relations with Indonesia, is a very valuable contribution to the body of knowledge and information about the important relationship between Australia and Indonesia. I joined this committee only a few months ago, and therefore have been involved in the latter part only of the deliberations and development of this report. Looking at the detail that is contained in the report, I think that all honourable members of this House can be pleased that what is being tabled today provides a very rational and balanced assessment of the strength of the relationship between Australia and Indonesia.

PARA.TAB: When we debate issues of importance—and we have talked about the issue of human rights and the difficulties that that issue has placed on the relationship between Australia and Indonesia—too often there is a misconception that those people who wish to pursue human rights concerns are anti-Indonesian, or that they have a negative view about Indonesia generally, and that they are using the issue of human rights to generally attack Indonesia and to undermine its authority in the world.

I think that what we have done with this report is lay a very solid foundation of understanding about where Australia comes from in its approach to human rights and its approach to Indonesia. I am on record in this place as having been critical of Indonesia about human rights and, in particular, about its treatment of East Timor. I stand by those criticisms but I also very solidly stand by the contents of this report because I am not anti-Indonesian. I think very few members in this House are anti-Indonesian.

I believe that it is very important that Australia continue to develop a very positive relationship with Indonesia because there are very important reasons and benefits for both our countries in that. What we have done in this report is clarify all of the arms of that relationship and give some very solid body to the detail about that relationship. We are making sure that it is a balanced assessment.

There are criticisms that we have of Indonesia, as Indonesians have criticisms of us. They have that right to criticise us. We have things that are wrong in our country that deserve to be criticised. I think if we are going to have a mature relationship with Indonesia, which I think we have now got, both countries have to accept that there are going to be differences of view on occasions and that there are going to be different perspectives on the way we handle issues. But what we need to do is have a much better understanding of where each country comes from, the historical context within which our criticisms might be placed and the structure within our societies. This report by the committee goes a long way towards achieving that. I think it is an excellent report and I am pleased to be associated with its production.

There are two particular elements of the report I would like to briefly comment on which I am not sure have been mentioned yet. The first one is in regard to the nuclear industry in Indonesia. That is an issue of particular concern to me. In chapter 11 of the report there are a number of recommendations outlining the committee's views in regard to the development of the nuclear power industry in Indonesia.

We understand and appreciate the incredible demand that is going to be placed on Indonesia's electricity supply industry over the next 20 years. We appreciate that Indonesia needs to be looking at the most efficient and effective ways of producing power. But I am very concerned that Indonesia needs to appreciate also the fact that Australia has some concerns about that because of possible safety implications in the future. I would urge the serious consideration of the recommendations contained in chapter 11 on that matter. It is an issue of concern to Australia that Indonesia look at other forms of technology as well.

I would also urge recommendation 28 to be adopted by the government. That says that the committee recommends the ministerial agreement on science and technology be debated in both houses of parliament after it is signed and that detailed information be given at that time about the scope of the subsidiary agreements. I think it is important that we all be aware of what is involved in that agreement and that Australia's concerns be clearly espoused in that.
I am pleased to support this report. I think it is a very important document for the future relationship between Australia and Indonesia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few brief references to this excellent report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, Australia's relations with Indonesia, and commend my colleagues for its completion. I would like to make some initial remarks in relation to the establishment of the committee's inquiry. I thank the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) for his comments about my role in that. I think it is only fair that I should also compliment him on his role in expanding the terms of reference. It is very important to note that although Indonesia received its independence very soon after the Second World War there has been a marked reluctance within this parliament to grapple with the issue of Australia's overall relationship with Indonesia.

PARA.TAB: When we first discussed this matter in the committee there was some reluctance because there was a fear about what the implications may be, a fear about how Indonesia would see the Australian parliament conducting a thorough review of our relationship with that country. We started to talk about issues relating to fishing in the northern waters of Australia and the difficulties we had there with Indonesian fishermen.

There was clearly a need to expand the reference in accordance with a decision of the committee some years previously to conduct a major review of all Australia's international relationships with our neighbours. In that context, I was able to argue with success that we could hardly ignore the most important neighbour of all.

Nevertheless, I later visited Jakarta and, to my surprise, I found there was some concern. There was a perception in Jakarta that, if a parliament was conducting an `investigation', as they put it, the presumption was that there was something to criticise. I went to some lengths to emphasise that that was not the purpose of the inquiry; rather it was to see in a holistic sense the Australian relationship as it had developed with Indonesia and to see how in a productive sense we could expand that relationship while at the same time admitting areas of friction, or areas of concern, or areas of difference, which we believe should be highlighted, and on that basis be in a position to come up with a series of recommendations as to how those problems should be addressed. In that context, Indonesia has accepted, I think, the role of this parliament, and I hope the day will come when it will be possible to put together joint inquiries of members of this parliament working with members of the Indonesian parliament, not just to develop in a wider context our relationship, but specific areas: for example, the expansion of trade between Indonesia and Australia, the question of the educational relationship and the need to expand our knowledge of language across the spectrum.

There is an enormous demand in Indonesia for English language training. Equally, there should be a greater demand in Australia to learn Bahasa Indonesia. The House should be aware that we are not just talking about the lingua franca or the national language of Indonesia; we are also talking about the national language of Malaysia and about the majority language of the southern provinces of the Philippines. In other words, with the exception of Chinese, whether it be Mandarin or Cantonese, or any other dialect of the south, Bahasa Indonesia or the Malay group of languages is in fact the most spoken language in the entire region north of Australia. Therefore, we need to take more seriously how its study should be expanded in Australia. I would like to see the development of a relationship between the governments of the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia, working together to see how they can expand and support development in Australia of a greater appreciation of the need to study the Indo-Malay language.

The issue also arose, within the context of this report, of the relationship between Australia and Indonesia and the political strength, or the Indonesian elites, which was referred to by the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett). The role of the armed forces in Indonesian politics, especially through the Golkar party, is manifestly obvious and one which we certainly cannot ignore. Nevertheless, there are other elites growing up. There is the intellectual elite through the universities of Indonesia, there is a commercial elite growing up through the vast and burgeoning industrial strength of Indonesia, and so forth, all of which Australia must tap into, and our report went to some length to try to identify the need for this. One of my colleagues has already spoken about the fact that as yet we have not managed to infuse into the Australian commercial atmosphere the need to create a longstanding relationship with Indonesia and not just the fly-by-night approach—`There's a big market up there; let's make a one-week visit, shake a few hands, eat some Indonesian food and disappear back to Australia, and wonder a year later why very little has resulted from it'.

Nevertheless, we are now building links through our legal firms, through our accountancy firms and so forth; a growing number of business partnerships are being created. All of this is helping to diversify the relationship. The essential point is this: Indonesia's motto is `Unity in diversity'. It is an extraordinarily complex society and it is a society which Australia must do all it can to understand and to cooperate with in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with others in welcoming this report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Australia's relations with Indonesia. Indonesia is one of our most important neighbours and the Australia-Indonesia relationship over many fields, but especially in the economic field, will grow and become even more important. I think all of us who were members of this inquiry, especially those of us who went to Indonesia, were amazed at the economic growth in that country and indeed the economic potential, and in a cooperative way we should be sharing in that and joining together.

PARA.TAB: It is true, as I think the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) said, that Australia and Indonesia do not know enough about each other, and I join with him in commending the work that has been done in the Northern Territory and, indeed, in Western Australia. I think that those states have taken the right approach to the relationship.

On this inquiry we received many submissions, and all members of the committee have been receiving, especially over recent weeks, a lot of letters about human rights issues in Indonesia. There is an important point we have to make in that area, and no-one is denying that the human rights issues are very important, but our mandate was to inquire into Australia's relationship with Indonesia. Human rights are part of that but our brief was a much broader examination of the full gamut of the relationship.

I was fortunate to be a member of the October 1992 study tour involving 10 committee members. We did have a dedicated RAAF aircraft which meant we were able to see a great deal of Indonesia in the limited time that we had available. Therefore, after we had been to Jakarta where we had discussions with government ministers and various research bodies, we flew to eastern Kalimantan to inspect the large open coalmine in which CRA is a joint venturer. Representing as I do a coal producing area, I was particularly impressed with the potential and indeed the vastness and quality of the coal resource in Indonesia.

We went on to southern Sulawesi where we were briefed on fishermen from that province who fish in Australian waters. In Surabaya we attended the annual Australia-Indonesia Business Council meeting. Some of us inspected joint ventures with an Australian involvement, while others had discussions with graduates of Australian universities at Malang in East Java.

In West Timor we had discussions with Australian aid workers, including a family which had driven from Dili in East Timor to meet us. In Irian Jaya, we were briefed on that province and visited one of the transmigration camps which have been the subject of a lot of discussion both here and in Indonesia.

While it was a very busy trip, it was very well justified in terms of the report which has just been tabled. It gave us the opportunity to see more of Indonesia than most people have. The tour had a specific emphasis on the eastern provinces where Australia's assistance to Indonesia is focused, and it showed us something of the variety of Australian interests in Indonesia.

One of the most important but least mentioned episodes of the study tour occurred in Jakarta. Some time ago this parliament's public works committee, of which I am chair, held an inquiry and tabled a report recommending the construction of a new Australian Embassy in Jakarta. One of our recommendations, which was accepted and included in the design, was the construction of an additional floor to the building. The bureaucrats fought this recommendation very strenuously, but the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) and I pushed it through because we wanted the additional floor to provide space for the likely expansion of staff in the embassy in the future. Such is the importance of Indonesia that we believed that the additional expenditure in construction would pay off quite soon. That has proved to be the case. The embassy was opened in August of this year and it is already full. So the decision that that committee took was justified.

The study tour brought great benefits to those members who were on it, and I believe that the report benefited greatly from the tour. I certainly believe that the credibility of this report will be greatly increased because some of the members now understand more about Indonesia because of what they saw last year.

I join with others in thanking the staff and the chairman. I commend the report to the House. It is an important report but one which we have to work on to ensure that its recommendations are implemented. Thank you.
Motion (by Mr Ferguson) proposed:
That the House take note of the report.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—In accordance with standing order 102B, the debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)noting the onerous conditions attaching to the award of disability pensions under the provisions of the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940; and
(b)observing that disability pensions available under the provisions of the Act have been awarded to fewer than 5 per cent of war-time mariners—
this House is of the opinion that:

PARA.TAB: (i)war-time mariners should be given access to the same benefits under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 as those who served in the armed forces; and
(ii)the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940 should be repealed.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this morning the Clerk of the House of Representatives reported to the parliament on the petition I presented to him. That petition carried the signatures of almost 13,500 citizens. The petition prays that the House repeal the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940 and that those mariners then be covered under the Veterans' Entitlements Act, with the same benefits as those who served in the armed forces. The petitioners came from across the length and breadth of this nation. They joined members from both sides of the House in the struggle to correct the great inequity and injustice that has been done to Australia's wartime merchant mariners for almost 50 years.

PARA.TAB: Last week our nation witnessed the entombment of the Unknown Soldier at the Australian War Memorial. It was an event that honoured our war dead as well as those who have made other sacrifices in wartime. However, death or injury in war is not limited to those who serve in one of the recognised services. As a nation, we still fail to recognise the important and critical role that Australian merchant mariners played during the Second World War, especially during those dark days when supply lines to Australia and to war theatres were under enemy attack or threat of attack.

Last year we paid homage to the many Australians who made the ultimate sacrifice—in battles on land and at sea a half century earlier—that we may live free today. We recalled their heroism in the grim and bloody struggles of the Kokoda Trail and Milne Bay, the bombing of Darwin and the great naval battle of the Coral Sea. Most Australians are aware of the deeds of the defence personnel involved in those events. Few Australians, other than those directly involved and their families, are aware of the sacrifices made, the agonies suffered or the deprivations and hardships endured by Australia's merchant mariners, the men who maintained the vital supply lines to Australia during those dire times throughout World War II.

Few Australians are aware that 54 merchant ships were attacked in Australian waters and 38 of them went to the bottom of the sea during World War II. The first Australian ship sunk was the small vessel the Nimbin, which struck a German mine off Port Stephens and subsequently sank later that day off Norah Head in my electorate.

The BHP's Iron Chieftain was torpedoed and sunk by a Japanese submarine 35 miles east of Sydney on 3 June 1942. Twelve mariners lost their lives. The following day, the Iron Crown was torpedoed and sunk by a Japanese submarine 44 miles south-south-west of Gabo Island, and 38 mariners lost their lives. From June to August of 1942, Japanese submarines wrought havoc among allied shipping off the southern Queensland and New South Wales coastlines.

On 8 February 1943, the Iron Knight was torpedoed and sunk by a Japanese submarine off Eden in New South Wales. Thirty-six mariners lost their lives. Overall, it is estimated that about 14,000 Australian merchant mariners served in World War II. The exact number and the precise number of casualties will never be known because many served under foreign flags, many served across the globe in allied ships, and there are no detailed records of all personnel lost or casualties suffered.

I have talked to mariners who served on Australian merchant ships and allied ships in Australian waters during World War II. One mariner witnessed from another vessel the sinking of the Iron Knight. He explained to me the helplessness of the merchant vessels when under attack by Japanese submarines. Those ships and their crews were sitting ducks for the submarines, yet today, a half century later, we continue as a nation to refuse proper recognition of those mariners who took inordinate risks to help defend our country.

In the war at sea, merchant ships were often more at risk than naval ships. Merchant ships were slower, ineffectually armed, if armed at all, and singled out for attack by the enemy. They were easy targets, as were their crews.

I make the point: in uniform or out of uniform, in war all mariners are mortal; they suffer the same; they bleed the same; they die the same; and those who survive age the same. That is why I believe it is a national shame that Australia's wartime merchant mariners are still denied the entitlements that have long been available to defence personnel who served in World War II.

That is why I am moving this motion today and why colleagues on both sides of the parliament are supporting it. It is a matter of great urgency, because if we delay much longer few wartime mariners will be left. Those that remain with us should be granted as soon as possible the same entitlements as are available to former members of the armed forces.

It is undeniably clear that the spirit and intent of the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act of 1940 has not been carried through. Under the act, merchant mariners have to prove that they suffered a war injury during war service, and the onus is on them to prove it. That might be easy if it could be shown that one lost a limb during one's service or under enemy attack, but first one had to survive.

Even though there was enough evidence given to the 1989 McGirr inquiry, the fact is that ships' logs recording injuries were often lost in action or, in many cases, records were not kept because of the conditions under which the vessels were operating. Obviously, if the ship sank the records went down with it. Therefore, in many cases, the task of having to show that a war injury was suffered has been impossible to complete. The restrictive nature of the act has meant that fewer than five per cent of eligible Australian merchant mariners have been able to gain a disability pension.

Let me contrast that with the case of veterans covered by the Veterans' Entitlements Act of 1986. They need only show that they did indeed serve in the regular forces and that a reasonable hypothesis exists to link that service to their illness or disability. The claimant does not have to prove the link.

It is indisputable that the government of the time intended that mariners be treated the same way as defence personnel. Speaking to the 1940 legislation, the then Minister for the Army, Senator McBride, concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: The measure brings seamen into line almost completely with soldiers.
It is also indisputable that the narrow interpretation placed on the provisions of the act by the bureaucracy in intervening years has frustrated the original intent of the legislation.
The McGirr inquiry in October 1989 came to the same conclusion, when it reported in paragraph 6.32:
It is clear that the original intention behind the introduction of the SWPA—
the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act—
in 1940 has not been realised.
The inquiry recommended:
That the SWPA Act be repealed and that claims relating to the death, disease or injury of Australian merchant mariners be provided for under the VEA—
the Veterans' Entitlements Act—
and that all existing benefits be preserved.

In 1991 the then Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys), succeeded in having veterans' medical entitlements extended to wartime merchant mariners, and I applaud him for his efforts. The current Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Faulkner, is, I believe, similarly supportive of mariners, but he also needs the support that this motion can bring to the cabinet room.
