PARA.TAB: It is not just the wartime mariners who remain who are being denied justice. The widows of their departed comrades are similarly being denied justice. Mr J.D. Macansh, of Newcastle Legacy, has written to me expressing his support of the action we are seeking today. The fact is that only 36 widows, or three per cent of wartime mariner widows, have benefited under the 1940 act. That three per cent of mariners' widows receiving war widows pensions compares with about 70 per cent of widows of service personnel who receive war widows pensions.

The recommendations of the McGirr report have the unanimous support of former merchant mariners, the RSL, other ex-service groups, Legacy, honourable members of both sides of this House, and the almost 13,500 citizens of this nation who signed the petitions presented to the House this morning. I commend all who are working for this cause, especially my constituent Mr Bob Nelson, OAM, of Mount Hutton, New South Wales, who has worked relentlessly for wartime mariners over many years.

We can no longer deny them and their widows just entitlements. The cost, I believe, is of the order of $3 million to $4 million per year. It is a small price to pay to bring justice to those who served this country at a time of dire crisis. We need to argue the case within the cabinet room and to the government that this justice is long overdue. When we look at the magnitude of the budget and the moneys being expended the amount involved here is a mere pittance.

I appeal to the government, the cabinet and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to right this wrong and to bring forward legislation to repeal the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act of 1940 and to give wartime mariners the same entitlements available to former defence personnel under the Veterans' Entitlements Act of 1986. I commend the motion to the House and seek the support of all honourable members of the chamber for this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed an honour and a privilege to rise in this place to provide a very large measure of bipartisan support to this commendable motion by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris). It. recognises a group disadvantaged in the service of our country but sadly forgotten by most. I congratulate him and his 13,500 petitioners for their initiative, as indeed I did in speaking to a similar motion in this place about 18 months ago. It is a measure of the honourable member's commitment to correcting the serious anomalies that exist for some, despite the political and protracted rhetoric from responsible ministers.

PARA.TAB: I also salute all of those who served in uniform and in the merchant marine, and it is to the latter that we pay particular tribute today. Clearly there is continuing dissatisfaction about the broad anomaly which is reflected in the motion before us today, particularly parts (i) and (ii), which call for the repeal of the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act, the SWPA Act of 1940, and for access to benefits under the Veterans' Entitlements Act of 1986.

This dissatisfaction is reflected succinctly in a very short article which appeared in the West Australian about two years ago. For the benefit of the House, I will read part of that article, which was headed `Seamen not happy with pension deal'. It said that merchant navy mariners who worked in World War II war zones were angry because of inequities between their disability pensions and those of returned servicemen in the pension changes that were announced at that time by the then Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys). It went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . mariners still do not qualify for disability pension unless their injuries can be directly attributable to a hostile attack during the war. All returned servicemen and women are paid the disability pension if they were injured during the war, whether it was during an attack or not. The disability pension, paid in addition to a service pension, is considered compensation for injuries . . .

PARA.TAB: Allied Merchant Seamen Association spokesman, George Hansen, said the 1989 McGirr inquiry into the needs of mariners found evidence which justified repealing the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act. Mariners could then be covered under the Veterans' Entitlements Act, bringing them into line with returned servicemen.

SPEECH.PARA: With that as background, I think it is worth reading into the record some of the historical aspects of the attendant legislation. Prior to the outbreak of World War II, seamen's disabilities were covered by the combined effect of the Navigation Act, the Seamen's Compensation Act and awards of the Arbitration Court. Liability for payments associated with the rights conferred under these statutes and awards rested with the shipowners.

PARA.TAB: The Navigation Act provided for medical treatment and wages. The Seamen's Compensation Act provided workers compensation cover. In line with other compensation schemes, it removed the necessity for seamen to prove negligence on the part of the shipowner before liability could be established. Provision was made for the payment of weekly benefits where an injury resulted in an incapacity for work. It also provided for lump sum payments for specific injuries, reasonable medical expenses, death and funeral benefits. The act applied to seamen on ships registered in Australia or employed under articles entered into in Australia.

As a general rule, compensation schemes and insurance agreements contain an exemption from liability for injury or damage caused by an act of God or an act of war. With the outbreak of World War II, additional measures were required to provide coverage for wartime circumstances. Hence we have the genesis of the SWPA Act of 1940, which provided for pensions and other benefits at Commonwealth expense for masters, officers and seamen employed in Australian merchant ships trading between a port of a state or territory of the Commonwealth and any other port. It also covered those employed on a lighthouse tender or pilot ships of the Commonwealth or of a state. The benefits in that legislation were available to these mariners if, while employed in their normal course of duty, they sustained a war injury resulting in death or incapacity, or were captured and detained by the enemy, or their effects were lost or damaged as a result of enemy action.

The SWPA Act also provided for pensions for dependants under certain circumstances. It was amended by several other pieces of legislation through 1942 and 1943, and in December 1943 the war cabinet authorised a grant of education benefits on the same lines as those available under the repatriation children's education scheme.

The National Security (Wages of Seamen Detained by the Enemy) Regulations and the National Security (Additional Pensions and Allowances) Regulations expired in 1946. All claims for detention allowances and compensation for loss of effects, which were dealt with by the Department of Shipping and Transport, were disposed of within five years of the end of the war. In 1952, the National Security Act was repealed and the SWPA Act was also amended to provide statutory authority for certain benefits which had been granted during the war under National Security Regulations and war cabinet decisions. The former related to medical benefits, sustenance allowances and funeral grants; and the latter to grants of furniture to certain merchant mariners and dependants, and to eduction benefits to the children of certain mariners.

In general, therefore, the amendments made to the SWPA Act after World War II have aligned the pension benefits available to Australian merchant mariners with changes made to the repatriation legislation—even if, in the early stages, there were some delays in making amendments to that act. In recent years, however, because the act adopts some provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements Act—in particular, the criteria for assessment of rates of pension—changes to the earlier act have been made at the same time as changes to the VEA.

In summary, in the SWPA Act we have a piece of legislation which, unless it is repealed—as the honourable member has said—and benefits are extended under the VEA 1986, will allow those injustices to persist. Those injustices will not disappear simply with the passage of time. I refer the House to the 1989 inquiry by the then Deputy President of the Repatriation Commission, Jocelyn McGirr, and to her report. I specifically refer to sections 6.29 and 6.32 of her report. Section 6.29 says, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Inevitably, there is likely to be some time lag between the report of the inquiry being presented and considered, and action taken to implement the recommendations through legislative change. If there were to be an undue delay, the full intent of the report might be lost or the recommendations substantially modified between the time the decision is taken and the changes implemented.
I add to what the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) has quoted from section 6.32:
Further injustice will result if undue delays develop.

I simply say to the present minister, Senator Faulkner, that we need a thorough and immediate review of the McGirr report. As a result of that review, hopefully, the minister and the government—and, indeed, particularly the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—will see their way clear to make it up to a very disadvantaged group of people, albeit a relatively small group, for the disadvantages that they suffer. I hope that in cabinet Senator Faulkner will soon be pushing for the necessary repeal of these provisions and for the increased access to all benefits that many others enjoy—and rightfully so—under the VEA 1986.

PARA.TAB: I finish by saying that a strong case exists to include many Australian merchant mariners as veterans under the VEA. The challenge clearly lies with Senator Faulkner, and I hope that he will take it up with vigour, and that my colleagues on both sides of the House are not back here in a year's time repeating the message for ageing and increasingly frustrated and desperate mariners. I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on this motion moved by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris). Indeed, as has already been mentioned, this motion is almost identical to that moved by the honourable member for Shortland and seconded by me on 18 May 1992. At that time, there was bipartisan support for this motion, and I am pleased that today that same bipartisan support can continue. It actually does show that, on some issues, we in this chamber can rise above petty party politics. Last year, I ended my speech by appealing to the then Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys), to correct this injustice to wartime mariners.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy Speaker, despite the speeches of members of the government and members of the opposition, despite the compelling case presented and despite my appeal to the then minister, very little has changed for the wartime mariners. What has changed is that a few more have died. Others have grown older, but they are still unable to gain access to the same benefits under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 as those who served in the armed forces. It has been put to me that, because merchant mariners were paid a higher rate than those serving in the armed forces, they are not now entitled to these same benefits. I reject this argument.

Under government legislation, merchant seamen were not permitted to leave the service for the duration of the war. Yet members of the other three services were able to transfer from one to the other, if they did not like the one they were enlisted in. Yet a lad of 14 who found he hated the sea and hated suffering from sea sickness was denied this basic right of choice. Those who served in the merchant fleet were continually exposed to dangers. Honourable members should study the list of ships sunk off the Australian coast.

I believe this is not an uncaring government. It is a government that has recognised past mistakes. Indeed it is a government that has seen the justice of correcting past injustices; yet it will not correct this injustice. As the honourable member for Shortland pointed out, it would cost $3 million or $4 million a year to correct this injustice. I ask: what is that in the overall budgetary context? It has been put to me, `Oh well, the government review committee or the razor gang cannot afford it'. I think that $3 million or $4 million could be found to correct this injustice.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's only a few teak tables.

—Yes. Those who served on the merchant ships were in much danger and were prepared to give their lives. Many of them did. I sincerely believe that these entitlements are their due. I believe that the time is long overdue to introduce the necessary legislative action to give merchant mariners equal access to the benefits that are now rightly enjoyed and have been enjoyed for decades by former armed forces personnel under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Are we denying the role that the merchant mariners played in the struggle to save this country? Few countries in the world today or in the past have been so dependent on shipping to maintain essential lifelines as has Australia.

PARA.TAB: There has been a continuing failure to recognise the contribution that our merchant mariners made to the defence of this country and to the maintenance of the lifelines of this country. The merchant fleet has always had to work very closely with the navy and it still does today. I make the point again that these people were prepared to give their lives to maintain the necessary lifelines to and from this country.

The mariners are currently covered by the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940. Under that act, merchant mariners have to prove that they suffered a war injury during war service. The onus is on them to prove it. That may be easy if they lost a limb in the course of service or if they were under enemy attack, but these people had to survive. Although there was enough evidence given to the McGirr inquiry, ships' logs recording such injuries have often been lost in action. Obviously, if a ship was lost later in the course of the war or in a later engagement, no records survived. In many cases, the task of having to show that a war injury was suffered has been impossible.

That burden on the individual to prove the injuries makes it difficult for ex-merchant mariners to show that they have suffered as a result of wartime service—for example, lung cancer or other respiratory diseases. The restrictive nature of the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act has meant that only three per cent of eligible Australian merchant mariners have been able to receive a pension.

The range of wartime experiences of Australian merchant mariners was comparable with the experience of veterans of the Australian defence forces; indeed, in some cases, it was more than comparable. Australian merchant mariners went to sea in ships that were not designed for warfare. They had little or no armour plating. Many of the smaller ships were unarmed. A large merchant ship may have had a crew of around 100. A navy ship of comparable size would have had in excess of 500 persons including medical staff and facilities. The merchant seamen were constantly exposed to attack by submarines, surface raiders and aircraft, with the added risk of enemy mines laid in coastal waters.

The number of ships that were sunk has been detailed here today. Those ships were sunk in my own area off Jervis Bay and off the north coast—all around the Australian coastline. Indeed, of the 73 ships attacked in Australian waters during World War II, 54 were merchant ships and 38 of them went to the bottom.

Many Australians served most of the war years on the dangerous Atlantic run on ships of various nationalities. These mariners were in particular danger. Enemy raiders were often given specific orders to avoid warships and to concentrate their attacks on the carriers of grain, petroleum, munitions and equipment to try to cripple the allied war effort.

Overall, there were about 14,000 Australian merchant mariners engaged during World War II. The McGirr report estimated that 520 mariners lost their lives. This was roughly equivalent to the casualty lists amongst other servicemen. There seems to be no question that World War II Australian merchant mariners should be treated on an equal footing with the veterans of the defence forces. This means equal treatment in benefits and equal access to disability pensions.

One point we have to bear in mind is that the future defence potential of this country relies very much on the merchant fleet and on civilians in the defence structure. We need only look at a couple of recent examples. Whatever we may think personally about the Gulf War or the Falklands War, in the Gulf War the United States had to rely on the merchant fleet to get much of its equipment to the Gulf, and the United Kingdom would not have been successful in the Falklands War had it not been able to use the merchant fleet. It is also important to note that all merchant seamen in the Falklands were volunteers.

Over the past few years much has been said, not least in this House, about Australian shipping. We have seen a restructuring of the seagoing union membership, a decrease in the number of crew, the introduction of multiskilling and the establishment of a career path for seamen. Australian ships today are crewed by well-trained, dedicated personnel, yet there remains a black mark that only the government can eradicate and that is the fact that governments will not grant Australian wartime merchant mariners their just entitlements.

I commend the honourable member for Shortland for again bringing this motion before the House. I know, as other members of this House know, that he has had an interest in correcting this injustice for a long time, and this is not the first speech he has made on this topic. I know that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Faulkner, is a very caring, sympathetic minister. I know that he has the concerns of the veteran community at heart and I know that he would agree with what the speakers have said today.

I am sure that, given that recommendation of him, Senator Faulkner will spare no effort in correcting this anomaly—and that is what it is. Those who were prepared to give their lives to defend the lifelines of Australia in time of war should be able to benefit from the entitlements. There can be no argument against their entitlement to this. I join with my colleagues in urging this parliament to make sure that that injustice and that anomaly are corrected as soon as possible.

Like other speakers, I urge the cabinet to carefully consider this. It is not going to break the budget. It is not going to cause a massive blow-out. I urge the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the cabinet and, indeed, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to correct this anomaly and give these merchant mariners their rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When is an Australian serviceman not a serviceman? When is a war prisoner not a war prisoner? When is doing one's duty for one's country considered not to be so? When will the men of the wartime Australian merchant marine be recognised for the role they played during the Second World War? It seems that we have a paradox when it comes to recognising those brave sailors who did no less than serve their country during its time of need.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to stand and support this motion today moved by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) which notes that wartime mariners should be given access to the same benefits under the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 as those who served in the armed forces, and that the Seamen's War Pension and Allowances Act 1940 should be repealed.

I represent those in the Cowan community who have not yet received proper recognition for their wartime contribution. It is obvious to state that the war, which affected so many Australian families, ended almost 50 years ago, and yet we have a continuing injustice within our community, for which many Australians took up arms 50 years ago.

The Australian merchant mariners were a proud and hardy bunch for they fought their war through getting through the much needed supplies and resources our community needed. They were sometimes left alone on their vessels to sail to their ports without adequate protection, and many of the ships on which they served were sunk by the enemy.

These mariners suffered the normal hardships of war while being separated from their loved ones. They faced the stresses of conflict and felt the degradation of war. They felt the rod of the prison master when they were confined to prisoner of war camps, although not all suffered this plight. Yet we learn that these silent heroes have not been adequately recognised for their service of their country.

I would like to note the thoughts of Mrs Beech of Kingsley, a constituent of mine in the seat of Cowan, whose family have a long and honourable tradition of serving their country. Mrs Beech was writing at the time of the Gulf War when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: Although it is very heart warming to see the men home safely from the Gulf War, I find it hard to come to terms with the fact that during World War II men and boys—some only 14 and 15 years of age—left the same shores as merchant seamen.

PARA.TAB: They didn't have any send offs, they were not welcomed home by the Prime Minister and their pay was not increased.
Most of these men are now suffering from stress or stress-related illnesses and have been fighting to gain recognition for full repatriation benefits.

All I can say is: give all who had to go a fair go. On a percentage basis, the merchant navy had the biggest casualty loss of all the forces. Seamen paid a vital part in the war. My husband was 14 when he left Fremantle. No doubt his mother and father felt the same anguish as the parents of those who left for the Gulf.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an indictment of our system of veterans' entitlements that it was not until 1989 that Australia's merchant mariners were entitled to limited benefits. In 1989 they were granted permission to use the rehabilitation hospitals and to obtain free dental and optometry care. Prior to 1989 they had never been recognised in any way for their service during wartime. Even today, full benefits have been denied to merchant mariners even if they had experienced disabilities caused as a result of wartime activity.

PARA.TAB: The Allied Merchant Seamen's Association (WA Branch) is testimony to the poor treatment and suffering that have been inflicted upon these ex-servicemen. The Western Australian sub-branch comprises approximately 40 members, over 90 per cent of whom were torpedoed or taken prisoner of war while they served at sea. They were no older than 16 and 17 years of age at the time.

One gentleman not only had to go through the trauma of being torpedoed at 16 years of age; he was also taken prisoner and interned in a prisoner of war camp in Java, where he celebrated his 17th birthday. He has had to endure the pain and suffering of not being recognised for his service until this year, over 50 years later, when he was granted a 100 per cent disability under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. It is a shame this gentleman had to endure his suffering long after the war had ended; it is a greater shame and embarrassment to some in Australia that many more still suffer and are not recognised for their outstanding war effort.

The issue of seeking appropriate and equitable compensation for Australian mariners is not a new one. As far back as October 1989 Jocelyn McGirr issued her findings arising from the inquiry into the needs of Australian mariners, Commonwealth and Allied veterans and Allied mariners.

That report recommended, firstly, that Australian merchant mariners of World War II be provided with repatriation health benefits on the same basis as veterans of the Australian defence forces of World War II, including the provision of treatment for cancer and pulmonary tuberculosis; and, secondly, that Australian merchant mariners of World War I be provided with repatriation health benefits on the same basis as veterans of the Australian defence forces of World War I.

Fundamental to this issue is the claim on the part of the Australian merchant mariners that because they have comparable service with veterans of the Australian defence forces they should have comparable entitlements. The inquiry report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The inquiry's conclusion is that the claim is justified. In line with this general conclusion the inquiry believes that the health needs of this group should be met in the same way as those of Australian veterans, and that there should be no distinction in access to treatment entitlements.

Although there was action to rectify the injustice regarding entitlements for these ex-servicemen, it seems that there was not enough. It is important that we reward our heroes in Australia; it is important that we recognise sacrifices for our country. We cannot continue to deny the rights of these mariners any longer. We need to right the wrong of such long standing and ensure that the mariners receive just recognition for the service they provided to our nation at its time of great need.

PARA.TAB: While appearing to be a bit late for this, I wish to thank the merchant mariners for their service and contribution to our country and, on behalf of those Australians that care about this issue and about what happens to them, I support the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) and his motion. The motto of the merchant mariners was `Silent Service'. We should not allow them to suffer in silence any longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace Mr E.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to the motion I acknowledge the long and dedicated hours of hard work that the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) has committed to this worthy cause, along with other members of parliament on both sides of the House. I also acknowledge the 13,500 petitioners whose concerns were reported to the House this morning.

PARA.TAB: Along with the honourable member for Shortland there are many worthy individuals and groups who have also sought this particular form of justice for a long time, including various RSL groups and merchant mariner organisations. As a former merchant mariner myself—even if it was during the Korean emergency and not during the Second World War—I can assure the House that it was not any great bag of laughs running around with aviation spirits and with MiG fighters following. We had no protection whatsoever except from Royal Navy ships which had to cruise within 500 metres. There is a powerful argument for the support of this motion in the House today.

In August this year the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Faulkner, announced the establishment of an independent review of the veterans compensation pensions scheme. Included in the terms of reference was the following clause:

SPEECH.PARA: other compensation—related issues, including the standard of proof provisions with any associated statutory time limit; the existing scheme for seafarers; and the interface between disability and service pensions.

However, we have already had one review, as has been pointed out in the House today, called the McGirr inquiry, which reported in October 1989. So the umpire has already spoken.The McGirr inquiry was established to look at the needs of Australian mariners, Commonwealth mariners and Allied and veteran mariners. It was the principal task of that inquiry to assess the level of benefits provided to Australian Second World War merchant mariners so as to determine whether they were comparable with the benefits provided by other countries. It was also the task of the inquiry to determine whether Australian mariners were unfairly treated when compared to Australian veterans. The sad thing is that there is not much difference between the treatment of Australian mariners and mariners throughout the world. It was only recently that the government of the United Kingdom acknowledged in the national service act that mariners like me who did their apprenticeship in the merchant navy were entitled to the national service medal. The fact that was I sent there forcibly did not seem to make much difference.

PARA.TAB: So other countries are not much different from Australia. It takes a long time, and a lot of the people who have entitlements have unfortunately passed away. That is why it is so urgent that this wrong be righted in this country.

The McGirr inquiry found that the range of experiences of Australian merchant mariners during the war was comparable with the experiences of the Australian defence forces. In fact, in some cases the experience of merchant mariners far outweighed those of their defence force counterparts, with some 520 losing their lives at a rate roughly equivalent to that amongst servicemen. Of course, there are no prizes for guessing what the conclusion of the McGirr inquiry was. Basically, the inquiry recommended that the level and range of benefits provided to Australian mariners should be the same as those provided to veterans.

My final point relates to petitions to the House today. Clearly 13,500 petitioners is a large number. However, in relative terms it is simply overwhelming to receive that many signatures from across the country and across the political spectrum. It clearly shows the depth and breadth of the community's dissatisfaction with the way that those brave men and women have been treated. Without doubt, it is now time for us to do the right thing and recognise our responsibilities to those people. Mr Deputy Speaker, I thoroughly commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that some 18 months ago we were debating in this chamber the same motion by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), and yet in 18 months nothing has happened in response to the McGirr report that came down in 1989. Perhaps the only difference is the tenfold increase in the number of petitioners on the petition presented now as against then. Could I say, Mr Deputy Speaker, to the honourable member for Shortland how pleased I am that he is taking this up with the vigour he has, because apparently it is only that type of vigour that is going to win the day.

PARA.TAB: The difference between 18 months ago and now is that inevitably there are fewer merchant seamen left alive to receive any benefit that might be coming on. Sometimes I think this is the bureaucrats' favoured method of dealing with things—

TALK.START.PARA: —No doubt about that.

—That is quite correct. They like to wait for a time when small numbers are going to be affected and then make a grand gesture. I blame that on the bureaucracy. It is interesting when we compare a situation like this with the situation with the Bushells case within the last couple of years, when a decision went against the Department of Veterans' Affairs in connection with an illness and they were all activity at that stage to rush into action and change the act to correct that. So there is a hypocrisy there.

PARA.TAB: The McGirr report found that the range of wartime experience of Australian merchant mariners was comparable with the experiences of veterans of the Australian Defence Force. It is clear from the McGirr report that it was the intention of the government of the day to bring the benefits available under the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940 into line, as far as practicable, with the benefits available to ex-servicemen.

When I spoke on this matter on 28 May last year, I did so with the conviction and knowledge that I had the support of the RSL right across Australia, and the Merchant Navy War Service League and 30 other ex-servicemen's groups, together with Legacy and war widows. I had one adverse reaction from an ex-serviceman who seemed to be hung up on the fact that there was still a belief that the merchant seamen worked for reward and not in the interests of the war effort. Yet I know that there are many merchant mariners who would have liked to have served in the armed forces but were physically prevented from doing so because of the acknowledged need for their services. Their effort in the war was absolutely essential, providing the resources that were required to wage that war and also transporting the manpower right across those seas. As the McGirr report indicates, they all took the same risks as anyone in the armed services would have taken, and in some cases they took more.

There is an ex-mariner in my electorate, in Mackay, who has done a tremendous community service in so many ways. I have to pay tribute to Captain Red Faulkner, who served within the harbour facilities of Mackay after the war, in that he has persistently pursued action in this regard. His history is an interesting one. I believe that he would have liked to have worked within the RAN itself but was prevented from doing so. He was a man who had a ship sunk under him twice, and he was able to be saved and went back to what would have been then described as a fairly perilous occupation—yet no recognition has been given.

We have also had the records of the ships that have been torpedoed off our own coast and in our own ports. We must then describe this as a war zone. Irrespective of where those ships were, they were in constant danger. For one who has a fear of going under water, there is no way in the wide world I would be working under the waterline in any ship, let alone above it, and so I pay tribute to these people.

However, it is the departmental attitude that really is the problem. It has been a saga as far as the department is concerned. A person by the name of Norm Watts was reported in the Sunday Mail of April 1988 as having said that he went into Veterans' Affairs and some public servants were so much out of touch there that one young fellow asked whether the war was still going on in 1942. The young fellow had then asked people, `Were you in a war zone? Did you fraternise with the enemy?'.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Order! The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)recognising that:
(a)Australia is over-governed with three levels of government in a nation which is geographically, demographically and socially one;
(b)since Federation there has been a continuing transfer of power from State to federal government;
(c)local government is an essential level of government and natural base for distribution of many services now being provided by State and federal governments; and
(d)State governments hinder rather than provide good government, increase the opportunity for corruption, confuse responsibility and accountability and reduce the sovereignty of the people; and
(2)this House calls on the Executive to:
(a)develop a strategy and a plan to continue the process of transfer of power from State governments but to both federal and local governments;

(b)initiate action to phase out State governments, to base reformed local government on less than a hundred population centres throughout Australia and to provide constitutional recognition and Senate representation for local government; and
(c)thoroughly examine all options for reforming the structure of local government to ensure that it provides democratic, efficient and accountable representation to the Australian people.

This week the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is at the APEC conference in Seattle, where people from all over the Asia-Pacific region are talking about cooperation in trade and setting standards, even down to power plugs. We sell $12 billion more to the Asian countries involved in the APEC forum than they sell to us, so there are great opportunities there which we are already taking advantage of. We can be held back only by a lack of power, particularly in local areas, to use local resources to advantage. I refer particularly to human resources—people in business and people who are working for a living.

PARA.TAB: The Australian people are not sovereign because in Australia we have 15 houses of parliament all making different rules. In 1978, the Economist said Australia was rotted by too much politics and was one of five overgoverned nations. In 1981, Milton Friedman—I know he is infra dig, but let us not throw away the rational part of economic rationalism—said Australia was the most cosseted economy on earth and riddled with restrictive controls, including state governments.

We have confusion and inefficiency, with a lack of coordination on issues such as the movements of criminals across borders, disputes about which police force is responsible for what, buck-passing between three levels of government on responsibilities for roads, and lack of recognition of a trade because a person comes from the wrong side of the border. I have heard of a highly qualified RAAF electronics engineer whose qualifications were not recognised in some states.

We have had port reform held back because of state interference in the setting of prices at ports. We have had bank practices—and I think of the state banks of Victoria and South Australia—where the Reserve Bank has not had the power that it should have had to interfere. We have had monopolistic trade practices and doctors and lawyers dealing with those trade practices being held back because of the refusal of states to cooperate. We have had the huge frustration of industries, such as the fishing industry—a $1.2 billion industry—which is trying to work under a snarl of federal, state and local jurisdictions. In New South Wales at the moment the state jurisdiction is very much holding back on the problems in the fishing industry.

There is a lack of cooperation on issues such as housing and industrial relations. We have got a proliferation of industrial relations rules so that when something unsatisfactory happens, as has happened in Victoria, people skip across to federal jurisdiction. Another issue is that we have had corporate legislation held back. All this is inefficient and costly. All our governments in Australia spend about $140 billion per year. Surely, by simplifying our procedures we can save at least $10 billion of that cost to taxpayers, businesses, householders and farmers.

Talking of farmers, I mention that the recent mice plague in Victoria, New South Wales and South Australia was believed to cost a huge $20 billion in South Australia alone. However, South Australia could tackle the problem with one particular poison but that poison was not allowed to be used in Victoria or New South Wales because those states operate under different poison laws. It is quite evident that mice do not recognise state boundaries, nor do feral pigs, dogs, cats, rabbits or goats. Neither should we, because all this holds back useful money for investment.

Just the other day in the government party room, the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) raised the issue of regional development. He pointed out—as had Santos—that people were not able to compete across state borders, because of the proliferation of legislation regulations. The Santos people said they were not able to export across state borders because there were huge costs and different regulations which were holding them back.

Only recently, the desire of the federal and some state governments to get an eastern power grid together was contested. New South Wales and Victoria were finding difficulties with it, and they are holding back on cooperation—when we could have much lower costs, as we have with Telecom and Australia Post, through efficiency. If they separated the transmission from the supply of power, then we would have much lower costs. Not just millions, but hundred of millions of dollars—perhaps well over a billion dollars—could be saved to consumers. And all this has been held back.

What has happened as well is, of course, that we have had states competing for investment. We have had the give-away stakes, with Premier Bolte saying in Victoria some years ago that Westernport would be the Ruhr of Australia, and enticing John Lysaght Steel to set up at Hastings. He told the local council that it was to charge much lower rates, so that Lysaght could afford to do it. The council did not want to do so, and he put legislation through the parliament to do just that.

We have had the Victorian government in the give-away stakes with Portland and Alcoa. We have had an attempt being made by the aluminium industry to entice the hydro-electricity commission of Tasmania in those give-away stakes, and all in the name of competition between regions. Of course we should have competition between regions, where you get the true perspective of costs and advantages, but that does not necessarily happen with our present state boundaries. No wonder overseas investors find the Australian market difficult to understand and difficult to penetrate.

The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry talked about multiple layers of government and overlapping jurisdictions leading to delays, inconsistencies and additional costs to business investment. That is absolutely and completely true. The CAI, in its support of federalism, called for sensitivity to regional preferences in policy development. Both the ACCI and the CAI support federalism, but it is stretching it to infer that the states are regions. The boundaries were drawn in the United Kingdom, perhaps a couple of centuries ago, so they are not natural regional boundaries. The natural regional boundaries are different.

Local government needs to be reformed. We need to get away from the three tiers of government that we have at the moment. The Business Council of Australia called for having two tiers and pointed to the dangers of having three. Of course, they wanted the two tiers they were calling for to be completely separate. They seemed to be favouring strong regional government and strong national government, with each raising its own funds and spending them. I would rather have that than the present system of three tiers, but I do see in it some danger of people moving from one region to another to try to get better welfare benefits, or of people not being able to move and being strongly disadvantaged because they cannot.

We have the Brisbane City Council and the Northern Territory, Tasmanian and Australian Capital Territory governments, which are all based on more natural regional boundaries and which can give us a lead in the logic of government. I believe that the Australian Capital Territory government, which has had a lot of criticism, is beginning to show us just how much better it is than the type of state governments that we have.

We do not need two levels of government in land management, because that is what has led to more corruption. We have 9,000 elected councillors all over Australia. Let us replace them with a few hundred full-time members of local government. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) pointed out that we could get comprehensive reform of building and development and save the economy a billion dollars a year, by getting together with local government.

We can reform local government by transferring federal and state powers of administration, and passing social security and employment opportunities to local government, thereby making it much stronger than it is now. Since the turn of the century, the transfer of power has been done in such a way that powers have gone to the national government. But let us now see that the power goes to both state and national government. Prime Minister Menzies sought from the High Court in 1950 permission to do away with state immunity from Commonwealth legislation. That was granted by the High Court. Premier Fahey just recently called for more power over Loan Council borrowings by Victoria.

So it is happening all the time; it is happening almost naturally. The courts are doing it through tax and the corporations and external affairs powers. Aboriginal powers have gone to the federal government through a referendum. There has been increased cooperation. It is something that has happened naturally. Let us do it in an ordered way and eventually we will have a referendum. We need to have that referendum and it does not need to have anything to do with a republic. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with enthusiasm to speak against the motion introduced by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) because I disagree wholeheartedly with all its provisions except part (1), clause (b) which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Since federation there has been a continuing transfer of power from state to federal government.
That, Mr Deputy Speaker, is a fact. However, in many instances, the transfer of power is to be regretted—but more of that later.

PARA.TAB: Australia needs a federal system of government, as do all nations covering a large land mass. Although Australia is an island, it is far from being one geographically, as the honourable member asserts. Consider the enormous geographic differences between, for example, the tropical areas of Far North Queensland and cool temperate regions like Tasmania and Victoria. The consequent infrastructures which have developed are vastly different from each other as one would understandably expect.

Despite the ease of modern communications—the telexes, faxes, electronic mail, et cetera—a government special to each area is still needed. The whole ethos of each state, as developed historically, is different from that of all of the others. Other similar countries, like the United States, Canada and India, covering large land masses and containing different geographic regions, require and have federal systems of government. Even in Europe, where countries are relatively small and where unitary systems of government have generally been adopted, the biggest country geographically, Germany, has a federal system. The disintegration of the erstwhile USSR was caused not only by the collapse of European communism, but also by the breakdown of communications between the central government and its various provinces, particularly outlying ones like Latvia, Lithuania, Georgia, and so on.

To return to our own country, despite its binding language, the states of Australia have developed heterogeneously. Each state government has provided a distinct and much needed special representation to suit the particular region concerned. One of the best illustrations of the distinctive characters of the different Australian states as they have developed historically relates to the topic of land usage. The ramifications of the present extremely difficult problem facing Australia regarding the High Court's Mabo decision centre around the different land management regimes in each state.

In Victoria, the difficulty is minimal because only 0.04 per cent of the state is given to leasehold title and vacant crown land, whereas in Western Australia, Premier Richard Court is grappling with difficulties involving a state in which 69.8 per cent of the land is affected, 36 per cent being leasehold and 32.8 per cent being vacant crown land.

If ever the necessity for continuing state governments to represent the interests of the people is evident, surely the case of Western Australia at the present time is the best possible example. I would very much doubt that the alternative of numerous local government entities as suggested in the motion would have the necessary clout to represent the Western Australian people as effectively. I would argue strongly that, far from reducing the sovereignty of the people, as part (1), clause (d) of this motion suggests, state governments increase and protect the sovereignty of the people.

I previously mentioned the continuing transfer of power from state to federal government referred to in paragraph (1) (b) of the motion. Some changes, particularly those in the area of transport, have been beneficial—and I concede that—but others have resulted in an unnecessary duplication in burgeoning bureaucracies. The two most obvious departments which spring to mind are health and education. Federal poaching in these two areas particularly is enormously and unnecessarily costly. I would trust that a future federal Liberal government would cut costs by transferring certain powers back to the states in these two important areas.

I have no criticism of local government council representatives—who, generally, are dedicated community activists, giving generously of their time and energy for little reward, as all of us in this place well know. However, over recent years there has been a massive and costly growth in local government bureaucracy. Ambitious city managers have poached the territory of state governments, particularly in the welfare area. In the Sydney Sun-Herald of August 29 this year, an article entitled `Top job salaries a shock to ratepayers' stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Some council managers will be in the same pay bracket as the N.S.W. Premier and Federal Government Ministers.
It stated further in that article:
At least two Sydney councils are offering packages adding up to $150,000.
Ku-ring-gai Mayor, Peter Derwent, is quoted as saying:
I know of two other councils where the package is $150,000. I talked to a country mayor yesterday and he was talking of offering their general manager $170,000.

Before dispensing with (1) (d), I would like to point out that corruption is not confined to state governments. We often hear of graft at local level, as in the case of the Sydney Morning Herald article of 12 March of this year entitled `Jobs for the boys row has a deja vu feel'. The article names the Labor Mayor of Liverpool, Alderman Mark Latham, as responsible for awarding a $46,000 a year research appointment to ALP colleague Peter Primrose, former Lord Mayor of Campbelltown and state MP for Camden. The selection committee comprised Latham, on a $25,000 allowance plus a car, and general manager John Walker, who was on a salary of $130,000. Apparently, the appointment was kept from other councillors. Another alderman, Tony Pascale, commented:
In my view it was a fully political appointment. To me, I'm 400 per cent sure it's jobs for the boys.

TALK.START.PARA: —An objective commentator, no doubt.

—He was. At the federal level, grave maladministration was fully exposed in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs business migration program in 1991. The public accounts committee's report of June that year was a damning indictment of appalling maladministration in the federal system. Additionally, it could well be argued that without state governments the central government would have to pick up some former state bureaucracies and would find it more difficult to keep track of the various government departments. As a result, corruption may well become more widespread, not less.

PARA.TAB: I would actively oppose all three parts of paragraph (2) of the motion. In summary, paragraph (2) merely restates, as it clearly shows, the Whitlam agenda of 1972-1975, which was a matter of advocating the setting up of regional councils to eventually replace state governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Spot on.

—That is an interesting concession from the other side. I believe that the success of the motion of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro would be detrimental to the wellbeing of the Australian people and, for that reason, I vigorously oppose the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in seconding this motion. The three-tier system of government in this country is now totally anachronistic. The state structure made sense in 1901 because there was relatively little interaction between the various major population centres in our country and we had relatively self-contained economies and societies operating in the then six colonies.

PARA.TAB: The recent revolution in transport and communications, which the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred) has referred to, has broken down these barriers, particularly in the past 10 to 15 years. We have cheaper air fares, cheaper phones, fax machines, video conferencing, better cars and a whole range of mechanisms which ensure that the degree of interaction between the various parts of our country is infinitely greater than it used to be.

In the last 10 years, the volume of interstate road freight has doubled. In the past 20 years, the number of domestic air passengers—the majority of them, of course, being interstate—has trebled. In the Hilmer report on national competition policy, this situation was very adequately summed up:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is for all practical purposes a single, integrated market. The economic significance of state and territory boundaries is diminishing rapidly as advances in transport and communications permit even the smallest firms to trade around the nation.

Everything is becoming more national: television networks; business activity; tourism; social activity; and sporting competitions in all the major sports, which is something that was unheard of 20 years ago.

PARA.TAB: The retention of our three-tier system of government now means that we have eight separate systems of law in the critical areas of criminal law, libel law, consumer law, road laws, food and beverage standards, occupational qualifications and environmental laws. We therefore have enormous amounts of resources, time and energy being devoted at the different levels of government to trying to achieve uniform regulations in many of these areas.

There must come a point when we step back and say, `In this welter of uniform national regulation being developed in so many areas, why is it that, if it is so important that we do have uniform national regulation, we retain the constitutional power to make these regulations in the states and therefore allow a lowest common denominator right of veto in all these areas?'.

There is no better recent example of this issue than the squabble over national education policy where, in spite of the clear support by business across the country for the development of uniform national education standards, two recently elected conservative state governments decided to gum up the works for a period of time. That is a classic illustration of the rapidly increasing irrelevance of state governments in these areas of genuine national significance.

We have overlapping and duplicatory planning and regulatory regimes. There are many horror stories which are often used as examples to illustrate problems with regulations per se. These are examples of business being unable to pursue legitimate development of often quite simple and straightforward things just because there are too many tiers of government, too many regulatory bodies and nightmares of bureaucratic duplication and obstruction. That is very much a product of having three tiers of government, and road funding is a classic example of where these sorts of anomalies lie.

The distribution of powers, logical as it may well have been in many respects in 1901, is now clearly out of step with the needs of national government. The need for the federal government to use export powers with respect to nationally significant environmental issues is an obvious example of the absurdity of our system.

The use of international conventions, which is so decried by those on the other side of the House, is simply a device which is forced upon the government in order to acquire the power to legislate. The vast majority of national governments across the rest of the world already have that power through the normal constitutional arrangements in those countries. It is not some sort of grand, international conspiracy with the United Nations thought police at the door; it is simply a mechanism to ensure that the national government can legislate on matters of national importance.

As my friend the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) has pointed out, we have the absurdity of umpteen different industrial relations systems, both at the federal and the state level, across the country. That is an illustration of the manifestly ridiculous nature of our structure of government. A better illustration would be hard to find.

The boundaries are absurd. Substantial parts of New South Wales economically and socially relate more to major centres in other states than to Sydney. The boundaries do not reflect real aggregations of social and economic interests and activities. We also have some of the ultimate absurdities like the fact that we cannot seem to get our act together on time zones and we have different state governments doing different things at different times. We have even managed to celebrate Australia Day on different days depending on which state we are in. We are possibly the only country in the world to manage that.

The issue is not, as is often said, about more power to Canberra. I commend the honourable member for Deakin for his relatively rational presentation, because often we hear from the other side of the House hysterical outbursts about how this is some sort of grand conspiracy to build a gigantic, bureaucratic behemoth in Canberra, as was said by the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) in a previous debate on this issue in 1990.

The issue is not about more power to Canberra, because it would be appropriate for most of the functions of state governments to go to regional governments; so they would go down the hierarchy and not up. The ACT government, which does have its faults—as all governments do—is a very good working model, although it is still in its infancy, of how a two-tier system can function quite effectively in this country.

The notion that the states and the Senate have functioned as protectors of the interests of the less populated regions in this country I would also challenge. I regard it as a myth. Contrary to what the honourable member for Deakin said, we are, compared with the rest of the world, a remarkably uniform people across our large continent. Political divisions within our community have almost invariably been across state boundaries and within states, not between states. This is why the Senate has not been a states house, because the vast bulk of issues we have had to deal with, the great issues that have divided the nation, have also divided people within their states and have occurred across state boundaries.

We have no Quebec, we have no Georgia or Uzbekistan to follow the Soviet Union example, and we have no Scotland. We are quite a uniform people. What this has meant is that neither of the major political forces can possibly hope to govern in this country nationally if they actively discriminate against one significant part of the country.

I suggest that if the opposition's view of the Mabo debate is accurate then we will lose government because we need to win seats in Western Australia. There has not been a government in the history of this country that has governed nationally without seats in Western Australia. What that reflects is the relative uniformity of our population across the country. There is no state that votes 80 per cent Liberal and 20 per cent Labor or vice versa.

I would appeal to people in the opposition to have a look at their traditional backers in the business community like the Business Council of Australia or like many of those businesses engaged in national and international economic activity and listen to them. What they are saying is, `We are tired of the inefficiency that is brought by this three-tier system of government, we want micro-economic reform in the area where it is most critical'.
To those on my own side who have some nervousness about this issue, and there are inevitably some, I would just like to conclude by quoting a very great former Labor Prime Minister. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I favour abolition of State Parliaments and greatly extended powers being given to local governing authorities. . . It is said that this proposal represents a revolutionary change, but to regard a great change as something fraught with dire danger is not always a sign of wisdom; it is more often a sign of a parish-pump mind. . . If it is carried it will be because the seeds of national unity which were planted at the time of federation have at last come to flower.

It may surprise members to know that that was not Gough Whitlam or Bob Hawke; it was Ben Chifley speaking in this House in 1930. I would commend his views to honourable members. I think they sum up the situation very well. It is time that our community fully grew to its potential and that we shed the last vestiges of the colonial structure which we have inherited, which no longer reflects the genuine economic and social structure of our society and which now inhibits economic efficiency to a considerable extent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) and the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) for bringing this matter up because what we have got is a plea for the most fundamental and radical reform of Australia's federal system in the history of the nation. It is a plan far more radical than the Labor Party's pre-1960s policy on federalism. It is a plan that is contrary to the new federalism attitudes and policies of the Labor Party and the government. It is a plan which is hopelessly out of step with the worldwide trend against highly dominant central governments and very much towards a devolution of power to small community groups. What he proposes—
—That is what it is about.

—Let us deal with that. He proposes to abolish the state and territory governments, to pass all executive responsibility to the federal government in Canberra, to abolish the present 911 local government authorities and replace them with something fewer than 100 regional authorities, and to bring representatives from the regional authorities into the Senate. In other words, the honourable member would have us abolish Australia's federal system in favour of a single all-powerful Canberra based government with up to 100 major population centres being administered by a form of municipal government, and with representatives from those municipalities, presumably, replacing the state representatives in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: In developing his case, the honourable member for Eden-Monaro makes the claim that state governments should be abolished because they hinder rather than encourage good government, they increase the opportunity for corruption, reduce responsibility and accountability and reduce the sovereignty of the people. What we really heard from the honourable member for Melbourne was the basis of this. He finished his speech by talking about vestiges of colonialism. He was not talking about good government; he just has this matter in the back of his mind that somehow all we inherited from the British Crown has to be abolished, set aside, got rid of.

Presumably the 50, 60 or 100 regional authorities of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro will be immune from failures of corruption, reduced responsibility and accountability, and all of those terrible things that he believes may be associated with the present system. I think it would have greatly assisted the House if the honourable member for Eden-Monaro had provided an explanation why his scheme would do away with all those demerits.

He also claims that the three levels of government are excessive for a nation which geographically, demographically and socially is one. I do not really believe that a member of this parliament is naive enough to suggest that the sixth largest country in the world, an area of about 8 million square kilometres, 4,000 kilometres from Perth to Sydney and the same from Darwin to Hobart, is geographically one. Except in the sense that it is an island state, it is not geographically one. It differs very greatly in its geography from one part to another, and it is absolute nonsense, I believe, to talk about a demographic oneness of the Australian people. What is true is that, despite the diversity of our geography and our people, we are one nation, a nation which we can be very proud of for having successfully integrated millions of immigrants into an incredibly cohesive and tolerant society with a strong and unique sense of nationalism. But that cohesive sense of nationalism or oneness is no basis, in my view, for forcing us into a single giant central government; quite the reverse.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will want one world government next.

—Yes. The geography of Australia and the diversity of its peoples demand the diversity of government, from federal to state, perhaps to regional, down to municipal. The honourable member for Melbourne probably has not travelled widely at this stage and he has obviously not been to northern Queensland to see the differences of view that they have up there. When they talk about the south, they are not talking about New South Wales or Victoria, they are talking about Brisbane. So he should not come in here and tell me that the people of North Queensland or the people of the Kimberleys believe that all wisdom resides in Canberra. It certainly does not.

PARA.TAB: I also question the claim of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro that a single all-powerful government in Canberra will give us better democracy and improved efficiency.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not be all-powerful.

—If we have got one national government with the power over all the others, we have centralised power in Canberra. Whichever way the honourable member likes to dress it up, that is the practical result of it. More to the point, the very diversity and size of the nation means that the most effective democracy occurs when people can directly involve themselves in the matters which affect their day-to-day wellbeing, that is to say, a decentralised system which reaches right into and operates at the community level.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro is wrong to claim that his scheme will be more democratic. How can people be more democratically represented when he would remove much of their municipal representation, abolish their state governments and create this Canberra bureaucracy? That is a scheme to create remoteness, and it must inevitably worsen the quality of democratic representation. Similarly, the honourable member has failed to convince me that his scheme will in itself improve efficiency and reduce corruption.

We often hear it stated that we are over-governed, and the honourable member used this argument to justify his radical proposal. However, there is undeniable evidence that we are not over-governed by international standards. If we take the number of parliamentary representatives, both national and state, in the major Western nations, and include Japan, and express them as a ratio of population per representative, we find that Australia has the lowest representation, which will come as a great surprise to a lot of people. The figures are: Australia, 20.3 persons per representative; Canada, 23.4; United Kingdom, 31.4; USA, 31.7; Japan, 34.0; and New Zealand, 34.8.

The honourable member for Eden-Monaro has made much of the inefficiencies of local government. I can see that in the 1950s and 1960s there was a widespread concern about many aspects of our local authorities, for example, the level of professionalism, a propensity for corruption, and all too evident signs of inefficiencies. However, over the past 20 years these problems have been addressed through the appointment of qualified people who have improved professionalism, a greater involvement in councils, the provision of community and welfare services, and better public access to the workings and decision making of councils. As well, I believe that there is a greater willingness by state governments to enforce and encourage administrative standards and effectiveness.

There are legitimate concerns about aspects of the local government system, such as very small councils which are not economically viable. There is concern about some voting practices and there is a need for vigilance over administrative standards and the propensity for corruption. However, compressing 911 councils into 100 or less regional authorities, as the honourable member seeks to do, will not overcome these problems and may well create their own sets of new problems.

Let us consider this proposal for a moment, because it is unclear to me just where these 50, 60 or 99 authorities are to be located. If it were one to each of the top 50 most populated areas of Australia, that would leave hundreds of fair-sized cities without any municipal representation. Or could it be that our population of 18 million-odd is to be divided into 50 authorities, each representing 360,000 people? In that event, we would get about 10 authorities covering the greater Sydney area and one covering the whole of New South Wales west of the ranges.

I am sure that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro is mesmerised by the economies of scale that are implied in these large operating units. I would refer him to studies which show that economies of scale in terms of administrative costs are optimised at a population of about 10,000.

Furthermore, cost is only one factor in determining municipal representation. For example, a regional authority located at Orange, with the responsibility for the entire western slopes and plains of New South Wales, might operate at maximum cost efficiency but could ultimately fail because of its remoteness from the majority of its clients. In fact, if the honourable member created such a structure, I predict that the Orange authority would quickly be creating subregional authorities to service the needs of larger cities and towns within its area of responsibility.

The honourable member would have us go full circle. He abolishes the state governments and almost all municipalities to satisfy his `overgoverned' complaint, and then he finds that his new structure can work effectively only by creating an administrative system almost identical, but with different names, to the one that he has abolished.

If we look more realistically at the economy of scale research, its message is clear. Successful municipal reform should be concentrated on amalgamating and restructuring those municipalities which service a population of something less than 10,000 people. When it comes down to the practical aspects of these things, not all wisdom resides in Canberra. There is a need for a diversion of power. Federal ministers need the leavening effects of opposition for some of their more harebrained schemes—and I am talking about ministers on both sides of the political fence. The properly authorised ministers of state governments represent the interests of their people in a very real and effective way.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Order! The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)notes the allocation of $1.2 million from the federal Budget, comprising $600 000 in 1993-94 and $200 000 in each of the following three years, to the Republic Advisory Committee and Constitutional Reform Unit to prepare the basic arguments for an Australian republic;
(2)notes that no allocation is made to any equivalent pro-monarchy organisation to provide balance to the debate on whether Australia should remain a monarchy or change to a republic;
(3)condemns the blatant bias in the Government's spending and propaganda priorities which will not provide a balanced debate on this subject; and

(4)calls on the Government to reconsider its priorities and provide equivalent funding to a pro-monarchy organisation, for example the Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy, to provide a properly balanced debate.

This motion we put before the House today demands bipartisan support, but I fear that that will not be the reaction of government members. It should be supported because the Labor government, in a blatant and discriminatory manner, has allocated from the federal budget $1.2 million of taxpayers' funds to the Republic Advisory Committee.

PARA.TAB: In a country that is proud of its democracy and its sense of justice and fair play, this appropriation is, in every sense, offensive and repugnant. Why is it offensive? Firstly, on any matter where a referendum will eventually be necessary, it has been the convention in the Australian democracy that both sides of the argument should have the equal opportunity to express their opinion. Both sides should have been funded publicly or, as the current economic climate would demand, no public funding should have been given at all. But the committee was publicly funded, and the other party against the proposition received not one single cent or any encouragement whatsoever. Indeed, the most responsible body to carry the other side of the argument, Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy, has been left to seek its own funds.

Secondly, the funding by taxpayers of this proposition means that over 50 per cent of Australians who support the current constitution and monarchy have to contribute to the funding of a view which they condemn. This is at a time when those same taxpayers are being asked to fund the other whims of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) such as child care, a Thai teak dining table and lithographs for the cabinet room: things which can only be described as gross indulgences. The people of Australia should—and do—say no to the extravagances of the Prime Minister at a time when Australians and Australian industries are still wallowing in debt and when this country has a record unemployment rate of 11.3 per cent.

The cost to this nation of the Prime Minister's predetermination to go down the path of a republic does not stop at $1.2 million. For instance, where within the appropriations were the costs of these published reports covered? Where did they cover the costs of the administration of the program, which seems to have taken up such an inordinate amount of time? Who pays for the National Media Liaison Service and the other government press which are committed to the republican debate? Who pays for the salary of David Hill and the ABC to promote a republic?

Worst of all, who covers the damage done to this country in terms of trade and loss of respect through the Prime Minister and his ilk on their many visits overseas sounding off against Australian institutions? The cost is not $1.2 million. It runs into tens of millions of dollars.

Years ago, when he was Treasurer, the Prime Minister talked about Australia becoming a banana republic. It only remains for the republic part of that prediction to come true. I do not denigrate the character of those who genuinely feel that a republic is worthy of consideration as we approach the centenary of Australia's Federation in 2001. However, why are those people worthy of consideration for funding whilst the members of the Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy are not? Can those people come up with one good reason for Australia to change its democratic system under the monarchy to a democratic system under a republic?

After two years, the Prime Minister has not been able to give one proper reason, and yet he has removed the process of democracy from this chamber itself. However, a unanimous decision about a republic has not as yet been made within the Labor Party, as the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) willingly testifies here on occasions.

There is only one change that Australia needs at the moment. It is not a change of the flag. It is not a change of the constitution. All that is needed is a change of government. It is interesting to look at the latest polls. It appears that the Prime Minister himself is our greatest advocate, as far as the polls are concerned, for our staying a democracy. Late last month, the Melbourne Sunday Herald-Sun had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: A newspaper readers' survey yesterday showed 77 per cent against the Prime Minister Paul Keating's plans for Australia to become a republic by 2001.

So it looks as though our best advocate is the Prime Minister himself. Surely, the main factor in this debate is the manner in which we, as the elected members, can protect and maximise the democratic right of all Australians under our constitution.

PARA.TAB: Our monarchy protects that democracy through the non-political appointment of a head of state. As with the governor-generals in the past, I believe that the current Governor-General, His Excellency the Hon. William George Hayden, knows those responsibilities and I believe that he would exercise those responsibilities impartially for the benefit of all Australians.

In addition, that democracy is further protected by an independent High Court of seven judges. Also, in addition to the House of Representatives where governments are formed, the Senate acts as a check and balance of the excesses of the executive of the day and, for example, that goes to the recent budget. Lastly, elections every three years are also a great check on government excesses. A republic cannot have a minimalistic position; either the democracy is retained or it is weakened, and that is what Australians will do by transferring to a republic, as our advisory committee has recommended.

For instance, the presidency will be a political appointment, beholden to a parliament or an electorate. The head of state would only be a figurehead. Will the states be preserved or will they, as the originators of the current federation, suddenly become the casualties of a republic? The previous debate suggests that is still Labor's policy.

Also, will the check of the Senate remain or will it be dispatched to the annals of history as the Labor Party policy appears to suggest? All I can say is, in no way will a change enhance the democratic right of ordinary Australians. The recent comment of Senator Gareth Evans that a republic would enhance the recognition of a president as the head of state is absolute rubbish. He used as his example the Governor-General's visit to the French war graves in September. With all due respect, Mr Deputy Speaker, what else would honourable members expect from the French?

In this debate, there is often expressed an opinion that eventually or inevitably Australia will become a republic. This is the softer line pushed by the potential republicans. In my mind, there is no inevitability; we should not change for change's sake. We too often see these days that change rejects traditions and principles and morals and comes up with fewer and worse standards.

I will return to the work of the report of the Republic Advisory Committee and the questions it asked.
