These referred only to matters of the removal of all references to the monarch and, in the light of that, the need for and the creation of a new office of the head of state and the provisions for such appointment, and so on. In no way were questions required to be answered as to whether people wanted to stay within the monarchy itself. For the expenditure of $1.2 million, it was entirely unbalanced. If it was balanced, it would have sought an opinion from people on the retention of the current constitution or on any suggested changes that might have been recommended to that constitution.

It was inevitable, when that committee met in public in Mackay on 12 July last year, that it was attended by some 50-odd citizens. That was a large number in comparison to other meetings. I understand, from those who attended the meeting, that all but the speaker and about two other citizens demanded to know why they could not discuss the retention of the present constitution—a constitution they were proud to have, to uphold and to retain. The whole argument for a republic and the argument for a change of our flag is but a diversion by a government who knows that it has no runs on the board for the economy, for debt, for employment, for the people—for children and families in poverty—and for the advancement of our underprivileged.

It was heartening to be present at the return of the Unknown Soldier just one week ago, 75 years after Armistice Day. To have returned to Australia a person representing the 60,000 dead from World War I reminded us that this soldier and all Australian soldiers fought, and some died, for the principles of democracy and freedom. They fought for a monarch and a constitution; they fought for their family and loved ones. For the brief time of that ceremony, I compared the Australia that the Unknown Soldier died and fought for with the Australia of today. I knew then that there should be no inevitability of change and no change whatsoever because that flag and that constitutional monarchy best serves me and my family today as it did my father and mother and their family 75 years ago.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an absurd motion because it is based on a widespread misunderstanding of the task that was actually bestowed upon the Turnbull committee by the government. It may be a fairly subtle distinction for some on the opposition benches to come to grips with but, believe it or not, the role of the Turnbull committee was not to promote the idea of a republic. The role of the Turnbull committee was to investigate options as to how a republic could be brought about.

PARA.TAB: The question it was charged with answering was not why, but how. The question it had to deal with was what were the mechanical problems—the logistical difficulties—of actually introducing a republic. The presumption behind the task of the committee was that the government is committed to proceed down that path. Honourable members may well recall that, in the policy speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) prior to the election on 13 March, this is precisely what was promised—that a committee would be established to investigate the mechanisms whereby Australia could become a republic.

The Turnbull committee's job was to go out into the community to consult—which it did—about the options, about whether we should have an elected head of state or an appointed one, about how one would deal with the problem of the state governors if Australia became a republic, and about what powers the head of state should have. It was about the details. That was what its task was. It was not to go out and promote the virtues of becoming a republic.

Although there were the occasional comments made by people like Malcolm Turnbull, they were perfectly entitled to make them. What they were engaged in doing was examining the constitutional complexities, the options for things like the method of appointment and powers of the head of state and the problems associated with state governments in Australia becoming a republic. That was their task. The line of argument that is put forward today by the opposition is deliberate obfuscation by those who are smart enough to realise these subtleties, and for those who are not it is just simply that they are enshrouded in a cloud of mysticism and nostalgia for the past that is no longer relevant to today's needs.

The Turnbull committee was quite logically headed by a republican because of the very task that it had to fulfil. No doubt if in the dim, distant future honourable members opposite ever come to government and set up a committee to inquire into deregulation of the labour market, it would be unlikely that somebody like John Halfpenny would be appointed to head the committee. It would have been absurd for us to appoint a monarchist to head that committee that was inquiring not into whether or not a republic should be brought about but into how such a change would be brought about and what sort of difficulties and obstacles there were, constitutionally, to bringing about that change.

So those monarchists who are around saying that it was an outrage that money was not given to monarchists in this process are being deliberately misleading. The issue that was being examined was not whether or not we should become a republic, the issue that was being examined was how. Clearly, one does not need to conduct a major inquiry into how to keep the status quo. The answer is very simple: do nothing. There is no need to have equality on these two fronts because, in order to examine the questions of fairly complicated change, there must be widespread community consultation and examination. There is no need for a detailed examination of how to retain the status quo, the alternative. I would argue that the Turnbull committee did an excellent job and it discharged its functions as it was supposed to do and, in doing so, it managed to sweep aside some of the more absurd furphies that have surfaced in this debate.
For example, it swept aside the suggestion that republics are by definition unstable and that monarchies are inherently stable. I quote from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: Experience throughout the world demonstrates that there is no necessary relation between a country's political stability or economic success and the nature of its head of state.
There are examples of successful and stable republics and successful and stable monarchies. There are unsuccessful and unstable republics and unsuccessful and unstable monarchies.

PARA.TAB: In the postwar period we have seen the two major defeated powers, Germany and Japan, both become economic giants. One is a republic, one is a monarchy. If one looks at the economic tigers in Asia, some are monarchies, some are republics. Perhaps the opposition is suggesting that the solution to the problems in Russia is that we might bring back the tsar or maybe anoint King Boris the First. Perhaps that would solve the problems there, and that really would sort everything out.

The Turnbull committee has also demonstrated that the notion of introducing a republic in Australia being constitutionally impossible is absolute nonsense. For example, it has been suggested by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) amongst others that the phrase in the covering clauses `indissoluble Commonwealth under the Crown' means that there was some form of contract entered into whereby the states—or the colonies as they then were—in effect entered into a contract which meant that the Crown had to be retained as the head of government in order for federation and the constitution to be retained. Overwhelming legal opinion as referred to in the Turnbull committee report shows that this is a ludicrous interpretation of the covering clauses and that there is no constitutional impossibility whatsoever to Australia becoming a republic.

The committee has also laid to rest the suggestion, which the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) gave a bit of a run before, that there is some sort of hidden agenda in all this process. The suggestion was that in some way we could have a nice, benign, minimalist referendum about republican change, and then wake up the next morning and suddenly find that the states have disappeared, or that the Senate has suddenly disappeared—magically and mysteriously. It is an extraordinary suggestion, because honourable members opposite all know as well as I do that, for any change of that nature, we would have to have the same process: a referendum, a decision amongst the people.

I support that change; but to suggest that in some way that will happen by stealth behind the scenes, just because we change the method of election of our head of state, is manifest scaremongering and absurdity. How could such an agenda be hidden? It is an absolutely ludicrous proposition to suggest to the people of Australia, and it is an insult to their intelligence. The motion that we have before us today reflects the level of paranoia that is abroad amongst many of the monarchist elements in our community, and their willingness to try to build up scares to frighten people about change. All sorts of absurd nonsense is being put forward in support of an increasingly indefensible status quo.

I am interested to hear the honourable member for Dawson quote the one opinion poll that had a very biased structure, in that the poll referred to `Mr Keating's republic'. I would suggest that he also have a look at some of the other opinion polls, which show overwhelming majority support for moving to a republic. They also show that the younger the age group, the higher the support for a republic; so that support is simply going to keep growing. The opposition had better get used to the idea that at some stage Australia will become a republic; that at some stage we will grow up and become an independent nation in our own right. These things will happen.

It would be far better for the Liberal Party and the National Party to learn from their mistakes in the Mabo debate, where they have been left sitting high and dry, with most of the supporters and interest groups that have traditionally backed them actually now supporting the government's position, and some of their own states backing the government's position. The opposition is going to end up in the same set of circumstances in this debate, where gradually some of the more rational and intelligent forces on the conservative side of politics in this community will realise—as many such as Nick Greiner and Peter Collins have already realised—that we should approach these issues with rationality and logic, and without trying to frighten people with scaremongering that there is some sort of incredible communist conspiracy of nasty reds under the beds, and all the usual stuff.

The opposition should approach the issues on their merits, argue them out and consider what the options are. Consider, for example, the very serious question which I think is one that is going to be very important to the debate, of whether our head of state should be directly elected by the people, or appointed by the government, or elected by the parliament in some way. There are arguments either way on those issues, and they should be properly debated. By taking the position it is taking, the opposition is removing itself from that debate.

I would urge everyone to participate in that debate, because that will help to form the political and governmental structure of this country for a long time to come, when this referendum is eventually put and this nation does decide to become republic. We will get a better result on those issues if all the major forces in our community participate in the debate, rather than putting their hands over their eyes and saying, `No! We don't want any part of this; this is all outrageous! It is change; it is all terrible!'. The opposition should participate in the debate on these issues on their merits and make a contribution. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to support the motion proposed by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), and I draw to the attention of the House the approach taken to the debate by the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner). He has fallen into the trap of getting into the debate about the republic and the constitutional monarchy and not addressing the fundamental issue of the funding of the Republic Advisory Committee and the government's approach to this whole matter.

PARA.TAB: The republican debate is a classic case of one group—those in favour of destroying Australia's internationally respected and successful constitutional monarchy—being funded by taxpayers, as a direct result of the dislike by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of anything that is even remotely connected with Britain. The opposing view—that Australia's existing system of government works well—is advanced by a group called Australians for Constitutional Monarchy. ACM now has over 6,500 active subscribers to its charter, yet that group has not received a single dollar of government funds.

On 26 May this year the Prime Minister informed the honourable member for Indi, in answer to a question on notice, that the estimated cost of the Republic Advisory Committee was about $280,000. The real cost proved to be far in excess of that. In an answer on 26 October to questions asked by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) and me, the Prime Minister said that the budgeted cost of the Republic Advisory Committee was $390,000. This was more than $100,000 over the Prime Minister's original estimate.

Of course, the committee could not even stick to its own budget. Although the opposition has been provided with the committee's expenses only up to 15 October, the Prime Minister has acknowledged that this little taxpayer funded baby of his spent at least $410,000 in less than six months of its life up to 15 October when it was disbanded.

Although the Chairman of the Republic Advisory Committee, Mr Malcolm Turnbull, declined to accept the $271 a day sitting fee laid down by the Remuneration Tribunal, other members of the committee had no such reservations. In total, committee members have claimed $11,400 in sitting fees. Two committee members, Miss Lois O'Donoghue and Ms Mary Kostakidis, are employed by ATSIC and SBS respectively and hence could not claim these fees.

The six members who did receive almost $2,000 each on average had their hotel bills paid, travelled business class by air and in hire cars and taxis. In contrast, Australians for Constitutional Monarchy representatives have always travelled economy class in planes as their funding comes overwhelmingly from public donations in $10 and $20 lots. Their largest single cash donation has been $2,500, a drop in the ocean compared with the public largesse received by the Republic Advisory Committee.

What I object to most about the workings of the Republic Advisory Committee is that, because two of its members, the chairman, Mr Malcolm Turnbull, and Dr John Hirst are members of the Australian republican movement and Professor George Winterton was a founding supporter, they have a position before they even started. So, despite its brief that it was to describe only the minimum steps that Australia would be obliged to take to become a viable federal republic, it could be said that the republicans had the advantage of a troika of representatives, whereas the opposing argument had no such status within the Republic Advisory Committee to ensure that there was another intrinsic view.

TALK.START.PARA: —They even knocked back Professor Blainey.

—This was further borne out by Mr Keating's refusal to accept the Victorian Premier's nomination of Professor Geoffrey Blainey as a committee member, as the honourable member for Dawson quite rightly interjects. Professor Blainey, who has lately been subject to some abuse from the Prime Minister, is an eminent Australian and a great historian. His presence on the Republic Advisory Committee would have added to the report's balance.

PARA.TAB: Australians for Constitutional Monarchy's submission and its legal committee's opinion were both specifically referred to in the Republic Advisory Committee's report. This is an admission of the quality of the ACM's work. More importantly, ACM should have at least had the right to equal funding because of the diversity of its support base. Let me quickly run through some of its Victorian council as a good example: the Hon. Don Chipp, former leader of the Australian Democrats; Ronald Conway, well-known psychologist; Richard Divall, Music Director of the Victoria State Opera; the Rt Hon. Malcolm Fraser; the Hon. Rod Mackenzie, former Labor and later an independent member of the Legislative Council; Dame Phyllis Frost, respected community worker; and last but not least, Mr Fred Maddern and Councillor Richard Meldrum, former lord mayors of Footscray and Melbourne respectively.

I commend the motion of the honourable member for Dawson and I bring to the House's attention the different treatment accorded to those who want to change our current constitution and those who, through Australians for Constitutional Monarchy, want to retain it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am puzzled by this motion, particularly the fact that it has been moved by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), who I always thought had a modicum of intelligence and commonsense. But, unfortunately, with the contents of this motion, he is displaying an amazing lack of credibility. He seems to have ignored totally what the reality is with regard to the committee chaired by Mr Turnbull, the Republic Advisory Committee. He has ignored the fact that it was not engaging in any public debate or promotion of the reasons for having a republic and that all it was doing was seeking to explain what the various options were.

PARA.TAB: If he has actually read the report, and I hope he has, he would understand that it has not made any judgments that we should have a republic and this is the way to go. It has actually listed the whole range of bits of information about the possible options and whether or not it could actually be done. He argues that somehow we need to be giving equal pay and equal time to this group called Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy when we have not yet in fact engaged in any public debate. Honourable members opposite should wait until the public debate starts, because that is when they will really start seeing the juggernauts for change rolling over them.

This motion is just the last gasp by the declining number of constitutional monarchists in this place and in this country. The fact is that they know they are on a loser; they know that they are not going to win this debate; they understand that the majority of people of Australia want change and are not frightened of change and, despite all of the fears and phobias that they are trying to build up and all the various peaks of hysteria that they have managed to drag out in this debate, the people of Australia are going to accept change. The people think it is time for change, and we are not going to cling to these old vestiges of the past that are represented by the monarchy.

If we are actually going to have fairness and equity in this debate, if we are going to have balance, the campaign for a republic, when and if that gets under way, should receive quite a few millions of dollars from the government, since the fact is that the government in its budget each year allocates millions of dollars to the constitutional monarchy. It does that through the office of Governor-General, and it does that through the fact that it pays for royal visits. I understand there is going to be a royal visit here next year, that Prince Charles will be coming out to Australia next year and we will be spending hundreds of thousands of dollars taking him around, showing him around to the people of Australia. That is the government's responsibility, but that is therefore spending money promoting the constitutional monarchy. If we are going to have a fair share we should have, at the same time as we are funding Prince Charles to be flown around, one of the republican people flying around also saying how silly the constitutional monarchy is. Let us get some rationality into this debate. The fact is that we spend millions of dollars supporting the constitutional monarchy and very little money has been spent by the government or by anybody on promoting the alternative procedures.

As my friend the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) outlined, we are trying to get some framework within which we can then engage in the debate. This motion is pre-empting what might in fact be the political process that occurs. We have not started the debate yet. Sure, there have been discussions and people have expressed a couple of points of view, but we have not really got into the body of the debate about having a republic or not. When and if that debate occurs, that is the appropriate time to talk about what allocations of financial support there will be to the various causes. In every referendum in this country the yes case and the no case have had equal funding. That has always been the process in a referendum and it will be the case, I am sure, in this referendum when we get started. All honourable members opposite know that that is a requirement and that that is what will occur. The yes case will be funded and the no case will be funded equally.

But that is not what this is about. When we are going to have a referendum, we must have some basis upon which to debate it, and that is what the Republic Advisory Committee was about—setting out the options so that there can be some understanding of the issues. We do not need to understand the issues with regard to the constitutional monarchy; we have had it for 93 years. People know all about it and they know its weaknesses and its failures. But they do need to know what the issues are in addressing a republic and the concept of a republic, and that is what the government has done. The government has acted very responsibly. I think the allocation of $1.2 million over four years is a very reasonable allocation. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with a great deal of pleasure to support the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) in this motion. I must say I have been somewhat surprised by the arguments advanced by my friends on the other side of the chamber. The honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) attacked it by saying it was an absurd motion because the issue was not why but how. If that is true, all I can say is that the government has put the cart before the horse. If it is a question of how but not why, the first question that should be answered is: why change? Why do we need a change? What are the benefits? Where is the current system falling down? Where does the current system fail Australian citizens? It does not, but we have got this impression of inevitability being promoted by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and others on his side that is starting to brainwash people. The reality is that it is not inevitable, and I happen to believe that there is no way that it is going to happen.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Melbourne said we have paranoia on this side of the House. I know where the paranoia is: it is on that side of the House. It is related to 11 November 1975 when the Governor-General dismissed the Whitlam government, and the whole push for the republic stems from the Labor Party's paranoia over that issue. As I said, honourable members opposite have put the cart before the horse; they have got it all wrong. The honourable member for Melbourne said that quite logically the committee is headed by a republican. The reason why the committee is headed by a republican is that it is a matter of, `Do not confuse them with the facts, I have already made up my mind'. That is quite obvious. It is absolutely true that the committee should not be engaging in any debate promoting the republic. The honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) said that it was not engaging in any public debate promoting the republic. I say to the honourable member for Moreton that he could have fooled me. All of the publicity committee members got as they went right around Australia, at the expense of the people of Australia, was in fact promoting a republic.

I want to put another point to honourable members opposite. My good friend the honourable member for Moreton in the debate a few minutes ago spoke about fairness and equity. Honourable members on the other side are always proclaiming their fairness, their equity, their love of justice. We share that on this side, but in this instance there has been no fairness, no equity and no justice, because taxpayers' money is being used to fund one side of the debate. The reason that has been done is that part of the program of honourable members opposite is to try to convince the Australian people that a republic is inevitable. The program is, `We are not bothering about the whys or the wherefores; we are just bothering about the hows'. They say it is going to be inevitable, so that is why we have got the committee on how we are going to do it. As I said, that has put the cart well before the horse.

The honourable member for Moreton has said to wait until the public debate starts. I can assure the honourable member for Moreton and others on his side that they should wait until the debate starts, because that is when they are going to get a very rude shock. I am very disappointed that the honourable member for Moreton should say that the government is spending millions supporting the constitutional monarchy and the Governor-General. But that system is the taxpayers' own government, that is what we are. That expenditure is not supporting the argument for a constitutional monarchy, but is part of the supporting expenditure for the system of government we have right now. So I say shame on the honourable member for Moreton for advancing that specious argument.

Then he comes up with the absolute dilly that Prince Charles is coming to Australia next year, and that is going to cost hundreds of thousands of dollars. We have prominent people coming to this country all the time: did the honourable member complain about all of the money spent by his government to bring Nelson Mandela here? No, he did not. What is the difference? The honourable member is using this specious argument to suggest that because Prince Charles is coming that that is a monarchical thing.

We are already an independent country. We are building closer and closer ties with countries outside the Commonwealth. Our future is in the Asia-Pacific rim and we can pursue that equally well as a constitutional monarchy or as a republic. I do not believe the republic is going to come. Let us get away from the red herring and let us be concerned about the economy of Australia, about the kids who cannot get a job, and about the families who have not got a job. Let us be concerned about Australians and Australia first and forget the nonsense of the republic.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as the last speaker on the list to participate in the debate on the motion moved by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). Undoubtedly this will not be the last debate to occur in the House on this issue, but I might be the last speaker today to comment on funding of the Republic Advisory Committee. Certainly there will be further debate about the options and the proposals to move towards a republic as we move closer to 2001.

PARA.TAB: The Republic Advisory Committee was not designed to prepare the basic arguments for an Australian republic but to look at options for implementing a republic. As the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) pointed out, the Australian people will decide whether they want a republic and, if so, the form that it will take.

The argument that there is no balance in the funding at this stage is, I think, very flawed. The simple fact is that, after some 90 years of constitutional monarchy here in Australia, without a doubt it is a healthy thing that we do have debate, that we do have consideration of other options. The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) said that the republican debate has only surfaced since 1975. That is completely incorrect. The republican debate has been around since the talk started about implementing federation as such and about a Commonwealth. In other words, from 1880 or even earlier the forms and the nature of government have been under discussion. Obviously, with the compromise settlement which was achieved in the 1890s and the implementation of the present federation, the constitutional monarchists, if you like, won the day. But if we go back to the debates that took place then, we see that they did not win it very handsomely. They did win the debate on the day and carry the numbers, and I guess that might be what it is all about. But it is more than that, it is about implementing a constitution; about a system of government which is real and recognised not just by the rest of the world but certainly by the Australian population. The debate and the options which are available for Australia in the 21st century are what we should be looking at.

In funding the Republic Advisory Committee, the government is not funding the debate but simply looking at the options, as I mentioned. The pro-monarchy organisations can put forward options, either to keep things the same or to change things around, so that the constitutional monarchy that they might propose does reflect the needs and the wishes of Australian society as we leave the 20th century and move into the 21st century. To say that we should not tinker with or even change certain aspects of our constitution belies what a constitution is all about. If they want to run that argument, let us run out the old Magna Carta and we will stick with that and we will not go to any further amendments or changes or constitutions, whether we are talking about a constitution such as the United States has or Australia has or any other country has. It is up to the people of Australia to adopt and maintain a constitution. If they want to reject a particular one, they are quite free to do so. They can do it through a democratic process or they can do it as Colonel Rabuka in Fiji chose to do it.

There were some comments made about government funding to other organisations when honourable members on the other side took some exception to the comments of the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) with regard to the funding which goes towards trips and what a visit by somebody like Prince Charles would actually mean to Australia. Without doubt, the presence of Prince Charles will be used very strongly by Australians for Constitutional Monarchy. That is their prerogative. President Bush, the head of a republic, was here as head of a state which just happens to be a republic. He certainly was not, as far as I can see or anyone else would argue, actually pushing the pro-republican debate into the Australian society. Neither was Nelson Mandela, but he was certainly extended due courtesy as the distinguished world person that he is.
Overall, I do not think there were too many points scored through the movement of this motion by the honourable member for Dawson. (Time expired)

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Order! It being 12.30 p.m. the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 104A. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.
Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In today's grievance debate I want to draw this House's attention to the plight of the seniors community and most particularly to the problems these people have in regard to their investments. But, first of all, I want to grieve about the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and the serious trouble she is in about the allocation of sporting funds.

PARA.TAB: Late last year I helped one organisation in my own electorate with its application and, lo and behold, when the application was granted, the letter of announcement came from the Labor candidate for my seat. I wonder whether the minister can explain how that was not a blatant abuse of the sporting facilities program. More of this matter on another day. It is my fervent hope that the government will take heed of the concerns I raise today, for the problems of Australia's aged communities are very real and have been totally overlooked and ignored by this Keating Labor government and its ministers.

Let me make it clear from the outset that I am responding to the level of concern that pensioners and retired people have raised with me over the past months. I rise here today to voice the concerns and views of those people whom I represent. As some honourable members may be aware, the electorate of Cook has Labor electorates as its neighbours. Indeed, one could drive for some miles before reaching another coalition electorate. However, I warn the government and the House that this situation will definitely change at the next election.

It is not surprising that many people from outside my electorate have found it necessary to contact me in regard to the problems they are experiencing, because they have simply come up against a brick wall when they have contacted their own local member, with one notable exception. There can be no clearer example of this than the issue of pensioners' shares. The government's handling of this issue was nothing short of a disgrace. Let there be no mistake about that. This Labor government was intent on reducing pensions for elderly people just because those seniors had invested in shares. Pensioners who had managed to save a bit of money for their retirement or who had decided to take early retirement with special redundancy payments—and there are many of them—and then decided to invest that money in Australian companies by buying shares were an easy target for this government. Let us not forget that fact.

This Labor government thought it was a good idea to rob pensioners of their main source of income. Only the sensible opposition to this move from the coalition and others prevented many pensioners from being caught in this net. Unfortunately, those pensioners who purchased shares after August 1992 are still subject to this iniquitous legislation which the coalition continues to oppose. So it is not surprising that my office was inundated with calls and letters from seniors regarding this particular issue. Pensioners who had received no assistance from their local Labor member were forced to contact my office to protest about the government's decision. Members of the government should hang their heads in shame, but I think we all know that they will not.

It is a sad state of affairs when the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) refuses to go on talkback radio to explain the government's legislation and to receive calls from pensioners. However, this should come as no surprise as the minister would not even face the parliament over the issue. He simply handed the baton to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) and washed his hands of the plight of pensioners.

The behaviour of the Minister for Social Security is characteristic of the government's attitude to the seniors community in Australia. This government has abandoned the concerns of elderly people, particularly those who have some form of investment. The seniors community is angry and frustrated that this government expects it to cope with enough changes to legislation to confuse most people in the accounting profession.

Pensioners are left waiting on the telephone for long periods, trying to get some explanation from the authorities for a reduction in, or indeed cancellation of, their pensions. There is no forewarning that their entitlements are to be affected. Pensioners have little recourse except to contact their local member when they feel they have been harshly treated. In Sydney, I can assure honourable members, many members of the government will not talk to their constituents on these matters.

The combined effect of these circumstances is causing great confusion amongst pensioners and retired people alike. The current issue of pensioners who hold managed investments is also of great concern to many pensioners and urgently needs to be addressed by the government. Presently, it is not uncommon for pensioners to find that their pension has been cancelled or severely reduced because the Department of Social Security has deemed a high rate of return on investments. However, the way in which the department and the fund managers assess the investments differs markedly.

Since March of this year the capital growth component of managed investments has been counted as income under the pension incomes test, though this bears no relation to the actual return to the pensioner. This is a similar situation to the way the government had shamefully attempted to treat increases in share values. Many pensioners feel rightly aggrieved that their investments are treated in this manner and clearly this is a real and significant problem which needs to be addressed.

It is not only the mechanism of the legislation which is wrong; it is the underlying principle behind the government's intention which is manifestly unfair. I find great difficulty in accepting that capital growth can be classed as income when the pensioner is not in receipt of that increase. Many pensioners hold a similar view and also raise the double effect of capital gains tax when the investment is actually realised.

The government cannot have it both ways. It is patently unfair to reduce a pension on the basis that the investment has appreciated and to class that increase as income, and then to tax that increase as a capital gain when the pensioner redeems the investment. That is double taxation, and very many seniors have raised this issue with me.

What needs to be remembered in the complete process of assessment of investments for pensioners is that this sector of the community should be afforded dignity. Many pensioner recipients have served in armed forces during several wars, most pensioners have lived through a depression—and are we not all living through one now?—most pensioners have contributed much to the development of this country and most pensioners have paid their fair share of taxes in their lifetime. I do not think, therefore, that it is unreasonable to grant them the degree of respect and courtesy which should be afforded them at this stage in their lives. Sadly, the government's legislation has created the opposite effect.

Consider the fact that a 91-year-old gentleman has to contact me, his local member, to get information about the constant changes to the way his small investments are being treated. One really has to wonder about the government's intentions. Sadly, this is what has actually happened in my electorate and is happening every single day. This is not an isolated case and this government has created such a confusing maze of regulations which are constantly changing that many pensioners simply do not know where they stand—and who can blame them?

When it is the hallmark of this government to ram through legislation via the guillotine, to stifle democratic debate, then it is no wonder that such a process will lead to general confusion in the seniors community. In all of my dealings with seniors who have investments it is evident that they place high priority on security in their retirement, though at present there is no such certainty. I implore the government, through the Minister for Social Security, to give them urgent consideration, for it is evident that the pensioner community is denied assurance that the rules will not change periodically.

The coalition has steadfastly argued that the legislation relating to the treatment of shares as income should be totally repealed and that there should be a full-scale inquiry into the assets and incomes test for pensioners. This has been our position for a long time, and it was only when the Labor government was faced with the resolution of the Senate that it proceeded to set up the current inquiry.

I note that the report of this committee is not scheduled to be released until September 1994. It is imperative that this committee conducts thorough investigations into the problem of pensioner investments. Along with many pensioners in the community, I look forward to reading the findings of that review process. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Swan Mr W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now widely accepted that our national prospects for economic growth and job creation are largely dependent on increasing our level of trade with Asia. Our chances of success will depend heavily on becoming more enmeshed with the region across a wide range of cultural and community activities. Our aim should be to increase mutual understanding and interchange with Asia. In particular, proficiency in Asian languages and knowledge of Asian cultures are the key to increasing mutual understanding as well as to creating the jobs of the future.

PARA.TAB: Whether we are talking about tourism or building exports in specialist Asian markets for our small manufacturing enterprises, knowledge of foreign languages is every bit as critical as proficiency in maths and English. For example, by the year 2000, 40 per cent of our jobs generated by international tourism will come from east Asian tourism. In that year, according to projections from the National Centre for Studies in Tourism, 571,000 Australians will be employed in domestic and international tourism. We can project that of those, 260,000 will flow from international tourism directly and of those 260,000, 103,000 jobs will come directly from east Asian tourism.

In the year 2010, based on the centre's projections, 895,000 Australians will be employed in tourism, and 203,000 jobs will come directly from east Asian tourism. In this context the recent recommendations of the caucus task force should be widely discussed and debated.

The recommendations of the caucus employment task force were, firstly, that all arms of government should be required to develop programs for engagement with Asia and, secondly, that Australia should attach the highest priority to the adoption and implementation of a long-term strategy to ensure that the Australian work force of the future is equipped with language skills and associated skills of cultural awareness of direct relevance to our national economic interest. This will mean targeting the principal languages of Asia.

Whether we are talking about jobs created in tourism or jobs created in manufacturing industry, which is getting exports into Asia, proficiency in languages is about employment across a wide range of occupations including the professions. Unfortunately, some in our community see foreign language education as being all too frequently necessary to allow Australians to `serve the drinks' rather than creating a range of jobs in management, accounting, computing, metalwork and communications.

The reality is that proficiency in languages will create jobs and occupations other than service occupations. Creating jobs in the tourist industry or selling computer equipment to Asia is not like selling iron ore to Japan or wheat to China. Things have changed dramatically. If we are going to create jobs in the tourist industry or in manufacturing exports it also requires a sophisticated cultural understanding because selling computers and running tourist resorts means that our work force has to have a sophisticated understanding of people-to-people contact. It is not like it was many years ago when we were selling those bulk commodities. At that time we did not require that sophisticated understanding of people to people contact, and to have that understanding we do require proficiency in foreign languages. But we not only require proficiency in foreign languages; we also require an understanding of cultures, particularly Asian cultures.

It is for that reason a comprehensive national language program in the early years of schooling is absolutely essential to our success as a sophisticated trading nation in Asia. I am pleased to report that in Queensland such a program is taking place. It is important that that program be extended nationally and that our national government takes up the challenge of bringing forth a national language program in the early years of schooling.

Accessing the markets of east Asia presents significant challenges for our Australian exporters. There are linguistic and cultural barriers facing Australian firms exporting to and investing in Asia. They are significant. There is a growing body of expert opinion which suggests that English is not the language of business in north Asia and South-East Asia. The economies of the region are becoming increasingly interdependent, generating their own sources of economic growth and correspondingly less dependent on trade outside the region. In these circumstances it is the languages of the region which are becoming the primary means of communication for business. As Dr Stephen FitzGerald has recently noted:

SPEECH.PARA: Between China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and the overseas Chinese, the world of finance and commerce within the Asian region is driven by the Chinese, in total about 1.2 billion people.

An inability by Australian exporters to Asia to conduct businesses in languages and understand the societies of the region will be a significant constraint on doing business in these markets. As Ross Garnaut has argued:
Australia's long-term success in getting the most out of its relationship with Asia depends more than anything else on the scale and quality of its investment in education.

The scale and quality of our investment in education means a large and continuing investment in foreign language education. To this end, Garnaut has recommended that a substantial number of Australians should achieve mastery of priority Asian languages, economics, politics and other attributes of their cultures. An understanding of the languages and operations of Asian societies will be essential if Australian businesses are to compete on an even or better footing than their competitors in the region. Overcoming many of these non-tariff barriers that exist in Asia is particularly important to the export of elaborately transformed manufactures and services and will require an understanding of Asian languages.

PARA.TAB: By the nature of the products, the successful marketing of elaborately transformed manufactures requires greater awareness of the operations of the market being targeted than is the case, as I said before, for the export of primary products such as wheat or iron ore. Similarly, trade in services is highly people to people intensive requiring in-depth knowledge of the language and the society of the customer.

The recent McKinsey report for the Australian Manufacturing Council entitled Emerging exporters provides a number of recommendations to enhance the competitive advantage of Australian industries. One of those recommendations is the need to improve market information and representation to facilitate local networking and joint ventures between local manufacturers and potential overseas partners. For east Asian markets, linguistic skills and cultural knowledge will be absolutely essential if Australian exporters are to obtain the required level of market information and penetration.

Against this background, it is critical that the Australian government attach the highest priority to the adoption and implementation of a long-term strategy to ensure that the Australian work force of the future is equipped with language skills, and associated skills of cultural awareness, of direct relevance to our national economic interests. Specifically, this will mean targeting the principal languages of east Asia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I grieve today for the future of our country. Our future is not with the machinations of this place but rather in the sandpits and on the swings in playgrounds around Australia as I speak. The future of our great nation is our children and we, as the caretakers of their future, should take extreme interest in their welfare for they will determine how our nation will operate in future decades.

PARA.TAB: Our children require us to provide them with a future which will allow them to develop and to nurture their own children; this is the way of our community. I noted with interest the impassioned declaration of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last Tuesday in question time when he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I will always be looking after the welfare of my children.
It was a fatherly declaration that many in the community would agree with and the general agreement within the community is that we should accept that responsibility and challenge.

PARA.TAB: The issue of child care is an important one and is of ongoing concern to many families living in the electorate of Cowan. It is growing in importance for two reasons. Firstly, with more parents entering the work force, as they have to these days, it becomes crucial that they are not confronted with barriers in providing adequate child care. Secondly, as more families choose to use child-care facilities, greater emphasis is being placed on the provision for sound and appropriate care which will enhance the children's development.

For instance, in Cowan there are some 12,000 children and one in 10 of the population is under five years of age. I must say that I share the concerns of these children's parents about adequate and proper child care, for my own children Anthony and Kaitlyn are aged under five. So this concern can be with anybody and everybody.

Cowan is named after Dame Edith Cowan, the first woman to enter any Australian parliament. She was renown for her efforts to ensure social justice and coincidentally fought for the establishment of day nurseries. How ironic that, some 60 years later, we are still to address this issue adequately, as I would like to address some of the problems experienced by child-care providers in Cowan.

My work in the child-care area has been supported by Lynette Kooperman of the Moolanda child-care centre and Tracey Pearse of the Girrawheen child-care centre. Both of these professionals are coping with the important role they play within the community.

However, both clearly agree without hesitation that an immediate review of the provision for funding in this very important area is required. The most dramatic effect that the issue of funding has on child care is the unacceptably large waiting lists which presently exist within many centres within Cowan, as I am sure they do in other electorates.

Other issues of importance surrounding child-care centres are the national accreditation system, the need to provide for children with special needs, and the need to extend the sales tax exemption to four-year-old family centres in Western Australia. To highlight the need to rethink the government's current policy on child care, I draw on the experiences of the two child-care centres I have previously identified. The Moolanda Community Centre in Kingsley is a community based child-care centre built in 1986 to provide care for 45 children. Recently it was given approval to increase the number of child-care positions to 48.

As a result of the centre being purpose-built, it is unable to cope with the ever-increasing demand from the community within the local area. It is funded by the Commonwealth and with some income coming from the parents. The Moolanda child-care centre, which is only seven years old, is now experiencing huge demand and, although it has closed registrations for 1994, it has a waiting list of over 60 children. The paradox of this problem is that a new child-care centre which is due to open in a few weeks was built some two blocks away to relieve the demand, but already it has a waiting list for 1994 of 40. The big problem, of course, does not end there, because I am advised that this centre receives 10 to 15 inquiries every week for child-care places: an enormous figure, and one which must be of concern to all within the child-care industry.

When Lynette Kooperman was asked how she would describe the current waiting list, she said enormous. I would think enormous would be an understatement. Perhaps troubling would be a better description—or, even better, disastrous—for the people of Kingsley wanting child care for next year. It is an absolute tragedy for parents of children within this district to be worried about their future because of the inadequate provision of child-care facilities. When we review the operation of the Girrawheen centre, in a lower socioeconomic area than Kingsley, we begin to see more clearly the enormity of the child-care problem within Cowan. This centre provides child-care facilities for families in one of Perth's most financially and socially depressed areas.

Not only are the families of Cowan asked to bear the brunt of the current high employment rates, which are as high as one in 10, but the families of Girrawheen are exposed to more crime, have higher rates of family breakdown, and now face the dilemma of shortage of child-care facilities. The Girrawheen centre is sponsored by the Sisters of Mercy and is presently licensed to carry 61 children per day. It has recently received Lotteries Commission funding to care for young babies. At times, they have waiting lists of up to 50 per cent.

The dilemma the centre is faced with is the ever-increasing demand for places for two-year-olds, a demand which will crowd out the system in future years. The staff advised me that not only are they under pressure to supply the increasing child-care needs of the community, but they are also asked to address the special needs of families. This centre has an increasing demand for respite care for families who are finding the current economic climate difficult to cope with when coupled with normal family duties.

It has been suggested to me that when staff are confronted with stressed parents wanting respite from their parental responsibilities, for whatever reason, then child-care providers find it difficult and unprofessional to refuse, and thus they accommodate the request. This places enormous strains, as one could imagine, on resources. Working and studying parents are given priority when it comes to child care and, although this may appear reasonable on the surface, it does not address the needs of the stressed parents within the community. In high risk child abuse areas, where unemployment and the associated stresses are magnified, the children of parents in desperate need are placed on a third or fourth priority for child care.

This issues needs addressing urgently. We cannot continue as a successful community to place our children—our future—at ongoing risk of neglect through inadequate child-care facilities. Clearly, the demands for child care require urgent attention and action, with the need to address the changing demands of communities, which may change from virtually one year to the next. The excellent work being provided by our child-carers within the 32 centres within Cowan should not be treated without the respect the industry deserves. We should place a higher priority on the need to continually review the system of child care. The work of Tracey Pearse and Lynette Kooperman should not be undermined by the lack of concern for the pressures they presently face.

The record of child care under this government continues to challenge the myths associated with the Labor Party. We are beginning to see that the myths about this party are nowhere near the reality. Under Labor, child-care fees have doubled over the last eight years. The government has failed to ensure that adequate child-care facilities are evenly distributed over the community to allow all Australians equal access to child care. The government insists on the paradox that child care should be subsidised for those that can readily afford it. The government continues to ignore children who are cared for at home. Child care is an issue that should be the concern of all Australians who care about the future and, therefore, our nation's children.

The coalition has shown through its policies over the years that child care is a high priority as it is at the base of the family unit. The coalition policy includes: a commitment to increase the availability of child-care places; a commitment to generous fee relief for those families that are in greatest need; a commitment to increasing funding for the care of children with disabilities or with special needs; a commitment to a voluntary national child-care accreditation system, a system that allows parents to choose the child care that will best suit their children.

Like the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—as he suggested the other day—I love my children, as I am sure every parent does. I will continue to work to ensure that their welfare is secure but I will go further by stating the commitment I am prepared to make. Without fear of reprisal, I pledge to the parents of the electorate of Cowan, who also wish to ensure the welfare of their children, that I will take steps in this place and within the electorate to improve the standard of child care by raising the need to increase child-care places and to support those within the industry in Cowan by bringing their concerns to the parliament of Australia. I say to all Cowan residents: our children need us; let us not repay their faith in us by losing our way for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recently held discussions with a business person in Geelong to receive an update on the progress of commercialisation of an innovative product that he had developed. It is one that I mentioned in my maiden speech: an oil immersed disc braking system which has been developed by a small Geelong firm called Gearing Dynamics.

PARA.TAB: The gentleman recounted a recent trip he had undertaken to Melbourne along the Princes Highway and observations he had made about the visible histories of unstable braking events that adorned that particular stretch of highway. The observation he made about these tyre skid histories on the road concerned the high proportion of what he called `single event happenings', that is, where the front wheel of the vehicle had locked and the car was caused to swerve and the stopping distance greatly extended.

I was particularly interested in his comments, as I have a 16-year-old daughter who recently expressed an interest in saving to purchase a motorbike as her preferred means of transport. I was keenly interested in the safety issues that would be canvassed by the situation that this gentleman had described.

He made a very perceptive statement and posed a very interesting question. In the last 40 years we have seen a staggering increase in the service life of engines and transmissions in motor vehicles, so why has there not been a corresponding improvement in the service life of the braking equipment, given that brakes represent, arguably, the most important safety device on a motor vehicle?

One important consequence of the improved performance of engines and transmissions is that, not only are motor vehicles used more often, they are less likely to be in the hands of skilled motor mechanics who would be likely to detect braking system wear and impairment. On reflection, one can only conclude that all motor vehicle drive train components, including the braking system, ought to have a whole of life service expectancy. In addition, they should not be the pollutive systems that they currently are. It is this latter aspect, the pollutive nature of current braking systems and technology, that I would like to comment on in this debate.

As honourable members would know, an important brake pad composite used in the past and indeed today is asbestos. It has been and is used primarily because it is cheaper than other composite materials. There are three types of asbestos. In layman's terms, they are white, blue and brown. Asbestos is widely known as a carcinogen and it was widely accepted in medical circles that blue asbestos caused mesothelioma, a fatal cancer of the chest or the abdominal wall. However, a study in recent years by the National Institute of Occupational Health and Safety has documented for the first time white asbestos as a cause of mesothelioma.

White asbestos is used as an important brake pad composite material and up to 10,000 tonnes are used each year in Australian industry, including the braking industry. The automotive industry has accepted the need to phase out the use of asbestos as a brake pad composite. Non-asbestos pads are now fitted to the current output of the industry. But there are still thousands upon thousands of vehicles on our roads today, especially in our cities, spewing into the air a fine, black dust residue containing asbestos fibre, which is being ingested by many Australians in urban areas.

What is worse is that there are many newer cars, originally fitted with non-asbestos pads, that, when put in for the fitment of replacement brake pads, are being fitted with cheap asbestos pad imports. The sad and disturbing fact about the situation is that currently there are no controls over products used in the brake replacement and fitment industry. Consequently, there has been a flood of cheap asbestos pad imports to this country from Malaysia, India and Spain. Not only does it threaten the livelihoods of those currently employed in Australia in the production of non-asbestos pads—the environmentally friendly pads, I guess you could say, in a relative sense at least—but this situation poses a long-term health hazard to Australians generally. While the major car manufacturers have been phasing out the use of asbestos pads in line with European and American conventions, the whole process appears to be undermined by the extensive use of asbestos pad imports in the brake replacement industry.

There are several possible solutions to the problem we face in the use of asbestos in braking systems. The government can regulate its use in the industry by banning it completely, it can ban the importation of cheap asbestos based replacement products for use in the braking industry, or it can tax the substance out of use, as it intends to do with lead in petrol. The other alternative, I guess, is to let the market decide by exerting its preference for a braking technology that effectively addresses the service life issue, the safety issue and the pollution issue.

I am pleased to say that that technology exists, and it has been developed in Geelong in my electorate by a very small innovative firm. The eternal argument about the use of asbestos or even non-asbestos materials as brake composites is now simply dated with the development of a new braking technology by this small Geelong firm. The totally sealed, oil immersed braking system, called SROID, that has been developed is not only pollution free but under test conditions displays inherently better stability and balance characteristics than existing conventional systems.

The question now is not really whether improved braking systems such as SROID ought to be universally adopted. The real question is how long we as a community are going to be prepared to tolerate the continued use of carcinogenic materials in a dated technology which poses a serious health risk to Australians living in urban areas. The development of this new automotive technology demonstrates once again that we are indeed an inventive and clever society in one sense, but the way we permit the continued use of materials that have great potential to cause public health harm and risk betrays what I would term a splendid stupidity in another sense.

The moves against the use of asbestos are fairly well developed in the United States. In the United Kingdom we see the great insurance company, Lloyds of London, reeling under actions that have been brought regarding the use of asbestos related products. I wonder how long it is going to take Australians to come to a similar conclusion about how dangerous this substance is. I wonder how long it is going to be before the environmental movement in this country pays some real attention to this new revolutionary technology, which not only has an application in the mining industry and in industry generally but has automotive applications as well. I wonder how long it is going to be before governments look seriously at the public health risks that are caused by the use of what are now outdated braking technologies. I hope that it will not be too long.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are very few opportunities for private members to express their views on matters of concern and I am pleased that we have the grievance debate in the parliament for this purpose. Today I wish to refer to an issue that I have been worried about for a very long time and that is violence, particularly in the video, television and film industries. The debate in this area is a never ending story. On the one hand, there are people who say that in any civilised society people should be able to read and see what they want. On the other hand, it is certainly not too much to ask for reasonable standards that do not undermine what is taught by families and schools; standards that do not peddle physical and sexual violence to our impressionable young people and others.

PARA.TAB: It is a simple fact of life that violence pours into homes across our nation. The mass media and entertainment industries see to that. My office, over the eight months since the last election, has been inundated with complaints about violence and pornography. Concerned constituents ring up constantly, and many of these complaints refer to television violence and to news services. Some of the horrible events in places such as Bosnia-Herzegovina and Somalia are shown in graphic detail across our television screens at early time slots when children could be watching.

Complaints also refer to videos and violence. In recent times we have actually had some people contact us expressing concerns about some violent computer programs. I am certain that honourable members on both sides of the House would have experienced similar complaints from people across our nation.

Recently, the head of the Australian Council for Children's Film and Television, Barbara Biggins, made comment on the impact that acts of violence portrayed on television have on the behaviour of some young children. As we all know, television, films and videos are powerful teachers, particularly for young children aged up to 11. United States research has found that media violence should be regarded as a public health problem.

Giving evidence to the federal parliamentary inquiry into violence in schools, the Children's Film Council president urged the inquiry to consider the role of mass media violence and its contribution to violence in schools, and urged government, media and broadcasters to unite in their responsibility to ensure healthy viewing for Australia's youth. I certainly support this aim and I would like to place that on record.

We open our newspapers and we read about serial killers. Unfortunately, many people have got the ideas for what they do from film violence, television violence and video violence. Our society, like other societies throughout the world, is a complex structure and it is difficult to study any single institution or social process in isolation. However, research has often shown a direct correlation between media violence and gross antisocial acts. This has been looked at from time to time but, to my knowledge, no satisfactory solution has yet been implemented. Serial killer Ted Bundy warned before his execution that the media had played a role in the development of his sociopathic behaviour.

Treating the media and entertainment industry as scapegoats, as the causes of never-ending social troubles, will get us nowhere. Violence has always existed; however, it has not always been beamed into homes across the nation. It has not always been beamed into the lounge rooms of Australia. It has not always been flaunted before the eyes of young children. Something has to be done about it.

I suggest that, sadly, more violence is now portrayed in videos, films and computer programs. Some social engineers say that this reflects the current nature of our society. That is an incorrect statement. People across the social and political spectrums share my concern in this area.

Purveyors of violence surely have a responsibility to the Australian public. Governments have a responsibility to the Australian public, as does the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The Film Censorship Board should also not be exempt from scrutiny. It is a cop-out to say that in a democracy we should be able to read and see what we want. Even if one held that view, what about our young people?

How can we protect our society? As I said earlier, I am inundated with phone calls from constituents complaining about the present situation in television, video and films. Violence and pornography are a major public concern. Frightening scenes for young children, such as those in Jurassic Park, have become the norm, and violence has become an everyday event. People cannot turn on their television without seeing violence. It is not easy to go to the video shop and hire a suitable video for children and we have to be very careful when buying computer programs if violence is to be avoided. Violence has been interwoven into every aspect of the media and entertainment industry.

The popularity of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles brought with it street fighting, increasing the incidence of schoolyard altercations. Standards continue to plummet. Violent TV programs are unfortunately advertised in early timeslots. Violent cartoons, where the main character or hero is the star thug, have raised concerns among parents. As everyone knows and accepts, these are major adverse influences on our children.

It can be argued that parents are primarily responsible for censorship in their own home. This is so, but it is becoming more and more difficult for parents to see what their children choose to watch. How do we balance parental and broadcasting responsibility? Modern technologies such as pay TV will make the position even more difficult for parents who are very careful about what their children see.

More and more families under Labor's recession have been forced into a situation where both parents have to go to work full time. It follows that latchkey children, old enough to care for themselves each afternoon after school, spend much of their time as couch potatoes in front of television or watching a video or playing a computer. It is a fact of life. It happens right across Australia. It is very difficult for parents, even those who are particularly concerned about their children's future, to monitor just what their children are doing at that time.

The wider Australian public is increasingly worried about violence. An Australian Broadcasting Tribunal report to the minister in 1990 formulated 13 recommendations. It found that violence occurred across a wide range of programs shown in Australia, including news and current affairs, cartoons, advertisements and fictional drama. The main thrust of the recommendations was to improve the public's knowledge of industry rules and regulations and to develop an industry-wide self-regulatory code on the presentation of violence. These codes certainly have their place in society but, in an industry which survives on ratings, is self-regulation an appropriate protection?

There is certainly confusion in the community about this. There is certainly confusion in the Fisher electorate regarding this issue of classifications for television and video. Many people still cannot understand—and I must say that I am one of them—why a violent film such as Silence of the Lambs, a film which shows cannibalism, received only an M rating. Violence has become a feature of television and video and is a problem deserving serious consideration. Violent computer programs must also be looked at very carefully.

The present situation is clearly unsatisfactory and must be addressed. It is totally unacceptable for the community to be subjected to violence on TV, videos and in computer programs. It is not good enough for people to be able to say that citizens should be able to see what they want because any civilised society must have standards which reflect its community values. As the father of two young children I share the concerns of my constituents and I think that we, in a non-partisan way, should be able to look at this major problem. I ask the government to reconsider this major problem confronting our nation. Society demands it and let us hope that something happens sooner rather than later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over recent days honourable members may have read something of the piracy activity that is occurring to the north of Australia. They may have read of the vessel Erria Inge which was taken illegally from Bombay in March 1991. It was allegedly pirated by two Singapore businessmen. I would like to commend the journalist who wrote all the material, Matthew Russell of the Sydney Morning Herald. I think we are going to hear a lot more about that.

PARA.TAB: I mention that only because it points to a major problem to the north of Australia that has been developing over recent years and that constitutes my grievance today. That grievance is the growing prevalence of piracy on the high seas and the failure of government to suppress its development. Most people think of the skull and crossbones when piracy on the high seas is mentioned. However, piracy in modern terms is the holding up of ships, the boarding of ships, the throwing aboard of Molotov cocktails to slow the vessel down, the use of fast boats that are low in the water and difficult to detect by radar, the holding up of the crew, the robbing of the safe, the injuring of the crew, and in some cases the murder of the crew members.

Probably the most important thing arising out of this, after injury and loss of life of crew members, is the danger to safe navigation of the ships concerned. What we are seeing today are modern bandits at sea. Of major importance is that danger being created for safe navigation. The nature and the seriousness of the attacks have grown over recent years. Back in the 1980s when we heard of piracy at sea to the north of us—it is mainly in Asian waters that I am referring to—the ships were attacked by assailants carrying knives or swords, not explosive weapons. In some cases they were even unarmed and what they were about was petty theft or getting cash.

However, in 1991 the use of hand guns began to become common, as did violence against crew members. By August 1991 the chief officer of a ship was shot and killed just eight kilometres out of Singapore Harbour. In April 1992 an oil tanker was attacked four hours out of Singapore, the one I referred to a moment ago. It was attacked by people from three fast boats. They threw molotov cocktails on board the vessel to slow it down. When the ship slowed down they forced the crew on deck and forced them out while they were fighting the fires on board. Subsequently a child and two crew members were injured in the confrontation. In December 1992 the master and chief officer of the Boltimar Zephyr were killed.

The instances of attacks in the Malacca Straits, the straits between Indonesia and Malaysia and down to the Singapore Straits, whilst they have subsided over recent months, were of growing prevalence and were of growing concern. But the actions of the Indonesian and Malaysian governments have resulted in some 40 persons being arrested.

In this case we ask, `Who are these people?'. The major information that comes to me—obviously from sources I cannot disclose—is that the behaviour of these people on board ships indicates that they are well trained, well disciplined people who know how ships are operated and know how to handle weapons. Most people thought they were off-duty defence personnel. I am told that some 40 of those people were shot and that the level of incidents has considerably subsided over recent months.

The action is moving more to the South China Sea now, into the Philippine Sea. So far this year 25 Russian ships have been attacked in the South China Sea. Quite a number of those vessels have been attacked in Chinese waters, and again there is an indication that the vessels concerned could be vessels operating out of Chinese waters. We do not know what origin; they are well equipped vessels that are carrying out the attacks. But there is a grave danger in all of this to safe ship operation. A vessel can be out of control while it is under attack; there can be nobody on the bridge. There is the case of the Nagasaki Spirit in the Malacca Straits in 1992 that was rammed by a container vessel. The tanker was full of fuel, it burst into flames and the crews of both vessels were incinerated. There is nobody left to explain what happened, but it is believed that one of the vessels was under pirate attack at the time of the collision. That is a very clear indication of what can happen.

People may ask, `Why should Australia be concerned about this? What is the interest of this to Australia?'. There is a grave interest for Australia because these activities are taking place across Australia's major trade routes. The fact is that five Australian ships have been attacked by pirates in the past 10 years. It is very hard to get the names of the vessels because there is a reluctance to disclose that a vessel was attacked. That may relate to insurance reasons; it may relate to reliability of service or whatever the reason, but it is difficult to get the names of the vessels. ANL had a piracy report on its Anro Australia, when it was attacked in June 1986 off Singapore by four male pirates. On that occasion, again the lesser kind of activity, the captain awoke to find a knife at his throat at four in the morning, and he was robbed of $2,000 and his personal possessions.

The piracy that is taking place is across our major trade routes. The International Maritime Organisation, IMO, has been advised of some 440 acts of piracy and armed robbery over the past 10 years. However, many acts of piracy go unreported, for the reasons I have referred to earlier, so the actual level of attack that is occurring is unknown. The IMO formed a seven-member working party, which included Australia, in January of this year, and obviously the activities of that group were associated with the actions of the Indonesian government and the Malaysian government in curbing the level of piracy attack in the Malaccan Straits.

I have referred to the danger to safe navigation and I pointed to what could have happened. There is another cost, the cost of delays of ships that may be the subject of pirate attack. There is the cost of inspection; there is the cost of investigation. An average ship costs something like $25,000 a day to run. So there is a cost to transport.
