There is also the interruption to transport schedules.

People might ask, `Who should protect them?'. On the high seas no country has jurisdiction, but the ship should be able to look to its flag state. So under law the responsibility would be with the country in which that ship is registered. It is interesting that a number of these attacks are occurring with the vessels registered in the flag of convenience countries, because obviously the bandits sorted out that they are not likely to have the resources to be sending their navies to the high seas to protect ships wearing their flags. So that again makes the acts of piracy much easier. It is clear that there is an interconnection with highly organised criminal activity. There is evidence of selective opening of containers or holds with high value cargoes, implying prior knowledge of the cargo manifest.

There is evidence that they know what the ship schedules are and when the ships are moving. The attackers have demonstrated knowledge of the ship's procedures, seeking to board when the bridge and engine room personnel are fully engaged in navigating through congested or restricted waters. The smaller crew numbers on ships have made it easier for pirates to attack ships. So, if we look to what can be done about this and who should be doing something about it, I said that the nation responsible should assist its ship: if it is wearing an Australian flag, it is the Australian government; if it is a Honduras flag, it is the Honduran government. What we could be doing is trying to better schedule our naval activities in those areas of pirate activity where Australian ships are likely to be endangered, and doing that in collaboration with the other nations in the area. That way we can get a better result to try and stem this disruption, the dangers, the loss of life that is being caused and the risk to safe navigation.

So I would like to see the Australian government, in response to my grievance today, taking more action in association with our neighbours to the north in coordinating the activities of the naval services to try to better protect Australian ships. In the process of doing that, the other nations that are involved will be protecting ships of other flags. In that way we can try to stem the growth in this horrendous activity, put an end to the loss of life and ensure that we have safe navigation and no more repetitions of the Nagasaki Spirit disaster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I grieve this afternoon at the way in which the High Court is moving to extend its powers and influence and to usurp the law-making functions of this parliament. Over recent years the High Court has made a number of decisions which have significantly altered the balance of power in our federation and changed the fundamental fabric of our society. The High Court has wrought change which would never have been approved by this parliament or by the Australian people in referendum. It is time that the parliament and the people re-asserted their right to make the laws of Australia and rejected any handover or subjugation of this responsibility to the High Court or international treaties.

PARA.TAB: The High Court was established under chapter 3 of the Australian constitution. Its powers, responsibilities and functions are prescribed in 10 of the 128 clauses of our constitution. Those powers do not include any right to make laws. Clause 51 of the constitution clearly `vests the powers to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth' in the parliament. Subsequent clauses detail how laws are made and they do not refer to the High Court at all. Indeed, parliament is given power to prescribe much of the detail of the way in which the High Court functions, not the opposite. The High Court is therefore threatening the democratic balances and processes of government in Australia when it pursues an activist role in public policy areas.

Many Australians are concerned that the High Court now seems to regard itself as having the right to extend or perhaps even change the meaning and intent of the constitution rather than just interpret what the people have put in place. The Franklin dam decision permanently altered the balance of powers between the federal and state governments in a manner that was clearly not in keeping with the intentions of the founding fathers. In the Mabo decision the High Court invented a new form of land title and gave recognition to an alternative system of law for some Australians. In the election electronic advertising case the court decided that the constitution implied a right of freedom of speech, even though it makes no reference to the subject.

In each of these instances the High Court could have decided the matter using existing law and precedents. However, with its pioneering attitude, the court seems to be searching for an excuse to invent new law. These decisions have not been based on a judgment of constitutional provisions but have been strongly influenced by the judges' assessment of what they think social policy should be.

The written Mabo judgments include outrageously emotive statements which, at best, must be regarded as personal opinions and which many qualified observers would see as objectionable. Two of the judges, Sir William Deane and Justice Mary Gaudron, acknowledged that they had been assisted in their judgments by:

SPEECH.PARA: ...the researches of the many scholars who have written in the areas into which this judgement has necessarily ventured.

So, in reaching a decision which has fundamentally changed the future of land management in Australia, the judges selectively accepted the work of some unnamed scholars, even though their work was not subject to scrutiny or cross-examination during the hearing process.

PARA.TAB: No less a figure than the former Queensland Chief Justice and State Governor, Sir Walter Campbell, raised concerns on this issue recently when he suggested that the court had reached its conclusions in the Mabo decision:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . through want of care because of the absence of representation and argument by all interested parties and also because of the lack of evidence as to the facts of the Australian mainland occupants.
In the same vein, Sir Walter places the blame on the High Court for the increased power of the Canberra government:

It has become clear that the drift to centralism of earlier years has now become quite a flood . . . potentially the Commonwealth can invade any field of governmental activity, and it has invaded many, producing a cumbersome and expensive duplication of bureaucracy.

The former Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs, said recently, `The High Court's often controversial interpretation of the constitution had left the states with no legal autonomy to defeat Commonwealth legislation or raise the money to exercise their own powers'.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps even more alarming were the comments of one of the High Court judges in a public address following the election electronic advertising decision, when he suggested that the High Court could give the Australian people a bill of rights, even though this concept had been rejected by the Australian people. Is it any wonder that many Australians are concerned about the balance of our democratic system when one of our High Court judges apparently holds the view that not only does the High Court have the right to make new laws, but also it can introduce laws that the people and the parliament have clearly demonstrated that they do not want.

The High Court cannot be placed above the democratic process. We cannot have a new group of unaccountable, unelected law makers in our country. Judges are qualified in the law. Indeed, High Court judges should be the best qualified people in the law and those best able to interpret the intent and meaning of the constitution and laws of the land. However, they have no special skills in assessing public opinion and social policy, and so they are ill equipped to make judgments based on such issues.

Indeed, High Court judges are not even typically representative of the population. By law they must have been solicitors or barristers and a judge of another court before being eligible to be appointed to the High Court. They enjoy incomes well above the national average, work in grand offices, fly first class between the various capital cities, meet and talk mainly with other lawyers and professionals and enjoy a lifestyle in keeping with their status. They have, therefore, no special understanding of the views, attitudes and aspirations of ordinary Australians.

The quality of their work is subject to little critical assessment. They are appointed until they turn 70 and can only be dismissed in the most extraordinary of circumstances. If the people are unhappy with their judgments, they cannot be voted out at the next election. There is no practical opportunity for the people to say, `No, you have got it wrong'. The parliament and the taxpayers are left to pick up the pieces after their latest whim.

The High Court is, of course, the highest court of the land, so when it makes a shock decision there is no opportunity to appeal. To go to the court again would be a classic case of appealing Caesar to Caesar. If the court comes up with an illogical surprise in a judgment that affects people who are not parties to the case at hand, there is no opportunity for them to put alternatives to influence the decision.

If it was intended to have a law-making, trailblazing High Court, we should never have got rid of appeals to the Privy Council. There clearly needs to be some review process for judge-made law. If the Australian High Court adopts the American tendencies of making judgments which take into account their assessments of what public opinion may be on a particular issue, it will expose the court to increasing political scrutiny and public criticism. I have no doubt that the Labor government is seeking to use the High Court to introduce social and constitutional change in Australia which it knows would never be approved by the Australian people in referendum and which it does not have the courage to put before the parliament.

High Court justices are appointed by the government of the day and so naturally the majority of the current High Court bench has been appointed by Labor. Recent comments by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and others about the gender and ethnic background of the judiciary highlight Labor's intention to appoint judges who meet a social engineering test rather than the best available jurists.

It is completely unacceptable for a government to seek to make social changes through the courts rather than the democratic parliamentary process. If matters other than the law are to be paramount in High Court decisions, the parliament and the public have a right to demand a much more critical scrutiny of the political and social views of potential High Court appointees. Instead, it would be far better to restore the balance of powers as intended in our constitution, with the parliament making the laws and the judiciary assessing disputes.

The extent of the current crisis can be assessed again from the Mabo decision, where only one judge, Sir Daryl Dawson, who incidentally was a Fraser government appointment, asserted that it was the role of the government to make policy. Sir Daryl Dawson maintained that the rightings of any wrongs experienced by the indigenous people required the implementation of new policy, saying, `That it is a matter for government, rather than the courts'. He warned that any alternative approach would impugn the foundations of the legal system.

By contrast, the Chief Justice, Sir Anthony Mason, was quoted recently as advocating the establishment of a new appeal court to allow the High Court more time to make laws. He advocated that there should be more judge-made law, and he even argued that judges in other courts—even the state courts—should get involved in law-making. Sadly, he gave his justification for increased judicial law-making as being an assessment that the parliament was incapable of effectively dealing with the issues of the day. It is unfortunate that the House of Representatives has become a farce, with the government using the guillotine and the might of numbers to deny any proper opportunity to develop and scrutinise appropriate laws for the land.

It is an appalling indictment of the government that the High Court regards the parliament as such an irrelevance that it feels it has to step in and exercise our legitimate functions. There is a need for the parliament to address its procedures and to ensure that it is able to respond effectively and appropriately to the needs of the people. Any weakness in our parliamentary system should be corrected and not used as an excuse by the High Court judges to extend their influence.

It is time for the parliament to rise up to defend our constitutional democracy and the right of the people to make the laws of the land through their elected parliament. If High Court judges want to reform the parliament and make laws, they should stand for election to the parliament rather than usurp the authority of the parliament. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mrs Silvia

TALK.START.PARA: —As elected representatives, we are often called upon to bring to the notice of this House matters of importance for our electorates. I would like to bring two matters of importance to the notice of the House today. One is to do with my electorate and one is to do with everyone within this nation.

PARA.TAB: I will firstly deal with a young boy from Georgia in East Atlanta in the United States of America. He wrote to me saying that he had terminal cancer and had one wish before he passed on. He is only seven years old and so he is going to lead a very short life on this earth. His wish was to collect business cards and to be noted in the Guinness Book of Records as having collected the most business cards in the world. That is a great wish for a seven-year-old.

Looking at the submission that came to me, it is clear that there are many people with hearts of gold who have reached out to young Craig Shergold. In my capacity as a member of this place, I have reached out to him. I have done what he has asked of me. I have also asked 10 of my fellow parliamentarians to assist me in this matter. I sincerely hope that if anyone else is asked to assist they will do so.

I also wish to mention a group in Tasmania that is fairly new. Most people find that they have difficulty in getting going when they form a new group, especially in finding their way to members of parliament and ministers. The group I am talking about is the Forest Protection Society. In Tasmania we have some very beautiful forests and we are looking after them. We are sustaining growth. We are sustaining the environment, and we are sustaining jobs.

This week many members of that society throughout Australia have met here in Canberra. They have been meeting here as coordinators of the Forest Protection Society and undergoing negotiations with many people within this House and within various representative groups. Two of the people that came from Tasmania, whom I have been assisting, are present in the gallery today. I acknowledge their presence.

In the gallery is Mr Barry Chipman from Campania in Tasmania. He is our Tasmanian State Coordinator of the Forest Protection Society. Also in the gallery today is Mr Andrew McMaster from Smithton. He is the President of the Circular Head branch. I might add that that is the branch that I belong to. I have a close affinity with the north-west coast of Tasmania, although I do not have the delight of representing the area at this time. Mr McMaster is also the national Chairman of the board of the Forest Protection Society.

This particular society consists nationally of 35 branches, and within those branches it has some 9,000 members. Therefore, at this point in time—and it is only at this point in time—there are 9,000 people nationally who are extremely interested in two things: the conservation of our forests and the preservation of our jobs within the forests. One of the main aims of these people is to get back to work within the forests. They also want to sustain the environment as we have it and as we know it, and to keep it for the future.

In Tasmania, which people in this country often see as rather insignificant in size, we have six branches. Honourable members may say that that is not very many, but in those six branches we have 900 members—10 per cent of the national membership—and they represent a community that depends on Tasmania's well-managed forests.

The community in Tasmania is genuinely of the opinion that Tasmania's forest industries lead the world in sustainable forest management. In a letter to me, Barry Chipman, the State Coordinator of the Forest Protection Society, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Our community is of the opinion that Tasmania's forest industries leads the world in sustainable forest management. We can continue to contribute to our nation's economy by providing the value adding products that our industry is well known for, and the same time Tasmania and its forests are held in the high esteem of being selected for the forthcoming International adventure travel and eco-tourism convention which reinforces that our forests are managed for all the community.
They are not managed for just a select few. The tantamount aim of the society is to represent all the community, not just one group.

PARA.TAB: A point of discussion at the last state executive meeting was that in the past there perhaps had been a failure to communicate with the right people. As a Tasmanian member in this House I, and other members from Tasmania, have set about, this week in particular, opening up lines of communication. I afforded the gentlemen, together with a national member of the board, Bronwyn Petri from Tenterfield, New South Wales, a meeting yesterday with the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly). It was a very fruitful meeting and we all learnt something about each other. Surely, part of our role as the elected representatives of our community is to assist the people within our community, to guide them and to help them whenever we can.

Tasmania is unique in that it has at present approximately 25 per cent of its land tied up, in one way or another, in order to protect the forests and their resources. I want to read from a paragraph written by the Forestry Commission on what is happening in Tasmania's forests. It explains about the using of the land in Tasmania, something that very few people know about. The note states:

SPEECH.PARA: Since the 1920s, forested lands have been identified and set aside as State forests to ensure that Tasmania has, on a sustainable basis, sufficient forests to meet community needs. The Tasmanian Parliament passed the Public Land (Forests and Administration) Act in November, 1991 which reformed public forest land use. It provides for a Public Land Use Commission to scientifically assess changes that may be required in land use for the future.
So the planners in Tasmania are not looking only at the present but also at the future. The note continues:
Twenty-five per cent of Tasmania's land area is reserved in World Heritage Areas, National Parks, State or other reserves.
Twenty per cent of the State's land area is now managed as Multiple Use Forest.
Some five per cent of Tasmania's land area is forested land placed on the register for Deferred Forests and is unavailable for wood production pending further scientific investigation.

From these examples, I commend the Forest Protection Society, and I commend what its members are doing. They will be a force to be looked at in the future. We must always remember in this country to conserve our environment for future generations, but we must also look out for the workers who need the use of that resource.

PARA.TAB: I have visited two areas, the Arthur-Pieman area in the north-west and the southern forests area, and I commend the work practices that are in place in those forests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being approximately 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That grievances be noted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —So intellectually defunct is the opposition that some of its members are now openly blaming workers, wages and industrial relations for the current economic crisis. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) tries hard to avoid blaming wage levels for unemployment, but we all know what he really means.

PARA.TAB: Waving the Hilmer report, those of the right prattle on about how inefficient our industries are. No-one bothers to mention OECD figures which show that Australia ranks 10th in the world on the basis of GDP per employee per hour. As Peter Roberts confirms in the Australian Financial Review today, we are not a high wage nation by developed country standards. Of course, we do not hear the opposition citing the great successes of the Old Dart when defending its labour market deregulation obsession.

The honourable member for Bennelong reckons he believes in minimum standards, but the minute we mention the no disadvantage clause he mounts the soapbox and paints the same old Dickensian picture. So right wing have opposition members become that the fact that the Labor Party has now institutionalised non-unionism is completely lost on them. The government might have conceded some ground on sections 45D and 45E. However, as the PSU recently discovered, the right to strike is certainly not sacrosanct.

For the government, deregulating industrial relations is the latest panacea for our economic ills. As we have discovered, if it is good enough for the postie, it is good enough for the last bastion of Labor mythology.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition failed yesterday to stop a bill which removes all reference to the Queen from the oath of citizenship. Under the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1993, introduced in the Senate in May, impending citizens will have a choice of two possible pledges, one referring to God, the other making no mention of God, with neither mentioning the Queen. The government says the bill proposes a pledge of commitment as a citizen of the Commonwealth of Australia to replace the current oath of affirmation or allegiance.

PARA.TAB: It was debated at length yesterday in this place, with the opposition saying that changes to the oath were un-Australian and a denial of Australia's history. The bill was passed by 71 votes to 58.
This morning I received a fax from one of my constituents as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: This is an absolute disgrace. It is undisguised TREASON. The combined forces of the Opposition must stop Keating's blatant attempts to destroy our heritage. He is another Nero, "fiddling while Rome (the country) is burning".

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to inform the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary) that one of his left wing heroes, Fidel Castro, actually supported Argentina yesterday evening in the historic game between Argentina and Australia in the second leg of the final qualifying match for the World Cup finals. I would like to congratulate the Australians on a tremendous performance. Notwithstanding the fact that they were pipped one to nil by Argentina, it was a superb game, and I think that under the circumstances, with a crowd of 68,000 Argentinians at the River Plate Stadium in Buenos Aires, they put on a tremendous performance.

PARA.TAB: I think that augurs well for the future of Australian soccer because it is clear that, notwithstanding the fact that Australia is ranked about 62nd or 63rd in the world, it managed to put up such a superb performance against the ninth ranked team in the world, Argentina. I understand there is a movement to form a parliamentary soccer association, similar to the one that is formed for rugby league, in a move to promote the cause of soccer within the federal parliament. I also understand there may be some move to have some sort of reception or welcoming back for the Socceroos when they come back from Buenos Aires in the near future. I hope that that will take place, and I would commend any such reception to the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like most Victorians, I recently received my council rates notice, and for the second year we have been slugged with the Kennett Liberal Party state government $100 state deficit levy or poll tax. A millionaire has to pay the $100, the same as a pensioner. It does not take a university degree to work out who can least afford it.

PARA.TAB: Money that Victorians are being forced to pay in their rates is not going back into their communities; it is certainly not going back into the Dunkley community. In fact, no-one knows where this money is going. The Kennett government has not let on. Perhaps part of it is going to renovate the ministers' offices or the elitist silver service in the parliamentary dining room. Local government has also been lumped with the cost of collection of this reprehensible tax. Not only is it a burden on the councils; it also forces up the rates.

Mr Kennett will remove the tax in an effort to win votes at the next election, but I am sure his plans are to bring it back straight away if the Liberals win government again. Surely this would not surprise anyone. How many draconian policies did Mr Kennett arrogantly drop on Victorians after he got into power? He never mentioned this tax before the election as part of his policy platform. He never let on about it or the wholesale closing down of schools, for example, and certainly did not have a mandate to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to express the anger and disillusionment of the public at the self-serving nature of the political system. I refer to the recent announcement of the government's submission to the Remuneration Tribunal supporting such things as a 26 per cent pay increase for Canberra bureaucrats; the effective $10,000 rise for MPs by the provision of all-expenses-paid cars; and the outrageous gold pass handouts to former MPs.

PARA.TAB: At a time when the pay of the bulk of Australians is being steadily driven down with endless calls for it to be reduced further to compete with places like Indonesia and Thailand, when there is record unemployment, and when older Australians are being told that they must use up all their assets before they can expect any pensions, the double standards and hypocrisy are sickening.

The fact that it is happening with the connivance of the coalition is a blatant conspiracy against the public. The coalition's own efforts to expand public subsidies for MPs' partners, and electorate, entertainment and travelling allowances, and to hold party meetings in such places as Cable Beach at Broome or Port Douglas, show its contempt for the millions of Australians whose wages and conditions it endlessly attempts to ratchet down, even further than the government. The public perception of arrogance is overwhelming and it reflects on every member of this parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in this House the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) was quite rightly brought to task by the Auditor-General for apparent political bias in the allocation of funds to sporting, recreational and cultural projects located in various federal electorates. During yesterday's MPI the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) and the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) established beyond doubt that blatant politically expedient funding had occurred in the $60 million expended in total.

PARA.TAB: During the debate the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) alleged that the people of Colac in the electorate of Corangamite had been disadvantaged due to my belief that any funding should be part of the normal budget process rather than through political favouritism. Any allocated funds should be based on merit, project viability and community utilisation of such facilities. I supported the Colac swimming pool project, provided the contributions from council, community and state government sources were assured and that the project was viable. The then minister, Senator Richardson, divided $5 million between 880 local councils throughout Australia, based on political criteria alone. Such a cynical political approach does no justice to the Australian parliament, as Minister Kelly discovered to her cost yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to follow some of the remarks earlier of the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth). In this place, since he has been re-elected, he has continued to make remarks about the Kennett government in Victoria, so much so that I suspect he ought have a look at becoming a member in the state of Victoria rather than the federal parliament.

PARA.TAB: The fact of the matter is that, whilst he criticises the government for some of the, as he would term, harsh ways in which that government has handled issues, he seems to forget the fact that the Cain-Kirner government in that state was very happy to sell off trams and trains and carry on with massive deficits in the state.

This is one of the problems that we need to recognise, not only in the state of Victoria, but here. I listen often to the deficit reduction issues that are raised in this parliament. The fact of the matter is that our deficit this year has increased by $1.5 billion. So much for deficit reduction! The reality is that we cannot continue to spend without having the money capable of carrying out the programs that we want in our state.

There is a necessity not only at the state level but at the federal level for us to get our administration of government into order so that people can look forward to a bright and successful future for their children. I would suggest that the honourable member for Dunkley look a little at some of the excesses of expenditure that have been made in the state of Victoria by the former state Labor government and consider what is now being done by a very successful Kennett government in that state.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak again, but the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson) spurred me into it. Let us have a look at some of the things that the Premier of Victoria is doing at the moment. If one wants to start a dictatorship, the first thing to do is to muzzle the press. Well, he has done that. The next thing to do is to have a go at the church. Well, he has done that. The next thing to do is to try to put the unions out of business. Well, that is what he is trying to do.

PARA.TAB: All of these things are starting to happen in Victoria. That is why people in their thousands are leaving Victoria. Every week we have thousands of people going up to Queensland. And why? To get away from one Jeffrey Kennett and the policies of his government.

One only has to look at some of the excesses of that government. It has spent hundreds of thousands of dollars on doing up ministerial suites, silver service in the parliamentary dining room—and people like us have got to pay $100 poll tax year after year. It just goes on and on. He has put up gas prices. I just got my gas notice and there is an extra $22 in there. Who knows what it is for. It is probably for helping run a certain company that Jeffrey had shares in; one never knows in these sorts of things.

He has continually run down the state of Victoria and what he is doing now is just destroying it. We have had a tremendous infrastructure there with schools and social services to support those people in need, and what has he done? He has abolished the lot of them. This is what he is intending to do, just destroy all that infrastructure that Victoria has built up. However, there is one person in this parliament who will speak out against it. I know honourable members opposite will not, but I will. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) came into the House to run down the record of the Labor government in the provision of pensions to our senior citizens. This government has a very fine record in the provision of support to our elderly citizens. In particular, the pension is at its highest real level since the war, but this is never acknowledged by the conservatives. It has increased in real terms by 13.7 per cent or $18.49 per week since 1983, and in 1991 reached its highest level as a percentage of weekly earnings since the 1940s. But constantly we have the opposition come into the House and tell the government how it should reduce expenditure. Currently this government spends around $8 billion a year on age pensions. Opposition members come into this House and say that we should be having levels of taxation and spending similar to those of many Asian countries.

PARA.TAB: As the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) has pointed out, the policy of people sitting on the other side of the House is to cut spending in this country by between $10 billion and $20 billion a year. What items would the opposition want to cut? It could cut age pensions to the tune of $8 billion a year, it could cut support through family allowance and family income supplements to the tune of $5 billion a year, and so on. The opposition in the House has a lamentable record in providing support to our senior citizens. Not only does it downgrade the importance of the age pension, but when it was in office it did nothing for independent retirees. This government has extended fringe benefits to independent retirees, people who are eligible for part pensions, from earlier this year. We are also bringing in a seniors cards for those senior citizens who have low incomes but are precluded from receiving a part pension through the assets test. We have a fine record in terms of supporting our senior citizens. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have just heard is just sheer bunkum. If the government stopped making decisions, every Aussie would be better off. It has ripped billions of dollars out of the pensioners and superannuation people of the country. In western Sydney, for instance, it is going to sell a naval establishment, HMAS Nirimba, and move everybody down to Victoria. It is going to cost millions of dollars, and it is presented as a saving measure. That naval community in western Sydney brings in $14 million to the local community. It is one of the real industries of western Sydney.

PARA.TAB: All the Labor members from western Sydney can say, `Some day, out here in the west we are going to build an international airport that is going to bring a lot of money and a lot of jobs into western Sydney'. The government is closing a facility that provides lots of jobs, it is closing a facility that brings lots of income into the local area. The Australian Labor Party does not understand how it needs to apply its mind to western Sydney and the importance of apprenticeship training, of instructors, of naval personnel and all of the ancillary services that go into HMAS Nirimba. Despite the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) having it pointed out to him time and time again that every part of this decision is costing more and more taxpayers' dollars as naval personnel move to Victoria, the honourable senator denies and continues to deny that this is a crazy and expensive decision which is wrecking the economy of western Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the dying moments of members' statements, I would like to bring to the attention of honourable members, particularly those honourable members on the other side of the House from Western Australia, an advertisement in today's West Australian on page 52. I am sure the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) has seen it. It is an open letter to him and his colleagues, reminding them of the terrible effects of the Keating Mabo legislation on Western Australia. It asks those members and senators from the Labor Party from Western Australia to reconsider their support for the Keating Mabo legislation, on the basis that it will terribly impede Western Australia's economic recovery. (Time expired)
—Order! It being now just after 2 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, is absent from question time today and Monday. The Prime Minister has gone to Seattle to the APEC meeting. In his absence, I will take questions addressed to the Prime Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Special Minister of State.
—Where is he?
—I do not know whether he has bothered to turn up.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Where is he?

TALK.START.PARA: —This is pathetic, Mr Speaker.
—In his absence, the honourable member for Chisholm might like to direct the question to another minister or resume his seat.
—I will direct it to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I seek information regarding part 7 of the Native Title Bill 1993. In clause 177(1) it states:

QUESTION.PARA: There is to be a register known as the Register of Native Title Claims. . .
There must be a register known as the National Native Title Register.

Does this mean that a separate new quasi-judicial system will be created with separate registrars, separate clerks, separate associates, separate tip staff, separate support staff and the whole paraphernalia of a separate appeals and tribunal system? If so, could he give the parliament an estimate of the cost?

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the minister, I point out that I listened very carefully and on the same basis as a question was allowed—

TAB.EMPHASIS: Mr Walker having entered the chamber—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, where have you been?
—We have already had a question for you.

—As I was saying, before being interrupted by the honourable member for Moore, again, yesterday I allowed a question on the issue of legislation pending before this House on the basis that it was not anticipating discussion on that legislation, but rather was seeking information and the clarification of information. On that basis, and on that basis alone, I will give call to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, but again I remind all honourable members of this place that the anticipatory rule is one which I am looking at very carefully in respect of these matters.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill, of course, is to be debated before the House. I think that, if there are detailed matters to be answered, they best be answered in the course of that debate. However, I am prepared to respond to the honourable member's question. I was not sure, when the question was asked, whether the honourable member was referring to a register of claims or the registrar of the tribunal or court. On the assumption that he is talking about a registrar, he then goes on to ask the question whether or not the system to be established by the Commonwealth will contain the usual elements associated with the judicial process. Of course, subject to the particular provisions in the Commonwealth legislation, it will. But it is intended to be a tribunal process established to ensure the greatest degree of informality and the greatest emphasis on consultation and negotiation between the parties. Can I say, it would be a great moment for this entire parliament and the nation if the coalition were able to join with the government in passing that legislation.

—My question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister. Has the Acting Prime Minister seen a report today concerning the High Court's decision on Mabo. In the light of that report, is it necessary to amend the government's native title legislation?
—Is this acceptable?
—It is, on the same basis as the last question was asked. It is seeking information.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: HOUSING, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports today about the coalition's response to the native title legislation and I would like to briefly take the opportunity to respond to those reports.

PARA.TAB: The basis of the High Court's decision on Mabo is recognition of native title. This recognition is the basis of the government's response on Mabo. The coalition claims to recognise native title and the High Court's decision, but will allow a bill in Western Australia which extinguishes native title. Which is it? Does the coalition support native title, or is the coalition essentially about extinguishment?

The coalition says that it recognises native title and wants the Racial Discrimination Act adhered to. The Racial Discrimination Act is law in this country. It is not up to the Liberals or the Nationals to decide whether it be adhered to or not. Those who claim the coalition's position on Mabo is a win for the moderates clearly did not hear the honourable member for Barker on ABC radio this morning. He clearly stated that the High Court's decision might have to be reversed and this was the effect of Richard Court's legislation. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . we're certainly not saying that at some stage or other that this decision may not, in the end, have to be reversed if it doesn't work.

Honourable members will recall that the honourable member for Barker said he would resign if he did not get his way on Mabo, but of course he is still there. He wants the High Court's decision reversed and he says the coalition policy does not rule that out. He says that the Western Australian bill, to which the coalition has now given effective support, does reverse that decision. So there is no real, practical recognition of native title. There is no policy to implement the recognition of native title.

PARA.TAB: The coalition spokesperson on Aboriginal affairs, said it could have been worse. For the indigenous people in this country, it is hard to see how it could have been any worse than what was decided last night.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I seek clarification and information and ask: has the minister's attention been drawn to the extraordinary comments by the head of BHP, Mr John Prescott, regarding the government's approach to the Native Title Bill where Mr Prescott said it was a recipe for `confusion, complexity and frustration' which would hamstring Australia's economic prospects? Is it a fact that the comments represent—in Ticknerspeak—`pure bunkum' or are they merely `tawdry'? Should they be `viewed with disdain by all fair-minded Australians'? Are they `outrageous scaremongering' and `unmitigated nonsense'? Finally, is Mr Prescott `breathtaking in his manifest ignorance' or just another business leader representing the `forces of self-interest and greed'? Or is he just right?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I wish to thank the Leader of the National Party of Australia for his question because it allows me to put a number of matters on the public record. I am in debt to the Leader of the National Party for showing such an avid interest in my public pronouncements, in response, I might add, almost on every occasion, to the Leader of the National Party in Queensland, Mr Borbidge; the Leader of the National Party in New South Wales, Mr Armstrong; and, indeed, his own comments which I think have done a great disservice to the coalition parties.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the question raised by the Leader of the National Party as it relates to Mr Prescott and to BHP. It is true that there have been some public comments made overnight which are critical of the government's proposals. The government believes that when those proposals are understood in detail by the mining industry it will understand that there is no right of veto conferred on Aboriginal people and that the whole intention of the Commonwealth legislation is to put in place a regime of certainty that will benefit not only Aboriginal people but also the mining industry itself.

In answering the question of the Leader of the National Party, I would be failing in my responsibility not to highlight to him and to this House what the peak organisation in the rural industry says about the government's proposal. The National Farmers Federation issued a public statement yesterday unanimously supporting the government's proposal. So out of step is the coalition, so out of step are the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party, that the peak organisation of the body that they were once close to, that once had a degree of respect and trust for them, has turned its back on them and endorsed the government's position.

The government has never believed that reaching a just outcome in response to the Mabo decision would be an easy task. There are some people who have not got all they wanted out of the government's outcome. The end result is that we have produced a package of measures that will work, a package of measures that delivers certainty to industry, but more importantly from my portfolio perspective a series of measures that keep faith absolutely with the sacred trust reposed in this parliament by the 1967 referendum to defend the human rights of Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform honourable members that we have present in the gallery a great friend of Australia, the former United States Ambassador to Australia, Mr Bill Lane, recently awarded I understand an honorary Order of Australia. On behalf of the parliament, we welcome you once again.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Treasurer inform the House of the significance of recent data on the economy released by Westpac and the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research?

—I thank the honourable member for Lilley for his question. Westpac and the Melbourne Institute have released two significant pieces of data over the last week. Most recently, we saw yesterday the release of the Westpac-Melbourne Institute leading index for September which was reported widely in the press. The index incorporates nine individual components which together have consistently provided a good indication of future trends in the economy. Yesterday's release showed that the index increased by two per cent in September and revealed an annualised growth rate of 11.6 per cent, the best result since 1985.
—Watch out for Laurie, John.

—I notice the mirth with which the opposition greets this improved information on the performance of the economy. It is a strange thing that the Leader of the Opposition has spoken about practically nothing else than the economy since he became leader, but of course he really only enjoys talking about the economy when he can talk the country down. When the data on the economy improves, when the evidence demonstrates that the economy is on the improve, his interest in the economy wanes. He does not want to talk about the economy because it is on the improve. All he will do is continue his mindless chatter across the table in an attempt apparently to disguise the importance of this information.

PARA.TAB: This leading index published yesterday is now 9.6 per cent above its level of just a year ago. Moreover, the strong upward growth evident over the last 12 months is now beginning to be reflected in the coincident index also released by Westpac and the Melbourne Institute. This increased by 0.9 per cent in September to its highest level since March 1991.

This index released yesterday followed a few days ago the release of the Westpac-Melbourne Institute consumer confidence index for November. Again this measure has shown an improvement where consumer sentiment is now at its highest level for five years. All this comes on top of the mounting evidence over recent months of a sustained pick-up in business expectations with the recent National Australia Bank, the Dun and Bradstreet and even the ACM surveys all pointing to an improvement in sentiment in the December quarter, and for the first time since 1989.

Westpac's chief economist, Mr Bill Evans, comments that this points to a brighter 1994 and suggests that it represents a marked acceleration in the economy. This is good news for Australia. I think it demonstrates that the economy is certainly on the move. I would not suspect that it was good news for the opposition, hence its dispirited demeanour as it sees increasing evidence of the recovery taking hold in Australia.

The mirror image of the leading index is the interest which the Leader of the Opposition takes in the economy. As I said earlier, he is only interested in talking about the economy when he can talk the economy down, when he can disparage the contribution of Australian working men and women in this country, and when he can disparage the efforts of Australian companies as they move to take advantage of the new opportunities which lie ahead of them.

Of course, there remains the issue of unemployment and how we reduce that over the months ahead. The government has quite clearly identified that as a clear area of priority for it in the months ahead. Having said that, this evidence, coming as it does from Westpac and the Melbourne Institute, relating to the leading index of economic activity and consumer sentiment, I think does portray the fact that the economy is clearly on the move, is clearly improving and that is what the government's policies have been all about. This is simply confirmation that those policies are right and working.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Treasurer. Does the Treasurer have any advice as to what employers ought to say to employees who are earning around $330 a week and who, on opening their pay packets this afternoon, will discover that, unlike their better paid colleagues, they will receive no tax break at all, and that between now and way beyond Christmas that situation will endure? In fact, on closer examination, they will find that they are, on average, 50c a week worse off than they are now.

—How totally laughable it is that the spokesman for the opposition on industrial relations should get up here and talk about the interests of low paid workers. We all know that what he has in mind for low paid workers is a pay cut. The honourable member for Bennelong, the shadow minister for industrial relations, actually thinks that low paid workers in Australia are paid too much, and the whole intent, focus and direction of his policies are all about how he can cut wages in order to pursue his policies.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you expect me to do?
—Order! The member for Bennelong on a point of order.

—My point of order is simply that I asked a question relating to the Treasurer's portfolio responsibility of taxation. He has made no attempt so far to answer that question. Mr Speaker, I ask that you invite him, under section 145 of the standing orders, to turn his attention to the question of relevance.

—The question you asked of the Treasurer related to low paid workers in the Australian economy and the responsibilities of the Treasurer in respect of tax. The Treasurer was talking about—from what I was listening to, at least—those people in receipt of that level of remuneration. The Treasurer is in order.

—What has also happened this week is that not only are the tax cuts being delivered—and we made it perfectly clear that those taxes were about providing a benefit to those people on or about average weekly earnings; a policy which we then extended by way of the rebate to include all taxpayers all the way down to the lowest tax paying taxpayer in Australia—but also the IRC announced this week that workers on minimum rate awards would receive an additional $8 a week as part of the settlement of the most recent wages case.

PARA.TAB: The government does have a policy which is about fairness for all Australian workers. We have taken more account of the interest of low paid workers over our 10 years in office than the honourable member for Bennelong could ever dream of doing in a lifetime. What he clearly has in mind but will not face up to—will never own up to—is the real object of his policy, which is about wage cuts, particularly for the low paid. It is that policy with which we will have no truck whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Has the minister seen media reports today concerning the Australian Taxation Office? What action is the minister taking to ensure that the Australian Taxation Office provides an appropriate level of service to the Australian community and, in particular, to the Australian business community? When is the minister intending to respond to the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts report on the Australian Taxation Office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will always give the Taxation Office all the resources it needs in terms of manpower, equipment and decent policies. In that regard, I welcome the report that was handed down in the House yesterday by the public accounts committee, which conducted a two year investigation of the Australian Taxation Office. I commend honourable members and senators of the committee for their hard work and the report that they handed down. In particular, I was pleased to see that the committee gave endorsement to the direction of the Australian Taxation Office over the last 10 years particularly in relation to self-assessment, the modernisation program and the decentralisation program. It was a long report with many recommendations. I can assure the committee and the House that the government will give this report every consideration.

PARA.TAB: The report was more than just a majority report. There was included in it a dissenting report. For those who have not read it, I would recommend it. It is fascinating reading. I am in a position to make a few comments about that here today. In her dissenting report, Senator Bishop sought to abolish or water down many of the policies that add fairness to the taxation system. I will touch on a few of those now.

In particular, I mention the capital gains tax. Those of us who were here in the 1980s remember that without the capital gains tax we had the lawyers and the accountants peddling the artificial schemes to all of those who could afford them. We understood, back in those days, that the people who were disadvantaged by that policy were ordinary working Australians.

She also wants to fiddle with the FBT. Apparently it is all right for ordinary Australians to pay tax on all of their income but, for people who can split their income between paid income and income in kind—in the form of cars, zero interest loans, mortgages, school fees, overseas holidays, HBF and other things—apparently, according to Senator Bishop, that is okay; do not worry about paying tax on that because the workers will pick it up.

Self-assessment was another area that she attacked in the dissenting report. What she wants to do is take the Taxation Office back to the 1970s where every tax return had to be scrutinised. That was a very tiresome and meddlesome process. The self-assessment program was endorsed by the majority of the public accounts committee.

Senator Bishop also wanted to fiddle with the foreign income rules. Apparently it is okay for the smarties to do their taxation business over in the Cook Islands or the Bahamas. We will have none of that. If we take all of that out of the taxation policy, what is left? But we have to ask the question: what does the opposition say about this? What is its tax policy? Does it agree with Senator Bishop? In the last 24 hours, I have not heard anybody stand up and say that that is not coalition policy. If those opposite believe that that is a fair way to go, let them stand up and say so.

I notice that the honourable member for Mayo will be raising a matter of public importance today. Maybe he can give us a few clues then about how he sees the recommendations in the dissenting report. The one thing that I am sure that all decent members of this House would agree with is the endorsement by the public accounts committee of the reputation of the former commissioner Trevor Boucher and its denunciation of the attack by Senator Bishop on the former taxation commissioner.

Everybody in this place knows that former commissioner Boucher gave 40 years of his life to serving the people of Australia in the Australian Taxation Office. He has an unblemished record of service to this country. What did we get in front of the public accounts committee? I know it must have embarrassed the Liberal members on the committee to see Senator Bishop attack the taxation commissioner with some unfounded allegations that he sought to use his position to receive some gain for himself after 40 years of unblemished service. Does she not look a lonely figure today? And so she should.

It was a cowardly attack on one of our best public servants—a public servant with a reputation for honesty and integrity not only in this country but also overseas. He was internationally renowned for the work that he did here. If that is not bad enough, the lack of leadership shown when Senator Bishop made those attacks should make every decent Australian sit up and take notice because the Leader of the Opposition should have called Senator Bishop into his office and said, `I used to work with Commissioner Boucher when I was on the staff of Treasurer Howard. I know him to be a man of honesty. I know him to be a man of integrity. What you did today was over the top'. That is what the Leader of the Opposition should have done. He should have shown some leadership on the issue.
In fact, the Leader of the Opposition was quoted in the Canberra Times on 23 October as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Hewson praised Mr Boucher's reforms of the Tax Office and said he would make a "fantastic contribution" as the OECD ambassador.

At least he had the decency to come out and recognise the good work Mr Boucher had done in the Tax Office and wish him well in his new post. However, the Leader of the Opposition could not sustain it, because on 27 October we saw in the Age `Bishop backed in tax row', and in the Canberra Times `Hewson support for Bishop'.

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is this: the Leader of the Opposition had it right the first time, but he could not help himself. He cannot bring himself to criticise a backbench senator when he knows that she is out of line. Mr Speaker, there is still a chance for the Liberal Party to show that there is some leadership outside of this parliament, if there is none inside it. I refer to the preselection panel for the seat of Mackellar. The members of the panel could say to Senator Bishop, `You have abused your position as a member of parliament in attacking public servants—in fact in attacking Commissioner Boucher. We will have nothing to do with you'. I hope they take that course of action.

In conclusion, let me say this: the government will look at the main report and will give it every consideration because it deserves it. But we will treat the dissenting report with the contempt that it deserves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Communications. In light of the continuing pay TV fiasco, and the already displayed incompetence of the minister, can he please explain why radio station 2KY in Sydney, owned by the New South Wales Labor Council and managed by former New South Wales Premier Barrie Unsworth, was granted two high power narrowcast licences to broadcast racing from its Sydney studios into Wollongong and Newcastle, on two AM frequencies, when 6PR in Perth and 5AA in Adelaide, which applied at the same time as 2KY—and given that Adelaide and Perth have a far greater spectrum underutilisation than Sydney—have had their applications caught up in the ABA's rule changes? Furthermore, would the quick manner in which Labor's 2KY received the licences have anything to do with the fact that Barrie Unsworth used the `old boys' Labor Party network in Canberra to gain advantage, and was 6PR in Perth denied a licence because, as a talkback station, it is often critical of the federal government's performance?
—Mr Speaker—
—Before I call the Minister for Communications to respond to the substance of the honourable member's question, in the first sentence or so there was as reflection on the minister, and I would—
—His incompetence.
—Order! You have just highlighted it again. I would ask the honourable member for Stirling to withdraw that part of his question. The rest of the question is in order.
—Because I am dying to hear the answer, I withdraw.
—No, because you withdraw, you withdraw.
—I withdraw because I withdraw.
—Thank you.

—In relation to the first part of the honourable member's question on pay TV, may I suggest that he has a little bit of patience and all may be revealed to him in the near future. In relation to the second part of the question about 2KY and the stations in Adelaide and Perth, no representations were made to me directly in relation to 2KY and I have not had discussions with Barrie Unsworth. But I have had a number of discussions with the applicants in both Perth and Adelaide, and those matters are ongoing. On the specific allegations that the honourable member makes about 2KY, I will take that on notice and report back to the House.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. In view of the very strong export performance by Australian manufacturing over the past 10 years, can the minister inform the House of measures the government has taken to facilitate this growth?

—During the past decade Australia's export performance has increased very positively, and indeed we have seen the export of manufactured goods increase at an annual rate of 12.5 per cent. Over the past 10 years Australia's manufactured exports to the Asia-Pacific region have increased by a whopping 378 per cent—that is, from $3.7 billion in 1982 to $17.7 billion in 1992. That represents more than half of the total growth in manufactured exports. This is not surprising given that the Asia-Pacific region now is the locus of world economic growth. Australia is well positioned to ensure that it continues to earn its share of the opportunities in that region.

PARA.TAB: Only last week I was in China, and I was quite taken aback by the breadth and diversity of Australian penetration into that rapidly growing market. One example is Olex Cables and NEC, who were putting optical fibre links between Xian, Chengdu and Chongqing, and also putting in very sophisticated telecommunications infrastructure into that part of China. Another example is AWA providing microwave landing systems to the Chinese air force in Chian. I made the observation that Chinese pilots now experience landings as smooth as a gravy sandwich. I am not sure whether they got the import of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't either.

—I would not expect the honourable member for Gippsland to pick up on something like that. Nevertheless, AWA is doing a great job. As honourable members know, the Prime Minister has left for the leaders meeting in Seattle, and the ministerial component of that meeting is currently under way. The meeting is of seminal importance, and of course Australia's role in bringing about the formation of APEC, trying to ensure its development as a forum for the appropriate exchange of views—views, I might say, less Eurocentric, or perhaps even trans-Atlantic, than one tends to get from other organisations such as the GATT; nevertheless, it is a very important forum indeed—and trying to progress it as an arrangement whereby we can move to more liberal trading arrangements is a role widely acknowledged in our region.

PARA.TAB: If the GATT round were to fail—heaven forbid—either in terms of an unsatisfactory outcome or in terms of the leadership responsibility GATT participants have, then it may fall to Australia and to countries in our region to consider utilising the APEC arrangements to do for the half of the world economy comprising the Asia-Pacific region what GATT may have failed to do for the whole of the world economy. At least in the APEC context we must genuinely try to move to more liberal and sensible trading arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Will the Federal Government provide financial assistance for the embattled Letona cannery and would it be the government's intention to match dollar for dollar the New South Wales state government grants provided for the canning fruit growers who stand to lose up to $2 million as a result of the cannery's present problems?
—The Commonwealth government has already provided substantial financial assistance to the Letona cannery.
—And no more?

—It is his question. Will you let me answer him. The first instalment was $312,000, given under an employment incentive scheme. The position is that we are still owed $2.5 million off a $5.5 million interest free loan. The position further is—it is understood by all and sundry, and I presume the honourable member does not have any disagreement with this—that the problem with the Letona cannery has been its management's failure. Therefore, the Commonwealth government is not going to give additional support to back up a company that has already failed and owes us money; and neither is the New South Wales government.

PARA.TAB: We have said consistently to the New South Wales government that, if a new commercial operator does come into the field and takes over the operations and develops a cannery, which clearly there is the potential to do because of the specific, unique location of the operations and the horticultural activities of the region, there is a raft of Commonwealth government programs, together with state government programs, that can be put together to assist in that development. There are things such as the world best practices program to get better linkages between the growers and the producers; the international trade enhancement scheme and the marketing skills program. There is a range of programs. There is a one-stop shop to which the operator can go. To date, a new commercial proponent has not come forward, but we understand that a number have expressed interest, but certainly not to the stage at which they have finalised any proposition.

In relation to the piece of legislation that has passed the New South Wales parliament that proposes to attach, I think, up to $5 million if we match it, I had the opportunity to speak to my counterpart minister in New South Wales yesterday. He confirmed with me that even if this money were forthcoming it would not save the cannery. I do not see any point in putting money—after what has already been put—into a badly managed operation, but I stand ready to support any new, viable proposition on the back of existing programs that the government has. Finally, clearly there is the opportunity under the rural adjustment scheme, which again we have in existence, whereby farmers can restructure their activities and take advantage of that program as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Treasurer provide the House with information regarding tax rates in the east Asian economies? Is Australia's company tax rate competitive by the standards of the east Asian economies?

—As the Deputy and Acting Prime Minister indicated, the Prime Minister is on his way to APEC for the APEC leaders' meeting, which is evidence of the increasing economic integration of the nations of the region and, most particularly, a measure of the integration of Australia with many of the countries of that region. It is for that reason that the government has been keen to compare the investment climate in Australia with those climates which operate in some of the countries of south-east and north-east Asia.

PARA.TAB: The question refers to comparable company tax rates in the east Asian area. Perhaps it is worth reminding the House of what those rates are for a selected group of countries. For Japan, the company rate of tax is 37 1/2 per cent; Taiwan, 25 per cent; Korea, 36 1/2 per cent; Thailand, 30 per cent; Malaysia, 34 per cent; Indonesia, 35 per cent; Singapore, 30 per cent; and the Philippines, 35 per cent. If one averages those rates which I have mentioned, the unweighted average in these economies would be 33 per cent. That is precisely the rate which now applies in Australia and, therefore, clearly puts Australia very much in touch with these economies on a comparable basis.

It is worth mentioning that many of the countries which I have mentioned continue to have a system of double taxation. In other words, they do not have the system of dividend imputation of the kind we have in Australia and, therefore, these tax rates probably understate for those countries the actual impact of that rate of tax on the companies. In this context it is intriguing that, with the policy chaos that exists on the other side, the opposition has continued to embrace a 42 per cent tax rate. In other words, when invited to clarify the opposition's tax policy the other day, the shadow Treasurer was unable to give an alternative view to the proposition that the opposition was still wedded to the idea of a company tax rate of 42 per cent, which of course was the rate with which it went to the last election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give it away; Laurie Brereton would be more effective than this.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo!

—One would have thought that even someone as dopey as the honourable member for Mayo would have realised that a company tax rate of 42 per cent was miles out of line with the rate that applies to these economies in Asia—the very economies which he and his colleagues have said Australia must increasingly compete with.

PARA.TAB: But what does the opposition propose? It effectively proposes increasing the tax on companies in Australia from 33 per cent to 42 per cent—gaining an addition $2.7 billion worth of revenue in the process. Is this the way in which Australia and Australian companies can compete with and become more engaged with these dynamic economies in Asia with which our future is so intimately linked, as evidenced by the work which is going on in APEC?

It is about time the opposition decided to abandon its policy-free approach to politics and have a tax policy—something which it was so crucially wedded to before the last election but which now remains a quagmire of chaos.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Acting Prime Minister whether it is true that under the Australian constitution the states and territories of Australia are and always have been responsible for the administration of land matters in Australia? If so, will the Acting Prime Minister give the House an assurance that that constitutional role will continue and that the states will continue to perform that role?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: HOUSING, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no difficulty at all in answering that question in the affirmative. But behind that question lies a much more profound political question—the question of political will, the question of political leadership, the question, effectively, of whether the Liberal Party confronted at this point with perhaps the most important set of policy decisions and perhaps the most far-reaching and significant legislation, is able to take the high moral ground or in fact is to become subservient, not to questions of state interests but, essentially, to the interests of electorates, of seats, of vested interests, particularly in the state of Western Australia, rather than look at the issue of Aboriginal people and the interests of Aboriginal people, together with the national interest.

PARA.TAB: It is very unfortunate that it is so clear that, in the deliberations that occurred yesterday and which were reflected this morning in the previous question I answered, the person opposite me—the man who would be Prime Minister—has been prepared to put aside questions of principle so effectively that not a single Aboriginal organisation in this country, no-one that represents Aboriginal people, has seen any attempt at all in the opposition's approach to find a solution in the best interests of all Australian people. That is the sad thing; not that we do not recognise the proper role of states and their responsibilities in terms of land.

The opposition leader in this federal parliament does not have enough spine and backbone to be able to decide a matter on principle. He is caving in to the kinds of vested interests that obviously lie so totally behind the position taken by so many honourable members opposite. It is an opportunity for leadership; but the opposition leader has caved in to vested interests. That is what is behind the question, not any fundamental change in the constitutional position that is being proposed by us or any change in the attitude towards land. We have worked very hard to protect the states' position of having responsibility for the management of land. Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
