TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The Government's plans to increase taxes to fund the hole in its deficit reduction strategy.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take up the point that the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) was alluding to indirectly a few moments ago; the very well-known fact that it was the minister's office that was enthusiastically predicting the demise of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), presumably with a view to the minister taking the Treasurer's seat in the parliament. The point is that this simply reflects—
—I raise a point of order. Is it in order for a member, when making a point in debate, to totally mislead the House? What a load of nonsense.
—There is no point of order.

—Everyone knows this, but it is only a symptom of the lack of confidence in the capacity and competence of the Treasurer amongst his cabinet colleagues and, indeed, amongst the backbench of the parliamentary Labor Party. The fact is that, ever since bringing down the budget on 17 August this year, the Treasurer's position in this government has been fundamentally destroyed.

PARA.TAB: We all know only too well that the last election was an election fought on the issue of tax. I do not think Australians will forget between now and polling day the next time around in two or 2 1/2 years that the Labor Party promised in the lead-up to the election that it would not increase taxes, and then after the election immediately increased the burden of taxes on Australians.

What is interesting is that, after that act of betrayal in the budget by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) straight after the election, both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer went around telling Australians effectively, `Look, we are sorry about the increases in tax this time, but we promise we will not do it again. We will do it this time on 17 August, but we won't do it again'. For example, on 18 August, the Treasurer said to the National Press Club:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is no fiscal imperative for us to increase taxation further on the basis of achieving that deficit target.
He went on to say:
So in terms of meeting the deficit reduction to about 1 per cent of GDP in 1996-97 there will be no fiscal imperative on us to raise taxes further.
It is strange language, I admit—`econotalk'. But what it means is that under Labor there will be no further increases in taxes over and above the increases that they have already brought forward.

PARA.TAB: The interesting thing is that this statement by the Treasurer was undermined in recent days, on 10 November, in a speech given by the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) to the Economic Society of Australia in Sydney. I do not think the Treasurer has read this speech, because it was not cleared with his office and he was unaware that the Minister for Finance was going to deliver this speech. When the Treasurer heard that the speech had been delivered, there was great anger in his office and much spleen was directed at the Minister for Finance. It is no wonder, because the Minister for Finance, in his speech—it is worth the Treasurer reflecting on this because I am sure he still has not read it all very carefully—said:

SPEECH.PARA: So dedication to the deficit reduction program will require constant government vigilance to keep expenditure under control.
Indeed it will. He went on to say:
It may also involve some revenue increases . . .

They are fatal political words for the Labor Party, because, although the Minister for Finance was clearly telling the truth in his speech and was once more showing that he is one of the few members of the cabinet who has genuine integrity on these matters, the Minister for Finance fatally undermined the position of a Treasurer who has been running around telling people, `I'm sorry we didn't tell the truth at the last election. I'm sorry we had to deceive the country. But, by the way, there won't be any additional deceit and there won't be any additional increases in taxes over and above the increases there have been'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why should we believe him?

—As the member for Gippsland says: why should we believe him? As a matter of fact, nobody does believe him. The Treasurer and the Prime Minister are the two most unbelievable people in the country. The Treasurer was much miffed by the Minister for Finance and he then rang around the Sunday newspapers. He likes to do this because he is frightened of the coalition. He is frightened that we will attack him and that the counterattack will give him yet another bloody nose. So he furtively rang around a few newspapers—presumably they published the reports fairly faithfully—and told them:

SPEECH.PARA: I'm opposed to future tax increases to meet the cost of any new obligations which come up . . . I see my job as resisting any claims for tax increases . . .

It has not been his job up until now, apparently. He has not been resisting those claims; he has been going to the cabinet with proposals for tax increases. What is interesting is that he says that he will resist them but he does not repeat what he said at the Press Club; that is, that there will be no need for them. That is the way the Treasurer operates. He tries to use too clever by half phrases and words which will leave him with some sort of out.

PARA.TAB: As the honourable member for Gippsland mentioned earlier, nobody would ever believe anything that the Treasurer has said. That has been the experience not just of us as politicians but also of an awful lot more people around the building, around this town and in the business community as well. For example, there was the wonderful saga of the Treasurer putting out a press release refuting an article in the Financial Review. It said that he had left the CPI forecast in the budget deliberately higher—3 1/2 per cent—despite the fact that the Treasury had told him that its assessment of the CPI increase in the financial year would be a more modest one; I think 3.25 per cent. We know all of this. There is no point in trying to pretend that we do not. He knows only too well that the forecast that he put—the one which was allowed to go ahead in the budget—was not a reflection of the views of the Treasury.

But then the Treasurer put out a press release, when a journalist wrote about this matter, saying that it was totally untrue. He demonstrated all sorts of unction and concern about the falsehoods of the journalist, but behind the scenes the Treasurer was briefing Labor members, saying, `This is right. As a matter of fact, we did not ever expect the inflation rate to be 3 1/2 per cent as we published it'. When the next CPI figure came out he went around and said that apparently he would now downgrade the forecast; downgrade it to what the Treasury said it was earlier. That is a typical act from this Treasurer.

So we have had many examples of this kind of loose behaviour with the truth from this Treasurer. As a consequence of that, and as a consequence of his obvious political ineptitude, he has lost the confidence—not of the opposition; it will never be very enthusiastic about a Labor Treasurer given the record of the Labor Party when it comes to economic management at the state and federal level—of his cabinet and colleagues. The Treasurer was rolled comprehensively on his favourite issue of bringing the budget forward to April or May rather than having it in August. The Minister for Finance fought tooth and nail in cabinet against the Treasurer and, in the end, the cabinet decided that it would give him a little out by saying that if he could reach agreement on a deadline with the Greens and the Australian Democrats then maybe they would consider it—all the time knowing that the Treasurer was unlikely to reach such an agreement and wanting to sabotage him but making sure that he could go out to the public with a face-saving formula.

The same occurred with Australia Post. The Treasurer ran around briefing journalists that reform was urgently needed. He told them that we have to stop this slacking off of the pace of reform; that we have to accelerate the reform of Australia Post. He was again rolled in the cabinet. Some compromise was worked out to make the Treasurer look okay, but the fact is that the Treasurer was rolled on that issue because he lacks authority and the confidence of his cabinet. It is not surprising. It is well known around the building, and it is sometimes written by people in this building, that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) will relatively soon replace the Treasurer in his job. That, as I said, is well known.

The budget and taxes will come back and haunt not just the Treasurer but the Prime Minister as well. When we look at the way that they have calculated the achievement of their deficit reduction target, we can see that it is based on assumptions—assumptions which have been heroically written into the budget papers but ones which do not stand up to the assumptions used by private sector economists or by the very reputable so-called alternative Treasury, Access Economics.

The Treasurer assumes that the economy will grow by four per cent in 1995-96 and four per cent in 1996-97. He assumes that, but if we use the assumptions that private sector forecasters such as Access Economics use we will see they expect the economy to grow by 2.9 per cent and 2.6 per cent in those years. What does that matter? That matters crucially because if Access Economics and the private sector are right the Treasurer and the government start with a $5 billion hole in their deficit reduction strategy. In other words, as the Minister for Finance has suggested, the government is secretly proposing to increase the tax burden on Australians by an additional $5 billion between now and 1996-97. The Minister for Finance has felt it necessary to lay the groundwork for the truth—I assume always recognising that the existing Treasurer will not be there when finally the policy is reversed and changed.

The fact is that either the government is proposing to increase taxes by $5 billion or so over the next few years or else its deficit reduction strategy is just in tatters. Alternatively, there will be a blow-out in the deficit and the government will not get anywhere near the strategy that it is pretending it will achieve. What further evidence is there of this secret plan of the Labor Party to increase taxes than the way the budget papers themselves are constructed? They have details, year by year to 1996-97, of outlays and growth in outlays in different portfolios. The budget papers tell us precisely what the defence budget will be for 1995-96 and precisely what expenditure in the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services will be. But what does it not tell us? It does not tell us how the government will get the money to finance these things. There is no detailed breakdown, year by year, of revenue—only of outlays. It is perfectly obvious it does not have the breakdown of revenue because it plans to increase taxes over and above the increases that were already imposed on Australians as a result of the budget on 17 August.

The government says that it cannot reduce spending to fund any of this, that it is utterly and absolutely impossible to reduce expenditure in this country. Let me remind the House of something that I think people should take back to their electorates and speak to Australians generally about. In this financial year alone, the running costs of government departments are to increase by nearly three per cent. Over the last three years, the average increase in running costs of departments has been five per cent per annum. Are the running costs of departments very expensive? The answer is that they are extraordinarily expensive. This year $11 1/2 billion will be spent on the running costs of government departments. If we take that one item of expenditure, its puts into some perspective the inefficiency of the way the government works and the absolute stupidity of a government saying that in no way whatsoever it can reduce spending.

As the Minister for Finance said, add to the government's $5 billion blow-out in taxes expenditure on Mabo compensation as well as expenditure on the Olympic Games, which may not be very much over the next three or so years, and we end up with a very sizeable hole with very sizeable increases in taxes confronting Australians—and a government and a Treasurer who say one thing one day and do another thing the next. This, in the end, is a government which will fall on the issue of taxation. It will fall because it deceived Australians in a way every man, woman and child in this country knows of. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to provide another opportunity for the education of young Alexander.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The Treasurer will refer to the honourable member by his title.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has been struggling mightily with the unequal battle of trying to come to grips with some of the big economic issues confronting this nation. But it is a losing battle as far as the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) is concerned. All he can do is come in here with this kind of overwhelming glee at the sound of his own voice. More than anyone else in this chamber or anyone else in the country, he loves the sound of Alexander Downer. He is like a rattling can—he is a political rattling can—in that he just goes around confronting whatever microphone is thrust in his face, just mouthing these empty words, displaying once again his total inability to come to grips with some of the large issues.

PARA.TAB: Let me make my modest contribution to the education of young Alexander. He is the last remaining member of this kind of second generation Liberal. The Liberals would have liked to have been able to bring in the sons and daughters of the knights. The sons and daughters of the Liberal knights were going to be brought in here as part of the regeneration and the rebuilding of the Liberal Party. They were trying to rebuild and recreate those halcyon days when all those funny old knights used to rattle around in Menzies' cabinet before they were despatched overseas in order to bring up their simple-minded children in the hope that they could follow them into the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Treasurer is demeaning the parliament by his choice of words. I ask that he withdraw that inference against the honourable member for Mayo.
—I said, `their simple-minded children'.
—Order! The Treasurer might help the debate by withdrawing.
—I withdraw.
—The Treasurer has withdrawn.
—We have had the little boys—

—If I could take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: the Treasurer is also casting I think very unwarranted aspersions on a distinguished, deceased former member of this House who not only served this country with distinction in this parliament but also in the Second World War as a prisoner of war. I think his comments are disgraceful, but they are typical of the sort of man he is.
—The Treasurer will get to the matter of public importance.
—I have made no reference—
—You have so.
—I happen to think—
—His father was a decent Australian.

—Of course, there were some distinguished Liberals. What I am saying is that they wanted to bring in the little boys and girls of the Chaneys, the Harrisons, the Downers, the Spenders and the Beales and they thought that this would be the way in which they could rebuild the party. Of course, one by one they have all either rattled through the parliament or rattled out of the parliament, unable to make a hint of the contribution that their forefathers did. But here we have little young Alexander—

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: the Treasurer, who is making his second speech in the parliament since the election, has already spent five minutes of his time on this MPI not talking about the MPI but descending to the worst kind of gutter personal abuse. I would have thought he would have liked to speak about the economy, which is the subject of this debate. I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the economy and taxation are the subjects of this matter of public importance, and the Treasurer is out of order.
—Order! The Treasurer will now get to the matter of public importance.

—I spent the first 10 minutes of the speech of the honourable member for Mayo listening to him throwing his quaint form of puerile abuse at me. I think that what this young fellow over here has got to learn is something about the great issues that confront this country. I would be more than delighted to spend the next 10 minutes educating young Alexander about some of these great issues.
—Order! The Treasurer will refer to the honourable member by his title.

—The young honourable member for Mayo. I want to refer to what has happened to the economy in the two years that I have been the Treasurer of this country. In the first place, we have seen the stock market rise by about 36 per cent; we have seen 10-year bonds fall from their levels of nine per cent to 6.5 per cent; and we have seen home mortgage rates fall from 12 per cent to 8.75 per cent, which translates to a reduction in mortgage payments of about $230 a month for someone with a mortgage of about $100,000 a year. As well as that, we have seen credit card interest rates come down from their peak in 1990 of 24 per cent to 14.5 per cent—in some cases, 11 per cent—representing a real saving to those people who rely on credit cards as a source of credit. In the last six or eight months, we have seen employment increase by 155,000 jobs. Yet did any of these matters pass by the honourable member for Mayo? No. All he could do was descend into his puerile, undergraduate speculation about—

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I refer you to standing order 85 on the question of irrelevant or tedious repetition in a debate. This is about the fifth time that the Treasurer has gone through the same particular point in his speech. I ask you to get the Treasurer to come back to the substance of the debate.
—The honourable member will resume his seat. The Treasurer will continue.

—I repeat to this House what I said to the National Press Club the day after the budget: there is no fiscal imperative for any Commonwealth government tax increases additional to those which have been legislated for in the budget process in order to meet the government's deficit reduction target. This debate really represents a recognition of the failure of the Liberal Party to score one point during the budget debate. It set itself the objective of knocking off four or five tax measures which the government had included in its budget. It succeeded on not one of them: it failed absolutely in the objectives which it set itself.

PARA.TAB: With the support of the House of Representatives and the Senate, the government put into effect a deficit reduction strategy which will see the government's deficit reduction target met in 1996-97. In the context of that deficit reduction strategy, we produced our forward estimates of expenditure and receipts. What a joke that the honourable member for Mayo, in defence of his point, raises Access Economics—otherwise known as `excess economics'.

Of course, Access Economics was the primary architect of the opposition's failed strategy—failed policy—which the people of Australia threw out so absolutely at the time of the last election. Now we find the failed architect of the opposition's policy being drawn in as pessimistic support for its views on where the economy will be in a few years time. It is as though the honourable member for Mayo would welcome the fact that the economy might be growing by only 2 1/2 per cent in a couple of years time.

It seems to me that the honourable member for Mayo is actually trying to wish Australia into slower growth and higher unemployment. The point that the opposition cannot comprehend is that the economy is improving, jobs are being created and the government has now, in legislated form, a deficit reduction strategy, which the opposition sought to wreck but was totally incapable of doing so.

The government has, as any government would, publicly put out its forward projections of expenditure and revenue based on the conservative projections which are included in the economic parameters and announced in the budget. They are assumptions—assumptions derived from the National Fiscal Outlook and supported by the FitzGerald report. From a range of scenarios, we took the midpoint as the basis for those assumptions—a point which, I am quite sure, would be totally lost on the honourable member for Mayo as he struggles to even comprehend what a national fiscal outlook statement might be, and as he struggles to comprehend what a national savings strategy might be.

Over the next three years there will be demands for additional government expenditure—that is inevitable—but the expenditure pressures of which I am aware can be accommodated by the government carefully examining its priorities and achieving cost savings in lower priority areas without the need for additional tax measures in order to meet those demands. We have spent 11 years painfully going through the process of readjusting priorities to take away some of the extravagance of the former Liberal government and reducing, as a proportion of GDP, Commonwealth expenditure from approximately 30 per cent down to about 24 per cent. We are on our way back to about 25 per cent on the basis of the forward estimates.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has established a committee of experts to examine options to assist Australia's unemployed and get them back into sustainable jobs. The committee on employment opportunities will be preparing a green paper and there will be a deliberate process of community consultation to be followed by the publication of a government white paper. In the context of the green paper, ACOSS has proposed a jobs levy to fund additional spending in this area. It has proposed some very considerable expenditures. I do not know whether the community would support those additional expenditures or the kinds of projects which it has in mind or whether, in that context, the community would support the additional revenue raising measures which ACOSS has proposed to fund them.

The government has given no formal consideration to this jobs levy proposal. I do not know whether any such proposal will be contained in the green paper; I am not one of its authors. One thing I do not intend to do now, or during public discussion of the green paper, is to pre-empt that discussion. Whether or not the green paper contains these proposals is a matter which should be quite deliberately considered part of the debate on how the community might best respond to this great issue of employment opportunities for people who are now out of work.

Those who propose these jobs levies must, at the same time, put forward a convincing argument that the expenditures that they are designed to support are efficacious in supporting those who are unemployed. They are obviously the priority group, as far as the government is concerned, in its policy considerations over the next few months.

The government has quite deliberately gone through an open process of putting the issue of employment opportunities on the table. There have been ideas coming in from a range of sources, including ACOSS. At this early stage whilst the green paper is still being prepared, the government does not want to pre-empt the discussion that might continue over the next few months.

Let me repeat, in words that the opposition spokesman might just understand when said for the third time: there is no fiscal imperative to increase taxes to meet the deficit reduction target which the government has set. Does he get it? Has he got it? That is what I said before. That is what I repeat today. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —You are lying; you are always lying.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member for Mayo said across the table, `You are lying; you are always lying'. I require him to withdraw.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—If the honourable member for Mayo did make those statements by way of interjection, he should withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I was saddened when listening to the speech of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) to the House this afternoon because a man who came into this House with great idealism and some ability has fallen so low that he has to resort to such a pernicious attack upon the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). It was low, it was disgraceful, and I think it demonstrates that the Treasurer is unfit for office.

PARA.TAB: In just over three weeks the people of my state, South Australia, will have their chance to say just what they think of Labor's taxes and Labor's promises. It is true to say that they hardly need to look to Canberra for an excuse to throw out the state Labor government. There are already 3.5 billion good reasons to dump Lynn Arnold and his team of incompetents. If, as expected, the State Bank needs yet another bailout there will be a few million more.

The tax cuts delivered this week will give Australians an extra $1.66 billion in their pockets this financial year, and an additional $12.2 billion in the next four years. But the tax increases that this `no new taxes' government has brought in mean that every Australian will be forced to shell out an extra $1,800 to the government over the next four years. Ordinary Australians know that they will be worse off. Labor's new taxes mean that every household will be slugged for an additional $5,650 on top of the taxes that they are already paying.

People will not forget that the Labor Party dumped the second round of tax cuts—tax cuts estimated to be worth $5.2 billion in 1995-96; tax cuts that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) promised them. At least South Australians will have an opportunity to pass a comment on 11 December. The comment will not be kind; it will be harsh, it will be brutal and it will be deserved.

The clowns from Adelaide's Trades Hall are busy shouting about the privations that they say South Australians will suffer under a Liberal government. It could be observed that it is only to be expected that members of a political organisation dumb enough to lose $3.5 billion would not be able to tell the difference between Dean Brown's Liberals and Jeff Kennett.

The Premier announced the election date in the suburb of Barton, a new development in his electorate on the very edge of Adelaide's northern suburbs. One of his minders told a journalist that he picked the location to show his support for working South Australians. Despite this, the people of Barton—and the dozens of suburbs like it—will be the ones who suffer most from Labor's losses. They are the ones who have had to wait longer to get new schools. They have poorer social services and community facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about what is happening in Victoria?

—In South Australia the government has closed 170 schools, I might tell my friend the honourable member for Gilmore. Do not talk to me about Victoria. The people of Barton have less access to public utilities such as proper sewerage, they have worse roads and less frequent transport serving fewer routes. However, they paid more in taxes and charges as the government desperately tried to wipe the slate clean.

PARA.TAB: The Keating government is hitting exactly the same people. Its tax cuts help high income earners. Its tax increases are highly regressive. Ordinary Australians are paying more every time they fill up the family car after dropping the kids to school, driving to work, getting to sport, or whatever. They are paying more every time they buy a soft drink. They are paying more if they buy household appliances or electrical goods. They are paying more when they grab a cask of wine for the barbecue or the picnic. They are even giving more money to the government every time they buy an absolute essential like a pack of soap.

This is how the Labor Party shows its support for true believers. It rips them off without any shame. It mouths pieties. It repeats worn phrases all the time, and they mean nothing to the government. The Labor Party dares to portray us as rapacious exploiters, as vindictive would-be oligarches, jealous of what ordinary Australians have been able to achieve, whilst the government's tax measures destroy the living standards and even the livelihoods of the people that it claims to champion. Labor now intends to further increase taxes. Rather than look for savings, rather than trim its programs, rather than toss fewer grants to its marginal seats, or make government run better, it intends to wring more money out of innocent taxpayers.

The sudden bout of candour of the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) last week has let the cat out of the bag. The government cannot satisfy its deficit reduction strategy without resorting to higher taxes. Projections tabled in the Senate have shown that tax revenue needs to grow by 8.1 per cent in real terms in the next financial year, by six per cent in 1995-96, and by five per cent in 1996-97 to meet the target. That means that the government needs an average real growth of 6.4 per cent over the three years, or a nominal increase in the tax take between this year and the 1996-97 financial year of a whopping 32 per cent.

If the government is to raise this revenue, it has only three options. It can do so through higher inflation; we all know how likely and how damaging this option would be. It can do so through strong growth; that is what the government likes to think it is doing, but there are very real concerns over the actual state of the economy. Reports have suggested that Treasury and the Reserve Bank believe economic growth is still weak. Many private sector economists have forecast substantially lower growth in the September quarter. If we have an upturn, it is slow, cyclical and unable to produce anything more than an unacceptably low rate of growth.

Figures produced by Access Economics show that the budget has overestimated economic growth, which will reduce government income, lead to greater expenditure and place the government deficit reduction target in even greater jeopardy. That leaves only one option: increased or more new taxes. In August, at budget time, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) told the National Press Club, `There will be no fiscal imperative on us to raise further taxes'. Now the finance minister has finally come clean. The government likes to claim that we are a low tax country. It holds up statistics comparing us to the United States and Europe. However, tax levels in Australia are double those of our east Asian neighbours. If Australia is to compete effectively in our region taxation levels must be reduced, not increased. The government's high tax policies do not just cost Australians more money, they cost them jobs. Labor's promises are empty.

But at least in South Australia we are going to get the chance to tell the ALP just how worthless it is. In South Australia, the people will not just be tossing out ministers—such as Greg Crafter, Kym Mayes, Bob Gregory and John Klunder—because of their gross financial mismanagement, they will be giving the ALP a record hiding because they know that Labor governments cannot be trusted. The people know that all the glossy brochures and all the pious words are, and can be, disregarded. They know that Labor's pre-election promises mean absolutely nothing.

The people know all this because they have seen how the Keating government behaves. They all remember the solemn pledges not to increase taxes that this government made. They all saw the Prime Minister put on his hurt look and tell us that tax cuts were law. The people all learnt on 17 August that they had been conned.

What makes the Labor Party and its union mates' much voiced support for the poor, for the underprivileged and for ordinary Australians that honourable members opposite keep talking about—in South Australia and nationwide—so absolutely sickening, is the actual way it governs. John Bannon, Lynn Arnold and the rest of the South Australian Labor ministry have managed to lose more than $3 billion. Ordinary South Australians will pay for it. But on 11 December, the South Australian Labor Party will pay the ultimate price.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to this matter of public importance, it is worth noting that we had, first of all, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) speaking about Australia Post and virtually everything else except the matter that is before the chair. Then we had the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) wanting to basically play some role in the South Australian election campaign, and that was really the sum total of his contribution to the matter of public importance.

PARA.TAB: When we come back to what are the key issues—and we look at, first of all, the government's deficit reduction strategy and the question of taxation—we find that the government can quite rightly point to the very positive steps that have been taken to reduce the overall level of income tax, particularly to increase the competitive position of business relating to taxation, to ensure that we have a fair taxation system and to ensure that the sorts of regressive, negative and damaging impacts that the Liberals would have sought to impose if it won the 1993 election, which were so soundly rejected, are not allowed to be revisited.

The opposition really hates the fact that the Australian economy is starting to turn around. It really detests the fact that the Australian economy has not double dipped but has kept growing. We have now had seven quarters of positive growth in the economy. That is something that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) willed his hardest not to happen, but it has happened in spite of him.

We have had constant suggestions that there would need to be a move to push up interest rates when bill rates have kept coming down. We have had the constant suggestion that there needs to be changes at the fiscal end because of our overall position in the world economy. Almost anywhere one goes around the world, people looking at Australia have said, `You have had seven quarters of positive growth. You have had some fiscal expansion in the short term to help create the economic stimulus that is required'. This government started doing that but we were decried by the opposition in the One Nation statement as following the wrong strategy.

It is interesting to note that, since then, the new Japanese government has decided that there needs to be some fiscal stimulus to get its economy going. At one stage some of those opposite felt that Canada should be the model to be followed. But Canada's government lost the election—in fact, it was wiped out. It had some of the policies that some of those opposite advocated before our last election. I think Canada had a GST, or some similar sort of beast, but the Canadian people, and the new government, have now said, `These are issues that were wrong. We have to go back and change. Apart from anything else, we have to have some fiscal stimulus in the short term for our economy'.

After two decades of the opposition encouraging and promoting an environment with high inflation and high interest rates, and after the 1982-83 recessionary period with double digit interest rates and inflation, this government has moved to get interest rates down to their lowest level in 30 years, and to get inflation down. Yet the opposition says that it has the answers today.

Nothing it has said adds anything to the economic debate. The tax cuts delivered last Monday are the tax cuts that the opposition opposed being delivered seven months early. It tried its hardest in the Senate to get the budget measures knocked over. It was desperate to stop those measures being brought forward. The honourable member for Sturt, who suggested that taxes be put off and scrapped, was one of those who opposed giving the tax cuts seven months early. He should be accountable to his electorate for trying to stop average wage earners in his electorate getting their tax cuts delivered on 15 November.

Then there is the question of taxation relating to business and the competitiveness of Australian business versus similar economies in the region. This government has already moved to cut the level of company taxation from 39 per cent to 33 per cent. It is certainly competitive with our trading partners and with countries in the region. At the same time, I believe that the opposition still has a policy of going back to a 42 per cent company tax rate. It actually wants to take the company tax rate to above 39 per cent. I do not know what the rest of its taxation policy is. One thing for sure is that in the contribution of the honourable member for Mayo we did not get one fact, one suggestion or one comment about what the opposition's taxation arrangements might be in the future—not even half a policy.

As far as we can understand it, its GST has gone; it has learnt that lesson. It took the opposition a few months too long to learn it, but it did. We also know that Senator Bishop, the would-be leader, believes that things such as capital gains tax have to go. I do not know how many of the other taxation arrangements that are in place have to go. We have had no policy statement from the opposition on those issues. We assume that it still has the $10 billion worth of public expenditure cuts that were part of its package before the election. If anyone wants to know a recipe to damage the people who most need assistance in the economy, a slashing of $10 billion worth of outlays is the sure way to ensure that happens.

Over the next two to three years, Australia needs to keep promoting the level of growth which has occurred in recent times. That is the fundamentally important policy objective for Australia. That needs to be the driving force for keeping the economic strategy in line because the deficit reduction strategy over the next four years, when we get down to approximately one per cent of GDP by 1996-97, is built around continuing to get stable, consistent and positive economic policies, an appropriate level of fiscal outlays over that time, and a gradual winding back as the private sector picks up its momentum through that period and jobs grow at the same time. The last lot of employment data clearly show that that process is occurring very positively and that participation rates are growing.

According to the honourable member for Mayo, one of the reasons why we had to put up new taxes was that Sydney was successful in its bid to host the Olympic Games. In bidding for the Olympic Games, the Premier of New South Wales made it very clear that the New South Wales government felt that it could run the games without having to raise any funds from the Commonwealth or elsewhere, other than the $150 million that the federal government has already committed to the project. Time and time again the New South Wales Liberal Party said publicly that that was the net contribution required. So, really, the honourable member for Mayo should go back and ask his state Liberal colleague in New South Wales why those facts changed within about 24 hours of Sydney successfully bidding for the games.

I turn now to look quickly at the concerns relating to revenue and the way the government has managed its fiscal position over the 10 years we have been in office and contrast that with what has occurred in the past. This government had three successive budget surpluses in the late 1980s, highlighting the fact that we maintain stringent controls over outlays, closely monitor expenditure and undertake a very vigorous process through the expenditure review committee looking at all the line items of expenditure and take appropriate action to ensure that the overall budget position is kept within responsible bounds.

Contrast those three years of budget surpluses, when the economy was moving strongly, with the approach of the opposition parties when in government. Even when the economy was growing quite strongly, the coalition parties in government still had deficit after deficit and one problem after another in being able to rein in expenditure and maintain a responsible budget. When we are faced with the cyclical impact of the recession and the severity of the needs of many in the community, the opposition suggests that somehow expenditure can be slashed and that ordinary citizens and those who are in need should not be given financial assistance.

In both the preparation of the green paper that is coming and the major employment statement that will follow, the government has made it clear that it will not leave behind the people who need assistance—namely, the people who, responsibly, should be considered as part of the changing conditions in the economy, as part of the structural changes that are occurring in the economy. The government will take account of the needs of those people. The government will ensure both sound and responsible budget outlays. The government will also ensure a socially humane and effective policy of a broad infrastructure net to look after all the needs of the community, across all the regions of Australia, including those regions with particular problems.

For that reason, I say very strongly that the deficit reduction plan that has been adopted will stay; it is workable and it will be achieved. The economy will continue to grow and prosper because of the positive and constructive policies the government has put in place over recent years. It ill becomes the opposition to keep trying to talk the Australian economy down and trying to wreak more harm on the people of Australia at the very time we should be trying to give the hope and stimulus that the figures in the economic performance suggest are quite rightly occurring each and every day. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Johns) has indicated, these amendments have been agreed to in the Senate. If I read what happened in the Senate debate correctly, it had an explanatory memorandum; but we are not favoured with the same information in this House. I suppose that is not altogether surprising. These amendments comprise proposals to the government, at the behest of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. Further amendments are proposed on the initiative of the opposition, in the person of Senator John Watson.

PARA.TAB: I have just received a copy of the Senate explanatory memorandum. Perhaps the parliamentary secretary could enlighten the committee on why we did not get some information. It is important that the House contribute to debate on the legislation. In the debate here on 27 September, when about seven bills were debated cognately after they had been introduced, we were presented with up to 20 pages of amendments—subsequent to the presentation of the bills before the House.

Now we have another few pages. This demonstrates the government's ad hoc approach to legislation on superannuation. Combining those circumstances with the bills under consideration, and the fact that there have been 14 or 15 major amendments to superannuation legislation during the term of this Labor government, it can be understood why practitioners in the industry, possible beneficiaries and superannuants are at a loss to know where they stand and what are their rights and obligations.

This is very messy legislation. One can only hope that when the amendments are passed the act, as it will become, will be in a better and more readable condition than the information we were given even in the first instance in September and now in the bill before the House. It makes a farce of the summing up to the second reading debate by the parliamentary secretary in September when he offered a stout defence of the government's skill in drafting legislation. It was wrong at the time for the reasons I have given. We had up to 20 pages of amendments to consider to legislation which previously had been lodged in the House. Now we have more. At one stage he even claimed they were right on top of superannuation legislation. Today's events and those in September give the lie to that proposition.

It is of some credit to Senator Watson, who chaired the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, that the legislation—by these further amendments—is being knocked into some sort of shape. As I have said before in other contexts, if we devoted more time in this place to the legislative process, and if the House were given the sort of information that is provided to the Senate at the second reading stage and the subsequent committee stage, we might not have to go through all this agony in deliberating Senate amendments. The Senate truly is the legislative chamber. We have let that role go by default. Having said that, and subject to anything the parliamentary secretary might say, we support the amendments. We regret only that they were not incorporated in the original legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the amendment be disagreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: If people were following the debate on the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Bill 1993 in the Senate, they would know that the Greens, the Australian Democrats and the Liberals have moved that the government consider the notion that we establish a legal and advisory service for those involved in superannuation disputes with their trustees. I think those people have failed to understand that in fact the government will establish a tribunal through this bill and will establish a secretariat of some 18 people who will be able to look after consumers' interests and will spend about $800,000 doing it. It is the wish of people, in addition to those moves, to establish a consumer legal service for the express purposes of representing individuals before the tribunal.

PARA.TAB: It is my view that the tribunal will act in an inquiry manner. We prefer not to have an advocacy situation which will probably spin out these questions and make them more expensive. Whilst a number of honourable senators in the other house were suggesting that we establish such an independent legal service, they did not want to fund it—they did not want to push us that far—but they asked us for some reasons. They wanted our reasoning on this question of support for a legal and advisory service. So I am here today to provide those reasons.

I think that the government is doing a great deal in spending about $800,000 to establish a tribunal. Individuals will be given free access to it and will be allowed the assistance of a secretariat of some 18 people. That will be free of charge to the individual. The tribunal will be looking for conciliation of matters—not just an arbitration of them. I think that is essential. We feel that, in most instances, these cases will be able to be conciliated and will not require a decision by the tribunal standing in the shoes of the trustees.

Keep in mind also that we have not yet established the tribunal. It will not be up and working until July next year. I think it needs some time to bed down, to see how many cases it gets, what sorts of cases it gets, the complexity of those cases and the ratio of successful and unsuccessful decisions, et cetera. I think we will build a good system. The tribunal will be independent. The secretariat will be separate from the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. There is no reason why it should side with individuals, trustees or insurance companies. The tribunal can be truly independent, and I think we should show good faith in going along with the bill unamended. We do not support the notion of spending another $666,000 to establish a legal and advisory service. I believe we have already done that work by establishing the tribunal and the secretariat.

TALK.START.PARA: —The assurances of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Johns) are noted and are welcome. I think what concerned our colleagues in the Senate was the inevitability that many of the people wishing to have matters resolved would be relatively unsophisticated and unskilled in the vagaries of the relevant legislation. The parliamentary secretary says that the tribunal to be established will fulfil the role. The coalition is prepared to accept that at least for the time being. But I urge the honourable gentleman and his government to keep it in mind that tribunals tend to become captives of themselves and that, depending on the way they are established, their guidelines and stated objectives, they may fail to provide the protection that could otherwise be provided in a manner suggested by the Senate.

PARA.TAB: One of the things which I am sure would have concerned the Senate is that, whilst there will be a tribunal, access to it will be necessarily difficult for people not living within the vicinity of where that tribunal is established. As far as I know—I stand to be corrected by the parliamentary secretary—the tribunal is not to be represented in other states and in other capital cities. Remembering that people who will need the assistance the tribunal sets out to provide will be spread around the country, it is difficult to imagine how they can get access without—in some cases anyway—going to considerable expense. So there is the prospect that the facilities the tribunal might be able to provide will not be there for everyone to use.

As I have said, the parliamentary secretary can correct me if I am wrong in any of the fundamental assumptions I have made in arriving at that conclusion. Given the relative novelty of the principal proposal, it is, however, reasonable to allow some time to see how it beds down and to see whether the objectives of the Senate and the coalition can be satisfied. A sum of money has been mentioned by the parliamentary secretary in giving this extra protection to superannuants and those who might want to refer matters for conciliation and resolution. We will be prepared to wait to see how the program goes. The expenditure of $660,000-odd is considerable and not to be undertaken lightly. Given, as I say, the novelty of the program itself, we perhaps should wait to see how it goes. I urge the government, however, to keep the matter under review.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) for his comments and consideration of our point of view. To explain one element, we do not envisage that many will come in person to the tribunal. Most of the work will be done on paper, but we are open to the notion of telephoning, video conferences and so forth. The honourable member is quite right: people should have access to the tribunal despite their being located perhaps in Perth. But we want as much as possible to keep this program non-adversarial, based on paperwork with qualified people sitting as tribunal members with the assistance of a secretariat. As yet, none of us knows how many people or how complex the cases will be. In that instance, I am grateful to the honourable member's views that we should let the program settle in so that we can have a good look at it to see how it works over a reasonable period. We can then always revisit these questions.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.
Motion (by Mr Johns) agreed to:
That Mr Hollis, Mr Price and the mover be appointed a committee to draw up reasons for the House of Representatives disagreeing to the amendment of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns The Hon G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the committee appointed to draw up reasons for the House disagreeing to the amendment of the Senate, I present the reasons which are being circulated to honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: Reasons for the House of Representatives disagreeing to the amendment of the Senate

PARA.TAB: The House rejects the amendment of the Senate for the following reasons:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.The Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Bill 1993 makes provision for complainants to be assisted by the Tribunal in making complaints.
Under the Bill the tribunal is obliged to:

TAB.TAB: assist a person in making a complaint (clause 16); and

make arrangements so that information about how complaints may be lodged and how they will be resolved are made reasonably available to members of regulated superannuation funds and beneficiaries of approved deposit funds (clause 13);

SPEECH.PARA: These services will be provided by the Tribunal through a full-time secretariat based in Sydney, which will be able to be contacted from anywhere in Australia through a toll free (008) telephone number. Offices of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission in State capital cities will also be able to assist and refer complainants to the secretariat.
The Tribunal will be in the best position to assist complainants, assess a complainants problem and to determine whether or not the Tribunal can hear the complaint.

The Tribunal and its secretariat can be relied upon to provide accurate and impartial assistance in resolving complaints. The secretariat who will, in practice provide the assistance to complainants will be staffed by public servants who have no vested interest in the outcome.

Given that the Bill addresses the concerns raised by the consumer movement in proposing the service, it is highly questionable whether the $660,000 needed for its establishment is an appropriate use of public revenue.

2.Should the Government endorse mandatory referral of complainants to a Service of the kind proposed, there would be pressure for lawyers from the service to represent the complainants before the Tribunal.
This would undermine the objectives of the Tribunal as a low cost, informal and expeditious disputes resolution mechanism.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Johns) agreed to:
That the committee's reasons be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the sixth, seventh and eighth reports of the committee for 1993 relating to partial refurbishment stage 1, Commonwealth Centre, Hobart; construction of air traffic control centres at Brisbane and Melbourne; and upgrading of Mount Wellington broadcasting facilities, Hobart.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The committee's sixth report of 1993 relates to a proposal sponsored by Australian Estate Management for the partial refurbishment of the Hobart Commonwealth Centre stage 1. AEM proposes to refurbish and upgrade the five upper floors of the office accommodation, the ground floor lobby area and associated building infrastructure. Some asbestos present in the 14th floor plant room will also be removed. The net lettable area of office space to be refurbished is 4,600 square metres. The limit of cost estimate for the project when referred to the committee was $8.3 million at September 1993 prices.

PARA.TAB: AEM is a budget funded operation of the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services and has overall responsibility to government for the management and development of the Commonwealth's office estate. In 1989 the Commonwealth's office estate was commercialised and departments were charged for the first time for the use of accommodation. In 1991, as part of the public sector reform process, the government decided to allow all departments to negotiate office leasing arrangements.

This effectively means that AEM is now in direct competition with the private sector in providing office accommodation to departments. The only exception to this is in the ACT where departments are still tied to the Commonwealth for the approval of changes in office accommodation.

The Hobart site was acquired by the Commonwealth in 1969 and the stage 1 building was completed and occupied in 1974. The stage 1 building provides over 15,000 square metres of office accommodation or about 25 per cent of the total Commonwealth requirements in Hobart. The stage 2 building was completed in May 1992, and comprises some 9,000 square metres of office accommodation.

In August 1991 the government approved the development of cost estimates and detailed design for the refurbishment of the stage 1 building. Later investigations, however, established that a refurbishment of the entire building was not at that time viable due to insufficient tenant interest for the space available. In December 1992 a reduced scope of refurbishment work was agreed by government subject to tenant commitment to occupancy of the refurbished space. The commitment was subsequently obtained and approval to proceed to reference to the committee was given on 14 April 1993.

Until November 1992 the stage 1 building was fully tenanted. At this time, the Australian Taxation Office relocated to an adjacent building leased from the private sector under a pre-commitment lease arrangement. The ATO relocation left some 7,000 square metres of space in the building vacant. Although AEM sought to retain ATO as a tenant it was unable to guarantee funds for the refurbishment of the building in a time frame which suited ATO's operational requirements.

The stage 1 building is ideally located close to major retail, business and service outlets. It is also close to public transport and public parking facilities and is readily accessible to both the public and building tenants.

The present condition of the stage 1 building and the standard of accommodation it offers is, however, below the requirements of expectations of tenant departments and also well below that provided in the market generally. It is therefore unattractive to potential tenants and is not competitive in its unrefurbished state. The building does not comply with current building standards and the condition of the decor and finishes has deteriorated with protracted use. In addition, the building services are nearing the end of their economic life and do not meet the operational or energy efficiency needs of modern office accommodation—a bit of a mess, in other words.

The Commonwealth owns some 27,000 square metres of office space in Hobart and also leases a further 33,000 square metres from the private sector. The committee was concerned to note that stage 1 of the Commonwealth Centre contains some nine floors containing 8,000 square metres of office space that it is not proposed to refurbish until tenants have been identified. However, at the public hearing AEM advised the committee that it believes there is a potential market among Commonwealth tenants currently in privately leased buildings of some 10,000 square metres over the next three to five years. In addition, AEM believes that it is possible that there will be some growth by the tenants that have committed themselves to the five floors to be refurbished over this period.

The committee recognises that the new government policy regarding the renting of Commonwealth accommodation does make departments more aware of the real cost of accommodation. However, it is concerned that policy may not be in the best overall interests of the Commonwealth if it leads to Commonwealth facilities remaining vacant while government departments lease private accommodation. The committee does not believe that it makes good sense for such a high proportion of the space in an asset such as the Hobart Commonwealth Centre, which is located in a prime position, to remain vacant while departments are renting private accommodation in adjacent buildings.

The committee, while agreeing that there is a need to refurbish the 4,600 square metres of stage 1 of the Commonwealth Centre as proposed in this reference, has also concluded that there is a need to refurbish as part of this project the remaining floors of stage 1 in order to attract additional tenants. The committee has also recommended that the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) should undertake a review of the current policy regarding the provision of office accommodation for Commonwealth departments to ensure that the operation of the policy is in the best overall interests of the Commonwealth and encourages the maximum utilisation of existing Commonwealth office accommodation.

The second report which I have tabled deals with the proposed construction of air traffic control centres in Brisbane and Melbourne required for the Australian advanced air traffic system, otherwise known as TAAATS. This project, as many would be aware, has had a long and somewhat tortuous passage. I remind the House that the proposed works were originally referred to the committee early last year. We had numerous public and private hearings in Brisbane, Canberra and Perth amidst considerable controversy concerning the awarding of the TAAATS contract to Thomson Radar Australia Corporation Pty Ltd.

This controversy spilled over into the committee's inquiry, although I made it plain at the outset that the committee did not wish to involve itself in issues relating to equipment contracts. A large number of witnesses expressed unease about the processes which had resulted in the CAA awarding the contract to Thomson. As a result, and because of the unwillingness or inability of key Civil Aviation Authority witnesses to answer key questions, I made a statement in the House on 3 June last year which called on the then Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Cook, to set up an independent panel to carry out a thorough review.

To Senator Cook's enduring credit, he appointed the Honourable Ian Macphee to undertake the review. The rest is now history. Mr Macphee's report was scathing of senior officials of the CAA and recommended that the tender selection process should be restarted with both Hughes and Thomson being involved in specification development before submitting competitive bids.

The proposal was re-referred to the committee in July. We had public and private hearings in Brisbane in October, and there was a profound change in attitude towards the committee by the key players at the hearings. The chief executive officer of the CAA, Doug Roser, led the CAA's team of witnesses and answered all our questions in a frank and open manner. There was no equivocation. We were given detailed briefings on the building designs by both tenderers.

The committee also had the benefit of advice from an independent auditor who was appointed to report to the CAA board on the relevance, integrity, probity and fairness of the evaluation of tenders. The committee's report recommends that the works should proceed.

For too long Australia's air traffic control system has been a patchwork of hybrid systems some of which are ancient, some of which are relatively modern, whose installation was subject to the vagaries of the budget processes every year. The TAAATS project is a bold initiative. It will provide integration of all en route air traffic control in two centres—one in Brisbane and the other in Melbourne. Both centres require to be in modern buildings incorporating sophisticated building services. Brisbane and Melbourne are suitable locations, being at the termination points of existing communications infrastructure.

The private briefings which were given to the committee by the tenderers demonstrated to the satisfaction of the committee that the dimensions and functional layout of the centres proposed by them are adequate and provide for future expansion if necessary. The committee intends to maintain a watching brief on the project as it progresses and we have recommended as a first step that the CAA brief us on the detailed design of each centre following the awarding of the TAAATS contract in December.

Terminal control units, which will be responsible for controlling air traffic in the vicinity of major airports, such as Sydney, Perth, Cairns and Adelaide, will also be provided as part of the project. The committee has concluded that the extent of the work required to accommodate these units is justified and makes good use of existing buildings.

In conclusion, the report makes the observation that the project has had a long and tortuous development. The committee's report, which I have just tabled, and the awarding of the TAAATS contract in December, will mark the end of a painful process, from which a lot has been learned, and the beginning of a new chapter in Australian aviation.

The third—and, thankfully, final—report which I have tabled today refers to the proposed upgrading of broadcasting facilities at Mount Wellington in Hobart. The existing Commonwealth owned transmission tower has been significantly modified during its life and carries additional services for which it was not originally intended. The tower is not capable of further major extension and is nearing the end of its useful life due to structural fatigue.

The proposal by the National Transmission Agency, the NTA, involves the construction of a tower consisting of a 70-metre tapered concrete shaft supporting a 60-metre steel frame upon which is mounted several transmission antennas and a protective fibreglass radar. The work also includes alterations and upgrading of the existing transmitter building, demolition of the existing broadcasting tower and site rehabilitation. The estimated cost of the work is $13.095 million at September 1993 prices.

A new tower is required in order to achieve government policy for the expansion of broadcasting services; to improve the quality of services already provided to the Hobart public by increasing their reliability through overcoming technical difficulties in the existing tower; to improve the safety of the public and maintenance workers at the site; and to reduce maintenance costs. Construction of the new tower will also provide an opportunity to reduce the environmental impact of transmission facilities on Mount Wellington.

The national services transmitted from the existing tower are subject to interruption for periods some ten times longer than equivalent services in other metropolitan areas of Australia. This is a result of faults caused by the poor condition of the tower and the NTA's inability to gain access to the structure in adverse weather conditions to rectify the faults. In order to bring further broadcasting services to Southern Tasmania and to pre-empt the possible structural failure of the existing tower, the proposal to erect a new structure at the existing site on Mount Wellington was developed.

The proposed tower must accommodate services currently transmitted from the existing tower and, in addition, it needs to provide capacity for the proposed new television licensee, Southern Cross TV and for additional FM radio services. The NTA has also allowed capacity for all foreseeable broadcasting and radio communication needs.

Consideration was also given to providing capacity for the existing Hobart commercial television licensee, Tasmanian Television, to be accommodated on the tower on the existing VHF channel 6. This would have required a tower 151 metres in height compared to the NTA proposal to the committee of 130 metres in height and an additional cost of approximately $2 million. However, Tasmanian Television has not agreed to move from its existing facility on Mount Wellington and was not prepared to give any commitment to using the VHF capacity if such additional capacity was to be included in the new tower.

During the inquiry it became clear to the committee that a desirable objective is a consolidation of all broadcasting facilities on Mount Wellington into one tower. At issue is the ability to remove an existing transmission facility located on Mount Wellington owned and operated by Tasmanian Television.

The NTA advised the committee that the management of Tasmanian Television has consistently and repeatedly stated that they have no plans to share the proposed NTA facility. While provision was not made on the tower proposal referred to the committee for Tasmanian Television's present VHF channel, provision was made to accommodate it on a UHF channel. However, at the public hearing NTA advised the committee that it was now able to offer Tasmanian Television VHF capacity without the need for the additional 21 metres of tower column. This would entail the installation of an antenna system on the NTA facility which would enable capacity for Tasmanian Television's channel 6 to be provided in the NTA proposal. In agreeing that the NTA proposal should proceed the committee has also recommended that the Commonwealth should consult with the management of Tasmanian Television regarding the possible use of a VHF facility by Tasmanian Television in the upgraded broadcasting facility.

The committee has also concluded that there is no environmentally or socially acceptable alternatives to the continued use of Mount Wellington as a broadcasting transmission site. The committee has further concluded that the proposed integration of the NTA's proposal with the proposed aerial tramway service to the summit of Mount Wellington is not practical and would lead to unacceptable delays in the provision of upgraded broadcasting facilities on Mount Wellington. Mr Deputy Speaker, I commend the reports to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS REFORM BILL 1993Cognate Bill:INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS COURT (JUDGES' REMUNERATION) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 17 November, on motion by Mr Brereton.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Industrial Relations Reform Bill. Its purpose is to give more flexibility in the industrial relations area by facilitating enterprise bargaining while maintaining the historical safety net of the award structure as a protection for working people in Australia. That has been there since just after Federation. I believe that because we have those awards in place it assists Australians to have the quality of life which they presently enjoy.

PARA.TAB: I was very interested to listen to the arguments of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), who were the two main speakers from the other side to oppose this bill. I was disappointed by both their speeches. They did not seem to get into the hype which I thought they would. I think their arguments have basically been rejected by most of the speeches from this side already.

There are a couple of points I want to deal with first of all. Their main argument was the continuing one of reducing conditions and wages for the Australian work force; that somehow, if we did that, it would be a magic answer to unemployment and there would be great productivity gains. That argument is totally wrong and this side of the House has continually rejected it.

The honourable member for Bennelong used figures from the United States. He said that the US had only six per cent unemployment and, therefore, there was something wrong with us because we had a more flexible labour market yet our figures were at 11 per cent. The figures that I got from America last year were 7.4 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The shadow minister at the table says that it is now 6.5 per cent. Let me quote him a few other figures on unemployment from the United Kingdom and other OECD countries. Unemployment in the United Kingdom in 1992 was at 10.1 per cent; in Canada, 11.3 per cent; Denmark, 11.1 per cent; and, Spain, 18.4 per cent. For the smaller countries in Europe, the figure was around 10.6 per cent. New Zealand, with its great cuts in wages and the social conflict that has been caused, was at 10.3 per cent. The average figure for OECD countries stood at about eight per cent, with most of the European Economic Community on an average 10.1 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The argument that was put forward by the honourable member for Bennelong really falls down on those figures. He was very selective in the figures that he used. His argument was that the US has more poverty, bigger collapses of family life and dislocation of its social infrastructure than Australia, but it has less unemployment. I thought the argument was rather shallow. I believe that one of the problems in the United States is that it does not have an award structure and workers in that country certainly do not have the protection that they have in this country. I believe that some of the workers in America are very poor and that there is a certain level of working poor that we do not have in this country.

Wages can be reduced to any level. If wages are reduced, we will get people who are very poor, trying to survive on wages that leave them no dignity. They are reduced to poverty, even though they have a job. Sometimes they have to rely on charities to survive. In summary, that is the position at the bottom end of the America labour market.

We do not have as many breakdowns in our families or the same levels of poverty in this country as America, mainly because we have an award safety net. I also believe that our unemployment benefits and other social benefits are superior to that available in America. In recent times, in the area of health, that has been pointed out quite openly through our media. So the argument of the honourable member for Bennelong about unemployment rates in Australia—which took up about two-thirds of his speech—is very shallow.

The Labor Party, as it did during the election campaign, rejects the position that cutting wages and conditions is in some way the simple answer to solving unemployment. It is not. We rejected it and we went to the election on it. The Liberals ran on a policy along those lines and were rejected by the people. The Labor Party stands for an increase in productivity, and that comes through training, improvement in job quality, lowering the amount of middle management and improving the overall performance of a company. Those things will improve productivity more than cutting wages will. Most of the academic reading in this area that I do now, and have done in the last couple of months, points exactly to the fact that, by cutting wages or by having a low wage economy, we cannot get quality production, goods and organisations within manufacturing.

The honourable member for Bennelong commented about women in the work force and the increase in part-time work in Australia. The situation only mirrors what is happening in most other countries. If we look at figures in other countries comparable to our own, we see exactly the same thing. There has been a great surge in part-time work and an increase in the amount of women in the work force. They are changes in society which all of those economies and societies similar to ours have to accept.

The honourable member for Bennelong made a comment in relation to manufacturing generally. Those opposite have finally worked out that Australian manufacturing workers are not paid exorbitant rates; that in the United States, Europe, Japan and some other places in the world, comparable rates in manufacturing and some other areas are well in front of what Australian workers receive. I only saw that briefly today in an article in the Australian Financial Review, which pointed out in addition that there are countries in Asia where, for some comparable classifications, wage rates are higher than in Australia. Indeed, there is a lot of evidence now that indicates that the argument from the other side is rather poor.

This bill will only continue to strengthen the direction in which Australia has been going in making its labor market more flexible. The sacrifices made by Australian workers over the last ten to twelve years have been enormous. I do not think that that has been understood by the other side of the House at all. There has been a 10 per cent reduction in the real costs of labour since about 1983. In my own state of Tasmania, the restructuring in most of the major industries that has replaced workers with machines has been enormous. Most of those companies have done that through negotiation and enterprise bargaining with their work force. There was one company that did not—APPM at its mill at Burnie. Egged on by the other side of the House—including the honourable member for Bennelong—the company went down the track of saying, `We own the capital and the workers will do what we tell them'. That was the philosophy undertaken by that company. The workers were not going to do that.

Instead of having decent negotiations, instead of looking at itself as a company that had not restructured over the years but needed to, instead of having labour and capital going down the one road, that company went down a road of bitterness and struggle which divided the town then and continues to do so. I hope that Amcor, the new manager of the APPM plants, will show—I am sure it will—the same progressive, modern management that it has shown in its Victorian plants where it has restructured through agreement with unions.

I want to mention the Tasmanian Liberal government's position on industrial relations and its move to enterprise bargaining. It changed the state industrial acts and went down the same road as that advocated by the honourable member for Bennelong. The first case involved a firm called Delta Hydraulics. The company is headed by a Mr White, one of the leading New Right members in Tasmania. He set up a ballot in his factory. He told the workers that he would sack 20 of them if they did not sign the agreement. His argument was, `I have to reduce costs', otherwise he would have to sack so many. Most of the employees signed it.

There were several union members in that factory, and they took up the issue with the union. A commissioner was appointed under the act to hear the matter. The union applied to represent its members at the hearing. The union informed the commissioner that it wanted to appear on behalf of its members in an industrial matter. Under the state act the commissioner refused the members representation.

The worst feature of that case was that the union claimed duress on behalf of its members. The commissioner saw the employees, seven at a time, and sat them at a table. He talked to them. He said that he had many years experience in industrial relations, and that he could see by the men's body language that they were not under any duress. That caused a lot of concern to those of us who were dreading the final outcome of this act.

Another ballot was held without consultation with the employees. The commissioner upheld the agreement and denied the union members the right to reject it. The result was a divided work force. Employees who were not directly involved on the factory floor—office staff and others—voted in the ballot for an enterprise bargain. Those people had no overtime and shift penalties to lose—unlike the tradesmen on the floor.

There was a reduction from 10 to eight hours in the rest period between shifts. There were less travelling provisions than those contained in the award. In-laws were taken out of the bereavement list that was contained in the award. The payment of sick leave was lower than the hourly rate prescribed in the award. Overall, there was a reduction in conditions for the people working in this factory.
