The commissioner asked the employer what productivity gains would be achieved by the implementation of this agreement under the state act. The first time he was asked the employer would not reply. Following a second question, the employer responded that there would be savings to the company by way of labour flexibility.

Following that and several other cases before that same commissioner in Tasmania, he made a public statement that the act was unfair and unjust in the sense that he believed that the act was only being used to reduce wages and conditions and had nothing to do with productivity. The state government in Tasmania has still not moved to amend the act. We accept that it was probably the original intention of the act—in line with Liberal Party policy—that if wages and conditions are reduced, economic problems are solved and some gain is made for the state. The commissioner concerned basically said that enterprise bargaining should not be used as a wage reduction process, but he had no powers to stop really bad agreements, and the state government needed to act.

In his speech the honourable member for Bennelong used terms such as `union thugs', `payback time for mates', `unemployment will increase', `small business will bleed to death', and `the mob'. He seems to have a total dislike for working people and their organisations. He continues to criticise, using words of that type. His words go on and on, attacking along those lines.

I believe that this bill will provide for the flexibility to enterprise bargain in the proper manner, give bottom line support to maintaining the award structure as a safety net, and protect decent wages and conditions for the majority of Australian workers. I support the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill. I have to say that the 200 pages of this bill make it a little difficult to give a reasonably detailed response to all its various parts, but a number of matters strike me as very important. I notice that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) has made a series of reasonably detailed responses to his own ideas over the last few months, so I suppose we can be forgiven.

PARA.TAB: There is a lack of consistency in some parts of the industrial relations policy that has been put forward by this government over the last few years. One, which I suppose is not the most important but which absolutely stands out, is the fact that not long ago we were requiring the minimum numbers for a union to be moved up towards a figure of 10,000. All of a sudden we have had a complete change of direction—what marvellous consistency!—and that figure has come down to 100.

The government has consistently espoused the decentralising of industrial relations arrangements, but has then gone about deliberately centralising the administration of those arrangements. Business itself, big and small, has been going about the process of decentralising the decision-making, the operation and the administration. One particular avenue of doing that is the removal of large numbers of middle management in the process.

The second thing that strikes me is the rather pathetic reliance on the conventions and arrangements of everyone else in the world, when in fact I would have thought that our maturity was sufficient so that we could rely on our own abilities. It is not only a reliance on other people's treaties and obligations, and the ones that we have signed with them, but a selective reliance upon those treaties. In a general sense, I think this country is becoming far too reliant on the treaties that other people make and which we sign with them. Surely if this government feels that we have to assert ourselves by starting the push for an Irish republic, then we must have enough self-confidence in our behavioural patterns and not involve ourselves in all sorts of ILO conventions that we could quite easily deal with ourselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a sectarian quip?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! The parliamentary secretary will cease interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I take a point of order on the honourable member's quip about an Irish republic. Is that meant to be offensive?
—Order! There is no point of order. The parliamentary secretary will resume his seat.

—The parliamentary secretary is very sensitive on the subject of the republic. As we know, there has been a great push for the republic, but every time the government of Australia sends the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to Ireland, the percentage supporting the republic goes down. We should pay him to go.
—I think you should come back to the topic.
—Well, it is true. As I said, the reliance on these selected treaty obligations—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on another point of order. The honourable member has been off the topic now for quite some time.
—Order! The chair is observing this. There is no point of order.
—I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to ask the honourable member to come back to the bill.
—Order! I ask you to resume your chair and to stop raising points of orders so often.

—As I was saying, the reliance in this bill is on certain selected treaty obligations. I notice that some of the treaty obligations have not been selected. One in particular is the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Article 20 of that declaration says that everyone has the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and association. I could not agree more. But part 2 says that no-one may be compelled to belong to an association. I can only recommend to the government that perhaps if it took a little more notice of some voluntarism in the membership of some of their organisations, it might have more members. But still, and I refer to the contribution of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams), there is this great urge in the Labor Party and in the ACTU for compulsion. This bill centres itself around trying to coerce more people to get involved in the system.

PARA.TAB: Whilst talking about the decentralisation of arrangements, it really does produce a system of arrangements where administration and the centralisation of industrial relations is encouraged to expand. I think it is important that we understand that what the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) said about this being a payback arrangement is true. There is a very good reason for that. The reason is that trade union membership is going down although, in a funny sort of way the, if you like, unofficial membership of small organisations within enterprises is building up. In other words, people are doing deals outside the system. That was recognised, and is being recognised, by the Labor Party, the government and the ACTU. It is being recognised to the extent that now we have an operation in this bill where we are trying to put the dog around these informal arrangements that are being made all over this country to see whether we can rope them back in again.

I will give an example. In my business association—not directly, but with people I know—last April, 12 months, one of my associates, not a business associate, was told by the bank that it was going to close him down. He had 10 employees and it looked as though they were in trouble. He went to the employees and they created a new arrangement—he did not go near the union. That arrangement was that they were going to get $387 a week, they were going to work for 40 hours and they would have an arrangement whereby if their productivity went up and the employer could charge out his clients at a greater number of hours, then they would get a benefit. At the beginning of that operation, the average salary was around $400 a week. There were two or three people on $420 to $430 a week. They then changed it. It worked very well. The bank was reasonably mollified. They changed that arrangement about a year later to a $430 a week minimum salary for 44 hours a week. The incentive arrangements now have at least three of the 10 employees on $570 to $630 a week. The employees are happy. They have kept their jobs, so they should be happy. The employer is happy, the bank is delighted and the business is still going.

That is an interesting set of circumstances, but it is all illegal. That is the sort of nonsense that is going on in this country today. I could tell the House that any number of those arrangements are going on in small business—not in big business, but in small business—where people are finding that they have to make arrangements that we could not possibly think up for them. That is because they are arrangements which suit the people and suit their own particular knowledge and abilities. I think this great desire by, if you like, invoking all sorts of international conventions and by trying to rope the thing back to a more centralised arrangement is going to fail. It is going to fail just as easily as did the direction before to go to giant unions. It was an aberration which was so laughable that nobody took it seriously.

I would also like to re-raise the subject of compulsory unionism and coercion. I have had a little experience with unions over the years and I find that many of them are absolutely marvellous supporters of their people. But some go over the top. Some of those people have used all sorts of compulsion—from force and undue picketing to arrangements which are nothing less than beyond the pale. I am delighted to see that in this country of recent times—probably due to a number of circumstances: the first reason being the straitened economic times, the second reason being that people are getting a little more sense, and the third sad reason, I suppose, is that we have an unemployment rate at around 11 per cent—the sort of coercion that was going on has started to disappear. I also think that there is a further reason for that: the unions are not strong enough to do it anymore. There are one or two unions around. The TFF try it on every now and then. I get a number of members in my electorate and from nearby electorates ringing me and saying that they are under pressure from this union or that union to join up or otherwise they will not be serviced.

But what is important is that there are proper legal systems in the proper courts for dealing with those things. We now have enough experience to know that those sorts of bluffs can be called. That leads me simply to say that whilst the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lyons, said that the honourable member for Bennelong used all sorts of words that were, perhaps, unfortunate and pointed to a certain frame of mind, the fact of the matter is that it still goes on and it is time it stopped. I am not saying that some employers are not just as tough, but it is time that those sorts of arrangements were finished in this country so that we can get back to competitive arrangements where people survive on merit.

That brings me to the subject of the unions within enterprises. I am absolutely sure in my mind that there are many more unionists in this country now than the official figures show. Some will be trade unionists but the others will be members of enterprise arrangements within companies. Whether they have small memberships or large memberships, they should be free to make arrangements exactly the way they like without having any benefit for being registered, unregistered or anything else; in other words, there should be no benefit for those people who happen to belong, or feel that they should belong, to the system.

Let me turn to those parts of the bill which deal with secondary boycotts. I note that access to common law remedies would be through the commission. Everybody in business knows that a secondary boycott can do enormous damage extremely quickly. A picket or a restrictive arrangement by a union, which has an effect on a third party or someone else, can damage very quickly. Many people who have been involved in those circumstances know that the last place where they want to battle the matter out is in the Industrial Relations Commission. That is why in 1977 the industrial relations arrangements were changed and sections 45D and 45E, in particular, were brought into the Trade Practices Act.

I suppose the first really effective operation that I can remember of sections 45D and 45E was in 1978 when there was a dispute in Adelaide and Perth called the live sheep dispute. An interim injunction was provided by the Federal Court reasonably quickly in those days, which prevented a picket which wanted a total ban on the export of live sheep. I suppose this was a motivation for the government. I would not be surprised if that interim injunction were still in place because, as I remember, it was one which prevented people from interfering with the export of live animals by sea, or words to that effect.

Members of the government have changed the game from where it is fair—that is, in the proper court—and, at least in the first instance, are going to filter it through the Industrial Relations Commission. I congratulate the government for doing it in its own interests or the interests of the ACTU, because it is simply a form of getting the game back onto its field and not onto a totally independent field. I congratulate it for its success in trying to favour itself, but I do not congratulate it for what it will do to Australian business.

If those opposite are saying that these sorts of matters cannot be properly handled straightaway by an independent court which, by definition, has shown itself in this country to be even-handed, there can be no other reason for wanting to filter the matter through the Industrial Relations Commission where such matters as contempt never occur. In the proper courts, however, people can quite quickly be in trouble for contempt of court.

In the past when people have tried to deal with these sorts of blockades, pickets, strikes, or whatever they are, that affect third parties, business people and the business of that second institution, if you like, there were a number of ways of dealing with it. Many years ago people either gave up, used some force or used some other strategy. In the late 1970s the government decided that the best and fairest way to deal with it was in the proper courts. I want somebody opposite to explain to me why we have to go back through the Industrial Relations Commission, which is a playing field that the people in the ACTU have used to their own advantage. That commission really has no sanction that is worth while. Under these new arrangements, people will have to ask permission to get to a proper court. It would be nice if the government had confidence in the independent Federal Court—that is what is really being said here: that the government does not have that confidence—to properly make a decision on these sorts of matters. The important point about independent courts such as the Federal Court is that they come to the matter fresh and not preprogrammed.

The great thing that is then working for people in business who are being blockaded, picketed or interrupted in their business through no fault of their own—after all, a secondary boycott is not something that they can do anything about because it is not usually a strike or picket against them, but against somebody else—is that the interim injunction can be put in place and, if the guilty parties continue, they can be up for contempt of court. But there is not any contempt of court in the IRC. I notice on occasions there is plenty of contempt for the IRC, but not much contempt of court there. It is very important that the government give some explanation—which I am sure it will not—why that needs to happen.

Lastly, I want to re-raise this matter of unionism in Australia. Unionism is down under 40 per cent. If it were not for the public service there would be a lot fewer than that. In private business trade unionism is at 30 per cent. The way to get trade union and non-trade union membership up, which I am all for, is to make sure that the arrangements are truly democratic. Perhaps if we could have a little more democracy in the Australian workplace we might get a much better result in industrial relations, and less coercion and centralisation will produce a much better result.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993, I feel it is necessary to revisit a little of Australia's industrial relations history in terms of landmark decisions. Before I list some of them, I might add that the Liberals and the Nationals or their forebears had very little to do with any of the industrial relations advances. It has been, and always will be, the labour movement and its political arm—the Australian Labor Party—which are always at the forefront, forcing the agenda, and delivering advances for working Australians. The conservative record is notable by its opposition to almost all of these advances in industrial relations.

PARA.TAB: I would like to note the Fahey government's act of perfidy in relation to Paul Matters and Neville Hilton, now facing charges for watching and besetting a picket. It is a pity that the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) has left the House, because he was speaking at some length about pickets. Watching and besetting comes under the criminal code in a 1927 act, and it is used almost exclusively in domestic violence orders. These people, who were at an authorised union picket that took place at Bombo quarry, have now been charged. The maximum sentence for conviction on this charge is six months gaol or a $500 fine. On estimate, Mr Fahey has spent well over $25,000 so far to put Mr Matters and Mr Hilton through the court system, and they will lose. These actions have taken these people through the criminal codes. It is exactly what the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was all about. He made statements on aspects of his legislation before the last election, but he was really about dealing with unions and industrial relations as though those people were criminals for standing up and speaking for their rights. This was a non-violent picket, opposed by the conservatives. Now the people of New South Wales are being forced to bankroll Mr Fahey's outrageous behaviour.

However, I would like to go through some of the milestones in Australian labour conditions. The 1880s were the period when some of the current Australian unions were formed—for example, the waterside workers. Eighteen-ninety saw the maritime strike which is looked upon by our side of parliament as the watershed of much of the current thinking in Labor politics over the last century. Eighteen-ninety-one saw the Queensland shearers strike and the formation of the Australian Labor Party.

Australia's constitution was written in 1901, with sections 51 and 34 providing for the resolution of interstate industrial disputes through conciliation and arbitration. In 1904 the Commonwealth court of conciliation and arbitration was formed—a world first. The concept of conciliation and arbitration in our constitution came directly from that maritime strike and the shearers strike and the desire of Australian workers not to be treated as dogs.

In 1907, we saw the Harvester judgment re the Excise Tariff Act. Mr Justice Higgins introduced the concept of a `living wage', based on a male employee supporting a family of three—a new standard. In 1924, the Queensland government legislated for a 44-hour week. Our lives are our own. While we are required to work to provide for our families, we deserve some leisure activities. In fact, we deserve to enjoy our lives.

In 1947, the New South Wales government legislated for the 40-hour week—by the way, all of these measures were introduced by Labor governments—and in 1948 the Commonwealth court followed with the 40-hour week. In the 1960s, four weeks annual leave became a standard through state governments. In 1966—this is something the Liberal Party can claim—legislation precluding married women from employment was repealed. That was 1966—my God!.

Nineteen-sixty-nine saw the first of the three equal pay cases affecting the pay of women and other minorities—for example, Aboriginals working on pastoral properties—come before the arbitration commission. In 1970, annual leave loading was negotiated in the waterfront industry, flowing mainly from state awards and decisions across the work force. In 1972, we saw the second equal pay case; in 1974, the third equal pay case; and in 1978—by God, listen to this—the maternity leave test case was run before the commission and accepted. Maternity leave was granted in 1978.

In 1982, the campaign in the metal industry for a 38-hour week saw it become a standard. In 1984, we saw the termination, change and redundancy case establish minimum standards for consultation, notice, dismissal procedures and redundancy pay, and the introduction of the Sex Discrimination Act. In 1986, we saw the introduction of the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Act. The arbitration commission accepted the concept of award provisions to require the employer to contribute to the employee's superannuation. In 1990, paternity leave was accepted by the commission—52 weeks unpaid leave. In 1991, the Occupation Health and Safety Act was passed for Commonwealth employment.

I would challenge the honourable member for Bennelong to deny that industrial disputation under this government has been 62 per cent lower than under the Fraser government in which he was the brains of the outfit. On top of this achievement in industrial harmony, the unions have dramatically restructured, awards have been substantially restructured, and a consistent and equitable framework of minimum award rates has been established through the minimum rates adjustment process—all of which have significantly contributed to micro-economic reform.

We are constantly given a frightened ostrich's view of industrial relations by the coalition. Let me state clearly for those on the other side: look at the history; look at the broad view; look at the magnificent record this country has in its short history compared to any other country in the world. That is predominantly due to the labour movement in this country and the political arm of that labour movement, the great Australian Labor Party.

Perhaps it would be appropriate to elucidate the definition of industrial relations for the benefit of those on the other side of this chamber. Industrial relations is the form and procedures engaged in by parties engaged in productive activities to determine the terms and conditions under which those activities proceed, the agreement of capital with labour for their mutual relations. While this may seem self-evident, it has apparently escaped the mental capabilities of the opposition, especially the honourable member for Bennelong. Let me point out to the honourable member for Bennelong that industrial relations is not defined as the rules that allow capital to dictate to labour the terms of its slavery.

Let us revisit in brief the honourable member for Bennelong's position at the last election. What essential features would Australian workers have had imposed upon them had the honourable member for Bennelong and his mates gained office? From my point of view, the essence of the honourable member's position was that unions had to be killed. And with some vague assertions about individual rights, he maintained that, on their own, individual workers would be able to negotiate equally with multinational corporations, companies with monopoly control of employment in small communities, as well as the significant government employers.

The imputation was that, without the help of unions and the collective bargaining position that unions afford their workers, individuals—irrespective of age, gender, ethnic background, personal intellectual ability or indeed the ability to research and collate the complexities of industrial relations—would miraculously obtain the skills of an industrial barrister, an occupational health and safety officer, an economic planner, a health scientist, a counsellor, an industrial negotiator, a political analyst and a communicator of high standard.

Clearly, the honourable member for Bennelong does not believe that this is possible. Therefore, his second imputation was that the representatives of capital and government representing the Australian employers are an angelic group of philanthropists whose sole purpose is the betterment of the conditions of all Australian workers. To verify this, one only has to recall his assertions that no Australian workers would be worse off under his unscrupulous proposals. Indeed, his outrageous claim was that most Australian workers would be better off. Clearly, these assertions question the judgment and sanity of anyone loopy enough to impute such nonsense.

I ask the honourable member for Bennelong to come clean and state the reality of his intentions, which I maintain would mean the destruction of the union movement so that the Australian work force would be left defenceless against the greedy, the unscrupulous, the standover merchants and the criminals, and the ugly face of Australian employers. Mr Deputy Speaker, consider this: if you were a caring employer aware of the honourable member's propositions and you saw your competitive position being undermined by those who represent the ugly face of Australian business—and let us name them: the Peko-Wallsend elements—in their industrial relations with their work force, would you not be forced against your altruistic judgments to take the same road to protect your competitive position? Would you not have to alter your bottom line to continue in business?

So is it not true that the honourable member for Bennelong and the coalition were all about lowering real wages for non-management workers in Australia? And for what purpose? To improve Australia? No. The real purpose was to redistribute income away from the majority of Australians for the benefit of their corporate mates. The coalition often talks about our union mateship and pay-offs. The coalition's intent was to force good employers to impoverish ordinary Australians in order to pay back the corporate backers of the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia who kicked the can heavily to fund their election expenses in the election that they could not lose but did.

The intent, stated and unstated, was to eliminate the ability of Australians to have a secure social security system, particularly in the unemployment benefits area. Those opposite hoped that, faced with starvation and the inability to provide for families, Australian workers would be forced to accept anything that employers were prepared to offer. This was the most un-Australian, unpatriotic position conceivable for those who believe—as I do—that Australia is the people who inhabit this continent. To act against the interests of the vast majority of Australians is to attack Australia—and is thus unpatriotic. It is a lot of other things, but the constraint of polite language and the rules of this House prevent my calling them what they deserve to be called for their intent to perform an act of perfidy against the vast majority of Australians.

In contrast, this bill, although not warmly embraced by the full family of unions and Australian workers, is a sincere attempt to adjust the Australian industrial relations environment to a changing, competitive world. It acknowledges that industrial relations is a marriage of two interests and that, as in all marriages, there needs to be an ability to compromise and reach consensus for the productive relationship to continue.

This act will enhance the accord's partners—unions and the government—and the ability to promote true enterprise bargaining, not some outrageous circumstance in which the boss takes all and dictates all. The award system is built as a safety net for all workers, whether or not they are unionists. It will be enhanced by the minimum entitlements legislation, based on the ILO conventions.

The legislation includes and strengthens the provision of equal pay for equal work, translated for the honourable member for Bennelong and for those opposite who do not care as equal pay for men and women for work of equal value. Workers will also be protected from unfair dismissal. It also strengthens the termination, change and redundancy test case. The honourable member for Bennelong wants to have workers in such a position that if a boss gives a 50 per cent cut in pay and the worker objects he or she is out the door. The legislation will also provide for unpaid parental leave, recognising the role men play in family life and care of their children in addition to the role played by women.

The flexibility clauses enable enterprises and workplaces to vary the general conditions of awards to suit particular needs. These must be ratified by the Industrial Relations Commission and—quite rightly—unions have the right and duty to be heard on that. The commission will maintain and update the award safety net. Minimum entitlements will be applied and it will conciliate in enterprise agreements. It will also supervise the no disadvantage clause guaranteeing the protection of workers against wage cuts and the disintegration of accepted standards. It can also ensure bargaining in good faith. I would have wished sections 45D and 45E to have been abolished completely. I will get to that in a minute. The industrial relations court will be established.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will need an extension of time.

—If there was a move for an extension of time I would gladly take it. The industrial relations court will be established. The bill includes an extensive range of safeguards to ensure fairness and equity for women and workers of non-English speaking backgrounds.

PARA.TAB: Sections 45D and 45E, as the honourable member for Barker said, removed the rights of Australian workers to picket and use their democratic means to protest acts of perfidy by business people. I suggest that the example I mentioned of Mr Fahey and the actions of the Liberal-National Party government in New South Wales towards Paul Matters and Neville Hilton over the Bombo quarry dispute show exactly what the honourable member for Bennelong is about and where the heart and soul of members opposite lie. They are saying that if people stand up for their rights in an industrial sphere those people are criminals but that a person who grinds down the noses of workers is a great Australian.

I am sure that if those opposite ever get back on the government benches—I do not think they ever will—they would start rewarding those people with Orders of Australia. I suggest that the honourable member for Bennelong put industrial relations in its true context and understand, whether he likes it or not, that workers will not lie down and die or go away; they will continue to advocate and pursue their rights and advances in industrial relations.

Australia, through the labour movement and the Australian Labor Party, will continue to be—as it has been this century and will continue to be through the next while we are involved on this side of the House—at the forefront of industrial reform. Industrial reform means advances. When people on the other side talk about industrial reform, they talk about chains, gaols and stopping people from pushing for their rights. They talk about $3.50 for young Australians and creating a situation in which most Australians would not be able to look after their own families.

I suggest the honourable member for Bennelong look at the judgment of Mr Justice Higgins in the Harvester case and tell Australians today they do not have the right to a roof over their heads, to look after their kids or put food on the table. He should tell them that they do not have a right to stand up and be counted. Because that is what the honourable member for Bennelong meant when he put up his proposals before the last election. Thank God the sense of the Australian people prevailed; they threw out those opposite and they will continue to do so while members opposite have such outrageous views.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

TALK.START.PARA: —Many times, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Please proceed.

—There is one area which, in the interests of proper debate and truth, I should correct. I have never advocated gaoling people for industrial offences. I do not favour—I never have and I never will—criminal penalties in relation to industrial matters. Many other things that were said were wrong. But I must record that that comment was an absolute, downright distortion of the truth, and it should not go uncorrected.

—I am pleased to participate in this debate on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill and to have the embarrassment of the rantings of the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott) removed. He is living in the past; we are trying to look to the future. I am glad the correction was made by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) because some of the statements were outrageously wrong. The honourable member for Gilmore is here as an apologist for the trade union movement, the Australian Labor Party or somebody else. Does anybody want to claim him?

PARA.TAB: This legislation is basically a big payback for the ACTU and the manner in which it conducted itself during the last election—and for the spending of some $30 million. It is not only a payback but a backdown by the government from its initial position before the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) attended the conference in Melbourne. That has been well highlighted.

There was a massive backdown. There was a lot to be commended in the new and enlightened opinions of the government as it came out of the last election. But all that enlightenment has been stomped well and truly—and forever. The package has been described as a partnership between the government and the ACTU, a party to the accord. There are no other partners. Some who might have enjoyed some assistance were from the employer organisations and the non-Labor states. But that is not to be.

I well recall in my own state of Queensland that once the Labor government was elected the first thing it did was repeal the voluntary employment agreements which had been wildly hailed throughout the state, and I believe beyond it, as being a measure by which people in a workplace were prepared to come together and voluntarily agree to award provisions in return for productivity. Probably the best known example of that was Power Brewing. I believe the relationship between the employers and employees was such that when the voluntary employment agreements were taken away from the employees the whole of that work force, which amounted to some 400 people, decided that in spite of union intervention they would proceed in the way that they were already going. I believe it is a great pity that in my own state of Queensland this is not one of the matters that we can look back on with some pride.

Probably one of the greatest offences of this bill is that yet again the government is seeking its powers externally, not from within Australia itself. When we look at the circumvention that will once again occur to overrule the state bodies—and I believe that there is very much a predetermination by the government to do this as far as Victoria is concerned—it is the external powers that will provide the facility for that circumvention. Those external powers are being used more and more by this government. One wonders whether the people who cry about the new world order do not really have something to complain about in that the power for Australians to legislate for themselves, it seems, is being transhipped to other places. I mention the Franklin Dam and the rainforests of North Queensland as examples of those powers being used to overrule the states.

The other problem with this legislation is that it walks away from common law remedies. I think that is a great pity. We hail many decisions that have been made by the High Court, in the name of common law, as being great decisions. Yet the most fundamental factor of common law is a contract that a person can make, one with another, and the manner in which common law reinforces that contract. This area is to be transferred to the Industrial Relations Act. I believe that is most inappropriate. So too are the anti-boycott provisions, on which some fundamental decisions have been made and which have been to a large extent a disciplinary factor that the unions have kept in mind before conducting some of the more outrageous ambit claims and strike actions that have taken place. Two examples of that which come to mind are the Mudginberri dispute and the Dollar Sweets dispute in Victoria. If it had not been for those protections within common law, goodness knows where those strikes might have gone. The Labor Party intends to transfer this matter to the Industrial Relations Act. If it could, it would try to get rid of it altogether. As I said before, the bill reinforces the award system with International Labour Organisation conventions and new minimum conditions.

This reform bill overlooks completely the one fundamental need in Australia to bring us back on the rails: a system that will create more and therefore fuller employment. In Australia today the official figure for unemployment is 11.3 per cent. If honourable members care to look at the unofficial figure—including those people who are on minimal conditions, on casual rates and in part-time employment—I believe it can safely be said that it is 20 per cent, not 11.3 per cent. The bill overlooks altogether the capacity of business in Australia to create employment and get us out of this mess. As I said before, it is nothing more than a payback to the ACTU. Labor unions and Labor governments, in their own time, are trying to take more and give less. They are the ones that have created this unemployment, and particularly the unemployment caused by the loss of existing jobs. Yet this situation will persevere because the reform package gives no hope, encouragement or incentive to small or big business. I think that is very important.

The only employment opportunities that are offered in Australia today are within the public services of the Commonwealth and the states. Those people engaged in training or who are attending educational facilities to acquire skills will still be on the unemployment list. So no real jobs are being created; incentives are needed to encourage small and large businesses to acquire greater productivity.

It is interesting to see that labour related taxes are paid by small and big business alike. I start with the superannuation levy. Five per cent of the payroll is being paid for doubtful superannuation and savings in the future—savings that are being lost for use in current conditions and for current spending. That is a huge burden on business. The fringe benefits tax—probably the most offensive tax that this government has ever introduced—is a tax on employment; it is a tax on fringe benefits and is paid by employers and not employees. The payroll tax—a temporary measure brought in over 50 years ago by the states—still exists as a major impediment to employment. I know that some workplaces have a scale of employment which will keep them under the ceiling at which they would have to pay tax. That is a deliberate policy. The training levy, the health and safety levy, penalty rates and workers compensation all stop businesses from employing, from being as productive as they might be and from expanding. As I said, there appears to be no relief in this legislation; once again it will reinforce union monopoly and control.

While it has been said in this House—and it is a known fact throughout Australia—that there is a decrease in membership of unions, this particular piece of legislation in reference to private contracts or enterprise agreements lets the unions play a de facto part of the negotiations. When a non-union work force tries for some improvement in an enterprise agreement, there is no doubt that the de facto negotiators from the union will represent that work force in order to create pressure such that the productivity sought by both employer and employee will not be able to be gained.

The industrial relations reform bill goes nowhere near providing relief from those pressures and labour costs that I have just mentioned. The enterprise agreements are a far cry from the voluntary employment contracts that the Queensland government once had. While enterprise agreements can be applied in non-union workplaces, the union will still be involved and have the power to intervene and spoil what I believe was meant to be a workable system.

I mention in passing the situation that exists in the sugar industry at the moment and the means by which all employees—field employees and mill employees—are compelled by an agreement between the peak bodies, the Queensland Cane Growers Council and the AWU, to have membership. The manner in which it is done is that an employer of any field worker—any person working on a harvesting or planting contract or involved with anything on that farm—who does not insist by 30 September each year that that individual worker be covered by an AWU ticket is boycotted from the supply of cane trucks for transport of the sugar cane. That is quite deliberate. Can anybody tell me that, in a situation such as that, unionism is other than compulsory and that there is any way out for the farmer apart from sticking to his principles and having his cane left in the field? The wretched part of that is probably that the peak body, the Australian Cane Farmers Association, is party to that agreement. Boycotting in those circumstances is without parallel.

This year, the combined mills of the Mackay Sugar Cooperative—some four sugar mills altogether—in the interests of productivity and keeping people employed, have arranged to transfer cane from one mill to another to crush the sugar cane. There were three days of strike at a time rather critical to the industry when the AWU called out its members so that certain of those mills stopped. To the credit of the employees of one of the sugar mills, they said, `No, we will not stop production', and they kept going. It was only when the commissioner told the AWU not to be so bloody-minded and stupid and to let its members go back to work that the strike eventually finished. These are just two examples that have happened within this year.

It is interesting to see that the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) is here, because, in a recent debate in this House in connection with South Sea Islanders, he said that the AWU did not have a proud record within the sugar industry because the AWU had insisted on a white Australia policy within the cane fields. He was quite right. South Sea Islanders were not allowed to register as members of the union. They were not allowed to work on those premises. As a result of that, South Sea Islanders worked at night by the light of the moon to do the work that was necessary in order to avoid that situation. The sugar industry, with the AWU within it, does not have a very proud history. I note that the brother of the honourable member for Reid is the President of the ACTU, but I thank him very much for the analogy I just gave.

This bill does not call on unions to be accountable. Here we have a Commonwealth piece of legislation—the same Commonwealth which legislates that corporate companies and people be accountable for taxation returns and everything else—which has nothing in it that calls upon a union to present a proper set of accounts as would be set out by any other registered organisation or company in Australia. I have not seen any balance sheets of late but I recall that about six or seven years ago I found that the balance sheet of a particularly big union was written on just one sheet of foolscap paper. Any statutory organisation in Australia today has to have its balance sheet qualified to a larger extent and in more detail. Yet we have here a situation where a union is not accountable to its members. Members of unions are asked to pay their fees. That is fair enough, but a lot are also asked to pay a levy to be used by that union for matters other than trade union work.

I ask: how much did the trade union movement fund the Labor Party in the last election? I know that, within my electorate, teachers, nurses and transport unions—the whole lot of them—provided money, and material was being issued all in the interests of the Labor Party. It is interesting now that those same teachers are complaining in Queensland because they think they are getting a raw deal from their state Labor government—the same government as they funded. The nurses are also up in arms. In relation to transport unions, it is particularly relevant that there have been threats against railway employees about taking up the lines in some areas, and this is all part of a system that they funded.

The final thing I want to talk about as far as fairness and equity are concerned is the privileged tax position that unions in Australia enjoy over any of their comparable company structures. They enjoy a tax exemption for any income they earn. I think it is under section 27 of the act. As a result, unions are able to amass quite a lot of funds to be used in ways in which the members would not want them to be used. It is another example of the manner in which this government will bend over backwards to accommodate the ACTU. As I said, the original program the government put to the ACTU is, as I understand it, a far cry from what we have here.

Those special privileged positions that unions enjoy under this government are not enjoyed by any other Australians. I refer again to the taxation exemption at a time when we are trying to deal with the taxation issue within our electorates. I imagine that all members of the House of Representatives know that pensioners and veterans are being persecuted as a result of the income testing of the value of their shares from one period to another, which is a scandalous situation. We see them persecuted. We see the loss of income as a result and loss of the pension as a result. Yet the union movement is able to escape the liability of taxation as would be applicable in any other case.

This legislation offers nothing to increase Australia's exports. It does nothing to increase the viability and expansion of Australian business. But it means a lot as far as a reward and a backdown to the ACTU by this government is concerned, which is not unusual in the circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contributions of those opposite in this debate on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill have been quite interesting. Perhaps the last speaker, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), more clearly than anyone else, drove home the antipathy towards the trade union movement. Opposition members are preoccupied with the taxation advantages of the trade union movement. It is a matter which those opposite do not often show much interest in. The recent performance of their leadership contender puts those kinds of comments into context. However, one of the more impressive contributions came from the honourable member for Grey (Mr Wakelin) who stressed his moderation, his membership of a trade union and his discussions with a previous minister in a Labor government. He went on to praise some of the comments made by the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) and to urge moderation and sanity in these kinds of debates.

PARA.TAB: It was unfortunate that those comments were not driven home to a number of those opposite. For instance, we had—as we always do in these industrial relations debates—the contribution of the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles). Whenever he speaks in industrial relation debates, we are reminded of the segregationalist governor of Alabama, George Wallace. After having been beaten in an election, he said that he was never going to be out-niggered again. There is no doubt that no-one on the opposite side is going to outdo the honourable member for La Trobe in his extremism in the industrial relations debate. We had a situation where the opposition lead spokesman on this matter, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), came up with a figure of eight hurdles introduced by this government for those who wanted to get involved in enterprise bargains. The honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) went up-market a bit more and he contended there were 13. But, as usual, the honourable member for La Trobe produced 16 supposed barriers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I think I heard the honourable member for Reid say that the utterances of the honourable member for La Trobe reminded him of a former governor of Alabama, George Wallace, who used the expression, after losing an election, that he would never be out-niggered again. That, of course, is a highly offensive racist statement. I have to say, in defence of my colleague the honourable member for La Trobe, that any attempt to suggest that he shares the racist sentiments of Governor Wallace is highly offensive and ought to be withdrawn. It is very unfair.

PARA.TAB: He may have meant that or, alternatively, I may have misunderstood what he said, or may not have heard it clearly, as I occasionally do not. I would be grateful if he would tell me what he meant. I hope the honourable member for Reid is a little more gracious than to suggest that. I always thought he had been. I do not think he could accuse my colleague the honourable member for La Trobe of being, in any way, like George Wallace. I think it is pretty unfair if he said that.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I heard the remark which the honourable member for Reid made. He was drawing an analogy between extremist points of view. Were it the case that he had ascribed racist sentiments to the honourable member for La Trobe, I would have agreed with the honourable member for Bennelong that there should have been a withdrawal. I do not think it was made in that context, and I think when the Hansard is read it will show he was, in a colourful way, drawing attention to what he regarded as extreme views.

—We will not have a debate on it; we are eating into the time of the honourable member for Reid. I am sure it will assist the processes of the House, if people found the term offensive, if the honourable member just withdraws it.

—I think the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs has explained the comment. I am speaking in a debate on industrial relations. The honourable member for La Trobe always ensures that he takes the most extreme view on the subject being debated. I certainly would not have intended any kind of analogy of a racist sort against the honourable member for La Trobe.
—So you have withdrawn that aspect of it?
—If it was taken that way.
—I accept that.

—Then we had the contribution from the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper). He certainly took no notice of the honourable member for Grey. We had this tirade about paybacks, payment of election debts, dictates of the union movement, government for mates, government with mates, government by the trade unions, et cetera. There was this general proposition that these particular changes in regard to enterprise bargaining in this country are simply a payback—total, end of story.

PARA.TAB: During the last federal election campaign the shadow industrial relations spokesman, the honourable member for Bennelong, was not too prominent for fairly obvious reasons: he was a very articulate representative of a point of view which really proved very unpopular with the Australian electorate. This was indicated by the former member for Bass who, after his defeat, commented that the main reason he lost his seat was the way in which the Labor Party drove home effectively the question of the youth wage throughout that campaign. He said that he could basically walk up and convince people individually, one-to-one, on the issue, but everywhere he went in his electorate he was confronted by people who hit him with this youth wage.

We are really seeing here an unwillingness by those opposite to accept that. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) might have tried to make industrial relations a lesser issue in the campaign. Certainly the government went out and fought this particular issue every day of the campaign in every electorate around this country. It might be worrying to members of the opposition that the kinds of attitudes that they put forward were rejected, and were rejected pretty thoroughly. It is even more telling when we look at the popularity of the union movement in this country. It is so low with the average elector and the average person, for a variety of reasons. The opposition has been fundamentally rejected because of the extremism of its industrial relations views.

To come in here today and say that it is a payback to the union movement is really putting it a bit simply. There has been great debate within the party on the matter. Some people have been perceived by a majority of members of their caucus as going too far out in suggesting changes. Obviously there is a close relationship between people who are members of trade unions and Australian politics. There is still an association between people in some occupations and their voting preferences. The opposition shadow spokesman came here today and said there has been some deal and that anything Jennie George says is of biblical significance because in some debate with Brian Noakes or Ian Spicer she said or whispered in their ears, `We won the election and we are getting paid back'. All of a sudden whatever Jennie George says is of biblical significance, according to the honourable member for Bennelong. Obviously that is not the case. It is part of a deeper picture.

There is an attitude on this side of the House that, although enterprise bargaining in this country should be opened up, it should be with a degree of protection. In talking about protection, there is the other thrust of the opposition's position. There is a bit of a worry about conspiracy theories. Those opposite are constantly trying to drive home this supposed undermining of Australian sovereignty, that through our process, because we actually have a government that has ratified certain conventions—not just those of the ILO but from a variety of international organisations—somehow our authority, our sovereignty, is undermined.

That is a conscious decision of the elected government of this country. The government is not compelled to ratify every convention. It has made a decision that in these particular areas those conventions are worth while; they have something worth while for the Australian population. Of course, that is central to the attitude of the government to these matters. Whilst people should move towards enterprise bargaining, whilst there should be an involvement by the work force with the employer—an attempt to see what a particular enterprise requires in order to get rid of practices that are undermining its operation—at the same time there should be some fundamental protections for the workers.

I refer briefly to one area that caused concern—a protection the government has introduced in this legislation—and that is the question of equal pay. Regarded as one of the dreadful actions of this government is its attempt to bring in certain minimums in regard to equal pay. I refer to an article by Karen Fredericks in the spring edition of Refractory Girl. I would not agree with her actual analysis of the government's policy when she said that we had introduced `an industrial strategy which could have been stolen wholesale from the Liberals' Fightback package'. That is certainly nothing the opposition would agree with. However, she made some very important points about the reality of women's wages. When we look at those under awards in this country we see that female wages are 93 per cent of male wages. When we go to the broader issue of average weekly earnings, we find they are only 66 1/2 per cent. There is a variety of reasons for that: the concentration of areas they work in, the nature of those industries, et cetera. It is relevant—it is not totally because of the industries they work in—that they also receive only 20 per cent of male overtime earnings. We have to consider that in the context of her statement where she said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian workforce remains the most sex segregated of all OECD countries, with women concentrated in the weakest, least strategically important, most geographically diverse and lowest value added areas of the economy.

Whilst those are ingredients of the total picture, the reality is that the award structure in this country has provided a degree of wage protection for females. This is why there has been extensive opposition to the drift down the enterprise bargaining way by women's groups in this country.

PARA.TAB: The reason this government has fundamentally chosen to go to enterprise bargaining is so that things like parental leave, equal pay, the right to avoid unfair dismissal and the right to fight it can be guarded against and protected. The problem can perhaps be summarised in a quote from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission on this very question of women's wages when it said in April 1991:

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot predict the extent of the disadvantage female workers will experience if the Commonwealth gives its approval of a scheme of enterprise bargaining. We do accept, however that enterprise bargaining—especially for over award payments—places at a relative disadvantage those sections of the workforce where women predominate.

Even the commission saw a very serious threat to women's conditions in this country by an uncontrolled drift towards enterprise bargaining. So the government has tried to ensure—not because a few trade union officials said we should do it but because it is a concrete problem out there—these minimum protections by legislation.

PARA.TAB: As I said earlier, there is a variety of things that the government has quite rightly sought to do something about. They cover, in addition to the matters I cited earlier, redundancy payments, equal pay and the ability and rights of people to conduct industrial action. In regard to redundancies, we have legislated to provide people with varying lengths of service with some warning or advice from the employer. This is attacked by a few people opposite as a bit of an impediment or a bit of a problem because when a lot of people are sacked the CES has to be told and it is the end of the world.

I think the average person in this country would find it a reasonable requirement that people facing redundancy should be consulted and warned—remembering that that is only in the case of 15 or more. Regarding parental leave, it is not a conspiracy by some Zionist type collection of people or some group of dictators to force unreasonable and unparalleled restrictions on us. It is simply saying that a husband and wife should have unpaid leave during a period of 12 months with conditions of notification, et cetera, attached to it.

I do not think that too many people are overly worried about the claim by those opposite that this is simply paying back a few union leaders for a supposed $30 million. The question of section 45D and 45E is also involved. Once again, there has been a very long campaign by the rank and file of our party to get rid of it. It has been raised at local branches, at our federal electorate councils, or FEAs, around Australia. This has involved the actual rank and file of our party—not just a few trade union heavies. It is the people who bother to go to the monthly meetings who have continued to press this government on.

Attempts were made in 1984 and 1987, and failed. This has not come out of left field, from some kind of cabal meeting after the last federal election. It is a measure of the degree of dissatisfaction with and opposition to the way people's legitimate trade union actions were voted for by members of their particular unions.

As far as the opposition is concerned, this is very dire situation because it is based on a reference to an ILO convention. Whilst there have been attempts by our party to change this measure, ILO convention 87, which we ratified back in 1973, finds it to be an impediment to union action. There have been three critical reports in the interim about its effectiveness on people's rights to exercise industrial action in this country.

No-one is saying that every time someone says we are contravening a human rights convention—saying, for example, that we cannot incarcerate boat people—or when someone in Geneva says this or that, that we have to follow every stricture. But what has been decided here is that the government of Australia did ratify this measure; it did decide that it was worthwhile and worth implementing. The experts from the ILO have concluded that the current legislation restricts people's rights.

There will be a number of exceptions in the area of secondary boycotts, and we will see primary boycotts and restrictions on them disappear. In regard to secondary boycotts the pecuniary penalty of $250,000 will disappear. There will also be—this is apparently very abhorrent too—a pre-litigation period in an attempt to conciliate and overcome disputes by discussions.

On occasion some small businesses could be hurt by this. That is a realistic concern. The so-called club, which is another evil organisation—the club of practitioners on both sides of the fence; people who have actually been involved in industrial disputes—are apparently to be condemned forever because of their actual involvement in this field. On the other hand, the supposed experts here, in most cases, have had no involvement at all. The people in that club often feel that going to court and seeking penalties, seeking to impose orders on people in a non-industrial tribunal, actually hardens attitudes, worsens disputes, and precipitates worse problems on the site. Once again, this is an area where there is very strong support within the government for change. There is also a view among most people in the Liberal Party that this legislation is long overdue; that the present practice is restrictive, undermines people's rights and should go.

A number of secondary boycotts will be allowed where there is a clear connection between the people involved in the original dispute on the site—that is, where their rights and those of other people and companies are interconnected. Litigation restrictions will not apply to disputes where it is found that there is a fundamental threat to sectors of the economy or where it is found that there is, say, a question of damage to property. That kind of slate cleaning will not occur.

In the last few years there has been a drift towards enterprise bargaining in this country. What we are seeing here are not only the protections implemented because of international conventions but also a variety of site requirements. The fact that the trade unions might have the right to be heard, even where they do not have members, causes fulminations from those opposite. The reality is that what occurs on sites where there are no union members can undermine the conditions of the union members throughout the work force.

I think most of us would find it easy to defend the notion that it is important for unions to have an input into the process. It is important for unions be able to represent their membership on those sites where they have membership and for there to be protection for those people who fail to come to an agreement with their employer with regard to sites. There will be provision for protection from inducements to leave the trade unions. In total, it is not a retreat from enterprise bargaining; it is an attempt to ensure that, when it does occur, female wages will be protected and people will not have their overall wage packet undermined.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly and sincerely do.
—Please proceed.

—I believe that the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) has distanced himself from any suggestion that he questioned my integrity when he referred to me in his speech in the debate on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill. However, I clearly heard him say—referring to me—that the honourable member for La Trobe had the most extremist views in this parliament on some issues relating to the industrial relations debate. I must say in my defence that if it is an extremist view to believe that one should have the right not to belong to an association as much as to belong or that—

—Order! You have already participated in this debate, as I understand it. We will not canvass the issues. You claim to have been misrepresented. You claim that the honourable member for Reid made a comment about your attitude. You have indicated that. As far as I am concerned, you have indicated how you consider yourself to have been misrepresented. You have put the record straight. You will now resume your seat because you are debating the issue and I will not allow that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan Ms J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I stand to speak on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993, I am deeply disappointed that a chance to move industrial relations out of the realm of the troglodyte to the light has been sacrificed for self-indulgence, self-interest and cosy deals. According to an Australian Bureau of Statistics paper released in February 1993, trade union membership has declined in this country by six percentage points to 40 per cent of employees. I quote from a report of a survey covering the period 1986 to 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: .Falls in membership rates were recorded in all industries except for Public administration and defence (which was relatively unchanged over the six year period). The largest falls were recorded in the Mining . . . Transport and storage . . . and Manufacturing . . . industries.

.Employees in the public sector had a membership rate of 67 per cent in 1992 compared with 71 per cent in 1986. For private sector employees the rate has fallen by five percentage points to 29 per cent in 1992.

The cosy rhetoric from the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) has little substance. To the contrary, this bill is not about—and I quote—`a more productive and competitive nature'. It does not lead to the generation of more jobs in the future. I do not believe that we can support the honourable member's belief that the Australian Labor Party's commitment to a fair and just system of industrial relations will emanate from this bill. As I said, his rhetoric has little substance.

PARA.TAB: My colleague the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was right when he said yesterday in his speech that this bill is a payback and a convenient deal to revitalise the union movement in Australia. I can appreciate that. I have come from business and I know what it is like. I know that we all have to work hard to maintain our positions. That is understandable. I also understand that unionism is big business in this country today and there is big money involved. I acknowledge that the unions have a part to play. The honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) may find that a little strange, but that is true. I believe—and I am sure my colleagues support my belief—that unionism has a very major part to play in Australian industrial relations today.

Let us face what Australian businesses have to face everyday: giving the customer good service; working in the customer's interest; learning to stand squarely on their own feet; and, competing for their market share. There is an important role for unions if they would only emerge from their troglodyte mentality and see that this country can and will prosper with sensible industrial relations that protects the interest of all parties. It is a partnership. It is something that we have to encourage all parties to work together on. We must give up the old aggressive way—beating them over the head with a piece of four-by-two—and start seeing what is happening between employers and employees in 1993. We very often look but do not see; we listen, but we do not hear. I am afraid that that is the case here.

Australia needs an industrial relations system giving greater flexibility to employees and employers to decide terms of employment, but backed by the rule of law providing certainty and due process when industrial power is misused. This Labor government brings forward a bill to reverse these priorities. On the one side, it intrudes the dead hand of unions to enterprise agreements that do not involve unionised workers. On the other, we see a sinister diminution of the legal safeguards of employers against the misuse of union power through the transfer of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act to the Industrial Relations Act, and so into the treacly world of the industrial relations club, which I heard the honourable member for Reid talk about in his speech just a few minutes ago. I would also like to think that we could move away from these cosy definitions, but it takes two to tango.

Once again, the government pursues its centralising agenda through the selective use of international conventions upholding the rights of unionists while ignoring article 20 of the United Nations Charter on Human Rights that declares that no-one may be compelled to belong to an association. This is a retrogressive bill, seeking to restrict enterprise bargaining and ensure that unions engaging in secondary boycotts will evade the full and proper force of the law. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) clutches at the mantle of Alfred Deakin to legitimise the bill's surrender to the vested interests of the ACTU. Students of history will know that the essence of Deakin's legacy was an open and empirical approach that would adapt to changing circumstances. We can beg to differ whether today Deakin would support the watering down of the legal rights of business as redress against intimidation.

It is a perversion of the constitution that a power expressly given to the Commonwealth for the resolution of interstate disputes has been usurped to allow interference at will with state industrial law. Taking a full historical perspective, it is a fact that the living standards of Australian workers in relation to other nations has actually declined since the early years of this century and that much of the blame is due to a regimented industrial relations system that priced Australians out of the job market once the cosy captive British markets of 1904 faded. Deakin was a reformer; this bill is not about reform.

This bill displays a crude and cynical bias in clause 170DF when it prohibits termination of an employee on the ground of his union activities, yet it gives no protection to an employee who may be dismissed or denied a job because of a principled refusal to join a union. Such an omission, conveniently ignoring the United Nations Charter on Human Rights, is a green light for unions to reverse their historic decline in the private sector work force through the intimidation of employers. This government would be glad to sanction a scenario whereby unions insist preference provisions are the price for their approval of enterprise agreements. Indeed, there is a real prospect under this bill that unions will be able to evade prohibitions on placing secondary boycotts on non-union enterprises to enforce union membership in contemplation of future claims.

There is a fundamental injustice for this legislation to give unions standing in enterprise agreements that substantially or entirely involve non-unionised employees. Australians accept that unions have a proper and necessary role in defending the interests of those employees who choose to be union members. They do not see why unions deserve to be invested with authority over the entire work force.

The worst aspect of this bill is its attack on the legal rights of the business sector to defend itself against secondary boycotts through the transfer of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act to the Industrial Relations Act. The minister disingenuously claimed that the government is seeking to address the majority report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training in its examination of this question. The minister is saying that the legislation conforms to the sanctimonious humbug contained in a report that carefully ignored the evidence submitted by employer organisations. It was a report full of weasel words deeming effective employer defence against the thuggery of secondary boycotts as `inappropriate' and creating `disharmony'. It was a report written on the premise that effective legal deterrents against the misuse of union power are illegitimate.

It is this attitude that has given us a bill put forward by a government that does not care whether businesses are sent to the wall by the actions of unions who do not represent the will of their employees. The private sector employers, who are Australia's only hope of reducing what has become structural unemployment, do not care whether they can obtain protection from industrial legislation, the common law, or trade practices legislation. It just so happens that the last of these happens to work, much to the chagrin of the ACTU. It is a simple fact that this 1977 reform of the coalition is effective because, unlike civil law, the complainant does not have to establish that the offender was aware of a breach of contract. Unlike the orders of the commission, enforcement is swift. This action belongs in the real world, the world of enforceable damages and not to the polite shadow boxing of the Industrial Relations Commission.

It is also a dubious principle to separate anti-competitive actions by unions from those of businesses. Placing one category under different legislation implies that unions should enjoy a relative immunity from legal sanctions. That was precisely the attitude rejected by the 1976 Swanson committee when it recommended reform of the Trade Practices Act.

The ALP will never provide Australia with leadership so long as the determinant of its industrial relations policy is the satisfaction of the corporate interests of unions, and not the national economic good or the upholding of justice and due process. Industrial relations cannot always be reduced to a comfortable moral relativism, aiming solely at the reconciliation of competing interests. This approach wilfully ignores those occasions where one party defies the rules and uses its intimidatory power to inflict crippling damage on what fair-minded people would regard as innocent parties.

In these instances, union officials who deliberately impose boycotts, and who then defy due legal process, should never be immune from the legal consequences of their actions. It is, of course, no accident that the pecuniary penalty of $250,000 operating under the Trade Practices Act will not be part of the Industrial Relations Act. The minister tries the weak excuse that the penalty has never applied since 1977. Does he think we have never heard of the deterrent effect of penalties? Certainly those unions for whom industrial harmony is synonymous with employer weakness were very conscious of them and have thus successfully achieved their removal.

The Amalgamated Meat Industry Employees Union would certainly remember the damages penalty—$1.4 million—imposed under the Trade Practices Act. Section 45D last year saved Tasmanian dairy farmers from the prospect of ruinous devastation through a milk-tanker drivers strike at the behest of the state Transport Workers Union in the course of a campaign against government legislation. This is a government that does not want the small producer to be protected from this kind of action—at least not until 72 hours have passed.

Any business could tell the minister that 72 hours of `pre-litigation conciliation' provides a wonderful opportunity to inflict a great deal of damage through boycotts. We might wonder why a similar 72-hour conciliation period is not a feature of all civil law. But, of course, it would rightly be regarded as an impediment to due process.

The record of section 45D in industrial disputes is an effective one, despite the obfuscation of the Senate committee majority report. It is a fact that of 206 court actions in the last 16 years, 40 per cent resulted in an interim injunction that generally had the desired effect of halting an unjustified boycott. In the real world—not the self-regarding world of the industrial relations club—ending the boycott all but settles the dispute.

In the same real world, it was submitted by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry that, according to the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry, each month in that state five secondary boycotts are lifted once there is a serious threat of action under section 45D. It is also a matter of record just how damaging secondary boycotts can be. Operations can be stopped completely, market share lost, reputations as reliable suppliers destroyed, cash flow cut drastically, and employees of firms who were not participating in the boycotts stood down. It is also a fact that secondary boycotts are so often directed to the building, transport and marine sectors of the economy. Damage to firms in these areas impacts deeply on the economy and, indeed, on our international reputation.

The government cites conventions of the International Labour Organisation and the ILO Committee of Experts, while ignoring those more basic international conventions that uphold voluntary unionism. A government that upholds a system that emphatically does not allow free collective bargaining is inherently infringing ILO conventions.

Putting aside the argument that the federal parliament of this nation has a primary duty to override international conventions in the interests of the Australian people if necessary, the ACTU and the government base the justification for change on distorted informa

SPEECH.PARA: tion. The government is not telling us that substantial legal checks on secondary boycotts apply in Germany, Britain, Sweden, Canada and the United States, and that those checks define them as unfair labour practices. In effect, the outlawing of secondary boycotts is not contrary to ILO conventions.

PARA.TAB: The bill also fails to recognise article 8 of the ILO convention—that it is incumbent on unions to respect the law of the land. It is ironic that a government that from time to time declares its abhorrence of privilege seeks to enshrine the worst kind of legal immunities for a privileged class of Australians—trade union officials.

This is not the first time in history that we have heard of such humbug.
