We have only to go back to that champion of the worker, Marx, who was proclaiming the rights of workers around the globe, but never bothering to pay his own servants a decent wage.This bill sacrifices freedom of choice and flexibility so that decaying institutions can enjoy a new lease on life and indulge in the worst kind of attacks on the smaller business sector while evading due process and effective legal sanction.
I read with interest a report put out by the Catholic Church Bishops Committee for Industrial Affairs recently in which a comment very pertinent to this debate was made. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Compulsion, either to join organisations or not to join them, is a breach of the right of individuals to choose whether and how they will exercise their right of Freedom of Association.
It went on:

The organisations themselves must act in the interests of their members and subject to law. It is a misuse of the power of organisations for them to be used for purposes other than those for which they were created, and for which members freely joined them.

The coalition, contrary to public opinion, has no argument at all regarding decent conditions and decent wage levels. What we are concerned about as a coalition is the wellbeing of all workers and that we get one million workers in this country back into jobs again. What we are concerned about in achieving that aim is the relativity between wage levels and productivity. No business proprietor in this country would be concerned about wage levels if productivity levels matched, and that has not always been the case.

PARA.TAB: It is time that we recognised that small business in this country contributes more employment growth than larger firms. It contributes largely to the revenue that runs this country. It contributes more than proportionately to innovation, to technological transfer and to opportunities for new ideas and skills. There are nearly 900,000 small business enterprises in this country. Business enterprises in total employ seven million Australians, and the small business sector employs 2.6 million.

The most significant problem facing small business today is government regulation. I would respectfully suggest that this reform bill does nothing except increase small business responsibility in terms of filling out forms, arbitration processes and all the other regulations and problems that go to cripple small business in this country. This bill is just another unnecessarily harsh impost on the small business sector. Would that this government had the honesty to say that it is trashing industrial relations flexibility, the rule of law and individual rights at the behest of a favoured clique of its supporters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) has turned up; I was a bit worried. The legislative reforms to the industrial relations system contained in the Industrial Relations Reform Bill allow increased flexibility while at the same time ensure that the rights of workers are protected. It is true that earlier in the consultation process surrounding the drafting of this legislation I did express concerns at measures that would allow the non-unionist work force access to enterprise bargaining, as did a number of other members of the labour movement. That concern was expressed as a result of my experience in Queensland in the days of the Bjelke-Petersen government when we saw so-called enterprise agreements or voluntary employment agreements which were certainly anything but voluntary and which caused massive problems for the work force. But those days are long gone and the work force appreciates that. The latest poll figures show that people now believe that industrial relations is not the priority it was earlier in the year, particularly leading up to the federal election.

PARA.TAB: However, I have been satisfied that these agreements will be subject to a series of safeguards to ensure that they do not disadvantage workers. I refer specifically to the agreements that have been put forward here and negotiated by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton). The decision to allow non-union access to enterprise flexibility agreements is only one element of the reforms which will maintain and strengthen the award system as a safety net and a basic benchmark for enterprise agreements.

The government will also legislate national minimum standards to ensure minimum wages, equal pay, parental leave and protection against unfair dismissal. It is a credit to the hard work of the Minister for Industrial Relations that he has been able to achieve increased flexibility in our industrial relations system while at the same time maintaining the rights and conditions of Australian workers. I commend the minister on his efforts in that regard.

Nowhere was the line that divided the government and the opposition at the last election more clearly drawn than in the area of industrial relations, as we all well know. Just as the Australian people rejected the GST and the cutbacks to Medicare proposed by those opposite, they also rejected the jobsback policy of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). This Labor government has much to be proud of in the area of industrial relations policy. Dramatic changes have occurred in the Australian work force during the past decade, with the complete overhaul of the trade union structure in this country, a reform process which will rationalise the structure of the union movement and overhaul the award system; and moves towards multiskilling, just to name a few.

The focus of this policy is the accord, an instrument that has resulted in a wages policy that has increased both productivity and wages. Australian workers and their trade union movement have shown remarkable restraint over the past nine years, average weekly earnings having fallen by 4.3 per cent. Under the last coalition government, Australia had the seventh highest labour costs in the OECD, whereas today we are 14th. These gains have been made in cooperation with the trade union movement rather than taking the confrontationist approach adopted in Thatcher's Britain, Reagan's America or Kennett's Victoria.

Already, federal government changes to the industrial relations system have seen 1,200 cooperative workplace agreements reached between employers, workers and their unions, covering 37 per cent of federal award employees. These changes have been achieved while also achieving reductions in the level of industrial disputation, with the number of disputes and the number of employees involved in disputes at their lowest level since 1961. The number of working days lost per 1,000 employees is at its lowest level since 1962, another great achievement.

So, quite contrary to the picture which those opposite try to paint of the trade union movement, the numbers of strikes are now at record low levels. They are now more than 60 per cent below the level they were when the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) was the economics adviser to the honourable member for Bennelong. The only states where overall levels of industrial disputation have risen in recent years are Victoria and Tasmania. The increased industrial disputation in these two states is because their conservative governments have by and large removed the safety net of awards and have moved towards the large scale introduction of a system of individual work contracts.

The industrial relations policies adopted by the Victorian and Tasmanian governments are similar to the industrial relations policies which the federal coalition attempted to introduce across Australia with its jobsback policy, which was rejected by the Australian people, and rightly so. This approach to industrial relations was comprehensively rejected by the people at the 13 March election earlier this year.

It was no accident that seven of the seats which the government won from the coalition in the election were in Victoria and Tasmania. Once again, the recent polls show that industrial relations is not the issue as it was before the lead-up to the federal election. People now see that this government is a responsible government when it comes to industrial relations.

The Victorian approach to industrial relations, the approach which the honourable member for Bennelong wanted to introduce across Australia in the jobsback policy, is a failure. It has done nothing to make workplaces in that state more productive. Sadly, the honourable member for Bennelong and the coalition have not recognised this fact. Some people are slow learners. Those opposite really are slow learners when it comes to industrial relations.

Honourable members opposite continue to push for an industrial relations system based on individual employment contracts and where the safety net provided by the award system is taken away from Australian workers. It is essential to look at the confrontationist policies being proposed by the coalition in order to understand why this government rejects those policies and why it has chosen the new industrial relations model contained in this legislation. The honourable member for Bennelong has indicated that the only part of the jobsback policy which the coalition took to the last election that will change is the $3-an-hour youth wage; I am not sure what he would do with it. Despite this change, the coalition's policy remains a very reactionary prescription.

The introduction of the coalition's industrial relations policy would mean that all workers would lose the protection of the award system and be forced into individual contracts except where their boss deigns to allow them to stay with the award. The only conditions employees would be guaranteed would be the base minimum rate of the old award, annual leave, sick leave and maternity leave. Workers would stand to lose their penalty rates, overtime rates, shift allowances, holiday loadings, award superannuation and redundancy entitlements.

Another great achievement of this government has been to provide superannuation for the Australian work force so that they can prepare for their retirement. But, under the policy proposals of the honourable member for Bennelong and the rest of those opposite, there would be no limits on the number of hours worked in a day and workers would lose their public holidays, rest and meal breaks and their right to permanent employment, which could be replaced by casual employment. Under the coalition's model there would be a requirement for individual employment contracts to be registered or checked by an independent body. In addition, employees coerced into unfair contracts would have no right of appeal to an independent arbitrator such as the Industrial Relations Commission. Unions would have no place in the negotiation of individual contracts, even if employees nominated them to negotiate on their behalf.

The most significant issues in Australian industrial relations are improving work practices, increasing productivity and protecting workers in a weak bargaining position relative to their employers. Unfortunately, the coalition's industrial relations policy does nothing to address these issues. All it has to offer Australian workers is the removal of the safety net provided by the Industrial Relations Commission, leaving them open to exploitation by employers who would be in a position to take away many of their basic rights and conditions. The sole aim of the opposition in industrial relations is to cut wages through the destruction of trade unions and the industrial tribunals.

The Keating Labor government utterly rejects this divisive and confrontationist approach. The Industrial Relations Reform Bill contains the federal government's drive towards a more decentralised industrial relations system. It is designed to encourage more bargaining at the workplace and enterprise level, and to reduce the reliance of parties involved in negotiations on arbitration to resolve differences. It represents a new approach to industrial relations for the changing reality of the Australian work force as we approach the 21st century. The new system will create a more flexible framework while at the same time protecting people who have little to bargain or who are in a weak bargaining position. This is a crucial difference between the government's industrial relations policy and the policies of those opposite, which are the same for most coalition type parties in Australia.

Our system protects workers' wages and conditions through the award system and by the no disadvantage test in the federal Industrial Relations Act. If the coalition followed the example of the Kennett government in Victoria, which it has supported on occasions, it would abolish the safety net of the award system. Workers would only have the protection of a minimum hourly wage, four weeks annual leave, one week sick leave per year and 12 months unpaid parental leave. Jeff Kennett's so-called industrial relations reforms simply swept away every other award condition. One of the principal goals of the legislation is to encourage a wider use of workplace agreements—and that should be encouraged.

As I said earlier, the workplace agreements already cover 37 per cent of employees under federal awards. This legislation will continue to encourage that process. While this is a substantial proportion of Australian workers, the government recognises the need to encourage the further decentralisation of our industrial relations system. While the government is keen to encourage Australian workers, their unions and employers to come to agreements on working conditions amongst themselves, these agreements are based on the condition that any pre-existing federal award previously operating in that workplace is not weakened. Under this legislation the award system will be maintained, providing a floor for wages and conditions which cannot be undercut by directly negotiated agreements. It will be the duty of the Industrial Relations Commission to protect these basic rates of pay and conditions of employment.

This bill will ensure that awards become more up to date and relevant to the modern workplace. It will encourage workers, unions and management to work together to reach agreements on how to organise the way work is done at an enterprise level. It is also designed to encourage the insertion of enterprise flexibility clauses into awards by the commission. Individual enterprises, with the agreement of that person's work force, will be able to make variations to the provisions of awards which apply to that person as long as the workers concerned are not disadvantaged.

One section of the legislation which I am particularly proud to support as a Labor member of parliament is the section that gives all workers without adequate protection access to minimum conditions of wages, equal pay for equal work, unpaid parental leave and certain rights relating to the termination of their employment. These are basic rights which all workers are entitled to, but which have been taken away under the reactionary policies of the conservative governments of states such as Victoria and Western Australia. The safeguarding of these rights throughout this legislation meets Australia's international obligations under International Labour Organisation conventions and other international treaties.

One aspect of this section of the legislation which is particularly pleasing to me is the section which places certain obligations on employers who terminate the employment of 15 or more of their workers for economic, technological or structural reasons. The Industrial Relations Commission will be able to order consultation with workers' representatives and it will also be under an obligation to notify the Commonwealth Employment Service. All too often major employers, particularly in regional areas, such as my own, make unilateral decisions to close down their operations without any recognition on their part of their obligations to the welfare of their employees or to the social impact of the closure on the area where the business is located.

In my electorate, at the present time, there is a clothing factory called the House of Jenyns, which is owned by a company called Tri-International. There is also a similar factory in the southern suburbs of Brisbane in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca). As a result of this company deciding to close and move offshore, it is effectively putting 400 people out of work—that is directly. I have been rather concerned and particularly critical of that company in the way it has gone about that process. Whilst negotiations are going on now with the workers, when the workers went to negotiate a redundancy package it was rejected by the company. It has now been resolved, but only after those men and, as I said, women in the work force were forced to picket the building and take very strong industrial action. That was something that they did not want to do, but it was forced upon them. They had very little choice but to force that issue and they have now been able to negotiate a reasonable redundancy package. But, overall, I believe that company should have done more to try to change with the times rather than trying to compete in a textile industry that has seen massive changes.

The federal government has been mindful of the need to assist the textile industry, as most honourable members from Victoria would know. There have been positive moves made in that direction over some time. Unfortunately, this company chose not to take it up. I just received a letter from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) today saying just that. But I hope that company will reconsider its position in the likelihood of trying to continue to operate those two clothing factories in Queensland and ensure that we keeps those jobs. That is just one of the areas that I wanted in particular to highlight in this debate.

I am sure that this bill is something all workers will be proud of and will welcome. I mentioned before the hard work that has been done by the minister and the negotiations he has undertaken. I now come back to the point that I was making about these employers. The provision I referred to in the bill will ensure that employers at least sit down and negotiate reasonable termination conditions with members of their work force before putting them off. That is an important reason that I mentioned before—but the Department of Employment, Education and Training has a role to play through the CES there. So, by notifying the CES, the employer will also enable the CES to develop a package of employment and training options for the retrenched workers. My local DEET office in Ipswich is actually doing that at the present time and I commend the staff's efforts in that regard. I was talking to the regional manager there only today to ensure that that is still in train.

The legislative entitlement to 12 months unpaid parental leave is another welcome initiative contained in this legislation. It is a somewhat modern thing. It is funny how the world changes because I can remember at a union conference in Albury-Wodonga many years ago I raised this issue and somebody thought it was a crazy idea. That person felt that mum should be at home with the children and dad should be at work. But I think the world has changed a bit and that it has become a bit more modern. The motion I put before the conference was rejected. The only supporters I had on the floor at the conference were the few women members. Strangely enough, the males did not want to support the motion. They were members of the banking industry and I hope that they have changed their attitudes a bit.

Having moved around the countryside a bit in a transient sort of job when working for a bank, I ran into that particular problem where parental leave was essential when people did not have their families close by them. In a country such as Australia where people move around a fair bit, it is pretty important. I have the large air force base, Amberley, in my electorate, as I often remind the House. The defence people in that area are also affected in the same way. So I hope they can be assisted somewhere like that as well. Before entering parliament I became most aware of the need for that type of legislation with my own family.

Increasingly, many families find themselves through choice and necessity in the situation where both parents are working. In modern Australia, that does happen and it is something that needs to be recognised more clearly. These sorts of proposals in the legislation will address those issues. Clearly the family unit is not to suffer—that is important. I just saw an item on the TV news where there was a big push to give the family unit more recognition. I think that helps the family unit in a lot of ways, by having the parents being able to work together. So for both parents to be able to take time off for the birth of a child is particularly important. I think that is something we should be very proud to support in this parliament. Such conditions are particularly important for workers subject to frequent transfers, as I mentioned before. It is not only in the areas that I mentioned before, for bank employees and defence personnel, but it is also for people in telecommunication areas and the like.

This legislation really strikes a right balance between making our industrial relations system more flexible and protecting the rights and conditions of Australian workers. It allows our industrial relations system to adapt to the needs of the Australian work force as we enter the 21st century, while also maintaining a safety net for workers in a weak bargaining position. They are very important areas.

I briefly come to the role of the trade union movement. I believe that in modern times in Australia our trade union movement has been second to none. It has been extremely responsible in its attitudes. The minister well knows how hard representatives of the trade union movement can be in negotiations. I know how they were in this particular situation. But at the end of the day, they sat down at the table with the minister and negotiated a very fair package for the Australian work force.

I commend the trade union movement—from the ACTU down to individual unions—for working through that, and I commend the minister and his staff for assisting in that area. It has been a difficult period for the minister to develop this legislation and it is right to give him the credit that is due. I was somewhat critical of the legislation in its early stages, but I believe that those concerns came out of my experience in my home state where there were great problems with the SEQEB dispute many years ago. I commend the bill to the House. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mick Jagger, that elastic example of baby boomer musicians, once recorded a song which, in part, says:

SPEECH.PARA: Let's work be proud
Stand tall touch the clouds
Men and women be free let's work
Get down in the dirt let's work
Get up be free
Get down in the dirt
Take off your shirt
Let's work be proud.

Listening to this debate on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill, I wonder whether those opposite feel proud that they are encouraging Australians to feel wasted and at the bottom of the labour pile when it comes to negotiating with the majority of Australian employers. I note that Jagger's song comes from his Sticky Fingers album, which sets the scene for many taking part in this debate.

PARA.TAB: I have listened with interest to the speakers opposite as each has risen to support the legislation. I listened with the hope of hearing a proper understanding of economics and what makes the community go around, and I have been disappointed with the result. Not one speaker has understood the very basis of the future of our country; that is, that there is no work for Australians if there are no companies to employ them. That means that there is no work for Australians wishing to maintain their lifestyle; no work for those Australians wanting to care for their families. There is no work for Australians. No employers means no employees.

Equally as important, as stated by each of the government speakers, no employees means no employers. But is this notion correct? Can a company operate without employees, thus increasing the unemployment queues? The answer to that conundrum, as we move towards the technological age, is simply: yes, it can happen. Our Labor colleagues have not quite come to terms with the fact that those who take the risk of investing money—and we should not be afraid to talk about money—will not do it if investment is made difficult, and why should they?

Our friends opposite will say, `They have a duty—a moral right to invest their money and employ people'. The reality is that investors, whether they be small business or large business, will not invest and thus employ if it is made difficult for them. It is time that those opposite realised that commercial investment is the basis of our social justice and the ongoing welfare of our community, not the ripping apart of the very fabric of the commercial aspect of our community.

The world is rapidly changing. Over 200 years ago, with the evolution into the industrial age, the world rapidly changed to industrialisation. Those who took advantage of that time were the capitalists who invested in industrialisation. Those countries wishing to hang on to the old ways and not wanting to change were left behind in the developing world. The need for unions was essential during that period, and they did their job very well, helping the evolution of communities from the agricultural age to the new industrialised world. They worked hard to gain many social justice reforms, and they helped to ensure that our communities were held responsible for the care of our fellow man. Unions had a very important role to play.

However, their time has passed, because the challenges which they faced, and duly accepted are no longer with us. The unions no longer play the dominant role within the community that they would have us believe. The membership of unions is reducing with no sign of reversal. Why is this the case? It is my view that unions are becoming irrelevant to the majority of those employed. In my view, one of the reasons for this is that their secretaries and their officers have never been on the factory floor. Most union officials come from universities and then move on to politics, and their members are becoming disappointed with the treatment they receive from their so-called union officials. Technology and its new work demands are upon us and, as we move quickly to the technological or knowledge age, we are finding that the union movement is becoming more and more irrelevant.

As the world's national boundaries break down we are witnessing an increased flow of information. For instance, it is now possible for a graphic designer in my electorate of Cowan to do in one hour what would have normally taken three days to do, and then he can send it off to anywhere in the world and communicate by computer. How does the union movement intend to compete with employees working to satisfy international clients when the need for structured hours and conditions are no longer there? At this very minute the world is trying to re-centre itself. It is desperately trying to build a new set of rules and values that mesh with the emerging social system—a system which many people do not quite understand. No longer can we allow ourselves to be like ostriches, simply putting our heads in the sand.

Right now, at the head of every major radio and TV broadcast, we hear and see the issue of values—or, more precisely, the lack of them—being raised. We are microscopically examining our values both in the workplace and at the home to discover how we evolved to the position we are in now, but, more importantly, how to redirect some of the potentially wrong turns that we have taken. We all begin life with a clean slate and pick and choose a variety of values as we approach adulthood. Along the way we change and adapt our values based on circumstances and situations set before us. One might say, `But my values have never changed'—I think that has been evidenced by those opposite during this debate—values like `all bosses rip off their employees', `all bosses don't care about their employees', and `only the union can provide employees safety nets'. I quote from yesterday's Hansard where the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) was giving an example of these values. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: A typical workplace would be a small wholesale company, which employs 20 workers and is non-unionised—
It is probably paying payroll tax. He went on to say:
There are numerous grievances. . . the boss is pretty obnoxious, he has a son on the payroll who sexually harasses some of the . . . staff—that sort of thing happens all the time—

He said that that was a typical workplace. Those opposite have clearly stated that enterprise bargaining came from the union movement. That is absolutely bunkum because this type of employee relationship—enterprise bargaining—was first developed by an American called Demming back in the 1950s when he went to Japan and developed it there. These values of the industrial age that the union movement talks about are quite out of turn. As we move into this new technological age we need a change in values. This enterprise bargaining idea was not the union's idea but Demming's idea back in the 50s.

PARA.TAB: The development of Japan and its social wealth has been well documented. It started not with the workers but with the employers. So to put forth the myth that enterprise agreements are the idea of the unions is absolute rubbish. The world of business, as any smart business person knows, is that the company's assets leave at five o'clock every day. If they do not come back the following morning, there are no assets left. The smart employers know that their staff are their major asset. I would think that this is the view of many, or perhaps even most, of the business people in Australia. To think any less is inviting chaos and uncertainty about a company's viability. A partnership between employees and employer is required, not a confrontationist approach from those with the industrial value that employers are the ones holding back development. We need greater negotiation than the union movement is prepared to have.

No Australian wants to screw another Australian to the ground. Crooks do, yet crooks can be found in employers and employees as well as unions. No-one has the absolute mortgage on purity when it comes to industrial relations. So there is no point in confusing this debate with the bunkum spoken by some of these pro-unionists.

This legislation is full of the values of the past. It ensures the values of payback to the union movement for its role in ensuring the return of the government at the last election. The union movement was faced with the reduction of the old, archaic industrial values it has held for many years and its leaders, rather than accept change, have demanded that their politician boys respond and respect their closed values and not place them at any threat.

The Labor Party, respecting these old world values, has responded and ensured ongoing discrimination within our industrial relations processes. It has not met the challenge of the new age of technology. To fully understand the values of the union movement and its political arm, the Labor Party, no better example is the attitude of the President of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court from 1907 to 1921, Henry Bournes Higgins, described as a middle-class radical and social reformer appointed to his life's work by Deakin.

Higgins placed his stamp upon the arbitration court with his Harvester judgment in 1907 which enshrined fair and reasonable wages. The result of this decision was the establishment of the first award wage. He based the 42 shillings a week calculation on the right of a worker with five children. Also taken into account were such things as lighting, clothing, boots, furniture, utensils, rates, life insurance, savings, accident or benefit societies, loss of employment, union pay, books and newspapers, tram and train fares, sewing machines, mangles, school requisites, amusements and holidays, intoxicating liquors, tobacco, sickness and death, religion or charity.

This wage fixation system was based on human need, not on profits or productivity. It entrenched the idea of the minimum wage being set by judicial decree. It enshrined the idea of the minimum wage which was sacrosanct and introduced the notion of family welfare into wage setting. It established the notion of the cost of living as a basis for wage movements. Yet, as the world changes, these principles of the union movement and its colleagues opposite do not.
Higgins was ruthless with his desire to protect his stand. In 1909, with the BHP case, Higgins said that it would be preferable to shut down the mine if BHP could not pay the minimum rate. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: If it is a calamity that this historic mine should close down, it would be a greater calamity that men should be underfed or degraded.

Unemployment, by implication, was preferable to cheap labour. These are the values of the labour movement through the union movement and its political wing—`Send the company to the wall, put our brothers on the unemployment line, and long live those still working'. This value has finished for many within industry and commerce and it seems the only ones wishing to hold onto such a concept are the unions and their spokespeople opposite. I wonder what the one in 10 Australians who are currently out of work think about this attitude—`Send the company to the wall, put our brothers on the unemployment line'.

PARA.TAB: The legislation before us stands out for one thing and one thing only: it is the total capitulation to the union movement's old age values and is a payback for electoral support. To support this payback notion, I would like to quote Ms Jennie George, a vice-president of the ACTU. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: What the employers have got to understand is that we won the election in March and this bill is payback for the commitments that were made by the government in the course of the election campaign.
This bill is another chapter in the long history of this government paying its political dues to the trade union movement of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Because of this bill it will now be more expensive to employ an Australian worker—not for the reasons of those opposite when they suggest that actual wage costs will go down. On this side of the House we support and always have supported the concept of a fair wage for fair work. This coalition view is, I believe, the view of many Australians and is part of our national ethos.

The real cost of employing people is not wages but rather the silent on-costs associated with wages and salaries. It would be surprising to some to learn that in some cases for every $1 spent on wages by companies a further $2 is spent on essential on-costs. Therefore, salary rates are not the issue that many naive-to-business speakers on the other side have stated. Rather, the on-costs are what employers are seeking flexibility with within this bill. But the bill fails to address these issues.

On-costs like payroll tax and the rates of insurances required to employ staff are good examples of what I am talking about. This bill does not relieve these costs of employing people and, therefore, does not support the notion of reducing unemployment. The bill is too rigid for enterprises—and by enterprises I mean companies and not the industries with which the unions prefer to deal.

In the past, industry work conditions have favoured larger companies capable of supporting such conditions. But small business has been sacrificed to the tragic expense of the increasing number of unemployed in Australia, which is now over one in 10. This was the doctrine of Higgins and remains the highly principled values of the union movement and its political wing.

This bill is against the basic principles of human rights and discriminates against many Australians. For instance, the bill refers to the noble right to strike. But where is the clause that refers to the right to work? The bill requires employers not to discriminate against union members. But where is the clause protecting non-union members? These are two examples of the bill protecting the ageing and outdated values of the union movement.

The bill is cumbersome and is piecemeal in its presentation, for it has over 35 pages covering some 200 amendments. This bill requires employers operating a non-union enterprise to go through four union protected hoops for approval of its agreement. Firstly, notification has to be made to a union to which no-one belongs; secondly, the company then has to observe the award and conditions of a union to which no-one belongs; thirdly, the enterprise then has to seek the approval of the industrial relations court; and, fourthly, the enterprise then has to seek approval from unions to which no-one belongs.

This is not enterprise bargaining or a company negotiating with its staff. This is the retention of the dinosaur values—outdated values—driven by the union movement. This bill does not address the demanding issues of the 21st century workplace and continues the dominance of a minority group within the industrial relations system. It is a sad reflection upon the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton), noted for his terrier skills in getting what he wants, and it is a sad day that we as an independent nation are hamstrung by the needs of a small group of self-interested, politically ambitious union representatives, like many on the other side.

It is time that we accept that the majority of Australians, whether they be employers or employees, are fair-minded and want to contribute to the development of our great country. This is not a time to encourage the withdrawal of investment in Australia by placing huge demands upon employers. It is a time for our community to work together in a sensible way to solve the problems of unemployment. It is not the time for the Higgins doctrine to continue to be driven by this union movement and its colleagues within its political arm.

It is time that the union movement and the Australian Labor Party realised that the way to solve our problems within this country is to work together. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), said the bill was a great achievement for workers, the union movement and the Labor Party. But honourable members opposite do not seem to realise that there are two parts to any industrial relations process: one is the worker providing labour; the other is the employer providing investment. If there is no employer, there is no employee. Unfortunately, those opposite and those terriers within the union movement do not quite understand the concept. They do not understand where the money or investment come from. Mick Jagger said, `I can't get no satisfaction'. I cannot get any from this bill either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haviland Mr C.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993. During the last federal election campaign, three major issues dominated the political debate. It was those same three issues which clearly demonstrated the differences between the Labor government and the opposition. Two of these were taxation, specifically the GST, and Medicare. The third was industrial relations.

PARA.TAB: We saw the opposition's attitude to industrial relations during the election campaign. Led by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the Liberal and National parties proposed to replace industrial awards with individual contracts, abolish the existing arbitration system and force young people onto wages of $3.50 an hour. The opposition's Jobsback policies were to be the most savage attack on the workers of this country ever proposed. The policy talked about greater flexibility in wages and conditions but those opposite were talking about flexibility one way—down for wages. They wanted to cut wages. We have only to look at what the Kennett government in Victoria has done to see what we would have had nationally had the coalition been elected.

Fortunately, although it is taking the opposition a while to understand it, the people of Australia emphatically rejected the draconian, anti-worker proposals; and the government was returned. By the time this legislation and Mabo are passed it will be close to Christmas and we will all have a break. The opposition may finally come to understand who won the last election—and who did not.

This bill has followed much consultation with the trade union movement, particularly through the ACTU. The opposition has a bit of a problem with this; it does not like us talking to the ACTU. It does not understand that the ACTU is a pretty significant peak council in this country; it represents the trade union movement. Trade unions are the legitimate and historical representatives of workers; and workers, of course, are people.

The honourable member for Cowan (Mr Evans) said that there cannot be employees without employers, but the reverse is obviously true as well. It is on the backs of the workers that this country survives. I am proud to be a former trade unionist and to be part of a government that consults with the ACTU. There were also consultations with employers.

As a former trade unionist, I understand the concerns that many in the union movement had originally with many of the proposals foreshadowed in the drafting of this bill. There were some tense times between the government and the union movement in the lead-up to the legislation. The main concern surrounded the proposal to provide access to enterprise agreements for non-unionists within the system of enterprise bargaining. I can well understand the concerns of the union movement about this, as I will explain later.

I have always had reservations about the concept of enterprise bargaining and the decentralisation of industrial relations. I always took the view that the decentralised system that we have had for most of this century, whilst by no means perfect, has served us well. Enterprise bargaining, on the other hand, is a by-product of the New Right economic rationalist thinking which dominated economic policy during the 1980s. It had the potential of breaking up the union movement into bite-sized chunks—just the right size to be gobbled up by predatory employers, particularly in the event of a coalition government either at state or federal level.

However, the ACTU and the trade union movement, in their wisdom, embraced enterprise bargaining. I emphasise that the brand of enterprise bargaining supported by this government, and agreed to by the ACTU, was vastly different from the sort of enterprise bargaining advocated by the opposition and some employers. One would question whether the opposition supports enterprise bargaining at all. It appears to be more interested in individual bargaining than in any genuine collective bargaining at enterprise level; that is, bypassing unions and `negotiating' with workers one by one. We all know what that means.

The icon of the New Right, the small business spokesperson Mr Peter Boyle, responded when asked a question about what would happen if an employee did not like a draft contract provided by an employer, `Beggars can't be choosers'. It is pretty obvious what he means by that: if an individual supposedly negotiating wages and conditions with an all-powerful employer did not like what was offered, that person would be shown the door and told, `Don't come back on Monday; find another job if you can. Good luck'.

That is what the opposition policies are all about. Let us not have this nonsense about genuine enterprise bargaining and flexibility. It wanted the flexibility to have a totally employer-dominated market. As I said, the ACTU embraced a system of enterprise bargaining which was underpinned by the award system. It was inevitable, in my view, that there would be pressure in some industries for access to enterprise bargaining for those workers who were not members of unions.

As I said earlier, this aspect of the bill initially caused most concern to the ACTU and the affiliated unions. It is a fair question: why should the benefits of trade union membership be shared by people who are not members? In any other organisation such as a club or service organisation it is accepted that the benefits of membership are enjoyed only by those people who join the organisation and pay their subscriptions.

TALK.START.PARA: —So why force them to be members of the union?
—Why should the benefits such as better wages and conditions, which have been negotiated and won over decades through the benefits of trade unions, be available at no cost to non-unionists?
—They will negotiate their own.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland!

TALK.START.PARA: —I ignore the interjections, Mr Deputy Speaker. This question is equally valid whether we talk about industrial awards which have been achieved by union representation over time or the benefits of enterprise agreements negotiated by unions for their members and is why the union movement was concerned. The issue has been a very sore point for a long time, especially in the public sector. In the public sector all employees enjoy the benefits—
—Your solution is to make everybody join a union.

—Scab employees enjoy the benefits of awards and conditions, and only 60 or 70 per cent of employees in the public sector are members of unions. Having said that, the reality is that in the private sector 71 per cent of workers currently are not members of a trade union. There are many reasons for this. To put this figure into context, while only 29 per cent of workers in the private sector are union members, about 82 per cent of workplaces have some union members, or at least are under union coverage. This still leaves about 18 per cent of workplaces virtually non-unionised.

PARA.TAB: There are many reason why this is the case. It is not as simple as saying that people do not want to join a union. Many of the non-unionised workplaces are small businesses, including family businesses. It is quite understandable that many workers in these situations have never seen a practical need to be a member of a union. This would apply particularly where the nature of the employment is such that it would be unclear to an individual which union might cover that person and whether the union's coverage would be relevant or beneficial in the particular circumstance.

Another issue is accessibility to union membership. In some industries, particularly the newer ones such as the computer industry, tourism, other service industries and some parts of the retail sector, there may be no union which has had traditional or well-established coverage of the work involved. I am sorry that the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) has left because I would have liked to hear his response to what I am about to say. There are many examples of a worker wanting to become a member of a union but being afraid to do so for fear of being dismissed. Some people join the relevant union but keep this fact secret from the employer.

One fast food chain is notorious for this situation. This would have become a much greater problem had the coalition been elected because its policies would have facilitated and even encouraged exploitation of workers, which sometimes occurs now in the industrially weak areas of the work force. There are many reasons why it may be impractical, or at the least difficult, for individual workers to join unions, let alone become active members. Perhaps some unions need to upgrade their coverage of recruitment arrangements to reflect the changing nature and types of industries—although I am certain the union movement is already mindful of this fact.

In any event, with the statistics that I have referred to in mind, and particularly with the decentralisation of industrial relations and the emergence of enterprise based bargaining, it was inevitable that there would be a need to consider the issue of access to enterprise bargaining for those workers who, for whatever reasons, are not members of unions. So, with the legitimate concerns of the union movement in mind, the government has produced a system outlined in this bill which allows that access for non-unionists under a set of conditions which emphasises and retains the primacy of the award system; which protects minimum standards; which provides a no disadvantage test in enterprise agreements; which indeed provides that there must be an award in place before any such agreement is reached; which gives registered unions access to industrial relations proceedings before agreements are ratified; and which protects union members against discrimination and victimisation in the workplace.

The bill also removes a number of draconian and outdated provisions in existing legislation as has been sought by the union movement. Obvious examples of that are the removal of sections 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act. Some people in the union movement will still be concerned about certain aspects of this bill, particularly the issue that I have mentioned of non-unionist access to the system of enterprise agreements. But, as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said about Mabo, nobody will get everything that they want from this bill. Having said that, I believe it will go a long way towards satisfying the concerns of a majority of reasonable people.

I believe that this bill throws out a worthy challenge to unions. Put simply, the challenge to unions is to go out and recruit more members. With the award system still in place and with unions retaining their rightful place as the principal players representing workers, there is plenty that unions have to offer to prospective members. As I have said, unions will need to adapt their recruitment techniques, public relations and internal structures to reflect the changing work force of the 1990s and beyond. Much has been done in this area already. However, the efficiencies gained by union amalgamations will need to be balanced against the need for unions to be relevant and responsive to workers at the grassroots level, particularly with a view to making inroads into that 71 per cent of non-union members in the private sector.

I now turn to a matter which can only emphasise the importance of having a fair, just and cohesive industrial relations system such as that outlined in this bill, as opposed to the law of the jungle approach favoured by those opposite. I draw the attention of honourable members to report No. 326 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled An assessment of tax, which was tabled yesterday. I particularly refer honourable members to the dissenting report of Senator Bronwyn Bishop and specifically to her concerns on industrial relations which are covered at pages 431 to 434 of the report. Senator Bishop says of the modernisation agreement between the tax office and the Pubic Sector Union:

SPEECH.PARA: The Agreement was intended to commit the PSU to the ATO's ten-year modernisation program aimed to improve the efficiency and productivity of the ATO.

Certainly, that was true. It was aimed at improving the efficiency and productivity, and it certainly is doing that. That is about where any semblance of the truth in relation to Senator Bishop's report ends. Senator Bishop, when talking about this modernisation agreement in the tax office, says that overgenerous benefits were given to the PSU. Let us look at the so-called overgenerous benefits and privileges that the would-be honourable member for Mackellar has suggested. She says that the union was given privileges to which it should otherwise not have been entitled. She also says:
From the outset, the Union was promised no compulsory retrenchments as a result of modernisation and no reduction in the classification of positions.
Is that not outrageous? Senator Bishop obviously has not done her homework at all, because that is standard practice in any negotiation which involves possible retrenchment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak under the standing order relating to relevance. I fail to see how the description of a dissenting report by a senator in the other place in any way relates to the bill before the House. If the honourable member is able to draw our attention to specific clauses, it may be relevant.

—The honourable member for Gippsland will resume his seat. The honourable member for Macarthur is using the dissenting report to illustrate a case study of a union's industrial relations practices in the workplace. He is in order; he will continue.

—Let us have a look at a few more of these `outrageous' privileges that the union was granted in this agreement, which was a pretty historic agreement. To use the jargon these days, it could almost be said as being the best practice in industrial democracy or industrial relations. As I have said, it is important to have legislation like we have at the moment—not to take the law of the jungle approach as those on the other side have. Let us have a look at these so-called outrageous concessions that the union was given in the tax office. Senator Bishop claims that there was a bar placed by this agreement on consultants and contractors. If she is so concerned about taxpayers' money and costs, surely she can understand that any consultant or contractor will cost the taxpayer a lot more than it would if the work was done by an officer of the tax office. It is a pretty stupid statement to make if she is talking seriously about saving taxpayers' money.

PARA.TAB: I move on to even more outrageous statements by Senator Bishop, the would-be honourable member for Mackellar. She says:

SPEECH.PARA: To say some of the terms reached in relation to the work environment were overgenerous is an understatement. For instance, no staff member is to be required to work for more than four hours on any one day on keyboard duties.

Heavens above! Does Senator Bishop not realise that the 50 per cent keying rule is a standard practice in the public sector and, if it is not standard practice in the private sector, it certainly should be. This originated from a report commissioned by the Public Service Board in 1983, because the Public Service Board and the government were concerned about the incidence of repetitive strain injury—otherwise known as RSI—in the work force. I would have thought that Senator Bishop would have been a bit more concerned for the female work force than to criticise any agreement which provides protection for keyboard workers.

PARA.TAB: The incidence of RSI was so great that the result of this report led to significant reforms which were in the second tier wage agreement in 1987. They were also endorsed in the national wage principle that year. Senator Bishop would not realise this, because she never does her homework; she just likes to grandstand. But the reality is that the second tier wage agreement in the Australian Public Service is one of the most far reaching and historic agreements that there have ever been. It created huge efficiencies and micro-economic reforms in the Australian public sector. It amalgamated the divisions of the Public Service, it created a single career stream rather than having all of those anomalies and stereotype jobs—particularly keyboard workers who were predominantly low paid female workers in those days—and it provided protection against overuse of keyboards. It is standard in the public sector—and should be if it is not already in the private sector—that keyboard operators should not work more than half of any one day on the keyboard.
Senator Bishop then goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Officers who are required to use screen-based equipment will be entitled to free eyesight tests, and where spectacles are required for such work, the ATO will be required to reimburse the cost of standard frames and monofocal lenses.

What a terrible thing! I happen to have a bit of a background on this issue because in 1980, at an annual general meeting of the union of which I was a member, a resolution was passed in my name which set in motion a review of policy of the then ACOA on screen based equipment. That led to the union's comprehensive policy on screen based equipment which, in turn, led to significant negotiations in areas like social security with the Stratplan agreement and then, eventually, the modernisation agreement. Now the PSU has across the board agreements about screen based equipment. When there is new technology, there are the dangers of overuse of screen based equipment and appropriate occupational health and safety measures have to be put in place, just as has to be done for keyboard work.

PARA.TAB: It is absolutely amazing that Senator Bishop appears to have no knowledge of occupational health and safety matters, let alone decent industrial relations practices. Indeed one could say that the tax office, if it does not have proper practices in place to safeguard against injury to keyboard workers or people using screen based equipment and suddenly has a lot of compensation cases, could be very heavily criticised. Its Comcare premiums might go up, not to mention other legal actions that could be taken against the tax office. That seems to have escaped Senator Bishop and those on the other side who do not believe in good industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any chance of getting back to the bill?

—We are talking about industrial relations. Unfortunately, the honourable member opposite does not understand that. Those opposite obviously do not understand industrial relations at all. It is just as well that they did not get elected; that is all I can say. They do not understand workers; they have probably never met a worker in their lives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993. This bill chains us to the rocks as we face an incoming tide. The tide of reform in the world economy is moving consistently towards more flexible working arrangements. The government has acknowledged this by supporting limited enterprise bargaining but, as they are controlled by thier union masters, this bill firmly chains Australian workers to the rocks of the award system. Our only option is to manage change to ensure that we improve our international competitiveness in a way which is socially beneficial.

PARA.TAB: Our centralised system of wage fixation maintains a complex system of awards governing wages and conditions of employment. It is outmoded in the dynamic international labour market in which we find ourselves. As a result it is a barrier to job creation. Professor Garnaut recently said:

SPEECH.PARA: Through closer integration with the international economy . . . and improvements in competitiveness, Australia can restore full employment. This may not be full employment with a distribution of income that Australians judge to be just. But high unemployment is the worst injustice and a fully employed, competitive Australia will have the economic resources to provide services through government budgets to those Australians who are dealt the weakest hand in the marketplace.

I will focus on how this bill will affect women in the work force. I do so not only because there are so few women in the House to provide this perspective, but also because women as a group are a good case study to highlight the impact of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Fifty-two per cent of women are in the paid work force. Gender segregation of the work force is more pronounced in Australia than in comparable countries. In Australia 36 per cent of full-time, full-year female workers are employed in clerical occupations, and 16 per cent are in sales work. Women are concentrated in areas which receive wages below the national average.

Within individual workplaces women tend to occupy lower status and lower paid positions—the glass ceiling effect. Women's career progress tends to be less than that of men. Women are more likely than men to drop out of the work force to embrace family responsibilities. Women have less access to accredited training than do men. Women's skills tend to be undervalued and under-recognised. Women are more likely than men to be poorly paid.
Social conditioning continues to tell against women who attempt to negotiate a better deal. Dale Spender reputedly summed it up when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: When men and women argue, women lose.
Women are disadvantaged when, as is all too frequently the case, women have to deal with male employers. They have this weight of disadvantage holding them up.

PARA.TAB: So what are unions doing to help women? It could be argued that, working from a position of disadvantage, women could therefore benefit from the support of the union movement. However, unions do not represent women. Women predominate in areas which have less industrial muscle. In August 1992 only 35 per cent of female employees were union members compared with 43 per cent of male workers. Women who work less than full-time hours are less likely to be unionists than women in full-time work. In 1992, only 16.5 per cent of female casual employees were union members.

Women who work in locations which employ fewer than 10 workers are far less likely to be members of trade unions than are women who work in large workplaces, and 12.1 per cent of women who work in locations which employ fewer than 10 staff are union members. In workplaces which employ over 100 workers, this figure rises to 52.8 per cent. Women are also under-represented in union structures. In mid-1992, only 10 of the 38 people who held executive positions within the Australian Council of Trade Unions were women. Three of those positions were affirmative action positions.

Let us never forget that, historically, unions have opposed women being allowed into the work force, on the ground that they were taking men's jobs. Although the union movement has affirmed a commitment to improving the gender balance within its structures, the fact remains that at present unions cannot hope to represent the interests of women, particularly women who work part time in small businesses.

Enterprise bargaining offers the prospects of huge benefits for Australian women workers. For example, take the case of maternity leave. Under the awards, women in full-time employment taking maternity leave must come back full time at the completion of their leave. But many women would prefer to move progressively back into full-time work, starting a day here or there as a casual—perhaps coming back a day or two a week as the child settles into child care—and eventually resuming full-time work. With this sort of flexibility workers are more likely to return to work earlier, ensuring better skill retention. As a former manager, I know that there are great benefits in flexibility of working arrangements, including employee contentment, productivity and the retention of a highly skilled and loyal work force.

I welcome the provisions of this bill which legislate for unpaid parental leave as a minimum entitlement for all workers. However, we should be aware that the provision of parental leave is only half the solution. It is most important that there be flexible working arrangements to allow a worker returning to work after such leave to make the transition to work effectively. Perhaps enterprise bargaining will deliver this flexibility where the government has failed.

As women continue to be the primary caregivers in Australian society for both the young and the elderly, it is inevitable that they will have more complex needs in working arrangements. For example, female participation is often dependent on community services that are available only during normal working hours on weekdays, such as child care. Women will have to work twice as hard as men and be twice as smart to achieve their objectives in enterprise bargaining. But we should not walk away from that challenge. Firstly, we have been doing it for decades; secondly, we have much more to gain from the process.

I draw the attention of the House to proposals of the New South Wales Liberal government to improve career paths for women in the public sector under the nation's only female Minister for Industrial Relations and Employment, Mrs Chikarovski. The draft proposals include job sharing at all levels of the public service, with an emphasis on senior career positions; family leave to let workers legitimately take time off to care for children or sick or elderly relatives; part-time work, including three-day weeks or part-year employment to help working couples share in child rearing; and home based working. Mrs Chikarovski said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we're looking at encouraging work practices in the Public Service that allow women to work at their careers but take note that many have family responsibilities.
She noted that enterprise bargaining, which is being introduced progressively throughout the New South Wales Public Service, was an obvious way to introduce these reforms. She said:
Obviously, enterprise bargaining gives us the flexibility to do these sorts of things because you can start negotiating different work structures.
Professor Judith Sloan, another woman leader in the industrial relations field, has concluded:

Female workers have lower earnings because they are less skilled, have less education, have had interrupted work careers or have worked part-time. . . . The very circumstances of women, particularly arising from child-bearing and rearing, will limit their ability to undertake training, acquire further education and work full-time.

Of course, women do not apologise for putting priority on their families. Women value children and the elderly, and choose to care for them at a greater rate than do men. But we must take action to reduce the impact that this choice has on the employment prospects of women. For example, we should be providing education options which are accessible to women. Professor Sloan mentions the limited ability that women have to participate in training and further education.

PARA.TAB: The business courses at Macquarie University are a good case study. The Macquarie Graduate School of Management has been operating for 25 years, and has the oldest established Master of Business Administration degree in New South Wales. One of the school's key courses is the advanced management program, a four-week residential school which attracts about 40 participants, of which only one or two would be women. Mr Gregory Dunne, the General Manager of the school, has said:

SPEECH.PARA: The greatest difficulty for women is that they are not always accessible to the programs because they have other considerations, such as family, to take into account and being away from home for four weeks is simply out of the question.

The school has responded by structuring courses to take into account the dual role of many potential female attendees. The Women in Management course is held each year as a two-day non-residential course and regularly attracts hundreds of women. Courses such as the emerging managers program operate from 8.30 a.m. to 5.30 p.m., Monday to Friday, for two weeks with a break in the workplace in between.

PARA.TAB: The award system was established by men and for men. It must be opened up to the fresh winds of enterprise bargaining. All this bill does is reaffirm the government's commitment to the old, tired industrial relations system.

It is important to ask how enterprise bargaining is affecting women workers. There is still very little factual information about the impact that enterprise bargaining has had upon women in the work force.

Many agreements offer opportunities that will prove beneficial to both male and female workers. For example, the Bendix Mintex agreement incorporates a commitment to reduce the divide between management and staff by fostering a team approach.Some agreements will be particularly beneficial to those who shoulder the double shift of domestic and paid employment—that is, women. For example, the Optus agreement incorporates part-time work provisions especially designed to cater to those with family responsibilities.

Some agreements will need to be examined in their application to assess their impact upon women workers. For example, the AMP Customer Service Division agreement allows employees to work from home. It remains to be seen whether this clause proves beneficial to women who juggle work and family responsibilities or whether in fact it merely enables them to perform both their paid and unpaid occupations simultaneously.

I am not a blind zealot in my support for enterprise bargaining. I acknowledge the persistence of sexism and the resultant unequal bargaining relationships under which women must operate in the labour force. It is likely that some women will be disadvantaged by enterprise bargaining. In fact, I am concerned that some agreements already settled will operate to the detriment of women, especially those who have parenting responsibilities.

The Alcoa Point Henry agreement, for example, incorporates mandatory overtime shifts each week. Such a work pattern presents an obvious hurdle for workers with family responsibilities but will also prove detrimental to the spouses of those who do work under such arrangements—eliciting a domestic contribution from someone who has just worked 12 hours seems fairly unlikely.

The National Pay Equity Coalition conducted a review of the 20 largest agreements for its submission to the last national wage case. It found that women under enterprise bargaining agreements are less likely to participate and be represented in bargaining, are getting lower and later wage increases than men, and are getting less access to new classifications and training than are men.

There are features in the labour force which make women vulnerable in enterprise bargaining. Firstly, there is occupational segregation. Women are overrepresented in people oriented activities, such as sales and service work areas, where it is difficult to measure productivity. Women are overrepresented in less profitable industries, such as the textiles industry, where scope for productivity based wage increases is limited. Secondly, there is minority status. Women's interests are often overlooked when working conditions are agreed to by most workers and imposed on all workers. Thirdly, there is persistent sexism. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs acknowledged last year that sex discrimination continues to play a part in the subjection of women in the workplace. Research suggests that 10 per cent of the gender wages gap exists because of sex discrimination.

There is growing evidence that the centralised wage fixation system is failing women. After making consistent gains over the past 20 years, in the past two years women's pay has fallen from 84.6 per cent of men's full-time adult ordinary time earnings to 83.8 per cent. The award system has proven to be damaging to women even without overt discrimination on the face of the awards. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has found that sexual discrimination is a factor which leads to the lower overaward payments of women. In announcing the tabling of the report, Sex Discrimination Commissioner, Quentin Bryce, said:

SPEECH.PARA: This report sounds a warning of what could happen to women's wages in the move to a less regulated industrial system.
Overawards are payments negotiated outside the award structure. Women have been disadvantaged in this area because of their lack of bargaining power and because the work that they do is undervalued.
Unless safeguards are in place the earnings gap between men and women could widen even further.

We should not forget that this current web of discrimination was developed under a centralised wage fixing system. Centralism has not protected women from discrimination, neither have the unions. Women need to take action for themselves to craft working arrangements that are fair, flexible and efficient.

PARA.TAB: The likely impact of enterprise bargaining on women is not clear. A survey of federal enterprise agreements by the Commonwealth Department of Industrial Relations found that 24 per cent of men received a pay rise compared with 15 per cent of women. This may reflect that women are bargaining for non-wage benefits.

On the other hand, consider the situation that exists in the United States. The United States has one of the most deregulated labour markets in the world, and unionisation in the private sector is just above 10 per cent. Yet in the past decade the gender earnings differential has narrowed. Women's wages have increased from just over 60 per cent of male wages to over 70 per cent—a 10 per cent shift. The jury is still out.

As we develop enterprise bargaining we need to take measures to ensure that equal employment opportunity is not impeded. One proposal is that there should be a standards framework within which the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is subject to the advice of the Sex Discrimination Commissioner. The AIRC would have a monitoring role to order alterations to discriminatory agreements. Another would be to develop legislative minimum standards such as this bill contains.

However, the problem is that a formal standard for enterprise agreements will need to be so general that they will not highlight situations of discrimination. For example, the introduction of 12-hour shifts may not be discriminatory to most people who work in the particular enterprise, but many women are highly unlikely to be able to join that enterprise with shifts that make child care impossible. It is this indirect discrimination that is the greatest danger.

The best protection for women is women themselves. They know what their interests are. They need to be empowered to pursue them. The government has failed them, the centralised wage fixing system has failed them and the unions have failed them. Our first goal should be to provide widespread education for women workers. The President of the NSW Anti-Discrimination Board, Mr Steve Mark, has said:

SPEECH.PARA: People do not know that they are being disadvantaged and the most important issue we can focus on is education . . . Women are not consciously excluded but workplace committees are not forced to think about these issues.

Perhaps it would be helpful to require bargaining units to provide statements on the effect of their agreement on a set of underrepresented groups. Further, we should establish an employee advocate as proposed by the coalition at the last federal election. Women do not belong to, and do not identify with, unions. We should offer support to women to pursue their industrial interests.

PARA.TAB: Women are interested in enterprise bargaining but are having trouble getting access to it. Clearly, we must maintain a watching brief on the impact of enterprise bargaining on women. However, faced with an award system which, two decades after the equal pay decision, is still not able to provide equity, why would women not give enterprise bargaining a go?

We must address the issue of why women are not getting access to enterprise bargaining. I consider that most workers, male and female, continue to exist in the conflict mind frame that was a feature of the award system. Yet, enterprise bargaining cannot operate effectively unless a climate of good faith exists between employees and employers.

The government is clearly failing to change the attitude of workers. It points to the unions as being largely responsible for the educative process of enterprise bargaining. Unions are a product of the class war mentality. Their lifeblood is conflict, so how will they cultivate an ethos of mutual respect and cooperation? Unions do not represent or talk to most women workers. How can they possibly educate them?

Yet this bill seeks to further entrench the role of unions in the industrial relations sector. This will be to the detriment of women workers. The safeguards proposed by the minor Senate parties, which involve an annual survey of agreements, are not going to do anything. The government ought to spend less money on promoting the proposed changes and more on education.

Business and government have a mutual interest in ensuring that women are equipped with the skills to strike effective and fair deals. Only then can we be confident that we are getting working arrangements which are economically productive, promote employment and are socially beneficial.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in support of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill this evening.
—You should be. It's your living. Of course you should.

—I am very indebted to the honourable member for O'Connor, but his remark is lost on me. I am quite happy to admit that I have been a trade union official, not in receipt of pay; and I have been on the executive of trade unions, not in receipt of pay. I do not regret or apologise for my activity whatsoever. The significance of his remark that `it is my living' escapes me totally.

PARA.TAB: Many opposition members have been quoting Jennie George this evening and suggesting that this legislation reflects some grubby deal and, to quote their words, is a payback for having won the last election. I do not want to dissociate myself from those remarks, because that is the nature of elections. The payback on the opposition's side would have been that workers would have received a GST of 15 per cent, the opposition's industrial relations program would have been instituted, and there would have been $10 billion cut out of federal expenditures with no elaboration on exactly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Billion?

—There would have been $10 billion cut out of federal government expenditure with no elaboration on where that would have come from. But one does not have to be blind Freddy to work out that billions would have come out of areas like education, social security. Of many electorates, none would have been worse affected than my own. It is history that the opposition did not win the election. It did not win the election because the voting people of Australia were quite intimidated by the GST and they were concerned about the industrial relations package of the opposition. They were equally concerned about how this $10 billion was going to affect them.

PARA.TAB: I think it is true to say that it was not so much that the government won the election as the opposition lost it. Its manifest of proposals was not implemented; ours was. We said that we were not going to set the clock back with respect to industrial relations. We said that we were in favour of enterprise agreements and would be bringing down legislation—and we are bringing down legislation. We are facilitating enterprise agreements. I do not understand why the opposition is so uptight about this. It is no secret what we were going to do.

Some 1,200 enterprise agreements have already been ratified by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Some 37 per cent of all workers in Australia are covered by enterprise agreements.
