But what is the difference when government members talk about enterprise agreements and when opposition members talk about them? There is a great deal of difference. There is no safety net in the opposition's proposal. We say that when workers and management get together to develop new and better ways of working, when we are able to eradicate things that have been entrenched over years—such as demarcations between different work groups—and when new technology is introduced, both should share in the consequent improvements. That is our approach. It should not be all one-way traffic.

The difference is even more fundamental than that. On this side of the House, we fundamentally believe that it is not appropriate or realistic and will not get us anywhere to believe that we can engineer a further recovery by driving down wages. We can never hope to compete with low wages in Indonesia or Malaysia or some of those other countries. In Japan, Korea and Taiwan, wages are even higher than they are in Australia. This whole philosophy that there is a simple tick solution for enterprises—whether they be small, medium or very large businesses—of getting a cheaper labour input to provide all the solutions is totally rejected by this side of the House.

If we look at the 1980s, there has been considerable wage restraint. Wages have not kept pace with inflation. But through the accord process this government has been able to negotiate a social wage. I do not want to go into the issue of a social wage tonight. Even so, I am trying to acknowledge the point that wages have not kept pace with inflation. We do not believe that flattening wages, which was at the core of the opposition's policies when it went to the people at the last election, is the economic solution that will get us going.

That is why, when we talk about enterprise agreements, we want a win-win situation. We want the enterprise and the management to win, but we also want the workers to win. We want to make sure that there are safety nets because opposition members like to quote examples of different trade union activity. Fundamentally and at my core I am a Labor man; I will always support the trade union movement. If that is what the shadow minister was driving at, I plead guilty; I really am a Labor traditionalist. But, like many organisations, I am sure that the performance of trade unions fits a normal, standard curve, as I suggest does business management or even the organisations that are established to represent the employers.

Why should we have trade unions? Why should Labor members feel so strongly about trade unions? Basically, because we believe that ordinary men and women have the right to organise themselves, elect officials and negotiate on an equal basis with employers. That is why we fundamentally believe in trade unions. We think it is a right that all Australians should enjoy. If we want to talk about how to gear this economy up even further—something the opposition focuses on so often—and while I am pleased see the elimination of some practices, such as demarcations and too many awards in a particular industry sector, we should also point the finger at the other side, in a balanced way, and acknowledge that management has a lot to answer for.

I well remember going around the country when I was Chairman of the House of Representative Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training when we had a skills reference. I particularly remember one Tasmanian factory. Along with other committee members, I had the privilege of talking to workers on the floor as well as to management. We were discussing enterprise agreements. One of the things a worker said to me was, `Before we got this enterprise agreement, as a worker, when I clocked on, I was expected to leave my brains behind. As soon as I clocked on, I was expected to leave my brains behind'. I think that is a reflection of a very outdated structure which was all too common in Australia. The most exciting enterprises are those that are able to recognise the worth of individual workers and harness their enthusiasm, their knowledge and their skills and get them fully participating and fully involved.

If we are talking about the problems of management, this country has an appalling record in research and development. We under-score on about every possible measurement. If there is a future for this country, it is in developing intellectual property. We have a tremendous reputation for being real innovators in research. We should therefore harness that. We should have a fuller commitment to research and development. If I am critical of the research side, I am appalled by the development side.

I know that there will be honourable members on both sides of the House who will be able to tell their own stories about something that was perhaps developed as a prototype and then went overseas to some other country. That is not good enough any more. Whilst I often say that ministers are fond of tracking and talking about our successes in this country—and we ought to do more of that—it is valuable to track our failures. We should have a register of failures to try to understand the mechanisms that led to the particular innovation, the particular product or the particular service being sold out of this country.

I was talking about the problems of management. There has been a colossal failure to make investments in productive resources in this country. We have had a culture almost of trying to extend the life of machinery for 25 years, 30 years, 35 years—far too long.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you let them use it 24 hours a day?

—The shadow minister asks why we do not let them use it 24 hours a day. Let me quote the example of Pacific Dunlop Ltd for his benefit. The National Union of Workers has complete coverage of workers in that company's factories. Pacific Dunlop Ltd is undertaking a significant restructuring and centralisation of its operations in tyre manufacture and it is utilising its machinery 24 hours a day.
—That's one.

—Of course, and there are more; I am the first to acknowledge that. The difference between the shadow minister and me is that he is saying that all the benefits, without any protection, should go to one side. What I am saying is that there ought to be minimum standards and the award safety net. When people sit down and negotiate, some of those benefits and some of the profits that flow from them should go to the worker as much as to the enterprise. That is where the shadow minister and I differ.

PARA.TAB: The opposition wants to take a sledgehammer to the workers, and it wants to negotiate on an individual basis with each and every person. The opposition wants to intimidate workers into signing the contract and give them no protection. Then the opposition asks why we oppose its ideas. The point is that our idea is working.

There is far too little investment. Management has a lot to answer for. I am pleased to see that the legislation has recently come forward in the House. I was appalled when the National Association of Forest Industries came before the caucus task force. The association was talking about what I think are very exciting opportunities for the industry to really grow, to value add and, in particular, to export. We were told that one of the real tragedies in this country is that we do not have the information—we have never done the research—to be able to tell us exactly what Australian woods we can use to replace imported timbers in housing, in window framing and in doors. Is that not a tragedy? Is that not sad? The industry has been operating for all these years—often in controversial circumstances—and we do not have the information.

We were given another example concerning the impact that steel is having in home building. The association suspects that with proper research we may be able to reduce the amount of wood required in the standard construction of a house by up to 25 per cent, making timber even more competitive with steel. What is the problem? The problem is that we have not done the research. I find it tragic. I appeal to members on both sides of the House. I know I have a sympathetic audience on this side of the House, but those opposite see things in a one-dimensional way, with one-shot solutions to difficult problems. Providing coolie wages for Australian workers is not the way to get over the problems with our economy.

I am very pleased—I hope those opposite are also—with the fact that the economy has recorded seven consecutive quarters of growth, and there is every indication that it appears to be gathering a bit of a head of steam. I sincerely hope so. But, of course, we do have a lot of unemployed people. There have been some real changes in the nature of long-term unemployed in the economy. Regrettably, with every recession, the hangover of long-term unemployed has been greater than in the previous recession, and that is the case now.

Indeed, through the 1980s when our economy was growing at such a rapid rate, we had an increase of some 1.6 million in the number of workers in the economy, but the unemployed were taken up at the rate of only one in seven. The unemployed present a particular challenge. I would not want to pre-empt what the expert committee might say in its white paper, but I want to raise the issue of the most marginalised unemployed. They are often characterised as people who have left school at grade 6, grade 7, grade 8, grade 9 or grade 10. Because we are looking for an ever-increasingly skilled work force, these people do not have much hope.

I am pleased to say that the government appears to be adopting very innovative problems—one being the community activity program designed to address the needs of these young people, and also, I might say, some older workers as well. That is exciting because we have not done that for 10 years. If a Labor government is not going to stand up and attempt to meet the needs of the most marginalised in the community, then I guess we cannot expect it from the opposition.

I want to make a special plea: we have to stop the young people from slipping through the hole. I am really concerned that the trends in education are such that we are giving power to principals to expel students rather than trying to address the cause of the behaviour that is leading them to that action. They are in effect punishing the effects. Often the problem is concerned with literacy. I find it really hard to credit that in the 1990s we still have an education system that is graduating students at year 10 who are functionally illiterate. I am appalled.

There is debate in the community about appropriate methods of teaching literacy. I think the federal government has a special responsibility in this regard. At best, I hope we adopt approaches that yield results rather than get involved in the particular ideology or methodology of the approach. But, if we cannot do that, we can at least opt for systems that are delivering results, and delivering results for people who are illiterate. I believe we have that responsibility. As much as I am really delighted that we are developing innovative programs that are reaching out to the most marginalised people, I believe that we have to start chopping off the number of candidates that are being produced through the system. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As secretary of the coalition industrial relations committee, I feel privileged to be able to contribute to this debate on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill. Whilst I concede that I agree with some of the things that the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) said, I believe he and others would do well to listen to what is said on this side of the chamber. I was particularly attracted by the thoughtful, compassionate and erudite comments of our last speaker, the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), where she put down in meticulous detail how the present system, as it works in this country, is disadvantaging women in the work force. I thought it was an excellent contribution.

PARA.TAB: I am very disappointed to be standing here at a time when Australia is struggling to come out of a recession—the recession the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said we had to have—and to be debating a piece of legislation that, in so many aspects, will take industrial relations back into the 1940s in this country. The world is decentralising its labour employee relationships and yet Australia is moving so slowly. It seems to me that Australia is now the only industrial nation left which still has a centralised compulsory arbitration system. Yet we have this bill here today—this thick bill of a couple of hundred pages—which will hand back considerable power to the trade unions. It will increase the rigidity of the industrial relations system. It will slow down and block the move towards enterprise bargaining which is so needed in this country. It will, above all else, increase the difficulties and the costs of employers to hire labour in this country. Goodness me, the No. 1 problem in this country is that we have a million people unemployed, and the government seems to have forgotten that.

Specifically, this bill strengthens the award system, uses the external affairs power and ILO conventions to create minimum wages and conditions, significantly lessens sanctions for industrial disputes, creates a new form of enterprise agreement for non-union workplaces and creates an industrial relations court. In saying that, I find the claims by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) about what this bill will do absolutely incredulous. He says that this bill will improve industrial relations in this country—for heaven's sake—and will increase flexibility. These sorts of claims remind me of examples of when language is used that is opposite to the truth, which we have so often seen around this world. Remember communist East Germany? What was that called? It was called the German Democratic Republic. Democratic is one thing that it was not. We call terrorists around the world who try to overthrow elected governments freedom fighters. The government even indulges in that from time to time. This year a budget bill was called the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill, which is pushing the deficit up by $15 billion, or whatever it was.

We are debating another classic example here tonight. As has been said by the shadow minister for industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), this bill is nothing more or less than a pay-off to trade unions for spending $2 million—or whatever it was—during the last election campaign when they acted as surrogates for the Labor Party to spread misinformation of what the coalition was offering to the Australian people. I might add that the government, from the latest figures I have, has given $45 million in grants to trade unions over past years. So the government has an interesting system where it pours taxpayers' money into the trade union movement and the trade unions, in return, support it in an election campaign to a very handsome extent indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's called greasing the palm.
—Another way of putting it might be laundering of taxpayers' money in an inappropriate way. I cannot help quoting again the words of Jennie George, Vice-President of the ACTU. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: What the employers have got to understand is that we won the election in March and this bill is a pay back for the commitments that were made by the government in the course of that election campaign.

I think that sums it up. The unions are getting a little desperate in this country. Their relevance to the work force is becoming less and less. I see now that only 29.4 per cent in the private sector are unionised compared with 67.1 per cent in the public sector where the unions, with the help of the government, can exert coercion and extract a higher level of unionism. The unions are now trying to shore up their place. They have spoken to the minister and they got their deal. It is mirrored in some very interesting figures. Workplaces with fewer than 10 employees have only 16.3 per cent unionism; those with between 10 and 19 employees, 29.8 per cent unionism; 20 to 99 employees, 46.1 per cent unionism; and workplaces with greater than 100 employees, 57.6 per cent unionism. But, despite that, 67 per cent of private sector workplaces have no unions members at all.

PARA.TAB: I would like to turn specifically to sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. Of course, these refer to the area where provisions are in place to stop those silly secondary boycotts that used to so cripple this country. The legislation, which has been in place for 16 years now, has been very successful in cutting out those silly strikes—not just to benefit industry but also to benefit workers in the industry and of course Australia as a whole. Those sections were able to do that because they cut out the coercion, the threats and the bullyboy tactics. A minister from the New South Wales right wing of the ALP now appropriately wants to do away with that legislation somehow. Why he would want to change highly successful legislation must be beyond the reasoning of any decent man or woman.

In effect, it will take away the access of the employer who comes under these coercive tactics from the real courts—the common law courts. This legislation will be taken out of the Trade Practices Act and put into the Industrial Relations Court—the industrial relations club, in effect. Access to remedies will become much more restrictive than it has been. I think this will be particularly onerous on small business, which is pertinent to my electorate. If a secondary boycott were put on small businesses in my electorate, they could immediately get injunctive relief for that. That will now pass. An unbelievable 72-hour provision has been put in—as if small businesses can get remedies after 72 hours. So many small businesses are at the edge of collapse now because of this government's economic policy. It is not just small business. Think what this will do to the shipping industry where the daily costs are horrific or to the building industry where daily costs are also very high. If they have to wait 72 hours before they can get action, they could be done in. I am amazed that the minister is party to facilitating this union requirement so that unions can blackmail business. The minister is handing unions the ultimate weapon.

There are many new laws in what the minister proposes to replace which I do not think even cover what would have been many past section 45D actions. I will give a few examples. Examples of past section 45D actions not in support of a claim, the subject of industrial disputes, appear to include the 1986 case Gibbins v. AMIEU, where the dispute was caused by that union's objections to the export of live sheep. They do not seem to include the 1977 Utah v. SUA case, where the dispute was over a union's desire to expand the employment of Australian seamen. They do not appear to include the 1978 Metro Meat v. AMIEU case, which again was a dispute over the export of live sheep. They do not include the 1983 Columbus Shipping Line case, which was a dispute over the banning of a ship because it was a cross-trader. In other words, it was not an Australian or North American line. They do not include the 1978 Wribass case that was a dispute over Saturday trading.

I can quote other cases. Pioneer Concrete had four cases brought under a section 45D action. Two of those cases do not appear to be actionable now under the new provisions because the disputes were about relationships between the company and the contractors. In the other two cases, it is because the primary boycotts exemption would apply. This will not be covered. Also, it appears it is not even clear that the anticipatory injunctions would be available under the new provisions that the minister is putting before us. Before we could restrain threatened boycotts under section 45D, section 80(1) of the Trade Practices Act. That seems to be gone. So I think we have taken a step back into the past under what is proposed here today.

I turn to the award system. That is being reinforced in this bill by making the commission responsible for its maintenance instead of the employers and unions or whoever. A whole new raft of minimum terms and conditions are to be put before us. The bill sets minimum standards based on awards which can apply right across Australia. It appears it is going to override state awards, state legislation and state based entitlements by the devious, backdoor method of the external affairs power, which was never intended to be used in this manner. This applies apparently because we are a signatory to the ILO conventions. I think it is absolutely disgusting.

The balance of power in this country in industrial relations is delicate enough as it is without tilting it in such a major way towards the trade union movement. To use the external affairs powers in this way opens up a whole new ball-game. It brings in creeping centralisation of power; it is an extension of federal power that threatens, I believe, future labour market reforms that we are starting to see in states around this country with Liberal-National Party governments. I believe the government's interpretation of the ILO conventions is wrong. It is interesting to turn to schedule V of the ILO convention relating to minimum wages. For example, article 1, section 1, says:

SPEECH.PARA: Each member of the ILO which ratifies this convention undertakes to establish a system of minimum wages which covers all groups of wage earners whose terms of employment are such that coverage would be appropriate.

That is high powered stuff. Most of us would perhaps aspire to that, but who are the signatories to this ILO? I see in the list before me such luminaries as Afghanistan, Albania—probably the most oppressive country in the world until recently—Algeria, Angola, Bangladesh, Bolivia and Burundi. I think one of the ministers was tied up there recently because he could not get out of the place. There is Cambodia, Chad, communist China, Congo, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Ethiopia, Guatemala and Haiti. For heaven's sake! Can you believe it: Haiti is a signatory to the ILO which we are now saying we have to support. Does that country support it? There is Iran, Iraq, Laos, Mongolia, Mozambique, Myanmar—that is the code name for communist Burma—Nicaragua, Romania, Rwanda, Sudan, Syria, Tanzania, Uganda, Vietnam, Zaire, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

TALK.START.PARA: —They look after your rights!
—It hardly gives one comfort to be signing these things, as the shadow minister says tongue in cheek. Section 2 of article 1 says:

SPEECH.PARA: The competent—
perhaps in inverted commas—
authority in each country—
that is the government in Australia's case—
shall, in agreement—
listen to this—
or after full consultation with the representative organisations of the employers and workers concerned, where such exist, determine the groups of wage earners to be covered.

I put it to honourable members: have the employers in this country been properly consulted, or consulted at all, by this government? I put it to honourable members that this government, despite being a signatory and trumpeting what a wonderful thing the ILO convention is, is already in breach of it, yet it is trying to impose on us in this country restrictions that are going to dilute the cherished sovereignty of this great country—or once great country. Under this government, one wonders whether that will continue. I believe this government is selling out Australia's independence at the very time when it is trying to get rid of the monarchy because, as it said, `We will be more independent somehow under a republic'.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to read the 570-page tome on the republic and to look up the examples that were studied. Trinidad and Tobago were studied at length and were given a whole chapter—also Mauritius, India and the Prime Minister's beloved Ireland. Even though I have a fair splash of Irish blood in me, of which I am very proud, I am disappointed that the Prime Minister's bog-Irish is colouring his judgment in his anti-British sentiment. If he wants to get rid of a few things British, let him get rid of all the remnants of the British craft trade union system. That would be the way to go if we want to make this country a little bit more independent than it is now.

I turn to some of the new requirements for the minimum standards provisions. We have the minimum wages, which I have mentioned, which can be fixed by the commission. We have equal wages and remuneration. We have parental leave unpaid for 52 weeks. We have termination of employment conditions. That is quite an onerous condition. Before an employer can lay off someone they must notify and consult the CES and the trade unions. If an employer fails to do this there are penalties. One can imagine the difficulties this is going to cause.

The commission is obliged to take into account—here is another convention we have signed—the ILO's family responsibilities convention to prevent discrimination against employees with family responsibilities and to help employees reconcile their employment and family responsibilities. That is pretty high sounding stuff. As it reads, I would support it thoroughly, but goodness knows what it means in practice. How can an employer do some of these things if he is scratching to keep a business alive and cannot afford to be laying out money in this direction? It probably means the employer will close down earlier and lay off people quicker.

We have new certified agreement provisions for unionists. They add eight new tests to the tests which are already there. So an employer has got 16 steps now before he can even get to the very first certified agreement. That includes the no disadvantage tests. In effect, that means that an employer can have only the cherished flexibility that the minister talks about upwards; he cannot have the flexibility downwards. The union must be notified even if the employees of a workplace are not members of a trade union because they do not want to be members. The union has to be called in to look over their shoulders while they do whatever they have to do.

There are new enterprise flexibility agreement provisions, designed to promote agreements in the non-union sector, in this bill. There are drawbacks in the existing mechanism. As a result, the provisions are hardly used at all. I think the Castle Bacon procedure is a classic example of that. But the new ones that have been put in place are at least as bad as the ones that exist now. I also predict that these provisions will not be used either.

The bill also establishes immunity for primary industrial action—that is the code word for strikes—taken during a bargaining period without a mechanism to bring intractable disputes to an end. To provide immunity while at the same time providing all the benefits for trade unions arising out of compulsory arbitration puts Australian trade unions in the most cosseted position of any trade union movement in the whole OECD. Why we want to go that way is quite beyond my comprehension.

In addition, we have the industrial relations court—another layer of courts in this country. Until now we have had specialised industrial judges in the Federal Court. The system has worked reasonably well. But now we are to have labour courts—club courts, if you like—doing their special deals. There has been a long history in this country of specialised courts doing specialised deals. I think this is a bad move in the wrong direction.

This bill is all about protecting privilege of the industrial relations club, which I thought we were moving away from, protecting privilege of trade unions and, sadly, selling out Australia's sovereignty to the ILO and overseas powers. It is restricting access of employers, which they surely should have in a free country, to common law courts. It will only force up the cost of labour ultimately, and that will mean fewer jobs. There is nothing in this bill about lowering the on-costs of wages. New Zealand's on-costs are a third to a half of Australia's on-costs. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to the debate so far on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill and the Industrial Relations Court (Judges' Remuneration) Bill, with great respect I suggest that opposition members have read the scripts from the 1950s or maybe earlier. They have failed to absorb the fact that industrial relations practice in Australia has changed enormously. In recent years, that practice has become increasing dynamic in changing Australia's competitive position and the relationship between management and labour, and improving the general productivity and flexibility of trade union arrangements and activities within workplaces. Having listened to the debate, it seems that opposition members have simply been asleep while those changes have been occurring. That is a pity because the Industrial Relations Reform Bill represents a major reform. It builds upon a very substantial achievement in industrial relations over the last 10 years.

PARA.TAB: Reading the reply to this legislation by the shadow minister for industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), one gets the impression that nothing has been learned from the lead-up to the election and its result in March, when industrial relations was one of the key issues. The opposition has learned nothing. It has refused to acknowledge that people would not accept the decimation of unions, the complete dismantling of the award system, the $3 an hour wage arrangements or the wholesale attack on Australian employees—and nor should they because trade unions, and employees generally, across the country have been prepared to acknowledge the part they have to play in the rebuilding of Australia.

Since October 1991, some 1,200 enterprise agreements have been ratified by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Around 37 per cent of workers under federal awards are now party to those enterprise agreements, and that process is continuing. The bills, introduced by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton), provide the scope for that strong reform and flexibility in the labour market to continue, but in a way that ensures that people are not worse off, that unions are not smashed to bits, and that people are not exploited in the way that the opposition's industrial relations policy apparently still proposes.

The honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) made it clear that the opposition's principal objection to the bill is that it does not have the downward flexibility—it does not provide real cuts in the living standards and wages of working people. The opposition's basic agenda is downward flexibility. The government has made it clear that the acid test of its legislation is flexibility; enterprise agreements can be entered into but not without cutting the real living standards of working people.

The government is about promoting productivity and ensuring fair conditions. However, the government also wants to ensure minimum conditions for workers and that the enlightened approach that is taken by large sections of management and the trade union movement is actually given some positive encouragement.

Earlier today opposition members quoted the chief executive of BHP on Mabo. What a pity they did not spend as much time talking about what Mr Prescott said about industrial relations. He has dismissed the need for big changes in industrial relations as advocated by those opposite. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think we have, fundamentally, a very good system.
It is a system in transition. And there has been a remarkable degree of common thinking and common purpose in its refinement and development over the last several years.

That is really the basis on which we need to proceed. That is the basis on which this industrial relations reform is proceeding. Another employer, Mr Warburton from Du Pont, highlights what can be achieved when an enlightened approach is taken by employers working constructively with their employees and the unions to achieve productivity gains, flexibility and all the dynamics that are needed in the multiskilling of the work force to produce strong profit and export growth in the business enterprise. That can be achieved more strongly with these bills.

PARA.TAB: However, if we get into the position that the opposition wants to go back to, namely, a constant 1950s battle about industrial relations, the net result will be that the historically low levels of industrial disputation that we have today would be cast aside, as would the real unit labour costs and the competitive position we presently have in that regard. One has to wonder why the opposition would want to embark upon that course of action. What is it, apart from its blind ideology, that drives that sort of thinking?

As we have seen in this debate, there is precious little to support the opposition's position. The opposition is desperate to get back to the 1950s—the $3 an hour and all those sorts of things. Many opposition members will not be satisfied until we get back to that situation.

I want to go back over some of the major provisions of the industrial relations bill. Firstly, the new objects of the bill are designed to ensure a more effective framework for the maintenance and strengthening of the safety net for employees through the award system and minimum entitlements; secondly, more effective arrangements for direct bargaining, including the establishment of a new stream for enterprise flexibility agreements and the creation of a sanction-free bargaining pre-negotiation of certified agreements; a more effective regime for regulating industrial action and enforcing agreements, including amendments to the current secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act; the establishment of the specialist industrial court; and more effective institutional arrangements, including the encouragement of industry consultative councils, revised requirements for union registration, and the restructuring of the National Labour Consultative Council.

Those provisions build on the strengths of the accord process. Industrial disputes are 62 per cent lower today under the accord than under the Fraser government. The confrontationist style of industrial relations—for which the opposition so desperately hankers—would phenomenally increase industrial disputes, strikes and the losses that would occur as a result. Further, it is clear that the wages system has responded to the various demands in the community. Indeed, many unions have lead the way in multiskilling, restructuring workplaces, utilising technology and coping with the challenges of technology.

Most of us from time to time visit plants, factories and major enterprises in manufacturing and other areas and see both the constructive and cooperative arrangements at work. We talk to workers and management about what things used to be like in the old days. That change in attitude has been achieved through sensible, cooperative dialogue rather than by going back to smashing unions and exploiting young people—the confrontationist policy with which the opposition went to the last election. That package, which was so soundly rejected, is still part of the opposition's agenda, which is why it is so fiercely opposed to the bill.

What approach should be followed in the future? What sorts of things are needed in the future? Firstly, there needs to be a real award safety net protection. We do not accept the Kennett or Court approach to industrial relations, where a term such as `safety net' is a name-only concept that has no reality. The Kennett and Court governments have been about real cuts and the real lowering of conditions for working people. Once that safety net is done away with, there is scope for people to be exploited. There is no sensible and cooperative dialogue arrangement; rather, people are pitted one against the other, which causes damage which inevitably results in an ineffective award system.

In Victoria, workers and unions have been voting with their feet and seeking to get out of those arrangements and under federal awards. So the protection and maintenance of the award safety net is fundamental to the legislation before the House—and it should be supported. The opposition should recognise that the policy it took to the election was unacceptable. No matter how much it protests now, the legislation will give more strength to those minimum conditions and the acceptance that we can have flexibility in wage arrangements. But we are not about flexibility down, which the honourable member for Parkes said should be in the legislation. We refuse absolutely to accept that. Victoria gives a clear example of why it is unacceptable.

We can go across the Tasman to New Zealand. It has the sort of model that the opposition from time to time likes to boast about. We can see the impact in terms of employment in New Zealand because of the wholesale savaging of the industrial relations system. Has it created more jobs and more opportunities for people? The jobs performance in New Zealand under those changed and decimated industrial relations rules that now apply has been abysmal. We can go to other countries around our region or to other parts of the world to see what is happening with employment, and what sorts of industrial relations systems work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Singapore, Hong Kong, Malaysia, Taiwan.

—The honourable member may think that the sorts of conditions that apply in those countries under the social contract there should be advocated here—which is probably what the opposition does advocate—but I do not believe the people of Australia accept that at all. We believe in a proper safety net and a social contract that the accord brings into the system, and we believe that the basic minimum standards provided under the award system have to be protected fundamentally. That is what this legislation is designed to achieve.

PARA.TAB: Let us move to what needs to be done. We recognise there is a case for flexibility and that the award safety net must be maintained. The enterprise flexibility clauses in awards allow individual enterprises or workplaces to reach agreements to vary individual conditions of the awards to suit their needs. Many awards already contain enterprise flexibility clauses. The legislation encourages their wider use and establishes some basic conditions for their application. These arrangements will help enterprises and workplaces to operate more efficiently. They will also make sure the interests of employees are properly taken into account so they are not disadvantaged.

Enterprise flexibility clauses can be used for agreements which cover single issues such as hours of work, flexitime or wide ranging agreements. Changes negotiated through an enterprise flexibility clause must be taken to the commission for approval. These changes are implemented through award variations and generally operate as a schedule to the award. An application is made to the commission for an award variation. Each union will be able to be part of that process. That is not an unreasonable suggestion. There is scope to have that flexibility and the sorts of dynamics that an individual workplace might need but, at the same time, we should ensure that the Industrial Relations Commission does properly scrutinise it so there is a legitimacy in groups that have an interest in industry, taking those issues into account, and being part of that process.

From time to time I have heard the opposition say there have been attacks from this side on the Industrial Relations Commission, but this legislation before the House is designed to ensure that it is meeting the contemporary needs of the community as far as labour relations are concerned but, at the same time, that it has the strength and teeth it needs to deal with those matters in a sensible and constructive way. The changes in this proposal enable that to occur in a sensible and ordered way. I think that will prove to be effective. It is happening already across a number of federal awards.

We can see in Queensland an increasing interest in enterprise agreements in a whole range of industries. There is value and virtue in having that ordered structure rather than the approach the opposition would take, which is basically about destroying trade unions. Those opposite have a philosophical problem with trade unions.

What does the new arrangement mean for women? It is important, when we introduce new industrial relations arrangements, that we recognise the particular needs of women and non-English speaking persons, and that we try to ensure, as far as we can through legislation, that the Industrial Relations Commission gets value for those people, recognising—particularly in difficult economic times—the challenge that creates. In many parts of western Sydney and elsewhere, examples can be seen of people in traditional industries, particularly from non-English speaking backgrounds and women, in relation to part-time work—which is increasing—who do not have the protections the system logically should provide. This bill provides a number of positive things for those groups.

The government recognises that many women and workers from non-English speaking backgrounds are concerned about the effect that a more involved industrial relations system will have on their wages and conditions. The industrial relations reforms encourage enterprise bargaining while ensuring that workers are protected. The government has taken into account concerns raised by women's groups, community organisations and many others about the effect of the reforms on disadvantaged groups.

The proposals before the House include an extensive range of safeguards to ensure fairness and equity for women and workers from non-English speaking backgrounds. The award system will be protected and strengthened as a prerequisite for enterprise bargaining. The safety net will be extended beyond the award system through minimum entitlements legislation giving effect to international conventions. This will guarantee rights for all workers to minimum wages, equal pay for men and women for work of equal value, protection against unfair dismissal and 12 months shared unpaid parental leave. The commission has to take into account the provisions of the International Labour Organisation convention in this regard.

We were told previously that, because we were taking account of those provisions that give certain guarantees to people such as women and those of non-English speaking backgrounds, that was denying the sovereignty of our nationhood. What could be further from the truth, when all we are trying to do is ensure some basic standards for all citizens and to recognise that some are in a stronger position than others to ensure that they get a fair go on such things as protection from unfair dismissal?

What possible reason could the opposition have for suggesting that that should not be supported? Whether it is in line with an international convention is surely not the issue. The principle is whether it is a proper consideration to be included in our bill, which it is. No-one can say that there should not be some protections against unfair dismissals. This is certainly in line with a proper international convention from the ILO. It is something that the parliament, not just the government, should support and see as a priority: to make sure that no person of non-English speaking background is disadvantaged or can be dismissed unfairly without some protective mechanism through the industrial relations system.

The legislation before the House carries those protections in their proper form. It does not matter to what country those provisions are applied; the ILO convention is appropriate and it is entirely proper for Australia to be following that course. So the bill is an important step forward in industrial relations. It recognises what has been the very real commitment of trade unions to reform over recent years and the fact that labour relations have changed fundamentally.

Whilst the opposition might still be in a time warp, the rest of Australia has moved on. Fortunately, management is generally more enlightened in its approach; and the nature of trade unions is fundamentally more enlightened in terms of flexibility in encouraging the range of opportunities that exist in multiskilling of the work force and so on. They have been able to undertake that change in attitude in a positive way with a dramatic reduction in the level of industrial disputes. I support the bill strongly. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am offended. I am offended by this debate. I am offended by the implication in this debate that everyone in this House belongs to some sort of past generation and past century of exploiters. I am offended by the remarks of the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), now sitting on the front bench. The honourable member for Chifley had the barefaced audacity to declare that the Liberal Party stood for coolie wages for workers.

PARA.TAB: I happen to belong to a party whose opposition to the Industrial Relations Reform Bill is not because of its members' involvement in business; it is not because we represent, as alleged, big business. Our opposition to this legislation is solely because of our concern for our children and the job opportunities that there will be in Australia for children of people represented by members on both sides of the parliament.

The real exploitation of workers in Australia has been the exploitation that has occurred through surging unemployment. As the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) said, and as all speakers on this side of the House have said, the legislation before the chamber tonight does nothing to encourage people and does nothing to encourage employers to put employees on.

When we, the opposition, first proposed a new attitude to enterprise bargaining, we did not envisage that the government's stance on legislation would be as it has been. Mr Alan Wood, the economics editor of the Australian, when the BCA initially put forward enterprise bargaining, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Fierce resistance was met from the Hawke government, Paul Keating (Treasurer), Bill Kelty (ACTU) and other employer groups.
Four years later, re-christened work-place bargaining, it is the proclaimed centre piece of Accord Mark VII and the basis for the Federal Government's industrial relations policy.
BCA's latest report provides studies to demonstrate that the Government/ACTU version is little more than heavily restricted over-award bargaining and not genuine enterprise bargaining at all.

What we are dealing with tonight is not enterprise bargaining; it is not an opportunity for employers and employees to enter into mature negotiations in the interests of offering productivity and providing new jobs. Instead, it is an opportunity, as the honourable member for Bennelong has said, for the trade union movement to demand some payback for its support of the government in the last election.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Chifley was anxious to ensure that we should all know precisely why we need to have trade unions. Why? He said that we need trade unions so that employees will have the right to organise and the right to representation. In his presence, I would like to tell the honourable member for Chifley that I agree, and that the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia agree. We are not opposed to the trade union movement. We are not offended by the trade union movement. In fact, most of us have belonged and—in my case, and in the case of many members of the coalition—still belong to representative bodies that recognise our involvement in one form of profession or another. The honourable member for Chifley went on to say that in one instance he felt when he was employed that as soon as he clocked on he was expected to leave his brains behind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that?

—The honourable member for Chifley. I am not about to make an uncharitable remark about the brains of the honourable member for Chifley, but I do want to say that I do not know of any employer who employs people on the basis that they will not make the maximum contribution and be as innovative as possible. If there are those employers, and if the honourable member for Chifley has had to deal with them, I would agree with the honourable member for Chifley that those sorts of employers do not deserve to succeed. But the employers in Australia in 1993 want employees who bring their brains to work. They want employees who are innovative, who have new ideas and with whom they can negotiate new and better packages.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams) came into this chamber and he gave us a complete list of the unemployed figures from all around the world. He said, `Australia is not a lot worse than anywhere else'. What sort of defence of the legislation was that? It may have been the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) who said that. If I have misrepresented him, I apologise. What sort of defence of the legislation was that? Are we, as Australians, supposed to get some succour from the fact that our unemployment rate is not a lot worse than unemployment rates in other parts of world? We are saying, `What can we do to ensure that Australia's unemployment rate falls; that there are more people employed and that we outperform our competitors in terms of offering young people jobs?'.

All of us, on both sides of the chamber, believe that this is the land of opportunity. We believe that here there ought to be chances to give unemployed people jobs. The obsession on this side of the House is not—I repeat, Mr Deputy Speaker, not—with getting people to work for less. It never has been and it never will be. We do not want to pay people a lower hourly rate. The obsession on this side of the House is with finding jobs, providing jobs and having people directly involved in being innovative in employment.

The honourable member for Chifley said, quite fairly, that what he wanted was a win-win situation: a win for the enterprise and a win for the worker. I agree with him; so do all members of the opposition. But I say to the honourable member for Chifley that we want a win-win-win situation. We want a win for the enterprise, a win for the worker and a win for the unemployed. We have not seen any indication of that sort of victory in 10 years of his government.

I happen to have some sort of commitment to this legislation because—in common with some other people on these benches, and with people on the other side as well—I happen to be an employer. I happen to be an employer in a labour intensive industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think any of them are employers. I don't think they know anything about how to employ people. That's the problem.

—I fear that the honourable member for Bennelong is right. But I was being my usual charitable self and I was simply wanting to make the point that, in my experience in a labour intensive industry, it was not a case of people being exploited by employers wanting to drive the award rate down, but employers being prepared to pay above the award so long as people were prepared to be productive.

PARA.TAB: Let me give my own illustration. Most honourable members know of my background in the fruit industry. For some time a number of people in my industry were employed on an hourly rate—low enough by any standards; less than I would have been prepared to pick fruit for, let me hasten to add, but above the award. I now happen to be in a situation where no-one picks fruit for me on an hourly rate because every member of the fruit-picking teams in the Riverland chooses to pick fruit on a contract basis. Why? Because under that sort of enterprise agreement they make twice as much money as they can make on an hourly rate, simply by being more productive.

Honourable members will not find employers anywhere in Australia unhappy about paying over the award if, in return, they are getting more productivity. All the employers want is people who feel more fulfilled because they have the opportunity to negotiate a package that suits employers and employees better. That is the sort of negotiation we are endeavouring to inject into this debate and into this legislation.

Contrary to the comments made by the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott), we are not calling for flexibility down. He will not find a speech delivered on this side of House that talks about flexibility down. We are talking about flexibility, in order to have flexibility up. In my industry, the capacity for people to earn more by doing more has been welcomed, to the point at which fruit is no longer picked on an hourly rate.

I have rather drifted into speaking of the fruit industry. I was provoked into doing that by the comments of the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham). In his speech on this legislation he responded to an interjection by the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter). He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Party member has just arrived. In the fruit industry, for instance, SPC did well. . .

It did too. What was the changed attitude in SPC? The changed attitude in SPC was a new opportunity to negotiate a different, better working arrangement. That is precisely why SPC has survived; precisely why we have a cannery at Shepparton and do not have a cannery at Leeton—this new opportunity for negotiation. More than that, this provided new opportunities for employment. This cannery is successfully exporting fruit. Had SPC not survived, there would have been rising unemployment levels in the Shepparton area.

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the House do now adjourn.
Mr Sciacca—I require the question to be put forthwith without debate.
Question resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS REFORM BILL 1993Cognate Bill:INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS COURT (JUDGES' REMUNERATION) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Mr Speaker, and I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) for his accommodation. As I have indicated in my remarks on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill, in its input to this legislation the opposition seeks greater flexibility, not in order to pay people less—that has never been our intention—but in order to allow employers and employees to enter into mature negotiations to the benefit of both.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) said it so eloquently in his opening remarks on this piece of legislation. He said simply: `Why don't people employ in Australia?'. It is not because there is a shortage of jobs, but because of what this legislation will do—introducing what he called, rather colourfully I thought, more `humbuggery' in the exercise of employing people.

As a representative of rural Australia, I happen to live in an area in which there are job opportunities, but these job opportunities are not being filled. Why? It is not because there are no people to do the work. Clearly that is not the case; the unemployment level is something over 11 per cent across Australia. More job opportunities are not being filled simply because, from the employers' point of view, there are too many risks in employing people.
I pick up the comments made in this debate by the honourable member for Grey (Mr Wakelin). Last night the honourable member for Grey—who, as we all know, is a new member of this House—said:

SPEECH.PARA: I come from small business, fundamentally, and I have employed a few people from time to time. I reached a point probably seven or eight years ago where I could not afford to employ people. The hassle was simply too great . . .
What did he say? He did not say, `I had run out of work to do'. I have been to the small business of the honourable member for Grey; I know there are job opportunities there today. He continued:

The hassle was simply too great and the margins too slim. I was in agriculture and we expect variations in business. However, the reality is, if employers are pushed too hard, if it is made too difficult for them to employ, and if incentives to employ are taken away, how in blazes are we going to get our young people back into work? Surely we should be looking at our employers and encouraging them as much as possible. Whether they are big, small or indifferent, right across the whole scale—particularly small business—surely we should be giving our employers every opportunity to employ. It is not just federal government, there are state governments involved in this as well.

Removing some of those disincentives to employment was what the honourable member for Grey was on about. That is what I am calling for tonight. That is what the coalition has been saying. The bill before the House is, if nothing else, most surely a disincentive to employment. Simply put, this bill makes employing people more difficult.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) said it: it strengthens the ILO power, it introduces and depends on United Nations conventions for its powers and it brings in a new rigidity to employment arrangements. As the honourable member for Bennelong stated earlier, it waters down sections 45D and 45E, moving them from the Trade Practices Act into the Industrial Relations Act. As honourable members are all aware, it provides that action will not be able to be taken under 45D or 45E without a 72-hour delay.

The honourable member for Bennelong made the point that 72 hours may be enough to send some small businesses broke, and I am sure he is right. Take an industry like my own—the fruit industry. Consider what a delay of 72 hours in the processing, loading or refrigerating of a perishable product can do, and one begins to see why we are apprehensive about the proposals that are part of this bill.

Has this government shown any real concern for the unemployed? It certainly has not shown any real concern for making employing people easier. In fact, it has put disincentives in the way of all employers. Here we are in a country where payroll tax is the third highest in the Western world and five times the OECD average. Honourable members know what we would have done with payroll tax. We spelled it out quite clearly. We would have created job opportunities by eliminating it. The burden of payroll tax—

TALK.START.PARA: —And introduced a GST. Tell the rest of it.

—Quite happily. We would have introduced a goods and services tax of 15 per cent. I do not avoid that; I am not an apologist for it. I happen to think that it was, and continues to be, a damn good idea. But we would have taken away the tax on employing people.

PARA.TAB: The government refuses to consider that. Instead, it would put in place the very legislation that is a disincentive for employers to employ people. The burden of payroll tax rose by 46 per cent from 1988 to 1992. It now takes one worker's pay for every 25 employed, and one worker's pay for every 15 in big business.

Much has been made tonight, in fact much has been made in this whole debate, of those businesses—quoted by honourable members opposite—that have been so successful as a result of the employee-employer arrangements they have entered into. We agree and we laud their success. I note, though no-one from the government has said so, that they entered into these negations without the assistance of the legislation we are currently considering.

More than that, I happened to be at a meeting in the Barossa Valley two weeks ago where the chief executive officer of Amecon, part of the Transfield group that took over the discredited Melbourne dockyards, told us of the success it had had as a result of its employee-employer negotiations—negotiations entered into without this legislation; negotiations entered into as the majority of surviving small businesses still enter into their negotiations with their employees, without necessarily having union representation. We are not opposed to unions being a part of that negotiation, but I point out that the very success stories I have been familiar with in my electorate have occurred because employers and employees have been prepared to sit down together and come to a sensible agreement on what a wage package ought to be. Their negotiations have been entered into with the minimum of additional obligations placed on the employer.

All that I have witnessed, particularly in the last two parliaments, have been added burdens placed on employers by this government: the burden of this legislation, the burden of continuing the state imposition of payroll tax, the burden of superannuation, the burden of making it increasingly more difficult for employers to take on employees because their obligations exceed what reasonable obligations between two human beings ought to be and are all one way.

I conclude by stressing this point. I have children who will very shortly be in the work force. I do not want them to be exploited; I do not want them to be in a situation where they are being used up by some other employer. But I do want them to have jobs. I do know that currently, as an employer, I am discouraged from employing people by the very volume of legislation and obligation that the government places on me. Our opposition to this legislation is based solely on our commitment to more jobs for more Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is now increasingly dependent on its tourist industry. A very large part of that industry is, contrary to the general view, at the lower end of the market. In 1992, there were some 166,000 backpackers who visited Australia and contributed around $545 million to the economy.

PARA.TAB: Unlike the upper end of the tourist market where substantial amounts of money never reach the country, the backpacker expenditure, averaging around $3,500 per person spread over some three months stay, supports a range of locally owned small business throughout Australia. The most popular city is Sydney, followed by Cairns.

In recent years the tourist industry has become threatened by the unfavourable worldwide publicity concerning the murder victims discovered at Bowral and, before that, with the burning to death of six backpackers in a hostel at Kings Cross. There is probably little that can be done in a general sense to avoid the repetition of the terrible murders but there is a great deal that can be done to avoid the firetraps, the overcrowded accommodation and the preying on backpackers by avaricious operators that have become a feature of this section of the tourist industry in the last decade.

I hasten to add that there are many responsible businesses providing a cheap and excellent range of facilities throughout Australia. I am sure they would be the first to want to drive out those who have discredited the industry by their irresponsibility and avarice.

Sydney's low cost accommodation industry has long been notorious for its attraction to shadowy and marginal operators. Suspicions of arson, thuggery and overcrowded firetraps have been regular features. The Downunder Hostel where the six backpackers were burnt to death was partly owned by Abe Saffron, a notorious Sydney underworld figure who happened to own, directly or indirectly, six other premises that were burnt down or demolished by explosives.

Many of these problems have been facilitated by the authorities, who are supposed to monitor issues such as building and fire regulations, either by sins of omission, incompetence or worse. Since many firetraps have existed for years with the full knowledge of local government bodies and fire authorities, the inescapable conclusion is that certain owners are being protected.

After the tragic Downunder fire in 1989 we saw belated handwringing and vows of closing the firetraps by premiers, mayors and fire brigade spokesmen around Australia. Mr Greiner in New South Wales urged a total review of local government powers. The New South Wales fire brigade sent a formal letter to every council and shire in the state. In Brisbane and Perth new legislation and fire regulations were proposed. In Darwin headlines said that the firetraps would be closed by the end of the month. Four years later, very little has been done judging by the performance in Sydney.

In my own electorate, the North Sydney Council has been clearly protecting the owner of a shocking firetrap at 41 Cremorne Road. Hostels such as the Backpackers Connection, Roslyn Street, Kings Cross; Aaronbrook Lodge, Brook Street, Coogee; Coogee Beach Backpackers, Beach Street, Coogee; Grand Pacific, Beach Street, Coogee; Indys Beachside Backpackers, Arden Street, Coogee; Manly Guest House, Whistler Street, Manly; Excelsior Hotel, Foveaux Street, Surrey Hills; Regent Street Hotel, Sydney; Australian Sunrise Lodge, King Street, Newtown; Thelellen Beach Inn, Campbell Parade, Bondi; Working Holiday Visa Flats, Illawong Avenue, Bondi; the Bondi Beach Guest House, Consett Avenue, Bondi—and no doubt many others—are all subject to overcrowding and gross breaches of fire regulations to varying degrees.

All have been known to the New South Wales fire brigade and to the respective councils for years. Why has nothing effective been done? Why are they allowed to continue to trade? Why are some owners whipped with a feather by council inspectors when other establishments have had the book thrown at them? Given the nature of some of the owners, and the fact that the difference between a hard and easy inspection is often a quarter of a million dollars, obviously some owners are being protected by council incompetence or by bribery.

Visitors to this country have a right to expect proper conditions and standards of fire safety. Australia's reputation as a tourist destination has been and is continuing to be damaged. I urge the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee) to bring this matter to the attention of state ministers responsible for tourism, local government and fire authorities, requesting that backpacker accommodation unfit for occupation be closed immediately and not permitted to re-open until the necessary work is implemented. The buck passing and protection that have characterised this industry for years must end.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly about a topic that touches all our lives more deeply than we often imagine, yet is very little discussed in this place. Urban design has recently been given prominence by the announcement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that he has commissioned a task force of eminent professionals to examine the forces that are shaking our cities.

PARA.TAB: Urban design has not generally been the business of government at any level in Australia. Australians have not traditionally been good at it, despite the presence from time to time of designers with international recognition. It emerges as a matter of public debate intermittently and unexpectedly, driven by individuals of vision, and it is always refreshing and exciting. The urban and regional review announced by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) is dealing with strategic aspects of this issue. The Prime Minister's new urban design task force will focus on some of its tactical aspects.

Urban designers have devoted their efforts mainly to the centres of our cities. The fringes have often been neglected because, being diffuse and lacking concentrated urban centres, they are relatively unattractive to designers and very few of them live and work there. The centre is always there but time spent in contemplation at the fringe sees whole fields disappearing under houses in a matter of months.

I think it is vital that the new urban design task force give much attention to these neglected edges of our big cities. Urban design is important to the articulate inhabitants of the centres. It is also important to the next generation that is growing up on the outskirts of the city because, as Winston Churchill observed, `We shape our buildings but thereafter they shape us'.

I will now briefly show how all this bears upon parts of my electorate of Macquarie. The traditional pattern of development produced many towns of great character that survived relatively intact until the postwar boom. Subsequent development pressures have fragmented them but some very fine urban centres remain. These places are threatened now by the type of development that flourishes naturally at the fringes where land is relatively cheap and, on superficial analysis, plentiful.

Huge tracts of low density cottage suburbs are served by shopping barns that stand in hectares of asphalt paving. Fragments of degraded bushland or mortally wounded farmland are surrounded and sterilised. Our most precious and irreplaceable resource, land, is being squandered. In architectural terms, we are creating vast paddocks of unrelated individual buildings with very few communal places. I fear that such development has social implications that can be described in similar terms.

In Macquarie, the clash between the spreading city and the surviving natural environment is of paramount concern. Urban design here must have a set of determinants quite different from those that operate in the old parts of the city. It is necessary here to preserve areas of remnant bushland to establish zones and precincts that protect river banks and catchments. It is necessary that there be provision in new developments for the urban forests and wetlands that can purify waste water.

It is necessary that rural and agricultural landscapes of high scenic quality be respected for their intrinsic as well as their economic value. It is necessary that the very great heritage value of some of the early towns be zealously guarded. All these things should be directly affecting the way in which we are now designing and building our towns and suburbs. There are many attempts under way.

Urban design studies and mainstreet programs are being commissioned and supported by councils that frequently find themselves in unfamiliar territory, exposed to criticism from conservative sections of their constituencies that believe exclusively in rates, roads and rubbish. There is often extreme pressure from impatient and hungry land developers that forces planning and urban design policies to be formulated on the run. Councils often find difficulty in reconciling the business of thoughtful urban design and integrated forward planning with local government's long tradition of simply reacting to proposals submitted by developers.

I believe that the issues of urban design arising on the fringes of our cities are distinctly different from, but just as important as, those that arise in the city centres and that so often seem to be much more exciting and engaging for professional designers. I believe that those engaged with urban design on the fringes of our cities have an important task, that they deserve recognition and much support. I have high hopes that the work of the new urban design task force will provide a significant part of that support. I commend the Prime Minister for this initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 28 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) a joint venture partner in the firm Airport Fine Foods; if so, (a) did the FAC pay $1.575 million to buy into the venture and budget for a loss of approximately $550,000 in 1993-94, (b) is the investment an appropriate expenditure of funds derived from the aviation industry and (c) what evidence is there to support the validity of the investment.
(2) What measures does the Minister's Department take to ensure its instrumentalities operate in a financially responsible manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) is a participant in Airport Fine Foods Pty. Ltd. through its 52.5% shareholding in the company.
(a) The FAC paid $1.575 million to purchase its share in Airport Fine Foods Pty.Ltd.

The question refers to the 1993-94 year. A profit is budgeted for the 1993-94 year. A loss of $539,000 was included in the budget for 1992-93. An actual loss of $477,279 was recorded for the 1992-93 year, of which the Federal Airports Corporation's share was $227,000.

(b) Yes, there are prospects of profits in future years. The Corporation derives revenues from the aviation industry through aeronautical charges. The FAC also derives revenues from its own commercial trading activities and from property rentals. The revenue derived from aeronautical charges paid by the aviation industry does not of itself yet fully recover the cost of providing airport facilities.

(c) The Corporation reviews the financial and operational position of Airport Fine Foods Pty. Ltd., based on financial and operational data provided by Airport Fine Foods Pty. Ltd. on a regular basis.

(2) The Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986, together with the government's Accountability Guidelines for instrumentalities such as the Federal Airports Corporation, provide mechanisms for monitoring the financial performance of the FAC.
